[{"uid": "ja484", "root_name": "S\u0101liked\u0101raj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Rice-Field ", "acronym": "Ja 484", "blurb": "\u201cThe crop of rice\u201d\u2014This was a story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, about a Brother who supported his mother. The occasion will be explained in the Sama Birth. Then the Master sent for this Brother, and asked him, \u201cIs what I hear true, Brother, that you support lay folks?\u201d \u201cIt is true, Sir.\u201d \u201cWho are they?\u201d \u201cMy mother and father, Sir.\u201d Said the Master, \u201cWell done, Brother! Wise men of old, even when embodied as the lower animals, having been born as parrots even, when their parents grew old laid them in a nest and fed them with food which they brought in their own beaks.\u201d So saying, he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja485", "root_name": "Candakinnar\u012bj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Pixies on the Mountain of the Moon ", "acronym": "Ja 485", "blurb": "\u201c\u2019Tis passing away\u201d\u2014This is a story which the Master told, while dwelling in the banyan grove hard by Kapilapura about Rahula\u2019s mother when she was in the palace.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja486", "root_name": "Mah\u0101ukkusaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Osprey ", "acronym": "Ja 486", "blurb": "\u201cThe country churls\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, about Mitta-gandhaka, a lay Brother.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja487", "root_name": "Udd\u0101lakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Udd\u0101laka, the False Ascetic ", "acronym": "Ja 487", "blurb": "\u201cWith uncleansed teeth\u201d\u2014This story the Master told, while dwelling in Jetavana, about a dishonest man. This man, even though dedicated to the faith that leads to salvation, notwithstanding to gain life\u2019s necessaries fulfilled the threefold practice of knavery.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja488", "root_name": "Bhisaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "A Meal of Lotus Fibres ", "acronym": "Ja 488", "blurb": "\u201cMay horse and kine\u201d\u2014This story the Master told whilst dwelling in Jetavana, about a backsliding Brother. The circumstances will appear under the Kusa Birth. Here again the Master asked\u2014\u201cIs it true, Brother, that you have backslidden?\u201d \u201cYes, Sir, it is true.\u201d \u201cFor what cause?\u201d \u201cFor sin\u2019s sake, Sir.\u201d \u201cBrother why do you backslide, after embracing such a faith as this which leads to salvation; and all for sin\u2019s sake? In days of yore, before the Buddha arose, wise men who took to the religious life, even they who were outside the pale, made an oath, and renounced a suggested idea connected with temptations or desires!\u201d So saying, he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja489", "root_name": "Surucij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Prince Splendid ", "acronym": "Ja 489", "blurb": "\u201cI am\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling hard by Savatthi in the mansion of Migara\u2019s mother, how she, Visakha the great lay Sister, received Eight Boons.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja490", "root_name": "Pa\u00f1cuposathikaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Five-Precept Sabbath ", "acronym": "Ja 490", "blurb": "\u201cThou art content\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, about five hundred lay Brethren who were under the Sabbath vows. At that time they say that the Master, seated upon the Buddha\u2019s glorious seat, in the Hall of Truth, in the midst of folk of all the four kinds, looking around upon the gathering with a gentle heart, perceived that this day the teaching would turn on the tale of the lay Brethren. Then he addressed these, and said, \u201cHave the lay Brethren taken upon them the Sabbath vows?\u201d \u201cYes, Sir, they have,\u201d was the answer. \u201cIt was well done, this sabbath celebration was the practice of wise men of old: the wise men of old, I say, kept the sabbath celebration in order to subdue the sins of passion and lust.\u201d Then at their request he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja491", "root_name": "Mah\u0101moraj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Golden Peacock ", "acronym": "Ja 491", "blurb": "\u201cIf I being captured\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling in Jetavana, about a backsliding Brother. To this Brother the Master said, \u201cIs it true, as I am told, that you have backslidden?\u201d \u201cYes, Sir, it is true.\u201d \u201cBrother,\u201d said he, \u201cwill not this lust for pleasure confound a man like you? The hurricane that overwhelms Mount Sineru is not put to the blush before a withered leaf. In days of yore this passion has confounded holy beings, who for seven thousand years held aloof from following the lusts that arise within.\u201d With these words, he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja492", "root_name": "Tacchas\u016bkaraj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Carpenter\u2019s Boar ", "acronym": "Ja 492", "blurb": "\u201cI wandered, searching far\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, about two ancient Elders.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja493", "root_name": "Mah\u0101v\u0101\u1e47ijaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Merchants ", "acronym": "Ja 493", "blurb": "\u201cMerchants from many\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, about some traders who lived in Savatthi.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja494", "root_name": "S\u0101dhinaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "King S\u0101dhina of Mithila ", "acronym": "Ja 494", "blurb": "\u201cA wonder in the world\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling in Jetavana, about lay Brethren who took on the fast-day vows. On that occasion the Master said: \u201cLay Brethren, wise men of old, by virtue of their keeping the fast-day vows, went in the body to heaven, and there dwelt for a long time.\u201d Then at their request, he told a story of the past. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja495", "root_name": "Dasabr\u0101hma\u1e47aj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Ten Kinds of Brahmin ", "acronym": "Ja 495", "blurb": "\u201cThe righteous king\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling in Jetavana, about a gift incomparable. This has been explained in the Sucira Birth of the Eighth Book.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja496", "root_name": "Bhikkh\u0101paramparaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Gathering Almsfood ", "acronym": "Ja 496", "blurb": "\u201cI saw one sitting\u201d\u2014This story the Master told, whilst dwelling in Jetavana, about a certain landowner. He was a true and faithful believer, and showed honour continually to the Tathagata and the Order.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

translated_name: Past Life Stories of the Buddha
blurb: A collection of 547 sets of verses telling stories of the Buddha’s past lives. The canonical Pali collection consists of verses arranged in numbered sets in the Aṅguttara fashion. The shorter sets illustrate a high point of a story, while the longer sets tell a complete story. These verses would have been passed down from the beginning with prose narrative to flesh out the story, which in the Pali is now found in the commentary. It is in the commentary that we find the explicit connection between the stories of the past and the present day, identifying the hero of the tale with the bodhisattva and the major protagonists with the Buddha’s contemporaries. This collection is the main source of Jātakas, but there are many similar stories found elsewhere in the Pali canon (a few in the four nikāyas, others in the Cariyapiṭaka) and throughout the Chinese, Tibetan, and Sanskrit texts. Most of the Jātakas began life as folk tales or myths, drops from the vast ocean of story in oral culture. Several Jātakas record versions of famous Hindu myths, while others share a common basis with European folk tales. The verse forms in the Jātakas are mostly of the earlier kinds, and the social and political reflect historical realities in the centuries before the Buddha, where, for example, Varanasi was an independent kingdom. The Jātakas are the oldest, largest, and best-preserved collection of ancient stories found anywhere in the world. One of the central themes is renunciation, with multiple stories depicting the hero going-forth from the home, each time from a different perspective. Jātakas generally illustrate moral messages, but since the hero is supposed to be imperfect, it is not unusual for him to be portrayed as making dubious choices, even breaking precepts. Taken as a whole, the Jātaka literature is a vast tapestry of story illustrating the twisting and uncertain path to Awakening. The Jātaka genre proved a popular and effective framework for incorporating popular tales into a Buddhist context. They feature prominently in Buddhist art both ancient and modern, and are a primary means of introducing Buddhism to children in modern Theravāda.

[{"uid": "an7.65", "root_name": "Hir\u012bottappasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.65", "blurb": "A sense of conscience is the foundation that leads step by step to liberation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.66", "root_name": "Sattas\u016briyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.66", "blurb": "A rare discourse on cosmic evolution. The Buddha describes the successive appearance of seven suns and how even the earth will be burned up.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.67", "root_name": "Nagaropamasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.67", "blurb": "When a king\u2019s fortress is well supplied with seven things and has four kinds of food supplies it is impregnable. Similarly, a noble disciple with seven qualities and the four absorptions is impregnable.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an7.68", "root_name": "Dhamma\u00f1\u00f1\u016bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.68", "blurb": "A mendicant who has seven qualities is worthy, with a special emphasis on listening to and learning the teaching.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an7.69", "root_name": "P\u0101ricchattakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.69", "blurb": "The blossoming of the Shady Orchid Tree delights the gods of the Thirty-Three, and in the same way, the renunciation of a Buddhist ascetic is delightful.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.70", "root_name": "Sakkaccasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.70", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta reflects on what a mendicant should revere in order to develop the wholesome. He reports to the Buddha that these things are indeed found in himself.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.71", "root_name": "Bh\u0101van\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.71", "blurb": "Liberation doesn\u2019t happen because you wish for it, but because you develop the path.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.72", "root_name": "Aggikkhandhopamasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.72", "blurb": "It would be better for a monk to embrace a blazing fire than to lie with a maiden.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an7.73", "root_name": "Sunettasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.73", "blurb": "There have been many great teachers in the past, who should not be reviled. But reviling a single noble disciple is even more serious.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.74", "root_name": "Arakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.74", "blurb": "Araka was a famous teacher long ago, when the life span was much greater than today. Nevertheless, he still taught impermanence; how much more is it relevant today!", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Arising” is the second of three similar sections, each of which takes a set of ten doctrinal items and presents it according to a set pattern. The current chapter focuses on the fact that anyone who has these things will suffer.

[{"uid": "sn6.11", "root_name": "Sana\u1e45kum\u0101rasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 6.11", "blurb": "Brahm\u0101 Sana\u1e45kum\u0101ra appears to the Buddha and asserts that the aristocrat or khattiya is the best caste, but the Buddha is the best of people.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn6.12", "root_name": "Devadattasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 6.12", "blurb": "Brahm\u0101 Sahampati, referring to Devadatta, points out that honors destroy a scoundrel.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn6.13", "root_name": "Andhakavindasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 6.13", "blurb": "Brahm\u0101 Sahampati appears to the Buddha and speaks in praise of the renunciates staying fearless in the deep forest, and celebrates the many who have found freedom.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn6.14", "root_name": "Aru\u1e47avat\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 6.14", "blurb": "The Buddha tells a story of the past Buddha Sikh\u012b and his disciple Abhibh\u016b. They visit a brahm\u0101 realm where they perform many astounding feats and give teachings.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn6.15", "root_name": "Parinibb\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 6.15", "blurb": "After the Buddha became finally extinguished, Brahm\u0101 Sahampati led a series of distinguished beings who uttered verses in commemoration", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses with Nuns” contains 10 discourses describing occasions when various nuns retreat to a forest for meditation, only to be challenged by Māra. The verses here partly overlap with the Therīgāthā, though there are some that are unique to this context, and we also have a prose narrative to flesh out the context. Māra’s challenges are various; sometimes he is sexist, alleging that women are weak in wisdom (SN 5.2). Several of these short texts are among the most frequently quoted of all the suttas.

blurb: The “Linked Discourses with Similes” contains 12 discourses with parables or similes illustrating diverse points of the teaching. This chapter highlights the Buddha’s skill in choosing vivid and suitable similes for any occasion.

[{"uid": "sn22.93", "root_name": "Nad\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.93", "blurb": "If you grasp at the aggregates as a self, you will meet with calamity, like a man swept down by a mountain river, grasping at grass or rushes.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.94", "root_name": "Pupphasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.94", "blurb": "The Buddha doesn\u2019t dispute with the world; the world disputes with him. He has understood the five aggregates and explains them. Like a lotus, he was born in the swamp, but rises above it.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.95", "root_name": "Phe\u1e47api\u1e47\u1e0d\u016bpamasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.95", "blurb": "The Buddha gives a series of similes for the aggregates: physical form is like foam, feeling is like a bubble, perception is like a mirage, choices are like a coreless tree, and consciousness is like an illusion. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "sn22.96", "root_name": "Gomayapi\u1e47\u1e0dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.96", "blurb": "Nothing in the aggregates has even the tiniest bit of stability or permanence. In a past life, the Buddha was a great king with vast properties, but all those conditions have passed away.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.97", "root_name": "Nakhasikh\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.97", "blurb": "A mendicant asks whether anything in the aggregates has even the tiniest bit of stability or permanence. The Buddha answers using the simile of a little dirt under his fingernail.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.98", "root_name": "Suddhikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.98", "blurb": "A mendicant asks whether anything in the aggregates has even the tiniest bit of stability or permanence.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.99", "root_name": "Gaddulabaddhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.99", "blurb": "Transmigration has no knowable beginning; even the oceans, mountains, and this great earth will perish. But like a dog on a leash running around a post, beings remain attached to the aggregates.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.100", "root_name": "Dutiyagaddulabaddhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.100", "blurb": "A dog leashed to a post will always remain close to that post. In the same way, beings remain close to aggregates in this endless cycle of transmigration. The Buddha refers to a well-known painting called \u201cConduct\u201d, and says the mind is even more diverse than that; and indeed, the animal realm is the most diverse of them all, and it is produced by the mind.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.101", "root_name": "V\u0101sija\u1e6dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.101", "blurb": "Contemplating the aggregates leads to liberation, but this may not be immediately apparent. The Buddha illustrates this with similes of a chook sitting on eggs, the wearing away of an axe handle, and the rotting of a ship\u2019s rigging.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.102", "root_name": "Aniccasa\u00f1\u00f1\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.102", "blurb": "The perception of impermanence eliminates lust, ignorance, and conceit. Illustrated with a long series of similes.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Corruptions” is the third of three similar sections, each of which takes a set of ten doctrinal items and presents it according to a set pattern. The current chapter focuses on the fact that desire for these things is a corruption of the mind.

[{"uid": "sn16.1", "root_name": "Santu\u1e6d\u1e6dhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 16.1", "blurb": "Kassapa is content with robes, alms-food, lodging, and medicines.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn16.2", "root_name": "Anottapp\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 16.2", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta approaches Kassapa and asks how it is that only someone who is keen and conscientious can realize freedom.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn16.3", "root_name": "Cand\u016bpam\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 16.3", "blurb": "Kassapa approaches families like the moon, with humility, keeping his distance, and not getting involved. So when he teaches, it is with pure intentions.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn16.4", "root_name": "Kul\u016bpakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 16.4", "blurb": "Some mendicants approach families in the hope of receiving fine gifts or respect\u2014but not Kassapa.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn16.5", "root_name": "Ji\u1e47\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 16.5", "blurb": "The Buddha points out that Kassapa has grown old, and urges him to give up his ascetic life and stay in a comfortable monastery.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn16.6", "root_name": "Ov\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 16.6", "blurb": "The Buddha invites Kassapa to teach the mendicants, but he is reluctant, since certain students of Anuruddha and A\u0304nanda have been competing to see who can teach better.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn16.7", "root_name": "Dutiyaov\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 16.7", "blurb": "The Buddha invites Kassapa to teach the mendicants, but he is reluctant, saying that the mendicants have become stubborn and their good qualities are declining.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn16.8", "root_name": "Tatiyaov\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 16.8", "blurb": "The Buddha invites Kassapa to teach the mendicants, but he is reluctant, saying that the senior mendicants used to set a good example, but now instead of respecting good practice, they respect fame and fortune.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn16.9", "root_name": "Jh\u0101n\u0101bhi\u00f1\u00f1asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 16.9", "blurb": "The Buddha asserts that just as he has full mastery of all the meditation attainments and higher spiritual realizations, so does Kassapa.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn16.10", "root_name": "Upassayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 16.10", "blurb": "When Kassapa is persuaded by A\u0304nanda to go with him to teach the nuns, the nun Thullatissa\u0304 compares him unfavorably to A\u0304nanda, prompting Kassapa to issue a warning and make a bold claim of his spiritual mastery. This discourse appears to be set after the Buddha\u2019s passing.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn16.11", "root_name": "C\u012bvarasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 16.11", "blurb": "When several of A\u0304nanda\u2019s students disrobe, Kassapa admonishes him, calling him \u201cboy\u201d. The nun Thullananda\u0304 hears of this and criticizes Kassapa, claiming he formerly followed another teacher. But Kassapa refutes this, and gives an account of his going forth and first encounter with the Buddha.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn16.12", "root_name": "Para\u1e41mara\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 16.12", "blurb": "Sa\u0304riputta asks Kassapa about whether a Realized One survives death.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn16.13", "root_name": "Saddhammappatir\u016bpakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 16.13", "blurb": "Kassapa asks the Buddha why there are now more rules but fewer awakened mendicants. The Buddha replies that it is due to the arising of the counterfeit Dhamma, giving five factors that lead to decline", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

children: [{"uid": "mn41", "root_name": "S\u0101leyyakasutta", "translated_name": "The People of S\u0101l\u0101 ", "acronym": "MN 41", "blurb": "The Buddha explains to a group of brahmins the conduct leading to rebirth in higher or lower states, including detailed explanations of the ten core practices which lay people should undertake, and which also form the basis for liberation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "mn42", "root_name": "Vera\u00f1jakasutta", "translated_name": "The People of Vera\u00f1ja ", "acronym": "MN 42", "blurb": "Similar to the previous. The Buddha explains the conduct leading to rebirth in higher or lower states, including detailed explanations of the ten core practices.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn43", "root_name": "Mah\u0101vedallasutta", "translated_name": "The Great Classification ", "acronym": "MN 43", "blurb": "A series of questions and answers between S\u0101riputta and Mah\u0101ko\u1e6d\u1e6dhita, examining various subtle and abstruse aspects of the teachings.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "mn44", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37avedallasutta", "translated_name": "The Shorter Classification ", "acronym": "MN 44", "blurb": "The layman Vis\u0101kha asks the nun Dhammadinn\u0101 about various difficult matters, including some of the highest meditation attainments. The Buddha fully endorses her answers.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "mn45", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37adhammasam\u0101d\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": "The Shorter Discourse on Taking Up Practices ", "acronym": "MN 45", "blurb": "The Buddha explains how taking up different practices may have harmful or beneficial results. The memorable simile of the creeper shows how insidious temptations can be.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn46", "root_name": "Mah\u0101dhammasam\u0101d\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": "The Great Discourse on Taking Up Practices ", "acronym": "MN 46", "blurb": "While we all want to be happy, we often find the opposite happens. The Buddha explains why.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "mn47", "root_name": "V\u012bma\u1e41sakasutta", "translated_name": "The Inquirer ", "acronym": "MN 47", "blurb": "While some spiritual teachers prefer to remain in obscurity, the Buddha not only encouraged his followers to closely investigate him, but gave them a detailed and demanding method to do so.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn48", "root_name": "Kosambiyasutta", "translated_name": "The Mendicants of Kosambi ", "acronym": "MN 48", "blurb": "Despite the Buddha\u2019s presence, the monks of Kosambi fell into a deep and bitter dispute. The Buddha taught the reluctant monks to develop love and harmony, reminding them of the state of peace that they sought.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn49", "root_name": "Brahmanimantanikasutta", "translated_name": "On the Invitation of Brahm\u0101 ", "acronym": "MN 49", "blurb": "The Buddha ascends to a high heavenly realm where he engages in a cosmic contest with a powerful divinity, who had fallen into the delusion that he was eternal and all-powerful.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn50", "root_name": "M\u0101ratajjan\u012byasutta", "translated_name": "The Rebuke of M\u0101ra ", "acronym": "MN 50", "blurb": "M\u0101ra, the trickster and god of death, tried to annoy Moggall\u0101na. He not only failed but was subject to a stern sermon warning of the dangers of attacking the Buddha\u2019s disciples.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}]

Master while at Jetavana, about the venerable Ananda.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about taking things on trust.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja94", "root_name": "Lomaha\u1e41saj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Hair-raising ", "acronym": "Ja 94", "blurb": "\u201cNow scorched.\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while at Patikarama near Vesali, about Sunakkhatta.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja95", "root_name": "Mah\u0101sudassanaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Great King Sudassana ", "acronym": "Ja 95", "blurb": "\u201cHow transient.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master as he lay on his death-bed, concerning Ananda\u2019s words, \u201cO Blessed One, suffer not your end to be in this sorry little town.\u201d", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja96", "root_name": "Telapattaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Pot of Oil ", "acronym": "Ja 96", "blurb": "\u201cAs one with care.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while dwelling in a forest near the town of Desaka in the Sumbha country, concerning the Janapada-Kalyani Sutta. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja97", "root_name": "N\u0101masiddhij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "One Who Thought Names Had Power ", "acronym": "Ja 97", "blurb": "\u201cSeeing Quick dead.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a Brother who thought luck went by names. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja98", "root_name": "K\u016b\u1e6dav\u0101\u1e47ijaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Cheating Merchant ", "acronym": "Ja 98", "blurb": "\u201cWise rightly, Wisest wrongly.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a cheating merchant. There were two merchants in partnership at Savatthi, we are told, who travelled with their merchandise and came back with the proceeds. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja99", "root_name": "Parosahassaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Over a Thousand ", "acronym": "Ja 99", "blurb": "\u201cFar better than a thousand fools.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master when at Jetavana, concerning the question of the unconverted. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja100", "root_name": "As\u0101tar\u016bpaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Unpleasant ", "acronym": "Ja 100", "blurb": "\u201cIn guise of joy.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Kundadhanavana near the city of Kundiya about Suppavasa, a lay-sister, who was daughter to King Koliya. 35.132", "blurb": "Students of the brahmin Lohicca make a racket while collecting firewood near Maha\u0304kacca\u0304na\u2019s hut. Maha\u0304kacca\u0304na hushes them and recites a series of verses contrasting the virtuous brahmins of old with those of today. Taking umbrage, they tell Lohicca, who goes to Maha\u0304kacca\u0304na to ascertain the truth. But when Lohicca hears what Maha\u0304kacca\u0304na teach on the six senses, he is so impressed he goes for refuge.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.133", "root_name": "Verahacc\u0101nisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.133", "blurb": "A student of the brahmin lady of the Verahacca\u0304ni clan recommends to her the teaching of Venerable Uda\u0304y\u0131\u0304, so she invites him for a meal. But when she displays a conceited attitude, he leaves without teaching. However, she corrects herself so he teaches her that pleasure and pain depend on the senses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses with Māra” contains 25 discourses featuring Māra, the god of temptation, deceit, and death. In these discourses, Māra typically appears in some terrifying or beguiling form, hoping to disturb the Buddha, or else he challenges the Buddha with a critical verse. Like the previous section, the narrative prose here is substantive. The Buddha recognizes him at once and exposes his deceit in a verse. Māra also appears throughout the next collection, where the nuns take him on.

blurb: Many of the discourses in this chapter delve into complex and analytical presentations of core teachings. It includes important discourses on meditation.
children: [{"uid": "mn111", "root_name": "Anupadasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 111", "blurb": "The Buddha describes in technical detail the process of insight of Venerable S\u0101riputta. Many ideas and terms in this text anticipate the Abhidhamma.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn112", "root_name": "Chabbisodhanasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 112", "blurb": "If someone claims to be awakened, their claim should be interrogated with a detailed series of detailed questions. Only if they can answer them clearly should the claim be accepted.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, cultivated or avoided, and Venerable S\u0101riputta volunteers to elaborate.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": blurb: The “Linked Discourses with Moggallāna” contains 11 discourses featuring Moggallāna, one of the chief disciples. He tells the monks of his struggles in meditation, and how he was encouraged by the Buddha. In the last two discourses, he visit the heavens and teaches the gods.

[{"uid": "ja301", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37ak\u0101li\u1e45gaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "King K\u0101li\u1e45ga ", "acronym": "Ja 301", "blurb": "\u201cOpen the gate\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while living at Jetavana, about the admission of four female ascetics to the religious life.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja302", "root_name": "Mah\u0101ass\u0101rohaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Great Horseman ", "acronym": "Ja 302", "blurb": "\u201cThy gifts bestowed\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, about the Elder Ananda. The circumstances that suggested the story have been already given. \u201cIn former days too,\u201d the Master said, \u201cwise men acted on the principle that one good turn deserves another.\u201d And hereupon he told them a story of the olden time.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja303", "root_name": "Ekar\u0101jaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The One King ", "acronym": "Ja 303", "blurb": "\u201cO monarch that erst\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, about a courtier of the king of Kosala. The circumstances that suggested the story have been already related in the Seyyamsa Birth. On this occasion the Master said, \u201cYou are not the only one who got good out of evil: wise men of old also got good out of evil.\u201d And he told an old-world story.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja304", "root_name": "Daddaraj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Dragon Named Drum ", "acronym": "Ja 304", "blurb": "\u201cO Daddara, who\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, about a certain choleric fellow.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja305", "root_name": "S\u012blav\u012bma\u1e41sanaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "A Test of Virtue ", "acronym": "Ja 305", "blurb": "\u201cIn sooth there is\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, about the rebuking of sin. The circumstances will be set forth in the Paniya Birth in the Eleventh Book. The following is a brief summary of it.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja306", "root_name": "Suj\u0101t\u0101j\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Queen Suj\u0101t\u0101 ", "acronym": "Ja 306", "blurb": "\u201cWhat is this egg-shaped fruit\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while dwelling at Jetavana, about queen Mallika. One day, they say, there was a dispute at court between her and the king. The king was so enraged that he", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja307", "root_name": "Pal\u0101saj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Parrot Tree ", "acronym": "Ja 307", "blurb": "\u201cWhy, Brahmin, though\u201d\u2014The Master, when he was stretched upon the bed of death, told this story of the Elder Ananda.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja308", "root_name": "Saku\u1e47aj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Swift Bird ", "acronym": "Ja 308", "blurb": "\u201cKindness as much\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while dwelling at Jetavana, about the ingratitude of Devadatta.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja309", "root_name": "Chavakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Wretch Who Became King of the Night ", "acronym": "Ja 309", "blurb": "\u201cHoly Teacher\u201d\u2014The Master while residing at Jetavana told this story, about the Fraternity of Six Priests. It is related in detail in the Vinaya. Here is a brief summary of it.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja310", "root_name": "Seyyaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Better ", "acronym": "Ja 310", "blurb": "\u201cNo throne on earth\u201d\u2014The Master told this story while in residence at Jetavana, about a backsliding brother, who in going his rounds for alms at Savatthi caught sight of a beautiful woman, and thenceforth had grown discontented and lost all pleasure in the Law.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: A partial translation of the Ekottarikāgama was made by An Shigao (安世高 ) in CE 148–170. Known as Qi Chu San Guan Jing (七處三觀經), it consists of one fascicle containing 47 shorter sutras. In the Taishō edition of the Chinese canon, it is text number 150A, located at T vol. 2, 875b.

[{"uid": "ja406", "root_name": "Gandh\u0101raj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "In the Kingdom of Gandh\u0101ra ", "acronym": "Ja 406", "blurb": "\u201cVillages full sixteen thousand\u201d\u2014The Master told this when dwelling in Jetavana, concerning the precept on the storing up of medicines.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja407", "root_name": "Mah\u0101kapij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Great Monkey ", "acronym": "Ja 407", "blurb": "\u201cYou made yourself\u201d\u2014The Master told this while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning good works towards one\u2019s relatives. The occasion will appear in the Bhaddasala Birth. They began talking in the Hall of Truth, saying, \u201cThe supreme Buddha does good works towards his relatives.\u201d When the Master had asked and been told their theme, he said, \u201cBrethren, this is not the first time a Tathagata has done good works towards his relatives,\u201d and so he told a tale of old time.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja408", "root_name": "Kumbhak\u0101raj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Potter ", "acronym": "Ja 408", "blurb": "\u201cA mango in a forest\u201d\u2014The Master told this when dwelling in Jetavana, concerning rebuke of sin. The occasion will appear in the Paniya Birth. .", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja409", "root_name": "Da\u1e37hadhammaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "King Da\u1e37hadhamma ", "acronym": "Ja 409", "blurb": "\u201cI carried for the king\u201d\u2014The Master told this when dwelling in the Ghosita forest near Kosambi, concerning Bhaddavatika, king Udena\u2019s she-elephant. Now the way in which this elephant was adorned and the royal lineage of Udena will be set forth in the Matanga Birth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja410", "root_name": "Somadattaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Elephant Somadatta ", "acronym": "Ja 410", "blurb": "\u201cDeep in the wood\u201d\u2014The Master told this while dwelling at Jetavana, about a certain old Brother. The story was that this Brother ordained a novice, who waited on him but soon died of a fatal disease. The old man went about weeping and wailing for his death. Seeing him, the Brethren began to talk in the Hall of Truth, \u201cSirs, this old Brother goes about weeping and wailing for the novice\u2019s death: he must surely have neglected the meditation on death.\u201d The Master came, and hearing the subject of their talk, he said, \u201cBrethren, this is not the first time this man is weeping for the other\u2019s death,\u201d and so he told the old tale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja411", "root_name": "Sus\u012bmaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "King Sus\u012bma ", "acronym": "Ja 411", "blurb": "\u201cHeretofore the hairs\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, about the Great Renunciation. The Brethren were sitting in the Hall of Truth, praising the Buddha\u2019s renunciation. The Master, finding that this was their topic, said, \u201cBrethren, it is not strange that I should now make the Great Renunciation and retirement from the world, I who have for many hundred thousand ages exercised perfection: of old also I gave up the reign over the kingdom of Kasi, three hundred leagues in extent, and made the renunciation,\u201d and so he told the old tale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja412", "root_name": "Ko\u1e6dasimbalij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Spirit of the Cotton-Tree ", "acronym": "Ja 412", "blurb": "\u201cI bore with me\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning rebuke of sin. The incident leading to the tale will appear in the Panna Birth. On this occasion the Master, perceiving that five hundred Brethren were overcome by thoughts of desire in the House of the Golden Pavement, gathered the assembly and said, \u201cBrethren, it is right to distrust where distrust is proper; sins surround a man as banyans and such plants grow up around a tree: in this way of old a spirit dwelling in the top of a cotton-tree saw a bird voiding the banyan seeds it had eaten among the branches of the cotton-tree, and became terrified lest her abode should thereby come to destruction:\u201d and so he told a tale of old.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja413", "root_name": "Dh\u016bmak\u0101rij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Smokemaker the Goatherd ", "acronym": "Ja 413", "blurb": "\u201cThe righteous king\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning the Kosala king\u2019s favour to a stranger. At one time, the story goes, that king showed no favour to his old warriors who came to him in the usual way, but gave honour and hospitality to strangers coming for the first time. He went to fight in a disturbed frontier province: but his old warriors would not fight, thinking that the new-corners who were in favour would do so; and the new-corners would not, thinking that the old warriors would. The rebels prevailed. The king, knowing that his defeat was owing to the mistake he had made in showing favour to new-comers, returned to Savatthi. He resolved to ask the Lord of Wisdom whether he was the only king who had ever been defeated for that reason: so after the morning meal he went to Jetavana and put the question to the Master. The Master answered, \u201cGreat King, yours is not the only case: former kings also were defeated by reason of the favour they showed to new-corners,\u201d and so, at the king\u2019s request, he told an old tale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja414", "root_name": "J\u0101garaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Who Wakes? ", "acronym": "Ja 414", "blurb": "\u201cWho is it that wakes\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning a certain lay-brother.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja415", "root_name": "Kumm\u0101sapi\u1e47\u1e0dij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "A Spoon of Porridge ", "acronym": "Ja 415", "blurb": "\u201cService done\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning queen Mallika. She was the daughter of the chief of the garland-makers of Savatthi, extremely beautiful and very good.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja416", "root_name": "Parantapaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Adulterer Parantapa ", "acronym": "Ja 416", "blurb": "\u201cTerror and fear\u201d\u2014The Master told this while dwelling in the Bamboo-grove, concerning Devadatta\u2019s going about to kill him. They were discussing it in the Hall of Truth, \u201cSirs, Devadatta is going about to kill the Tathagata, he has hired bowmen, thrown down a rock, let loose Nalagiri, and uses special means for the destruction of the Tathagata.\u201d The Master came and asked the subject of their discussion as they sat together: when they told him, he said, \u201cBrethren, this is not the first time he has gone about to kill me: but he could not even make me afraid, and gained only sorrow for himself:\u201d and so he told the tale of old.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

translated_name: The Chapter on Perceptions for Ascetics
children: [{"uid": "an10.101", "root_name": "Sama\u1e47asa\u00f1\u00f1\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.101", "blurb": "Three ascetic perceptions lead to seven results.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an10.102", "root_name": "Bojjha\u1e45gasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.102", "blurb": "The seven factors of awakening lead to realizing the three knowledges.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an10.103", "root_name": "Micchattasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.103", "blurb": "The tenfold wrong path leads to failure, the tenfold right path leads to success.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an10.104", "root_name": "B\u012bjasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.104", "blurb": "When a person has wrong view, all their path development is wrong. But when they have right view, everything good follows.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an10.105", "root_name": "Vijj\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.105", "blurb": "Ignorance is the precursor of wrong view and the other bad qualities, while right view is the opposite.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an10.106", "root_name": "Nijjarasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.106", "blurb": "Each of the ten path factors wears away its opposite.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an10.107", "root_name": "Dhovanasutta", translated_name: The Chapter at the Cāpāla Shrine
children: [{"uid": "sn51.1", "root_name": "Ap\u0101rasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.1", "blurb": "The four bases of psychic power lead from the near to the far shore.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn51.2", "root_name": "Viraddhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.2", "blurb": "One who has neglected the four bases of psychic power has neglected the path to the end of suffering.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn51.3", "root_name": "Ariyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.3", "blurb": "The four bases of psychic power are noble and emancipating.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn51.4", "root_name": "Nibbid\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.4", "blurb": "The four bases of psychic power lead to dispassion.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn51.5", "root_name": "Iddhipadesasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.5", "blurb": "Those who have developed psychic powers in part have developed the four bases of psychic power in part.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn51.6", "root_name": "Samattasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.6", "blurb": "Those who have developed psychic powers in full have developed the four bases of psychic power in full.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn51.7", "root_name": "Bhikkhusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.7", "blurb": "Whatever mendicants realize perfection do so by developing the four bases of psychic power.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn51.8", "root_name": "Buddhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.8", "blurb": "It is because of developing the four bases of psychic power that the Realized One is called a Buddha.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn51.9", "root_name": "\u00d1\u0101\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.9", "blurb": "On the night of his awakening, understanding and vision came to the Buddha regarding the four bases of psychic power.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn51.10", "root_name": "Cetiyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.10", "blurb": "The Buddha says he could live to the end of the eon due to developing the four bases of psychic power. But \u0100nanda doesn\u2019t get the hint.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: Also attributed to Dharmatrāta’s compilation, this was translated by Tianxizai 天息災 (?–1000), who arrived at the capital of Song dynasty in 980. It has 33 chapters corresponding to the chapters of the Udānavarga, but, unlike T 212, this text has only verses without commentaries. The translator of T 213 followed the translation of T 212, and he also followed the translation of T 210 when those verses are not in T 212 but same with T 210.

[{"uid": "sn35.84", "root_name": "Palokadhammasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.84", "blurb": "The Buddha tells \u0100nanda that in the training of the noble one the \u201cworld\u201d consisting of six sense experience is liable to wear out.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.85", "root_name": "Su\u00f1\u00f1atalokasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.85", "blurb": "The Buddha tells \u0100nanda that the \u201cworld\u201d consisting of six sense experience is empty because it is empty of self and what belongs to self.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.86", "root_name": "Sa\u1e41khittadhammasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.86", "blurb": "\u0100nanda asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha teaches him that the senses are impermanent, etc.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.87", "root_name": "Channasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.87", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta and Mah\u0101cunda visit Channa, who is ill. Channa says that he lacks for no care, but is in such great pain that he wishes to take his own life, insisting that he will do so blamelessly. S\u0101riputta tries to dissuade him, and questions him closely about attachment to the six senses. Later Channa does take his own life, and the Buddha confirmed that, despite S\u0101riputta\u2019s doubts, he was indeed blameless.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.88", "root_name": "Pu\u1e47\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.88", "blurb": "Venerable Pu\u1e47\u1e47a goes to the Buddha and asks for a teaching before he departs to the foreign land of Sun\u0101paranta. The Buddha warns him that folk there are fierce, and questions whether he is ready for such a difficult assignment.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.89", "root_name": "B\u0101hiyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.89", "blurb": "Venerable B\u0101hiya asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha teaches him that the senses are impermanent, etc.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.90", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamaej\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.90", "blurb": "Being stirred by craving is painful, so the Realized One lives unstirred, not identifying with any aspect of sense experience.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.91", "root_name": "Dutiyaej\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.91", "blurb": "Being stirred by craving is painful, so the Realized One lives unstirred, not identifying with any aspect of sense experience, or indeed, with the entire scope of the aggregates, elements, and senses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.92", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamadvayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.92", "blurb": "The dyad is the interior sense organ with its corresponding exterior sense stimulus.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.93", "root_name": "Dutiyadvayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.93", "blurb": "Consciousness arises from the dyad of the interior sense organ with its corresponding exterior sense stimulus. All these things are conditioned, impermanent, and constantly falling apart.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on the Truths” contains 131 discourses on the four noble truths: suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path. These formed the main subject of the Buddha’s first discourse, which is included here as SN 56.11. The Buddha said that all of his teaching was comprised within the four noble truths. Indeed, the overall structure of the main doctrinal Saṁyuttas can be seen as an expanded example of this: The sections on the Aggregates and the Sense Fields deal with the first noble truth; Dependent Origination deals with the second and third; and the chapters on the Path deal with the final truth. This chapter thus provides an overall perspective on the other teachings, and the chapter occurs at the end just as the realization of the four noble truths emerges from the path.

translated_name: The Chapter with the Pāṭali Villagers
blurb: The final chapter deals with the Buddha’s final passing away and the crisis of faith that this created. It begins with series of solemn declarations on Nibbana and ends with the spectacular passing of the monk Dabba.

[{"uid": "sn2.1", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamakassapasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.1", "blurb": "A deity named Kassapa comes to the Buddha and speaks of the training of a mendicant in seclusion and right speech.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.2", "root_name": "Dutiyakassapasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.2", "blurb": "The deity Kassapa speaks of how a mendicant should be a meditator, peaceful and free.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.3", "root_name": "M\u0101ghasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.3", "blurb": "The god M\u0101gha asks the Buddha about what one should slay in order to sleep well and be without sorrow.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.4", "root_name": "M\u0101gadhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.4", "blurb": "The deity M\u0101gadha asks the Buddha how many sources of light there are in the world. The Buddha speaks of five lights, but the Buddha is the best of them.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.5", "root_name": "D\u0101malisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.5", "blurb": "Da\u0304mali the god suggests that a true brahmin must strive to abandon desire. The Buddha disagrees, saying that a true holy one has already completed their work.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.6", "root_name": "K\u0101madasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.6", "blurb": "The deity Ka\u0304mada addresses the Buddha with a series of cryptic statements lamenting the difficulty of spiritual practice. The Buddha agrees, but points out that true practitioners do it even though it\u2019s hard.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn2.7", "root_name": "Pa\u00f1c\u0101laca\u1e47\u1e0dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.7", "blurb": "Pa\u00f1ca\u0304laca\u1e47\u1e0da praises the Buddha for finding the opening amid the confinement of the world. But the Buddha affirms that anyone with mindfulness and stillness may find such an escape.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.8", "root_name": "T\u0101yanasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.8", "blurb": "Ta\u0304yana, a deity who was in a past life was a leader of a non-Buddhist sect, speaks a series of verses in praise of strenuous exertion and discipline. These famous verses are commonly recited by Theravadin monks.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.9", "root_name": "Candimasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.9", "blurb": "In a parable of a lunar eclipse, the moon god Candima\u0304 is swallowed by the demon lord R\u0101hu. Candima\u0304 appeals to the Buddha, who tells R\u0101hu to let go. This sutta is recited as a protection verse.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.10", "root_name": "S\u016briyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.10", "blurb": "In a parable of a solar eclipse, the sun god Suriya is swallowed by the demon lord R\u0101hu. Suriya appeals to the Buddha, who tells R\u0101hu to let go. This sutta is recited as a protection verse.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses with Sāriputta” describes Sāriputta’s deep meditation practice, and his conversations with Ānanda, who noticed how radiant and glowing he was. An exception to this pattern is the final sutta, which depicts Sāriputta responding to the challenges of a female wanderer.
children: [{"uid": "sn28-sariputtavagga", "root_name": "S\u0101riputtavagga", "translated_name": "The Chapter with S\u0101riputta ", "acronym": null, "blurb": null, "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 28.1\u201310", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 10}]

children: [{"uid": "sn22.113", "root_name": "Avijj\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.113", "blurb": "Ignorance is not understanding the aggregates.", "node_type": "leaf", "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn22.117", "root_name": "Bandhanasutta",
