"child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn22.119", "root_name": "Dutiyaparipucchitasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.119", "blurb": "The Buddha questions the mendicants on the aggregates.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn22.120", "root_name": "Sa\u1e41yojaniyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.120", "blurb": "The aggregates are the things that fetter, the craving is the fetter.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn22.121", "root_name": "Up\u0101d\u0101niyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.121", "blurb": "The aggregates are the things that are graspable, the craving is the grasping.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn22.122", "root_name": "S\u012blavantasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.122", "blurb": "Mah\u0101ko\u1e6d\u1e6dhita asks what an ethical mendicant should focus on, and S\u0101riputta replies that if they focus on aggregates as impermanent, etc. they may become a stream-enterer. A stream-enterer contemplating in the same way may become a non-returner, a once-returner, and a perfected one.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.123", "root_name": "Sutavantasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.123", "blurb": "Mah\u0101ko\u1e6d\u1e6dhita asks what an educated mendicant should focus on, and S\u0101riputta replies that if they focus on aggregates as impermanent, etc. they may become a stream-enterer. A stream-enterer contemplating in the same way may become a non-returner, a once-returner, and a perfected one.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn22.124", "root_name": "Kappasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.124", "blurb": "Venerable Kappa asks the Buddha how to see so as to let go of conceit. The Buddha tells him to contemplate the aggregates in terms of not-self.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn22.125", "root_name": "Dutiyakappasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.125", "blurb": "Venerable Kappa asks the Buddha how to see so as to let go of conceit and be freed. The Buddha tells him to contemplate the aggregates in terms of not-self.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "ja351", "root_name": "Ma\u1e47iku\u1e47\u1e0dalaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Jeweled Earrings ", "acronym": "Ja 351", "blurb": "\u201cStript of all the joys of life\u201d\u2014This story the Master, while dwelling at Jetavana, told concerning a councillor who was guilty of misconduct in the harem of the king of Kosala. The incident that gave rise to the story has been given in full before.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja352", "root_name": "Suj\u0101taj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Pious Son Suj\u0101ta ", "acronym": "Ja 352", "blurb": "\u201cWhy haste to bring\u201d\u2014This story the Master, while dwelling at Jetavana, told concerning a landowner who had lost his father.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja353", "root_name": "Venas\u0101khaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Beneath the Spreading Branches ", "acronym": "Ja 353", "blurb": "\u201c\u2018Though thou art now\u201d\u2014This story the Master, while living in the Bhesakala grove near Sumsumaragiri (Mount Crocodile) in the country of the Bhaggas, told concerning young prince Bodhi.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja354", "root_name": "Uragaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Snake ", "acronym": "Ja 354", "blurb": "\u201cMan quits his mortal frame\u201d\u2014This story the Master, while dwelling at Jetavana, told concerning a landowner whose son had died. The introductory story is just the same as that of the man who lost both his wife and father. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja355", "root_name": "Gha\u1e6daj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Prince Gha\u1e6da ", "acronym": "Ja 355", "blurb": "\u201cWhile others weep\u201d\u2014This story the Master, dwelling at Jetavana, told concerning a minister of the king of Kosala. The introductory story is identical with one already given. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja356", "root_name": "Kora\u1e47\u1e0diyaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Student Kora\u1e47\u1e0diya ", "acronym": "Ja 356", "blurb": "\u201cWhy in forest\u201d\u2014This was a story told by the Master while dwelling at Jetavana, concerning the Captain of the Faith (Sariputta). That elder, they say, when wicked folk came to him, such as hunters, fishermen and the like, laid down the moral law to them, and any others that he might see from time to time, saying, \u201cReceive ye the law.\u201d Through respect for the elder, they could not disobey his words and accepted the law, but failed to keep it, and still followed each after his own business.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja357", "root_name": "La\u1e6dukikaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Quail ", "acronym": "Ja 357", "blurb": "\u201cElephant of sixty years\u201d\u2014This was a story told by the Master while dwelling in the Bamboo Grove, concerning Devadatta. One day they raised a discussion in the Hall of Truth, saying, \u201cSirs, Devadatta is harsh, cruel, and violent. He has not an atom of pity for mortals.\u201d When the Master came, he inquired what was the topic the Brethren were assembled to discuss, and on hearing what it was, he said, \u201cBrethren, not now only, but formerly also he was pitiless.\u201d And herewith he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja358", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37adhammap\u0101laj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Shorter Tale of Dhammap\u0101la ", "acronym": "Ja 358", "blurb": "\u201cMahapatapa\u2019s wretched queen\u201d\u2014This story the Master, when dwelling in the Bamboo Grove, told concerning the going about of Devadatta to slay the Bodhisatta.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja359", "root_name": "Suva\u1e47\u1e47amigaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Golden Deer ", "acronym": "Ja 359", "blurb": "\u201cO Golden foot,\u201d This was a story told by the Master while in residence at Jetavana, about a maiden of gentle birth in Savatthi.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja360", "root_name": "Suyonand\u012bj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Queen Suyonand\u012b ", "acronym": "Ja 360", "blurb": "\u201cI scent the fragrance\u201d\u2014This story the Master, while living at Jetavana, told concerning a backsliding Brother. The Master asked if it were true that he longed for the world, and what he had seen to make him regret having taken orders. The Brother answered, \u201cIt was all owing to the charms of a woman.\u201d The Master said, \u201cVerily, Brother, there is no possibility of being on one\u2019s guard against womenfolk. Sages of old, though they took the precaution to dwell in the abode of the Garudas, failed to be on their guard against them.\u201d And being urged by him, the Master related a story of the past. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an4.37", "root_name": "Aparih\u0101niyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.37", "blurb": "A mendicant who has translated_name: The Group of Linked Discourses Beginning With the Aggregates
blurb: The “Book of the Aggregates” is the third of the five books of the Linked Discourses. It is named after the first and longest saṁyutta, which deals with the core Buddhist teaching of the five aggregates. Of the remaining twelve saṁyuttas, three also take up the theme of the aggregates, while the remainder deal with miscellaneous secondary themes, some organized by subject, others by person.
children: [{"uid": "sn22", "root_name": "Khandhasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on the Aggregates ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on the Aggregates\u201d contains 159 discourses on the core doctrinal topic of the five aggregates. This term was introduced in the first sermon as the summary of the noble truth of suffering, and became a foundational teaching in all forms of Buddhism. The basic idea of an \u201caggregate\u201d is a set or class of phenomena. The five are form (r\u016bpa, i.e. \u201cphysical phenomena\u201d, or sometimes simply \u201cbody\u201d; note that in Buddhism, r\u016bpa includes all things with material properties such as shape and color, including visions perceived only in the mind), feeling (vedan\u0101, i.e. the pleasant, painful, or neutral tone of experience), perception (sa\u00f1\u00f1\u0101, i.e. the recognition or interpretation of experience, not sense awareness), choices (sa\u1e45kh\u0101r\u0101, i.e. intention, will, or volition; the choice to perform an act, especially one with an ethical dimension), and consciousness (vi\u00f1\u00f1\u0101\u1e47a, i.e. the subjective process of awareness itself). The \u201caggregates\u201d are the various different phenomena so classified. Almost always, they are referred to as the \u201caggregates connected with grasping\u201d (up\u0101d\u0101nakkhandha). The relation between \u201cgrasping\u201d and \u201caggregate\u201d encompasses a number of aspects. The aggregates are the subject of grasping, in that they are the things that are normally attached to and taken to be the permanent \u201cself\u201d. But they are not merely passive spectators: they are also the functional support of grasping, the things that make grasping work. As active participants in the process of grasping, they stimulate grasping to themselves (up\u0101d\u0101niya). And finally, they are the product of grasping in the sense that attachments in past lives have given rise to the aggregates in this life (up\u0101dinna). One of the key functions of the aggregates is to categorize theories of the self. From the discourses, non-Buddhists seem to be familiar with this, yet we cannot identify the aggregates in any pre-Buddhist texts. Regardless of whether the set of categories was pre-Buddhist, the Buddha treated them in his own distinctive way, emphasizing that nothing in the aggregates was a permanent self or soul. In this collection we find a large number of striking and lively narratives, showing how the aggregates could be a solace at the time of death, a guide to the knotty theoretical debates on identity, or a framework for insight meditation. Many of the short abbreviated texts are built from the same templates employed in the \u201cLinked Discourses on the Six Sense Fields\u201d.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 22", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 263}, {"uid": "sn23", "root_name": "R\u0101dhasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses with R\u0101dha ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses with R\u0101dha\u201d contains 46 discourses with a monk named R\u0101dha on the topic of the five aggregates, and may be considered as an appendix to the previous sa\u1e41yutta. ", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 23", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 26}, {"uid": "sn24", "root_name": "Di\u1e6d\u1e6dhisa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on Views ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on Views\u201d contains 96 discourses on views, methodically analyzed through the lens of the aggregates. A wide variety of views is assessed, most of which are familiar from elsewhere in the canon, although the first one is unique.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 24", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 35}, {"uid": "sn25", "root_name": "Okkantasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on Arrival at the Truth ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on Arrival\u201d is the first of three similar sections, each of which takes a set of ten doctrinal items (shared also with SN 18 R\u0101hula) and presents it according to a set pattern. The current chapter focuses on the distinction between those who accept the teachings by either faith or intellectual understanding, and those who have realized them for themselves.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 25", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 10}, {"uid": "sn26", "root_name": "Upp\u0101dasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on Arising ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on Arising\u201d is the second of three similar sections, each of which takes a set of ten doctrinal items and presents it according to a set pattern. The current chapter focuses on the fact that anyone who has these things will suffer.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 26", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 10}, {"uid": "sn27", "root_name": "Kilesasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on Corruptions ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on Corruptions\u201d is the third of three similar sections, each of which takes a set of ten doctrinal items and presents it according to a set pattern. The current chapter focuses on the fact that desire for these things is a corruption of the mind.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 27", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 10}, {"uid": "sn28", "root_name": "S\u0101riputtasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses with S\u0101riputta ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses with S\u0101riputta\u201d describes S\u0101riputta\u2019s deep meditation practice, and his conversations with \u0100nanda, who noticed how radiant and glowing he was. An exception to this pattern is the final sutta, which depicts S\u0101riputta responding to the challenges of a female wanderer.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 28", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 10}, {"uid": "sn29", "root_name": "N\u0101gasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on Dragons ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on Dragons\u201d is the first of four similar sections dealing with the modes in which various semi-celestial beings may be reborn. [{"uid": "sn46.51", "root_name": "\u0100h\u0101rasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 46.51", "blurb": "The Buddha spells out in detail the factors that nourish the hindrances, and those that nourish the awakening factors.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn46.52", "root_name": "Pariy\u0101yasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 46.52", "blurb": "Some wanderers tell some Buddhist mendicants that they, too, teach the five hindrances and the seven awakening factors, so what is the difference? The Buddha explains the detailed connection between the Brahm\u0101 meditations and the awakening factors, which taken together lead to liberation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn46.55", "root_name": "Sa\u1e45g\u0101ravasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 46.55", "blurb": "The brahmin Sa\u1e45ga\u0304rava asks why sometimes verses stay in memory while other times they don\u2019t. The Buddha replies that the cause of ignorance is the hindrances, and the cause of knowledge is the awakening factors.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

[{"uid": "ja21", "root_name": "Kuru\u1e45gamigaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Antelope ", "acronym": "Ja 21", "blurb": "\u201cThe antelope knows well.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at the Bamboo-grove about Devadatta. For once when the Brethren were gathered together in the Hall of Truth, they sat talking reproachfully of Devadatta, saying, \u201cSirs, with a view to destroy the Buddha Devadatta hired bowmen, hurled down a rock, and let loose the elephant Dhana-palaka; in every way he goes about to slay the Lord of Wisdom.\u201d Entering and seating himself on the seat prepared for him, the Master asked, saying, \u201cSirs, what is the theme you are discussing here in conclave?\u201d \u201cSir,\u201d was the reply, \u201cwe were discussing the wickedness of Devadatta, saying that he was always going about to slay you.\u201d Said the Master, \u201cIt is not only in these present days, Brethren, that Devadatta goes about seeking to slay me; he went about with the like intent in bygone days also,\u2014but was unable to slay me.\u201d And so saying, he told this story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja22", "root_name": "Kukkuraj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Dog ", "acronym": "Ja 22", "blurb": "\u201cThe dogs that in the royal palace grow.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about acting for the good of kinsfolk, as will be related in the Twelfth Book in the Bhaddasala-jataka. It was to drive home that lesson that he told this story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja23", "root_name": "Bhoj\u0101j\u0101n\u012byaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Destrier ", "acronym": "Ja 23", "blurb": "\u201cThough prostrate now.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about a Brother who gave up persevering. For it was then that the Master addressed that Brother and said, \u201cBrethren, in bygone days the wise and good persevered even amid hostile surroundings, and, even when they were wounded, still did not give in.\u201d And, so saying, he told this story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja24", "root_name": "\u0100ja\u00f1\u00f1aj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Thoroughbred ", "acronym": "Ja 24", "blurb": "\u201cNo matter when or where.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about another Brother who gave up persevering. But, in this case, he addressed that Brother and said, \u201cBrethren, in bygone days the wise and good still persevered even when wounded.\u201d And, so saying, he told this story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja25", "root_name": "Titthaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Bathing-place ", "acronym": "Ja 25", "blurb": "\u201cChange thou the spot.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about an ex-goldsmith, who had become a Brother and was co-resident with the Captain of the Faith (Sariputta).", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja26", "root_name": "Mahi\u1e37\u0101mukhaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Damsel-face the Brigand ", "acronym": "Ja 26", "blurb": "\u201cThrough hearing first.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at the Bamboo-grove, about Devadatta, who, having secured the adherence of Prince Ajata-sattu, had attained both gain and honour. Prince Ajata-sattu had a Monastery built for Devadatta at Gaya-sisa, and every day brought to him five hundred kettles of perfumed three-year-old rice flavoured with all the choicest flavourings. All this gain and honour brought Devadatta a great following, with whom Devadatta lived on, without ever stirring out of his Monastery.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja27", "root_name": "Abhi\u1e47haj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Familiarity ", "acronym": "Ja 27", "blurb": "\u201cNo morsel can he eat.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a lay-disciple and an aged Elder. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja28", "root_name": "Nandivis\u0101laj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Bull Named Ample Joy ", "acronym": "Ja 28", "blurb": "\u201cSpeak only words of kindness.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about the bitter words spoken by the Six. For, in those days the six, when they disagreed with respectable Brethren, used to taunt, revile and jeer them, and load them with the ten kinds of abuse. This the Brethren reported to the Blessed One, who sent for the Six and asked whether this charge was true. On their admitting its truth, he rebuked them, saying, \u201cBrethren, hard words gall even animals: in bygone days an animal made a man who had used harsh language to him lose a thousand pieces.\u201d And, so saying, he told this story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja29", "root_name": "Ka\u1e47haj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Bull Named Black ", "acronym": "Ja 29", "blurb": "\u201cWith heavy loads.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about the Double Miracle, which, together with the Descent from Heaven, will be related in the Thirteenth Book, in the Sarabhamiga-jataka.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja30", "root_name": "Munikaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Pig Named Munika ", "acronym": "Ja 30", "blurb": "\u201cThen envy not poor Munika.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about being seduced by a plump young woman, as will be related in the Thirteenth Book in the Culla-Narada-Kassapa-jataka.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

translated_name: Past Life Stories of the Buddha
blurb: Texts that have been classified as Jātakas (本緣部), or stories of the Buddha’s past lives, similar to the Jātakas of the Pali Khuddhaka Nikāya. In the Taishō edition of the Chinese canon they are found in volumes three and four.

blurb: The Cūḷaniddesa or “Shorter Exposition” is really one half of a book together with the Mahāniddesa or “Great Exposition”. They offer commentaries on certain portions of the Sutta Nipāta, and lack counterparts in the northern canons. The Cūḷaniddesa comments on the “Way to the Beyond” and the “Rhinoceros Horn Sutta”.

[{"uid": "ja101", "root_name": "Parosataj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Over a Hundred ", "acronym": "Ja 101", "blurb": "This story is in all respects analogous to the Parosahassa J\u0101taka (No. 99), with the sole difference that \u2018think hard\u2019 is read here.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja102", "root_name": "Pa\u1e47\u1e47ikaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Greengrocer ", "acronym": "Ja 102", "blurb": "\u201cHe that should prove.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a lay-brother who was a greengrocer in Savatthi and made a living by the sale of various roots and vegetables, and pumpkins and the like. Now he had a pretty daughter who was as good and virtuous as she was pretty, but was always laughing. And when she was asked in marriage by a family of his own station in life, he thought \u201cShe ought to be married, but she\u2019s always laughing; and a bad girl married into a strange family is her parents\u2019 shame. I must find out for certain whether she is a good girl or not.\u201d", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja103", "root_name": "Verij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Enemies ", "acronym": "Ja 103", "blurb": "\u201cIf wise, thou \u2018lt loiter not.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master at Jetavana about Anatha-pindika. For we hear that Anatha-pindika was returning from the village of which he was headman, when he saw robbers on the road. \u201cIt won\u2019t do to loiter by the way,\u201d thought he; \u201cI must hurry on to Savatthi.\u201d So he urged his oxen to speed and got safely into Savatthi. Next day he went to the monastery and told the Master what had befallen him. \u201cSir,\u201d said the Master, \u201cin other times too the wise and good espied robbers on the road and hastened without delay to their homes.\u201d Then at the merchant\u2019s request he told this story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja104", "root_name": "Mittavindakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "On Mittavindaka ", "acronym": "Ja 104", "blurb": "\u201cFrom four to eight.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, concerning an unruly Brother. The incidents are the same as those in the previous story of Mittavindaka, but belong to the days of the Buddha Kassapa.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja105", "root_name": "Dubbalaka\u1e6d\u1e6dhaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Weak Branch ", "acronym": "Ja 105", "blurb": "\u201cFear\u2019st thou the wind.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a Brother who lived in a perpetual state of nervous alarm. We learn that he came of a good family in Savatthi, and was led to give up the world by hearing the Truth preached, and that he was always in fear of his life both by night and by day. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja106", "root_name": "Uda\u00f1can\u012bj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Water Hauler ", "acronym": "Ja 106", "blurb": "\u201cA happy life was mine.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a temptation by a fat girl. The incident will be related in the Culla-Narada-Kassapa Jataka in the Thirteenth Book.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja107", "root_name": "S\u0101littakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Benefits of Good Aim ", "acronym": "Ja 107", "blurb": "\u201cPrize skill.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a Brother who threw and hit a swan. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja108", "root_name": "B\u0101hiyaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Foreigner ", "acronym": "Ja 108", "blurb": "\u201cLearn thou betimes.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master, while he was dwelling in the Gabled Chamber at the Great Grove near Vesali, about a Licchavi, a pious prince who had embraced the Truth. He had invited the Brotherhood with the Buddha at their head to his house, and there had shewn great bounty towards them. Now his wife was a very fat woman, almost bloated in appearance, and she was badly dressed.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja109", "root_name": "Ku\u1e47\u1e0dap\u016bvaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Cake ", "acronym": "Ja 109", "blurb": "\u201cAs fares his worshipper.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master when at Savatthi, about a very poor man.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja110", "root_name": "Sabbasa\u1e41h\u0101rakapa\u00f1haj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "All-embracing ", "acronym": "Ja 110", "blurb": "\u201cThere is no All-embracing.\u201d\u2014This All-embracing Question will be set out at length in the Ummagga-jataka. This is the end of the All-embracing Question.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "ja341", "root_name": "Ka\u1e47\u1e0dar\u012bj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "On Ka\u1e47\u1e0dar\u012b ", "acronym": "Ja 341", "blurb": "The story of this Birth will be set forth in full in the Kunala Birth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja342", "root_name": "V\u0101naraj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Langur ", "acronym": "Ja 342", "blurb": "\u201cHave I from water\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master, when dwelling in the Bamboo Grove, concerning the going about of Devadatta to kill the Buddha. The incident that led to the story has been already given in detail. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja343", "root_name": "Kuntin\u012bj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Heron ", "acronym": "Ja 343", "blurb": "\u201cLong I held\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master at Jetavana, concerning a heron that lived in the house of the king of Kosala.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja344", "root_name": "Ambaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Mangoes ", "acronym": "Ja 344", "blurb": "\u201cShe that did thy mangoes eat\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, concerning an elder who kept watch over mango fruit.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja345", "root_name": "Gajakumbhaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Slow Tortoise ", "acronym": "Ja 345", "blurb": "\u201cShould a flame sweep\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master at Jetavana, concerning a slothful Brother. He was, it was said, of gentle birth and lived at Savatthi. And after giving a hearty assent to the doctrine and taking orders, he became slothful.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja346", "root_name": "Kesavaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Ascetic Named Hairy ", "acronym": "Ja 346", "blurb": "\u201cThou that of late\u201d\u2014This story the Master while at Jetavana told concerning the Feast of Friendship.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja347", "root_name": "Ayak\u016b\u1e6daj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Iron Hammer ", "acronym": "Ja 347", "blurb": "\u201cWhy in mid air\u201d\u2014This story the Master, while dwelling at Jetavana, told concerning the duty of doing good to men. The incident that led to the story will be set forth in the Mahakanha Birth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja348", "root_name": "Ara\u00f1\u00f1aj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "From the Wilderness ", "acronym": "Ja 348", "blurb": "\u201cThis doubt, my father\u201d\u2014This story the Master told when dwelling at Jetavana, concerning the seduction of a youth by a certain coarse girl. The incident that led up to the story will be set forth in the Cullanaradakassapa Birth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja349", "root_name": "Sandhibhedaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Slander ", "acronym": "Ja 349", "blurb": "\u201cNought in common\u201d\u2014This story the Master, dwelling at Jetavana, told concerning the moral precept on slander.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja350", "root_name": "Devat\u0101pa\u00f1haj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Deity\u2019s Question ", "acronym": "Ja 350", "blurb": "This Question will be found in the Ummagga Jataka.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "sn17.1", "root_name": "D\u0101ru\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 17.1", "blurb": "Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, obstructing spiritual progress.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn17.2", "root_name": "Ba\u1e37isasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 17.2", "blurb": "Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, which catch you like fish on a hook.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn17.3", "root_name": "Kummasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 17.3", "blurb": "Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, which hit you like a harpoon hits a careless turtle.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn17.4", "root_name": "D\u012bghalomikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 17.4", "blurb": "Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, which snare you like a long-haired goat in a briar patch.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn17.5", "root_name": "M\u012b\u1e37hakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 17.5", "blurb": "A mendicant who is proud on account of their material possessions, honor, and praise is like a dung beetle proud of their ball of dung.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn17.6", "root_name": "Asanisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 17.6", "blurb": "Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, like a lightning strike.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn17.7", "root_name": "Diddhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 17.7", "blurb": "Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, like a poison dart.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn17.8", "root_name": "Si\u1e45g\u0101lasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 17.8", "blurb": "A mendicant who is proud on account of their material possessions, honor, and praise is never at peace, like a mangy jackal.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn17.9", "root_name": "Verambhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 17.9", "blurb": "A mendicant who is proud on account of their material possessions, honor, and praise is never at peace, like a bird in a gale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn17.10", "root_name": "Sag\u0101thakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 17.10", "blurb": "Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, and attachment to them leads to a bad rebirth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": [{"uid": "an5.71", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamacetovimuttiphalasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 5.71", "blurb": "Five meditations lead to freedom. The Buddha supplies five similes, which subtly illustrate five aspects of awakening.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an5.72", "root_name": "Dutiyacetovimuttiphalasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 5.72", "blurb": "Five meditations lead to freedom. The Buddha supplies five similes, which subtly illustrate five aspects of awakening.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an5.73", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamadhammavih\u0101r\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 5.73", "blurb": "The difference between someone who merely studies the letter of the Dharma, and someone who truly lives by it.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an5.74", "root_name": "Dutiyadhammavih\u0101r\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 5.74", "blurb": "The difference between someone who merely studies the letter of the Dharma, and someone who truly lives by it.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an5.75", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamayodh\u0101j\u012bvasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 5.75", "blurb": "Some warriors, like some monks, falter before the threat of battle, while others emerge victorious. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an5.76", "root_name": "Dutiyayodh\u0101j\u012bvasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 5.76", "blurb": "Some warriors, like some monks, are killed or injured in battle, while others emerge victorious. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an5.77", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamaan\u0101gatabhayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 5.77", "blurb": "The dangers of living in a wilderness among wild beasts and so on.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an5.78", "root_name": "Dutiyaan\u0101gatabhayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 5.78", "blurb": "The uncertainties of life may prevent your practice.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an5.79", "root_name": "Tatiyaan\u0101gatabhayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 5.79", "blurb": "When the teachers and leaders of the Sa\u1e45gha are not well practiced, their weakness will be passed down the generations.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an5.80", "root_name": "Catutthaan\u0101gatabhayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 5.80", "blurb": "The Sa\u1e45gha may forsake the simple life and indulge in luxuries.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

translated_name: The Chapter on a Great Sacrifice
children: [{"uid": "an7.44", "root_name": "Sattavi\u00f1\u00f1\u0101\u1e47a\u1e6d\u1e6dhitisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.44", "blurb": "Seven planes of consciousness in which beings may be reborn.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.45", "root_name": "Sam\u0101dhiparikkh\u0101rasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.45", "blurb": "The path factors are the prerequisite for right immersion.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.46", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamaaggisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.46", "blurb": "Seven fires, some physical, some psychological.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.47", "root_name": "Dutiyaaggisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.47", "blurb": "The brahmin Uggatasar\u012bra has arranged a great sacrifice. On \u0100nanda\u2019s advice, he asks the Buddha how to make a sacrifice beneficial.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.48", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamasa\u00f1\u00f1\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.48", "blurb": "Meditating on seven perceptions leads to the deathless, in brief.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.49", "root_name": "Dutiyasa\u00f1\u00f1\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.49", "blurb": "Meditating on seven perceptions leads to the deathless, in detail.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an7.50", "root_name": "Methunasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.50", "blurb": "The brahmin J\u0101\u1e47usso\u1e47\u012b asks the Buddha about behaviors that are a blemish to the celibate life.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.51", "root_name": "Sa\u1e41yogasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.51", "blurb": "By focusing on their own gendered attributes, a man or woman becomes attached to them and develops lust for the opposite sex.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an7.52", "root_name": "D\u0101namahapphalasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.52", "blurb": "The lay followers of Camp\u0101 seek a teaching from the Buddha. Together with S\u0101riputta, they ask the Buddha about what makes a gift fruitful.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an7.53", "root_name": "Nandam\u0101t\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.53", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta and Moggall\u0101na are on tour in the southern hills. A deity informs the laywoman Ve\u1e37uka\u1e47\u1e6dak\u012b that they are approaching. When S\u0101riputta expresses his amazement that she speaks with the gods, she goes on to list many other of her own amazing qualities.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "sn51.55-66", "root_name": "Balakara\u1e47\u012byavagga", "translated_name": "Hard Work ", "acronym": "SN 51.55\u201366", "blurb": null, "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

translated_name: The Chapter with the Poet Vaṅgīsa
children: [{"uid": "sn8.1", "root_name": "Nikkhantasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 8.1", "blurb": "Enticed by the sight of beautiful women, the newly ordained monk Va\u1e45g\u012bsa dispels desire and celebrates his commitment to the spiritual path in verse.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn8.2", "root_name": "Arat\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 8.2", "blurb": "Va\u1e45g\u012bsa is troubled again by lust, but manages to dispel it through his own efforts. His verse speak of the way of the renunciate, letting go of desire and wrong views, and dedicated to ethical conduct and seclusion.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn8.3", "root_name": "Pesalasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 8.3", "blurb": "As a renowned poet, Va\u1e45g\u012bsa looked down on less skilled mendicants. Ashamed of his conceit, he exhorted himself in verse to be humble and at peace.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn8.4", "root_name": "\u0100nandasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 8.4", "blurb": "Troubled once more by lust, Va\u1e45g\u012bsa turned to \u0100nanda for support. \u0100nanda tells him to shift his perception so that beautiful things no longer seem so.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn8.5", "root_name": "Subh\u0101sitasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 8.5", "blurb": "The Buddha gives a simple teaching on four qualities of good speech. Va\u1e45g\u012bsa is inspired to utter a more elaborate set of verses on the topic, praising especially the speech of the Buddha that leads to the Deathless. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn8.6", "root_name": "S\u0101riputtasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 8.6", "blurb": "Seeing S\u0101riputta speak on the Dhamma, and the rapt attention of the Sa\u1e45gha, Va\u1e45g\u012bsa comes out with verses in his praise.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn8.7", "root_name": "Pav\u0101ra\u1e47\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 8.7", "blurb": "On the Pav\u0101ra\u1e47\u0101 day at the end of the rains retreat, the Buddha invites the Sa\u1e45gha to admonish him. But not only is the Buddha faultless, so are all the 500 monks present. [{"uid": "sn24.1", "root_name": "V\u0101tasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 24.1", "blurb": "The Buddha mentions a strange view to the effect that all changing phenomena of the world are really still and motionless. [{"uid": "sn11.11", "root_name": "Vatapadasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.11", "blurb": "Sakka achieved his status because of seven vows he kept in the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn11.12", "root_name": "Sakkan\u0101masutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.12", "blurb": "Sakka\u2019s many names arose due to the diverse good deeds he did in the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn11.13", "root_name": "Mah\u0101lisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.13", "blurb": "Maha\u0304li the Licchavi is skeptical as to whether the Buddha has really seen Sakka.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn11.14", "root_name": "Daliddasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.14", "blurb": "The gods complain when a poor man is reborn in heaven. But Sakka points out that even though poor, he did many good deeds.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn11.15", "root_name": "R\u0101ma\u1e47eyyakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.15", "blurb": "When Sakka asks what place is truly delightful, the Buddha replies that it is wherever the perfected ones dwell.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn11.16", "root_name": "Yajam\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.16", "blurb": "When Sakka asks where a gift is most fruitful, the Buddha replies that it is the Sa\u1e45gha.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn11.17", "root_name": "Buddhavandan\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.17", "blurb": "Sakka and Brahm\u0101 Sahampati come to the Buddha\u2019s hut and speak in his praise.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn11.18", "root_name": "Gaha\u1e6d\u1e6dhavandan\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.18", "blurb": "When Sakka sets out on a pleasure jaunt, he begins by lifting his joined palms to the four quarters . His charioteer Ma\u0304tali points out that Sakka is venerated by gods and men, and asks who he is venerating. Sakka replies that he venerates both well-practiced mendicants as well as virtuous lay folk.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn11.19", "root_name": "Satth\u0101ravandan\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.19", "blurb": "When Sakka sets out on a pleasure jaunt, he begins by lifting his joined palms to the Buddha. His charioteer Ma\u0304tali points out that Sakka is venerated by gods and men, and asks who he is venerating. Sakka replies that he venerates the Buddha, the perfected mendicants as well as trainees on the path.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn11.20", "root_name": "Sa\u1e41ghavandan\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.20", "blurb": "When Sakka sets out on a pleasure jaunt, he begins by lifting his joined palms to the Sa\u1e45gha of mendicants. His charioteer Ma\u0304tal asks why Sakka venerates smelly mendicants. Sakka replies that he venerates them for their renunciation and peacefulness.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

[{"uid": "sn11.21", "root_name": "Chetv\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.21", "blurb": "Anger is the only thing whose slaying the Buddha commends.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn11.22", "root_name": "Dubba\u1e47\u1e47iyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.22", "blurb": "When an ugly spirit takes Sakka\u2019s throne, the gods were outraged. But the more they complained, the prettier he became. Sakka realized this was the so-called \u201canger eating spirit\u201d, and treated him with kindness and respect. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn11.23", "root_name": "Sambarim\u0101y\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.23", "blurb": "When Vepacitti fell ill, Sakka visited his old adversary, who begged to be cured. But Sakka demanded to be taught a powerful magic spell first.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn11.24", "root_name": "Accayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.24", "blurb": "When two mendicants have a falling out, the Buddha recalls the wise words of Sakka on not letting anger ruin friendship.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn11.25", "root_name": "Akkodhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.25", "blurb": "The Buddha recalls the words of Sakka warning of how anger crushes people like an avalanche", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: Broadening the focus from the individual practitioner, this chapter deals with the “all”, and shows how the Dhamma is inclusive of all beings, from kings to little fish.
children: [{"uid": "ud5.1", "root_name": "Piyatarasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "Ud 5.1", "blurb": "King Pasenadi asks his queen, \u201cIs there anyone dearer to you than yourself?\u201d", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "ud5.2", "root_name": "App\u0101yukasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "Ud 5.2", "blurb": "Ven. \u0100nanda comments on how the Buddha\u2019s mother died shortly after his birth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "ud5.3", "root_name": "Suppabuddhaku\u1e6d\u1e6dhisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "Ud 5.3", "blurb": "A leper becomes a stream-enterer, dies, and is reborn as a deva.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "ud5.4", "root_name": "Kum\u0101rakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "Ud 5.4", "blurb": "A lesson to young boys: If you don\u2019t want to suffer from pain, don\u2019t inflict pain on other beings.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "ud5.5", "root_name": "Uposathasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "Ud 5.5", "blurb": "Ven. [{"uid": "sn54.1", "root_name": "Ekadhammasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 54.1", "blurb": "Breath meditation is very beneficial. It is developed by going into seclusion, establishing mindfulness on the breath, and proceeding through sixteen stages. When developed it leads to perfection or one of the lesser attainments.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn54.6", "root_name": "Ari\u1e6d\u1e6dhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 54.6", "blurb": "When the Buddha asks Venerable Ari\u1e6d\u1e6dha about breath meditation, his answer, while not incorrect, does not do full justice to the practice.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn54.7", "root_name": "Mah\u0101kappinasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 54.7", "blurb": "The Buddha sees Venerable Mah\u0101kappina meditating nearby and points out that his steadiness and tranquility are due to practicing breath meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn54.8", "root_name": "Pad\u012bpopamasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 54.8", "blurb": "Before his awakening the Buddha generally practiced breath meditation, which kept him alert and peaceful and led to the ending of defilements. One who wishes for any of the higher fruits of the renunciate life should practice the same way.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn54.9", "root_name": "Ves\u0101l\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 54.9", "blurb": "The Buddha taught the meditation on the ugliness of the body, then left to go on retreat. However, many monks, misconstruing the teachings, ending up killing themselves. The Buddha taught breath meditation as a peaceful and pleasant abiding.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn54.10", "root_name": "Kimilasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 54.10", "blurb": "When the Buddha asks Venerable Kimbila about breath meditation, he is unable to answer. At \u0100nanda\u2019s urging, the Buddha explains in detail.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

children: [{"uid": "sn55.51", "root_name": "Sag\u0101thakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.51", "blurb": "A noble disciple with the four factors of stream-entry is a stream-enterer. With verses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn55.52", "root_name": "Vassa\u1e41vutthasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.52", "blurb": "When a monk comes from S\u0101vatth\u012b to Kapilavatthu, the Sakyans visit him and ask as to the health of the Buddha and the Sa\u1e45gha. Then they ask what the monk has learned. He replies that the number of perfected ones is few, and those on lower levels of attainment are greater in number.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn55.53", "root_name": "Dhammadinnasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.53", "blurb": "The lay follower Dhammadinna leads a group of 500 to visit the Buddha. He encourages them to study deep discourses, but they protest that they don\u2019t have enough time. So the Buddha encourages them in the four factors of stream-entry.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn55.54", "root_name": "Gil\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.54", "blurb": "Mah\u0101n\u0101ma asks the Buddha how a lay follower should teach a wise lay follower who is ill. blurb: The “Linked Discourses with Chiefs” contains 13 discourses featuring various headmen or chiefs. They sometimes ask questions relating to their professions, from entertainers to warriors, while several discourses touch on familiar Dhamma themes, such as overcoming anger, the validity of brahmanical rites, or whether monastics should use money. Some of the chiefs are quite adversarial, aiming to trip up the Buddha in debate, or accusing him of being a magician. In the end, though, the Buddha’s compassionate and measured responses win them over.

[{"uid": "ja291", "root_name": "Sur\u0101gha\u1e6daj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Lucky Cup ", "acronym": "Ja 291", "blurb": "\u201cA ne\u2019er-do-well did once\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Jetavana, about a nephew of Anathapindika.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja292", "root_name": "Supattaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Fairwing the Crow King ", "acronym": "Ja 292", "blurb": "\u201cHere, in Benares city\u201d\u2014This story the Master told in Jetavana, about a meal of rice mixed with new ghee, with red fish to flavour it, which was given by Elder Sariputta to Bimbadevi. The circumstances are like those given above in the Abbhantara Birth-tale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja293", "root_name": "K\u0101yanibbindaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Dispassion for the Body ", "acronym": "Ja 293", "blurb": "\u201cDown smitten with a direful illness\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Jetavana about a certain man tormented by jaundice, given up by the doctors as a hopeless case.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja294", "root_name": "Jambukh\u0101dakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Crow Eating Rose-Apple ", "acronym": "Ja 294", "blurb": "\u201cWho is it sits\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at the Bamboo-grove, about Devadatta and Kokalika.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja295", "root_name": "Antaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Worst ", "acronym": "Ja 295", "blurb": "\u201cLike to a bull\u201d\u2014 This is another story told by the Master in the same place and about the same people. The circumstances are the sane as before.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja296", "root_name": "Samuddaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Drinking Sea Water ", "acronym": "Ja 296", "blurb": "\u201cOver the salt sea wave\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Jetavana, about Elder Upananda. This man was a great eater and drinker; there was no satisfying him even with cartloads of provisions. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja297", "root_name": "K\u0101mavil\u0101paj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "A Lament of Love ", "acronym": "Ja 297", "blurb": "\u201cO bird, that fliest\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Jetavana, about a man who pined for his former wife. The circumstances which called it forth are explained in the Puppharatta Birth-tale, and the tale of the past in the Indriya Birth-tale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja298", "root_name": "Udumbaraj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Ripe are the Figs ", "acronym": "Ja 298", "blurb": "\u201cRipe are the figs\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Jetavana, about a certain Brother, who had made a hermitage to live in at a certain village on the frontier.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja299", "root_name": "Kom\u0101raputtaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Ascetic Kom\u0101raputta ", "acronym": "Ja 299", "blurb": "\u201cAforetime you were used\u201d\u2014This story the Master told in Pubbarama, about some Brethren who were rude and rough in their manners.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja300", "root_name": "Vakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Wolf ", "acronym": "Ja 300", "blurb": "\u201cThe wolf who takes\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Jetavana, about old friendship. The circumstances were the same in detail as in the Vinaya; this is an abstract of them. The reverend Upasena, a two-years\u2019 man, visited the Master along with a first year\u2019s man who lived in the same monastery; the Master rebuked him, and he retired. Having acquired spiritual insight, and attained to sainthood, having got contentment and kindred virtues, having undertaken the Thirteen Practices of a Recluse, and taught them to his fellows, while the Blessed One was secluded for three months, he with his brethren, having accepted the blame first given for wrong speech and nonconformity, received in the second instance approval, in the words, \u201cHenceforth, let any brothers visit me when they will, provided they follow the Thirteen Practices of a Recluse.\u201d Thus encouraged, he returned and told it to the Brethren. After that, the brothers followed these practices before coming to visit the Master; then, when ho had come out from his seclusion, they would throw away their old rags and put on clean garments. As the Master with all the body of the Brethren went round to inspect the rooms, he noticed these rags lying about, and asked what they were. When they told him, he said, \u201cBrethren, the practice undertaken by these brothers is short-lived, like the wolf\u2019s holy day service\u201d; and he told them an old-world tale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: The Indian original text compiled by Dharmatrāta 法救 consisted of 33 chapters and about 1000 verses, and it was translated by Saṃghabhadra 僧伽跋澄 and Zhu Fonian 竺佛念 during 398–399. The present T 212 has 34 chapters, and its chapters correspond to the present Udānavarga, which has 33 chapters and 1050 verses, except that it has two separated chapters, i.e. the chapter of non-carelessness 無放逸品 and the chapter of carelessness 放逸品, for the chapter 'Apramādavarga' of the Udānavarga. Like T 211, this text also provides the verses along with the background stories in prose. When the verses are same with those of T 210, the translators of T 211 followed the translation of T 210 rather than did a new translation.

[{"uid": "sn35.94", "root_name": "Adantaaguttasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.94", "blurb": "The six fields of contact lead to suffering if left unguarded, but if guarded lead to happiness. A lengthy set of verses illustrate this.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.95", "root_name": "M\u0101lukyaputtasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.95", "blurb": "Venerable M\u0101lu\u1e45kyaputta asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha wonders how to teach an old monk like him, then questions him on his desire for sense experience that has been or might be, and encourages him to simply let sense experience be. M\u0101lu\u1e45kyaputta says he understands, and expands the Buddha\u2019s teaching in a series of verses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.96", "root_name": "Parih\u0101nadhammasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.96", "blurb": "When a mendicant tolerates evil thoughts that arise from the senses, they are liable to decline. If they don\u2019t tolerate them, they\u2019re not liable to decline. When such thoughts not longer arise, they have mastered the senses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.97", "root_name": "Pam\u0101davih\u0101r\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.97", "blurb": "When a mendicant lives without restraint regarding the senses, they are negligent. If they have restraint, they are diligent.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.98", "root_name": "Sa\u1e41varasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.98", "blurb": "Non-restraint is delighting in the senses, restraint is not delighting in them.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.99", "root_name": "Sam\u0101dhisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.99", "blurb": "Develop meditative immersion so as to truly understand the process of sense experience.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.100", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6disall\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.100", "blurb": "Develop seclusion so as to truly understand the process of sense experience.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.101", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamanatumh\u0101kasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.101", "blurb": "Let go of what is not yours: the process of sense experience. You wouldn\u2019t be upset if someone took the grass and sticks from the monastery grounds, so why worry over the aggregates?", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.102", "root_name": "Dutiyanatumh\u0101kasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.102", "blurb": "Let go of what is not yours: the process of sense experience.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.103", "root_name": "Udakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.103", "blurb": "The Buddha\u2019s former teacher Uddaka R\u0101maputta claimed to be a knowledge master, a universal victor, who had excised the tumor. But a true knowledge master understands the senses, a victor is freed from them, and excising the tumor is being free from attachment to the body.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

[{"uid": "sn1.21", "root_name": "Sattisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 1.21", "blurb": "A mendicant should live as if their head was on fire.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn1.22", "root_name": "Phusatisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 1.22", "blurb": "The evil you do hurts yourself.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn1.23", "root_name": "Ja\u1e6d\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 1.23", "blurb": "This generation is all tangled up like a nest of matted hair. But who can unravel the tangle?", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn1.24", "root_name": "Manoniv\u0101ra\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 1.24", "blurb": "One should rein in the mind, but only from that which is evil.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn1.25", "root_name": "Arahantasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 1.25", "blurb": "If a perfected one has gone beyond all sense of self, would they still refer to themselves as \u201cI\u201d? ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn1.26", "root_name": "Pajjotasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 1.26", "blurb": "How many lights are there that light up the world?", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn1.27", "root_name": "Sarasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 1.27", "blurb": "The stream of rebirth stops flowing when name and form ceases.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn1.28", "root_name": "Mahaddhanasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 1.28", "blurb": "Even the rich are full of greed for more\u2014is there anyone free of greed?", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn1.29", "root_name": "Catucakkasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 1.29", "blurb": "A riddle on the topic of escape.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn1.30", "root_name": "E\u1e47ija\u1e45ghasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 1.30", "blurb": "The Buddha is asked how to find release from suffering.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]
