[{"uid": "ja61", "root_name": "As\u0101tamantaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Unpleasant Spell ", "acronym": "Ja 61", "blurb": "\u201cIn lust unbridled.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a passion-tost Brother. The Introductory Story will be related in the Ummadanti-jataka. But to this Brother the Master said, \u201cWomen, Brother, are lustful, profligate, vile, and degraded. Why be passion-tost for a vile woman?\u201d And so saying, he told this story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja62", "root_name": "A\u1e47\u1e0dabh\u016btaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Blindfolded Husband ", "acronym": "Ja 62", "blurb": "\u201cBlindfold, a-luting.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about another passion-tost person.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja63", "root_name": "Takkapa\u1e47\u1e0ditaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Buttermilk Sage ", "acronym": "Ja 63", "blurb": "\u201cWrathful are women.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about another passion-tost Brother. When on being questioned the Brother confessed that he was passion-tost, the Master said, \u201cWomen are ingrates and treacherous; why are you passion-tost because of them?\u201d And he told this story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja64", "root_name": "Dur\u0101j\u0101naj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Inscrutability of Women ", "acronym": "Ja 64", "blurb": "\u201cThink\u2019st thou.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a lay-brother. Tradition says that there dwelt at Savatthi a lay-brother, who was stablished in the Three Gems and the Five Commandments, a devout lover of the Buddha, the Doctrine and the Brotherhood. But his wife was a sinful and wicked woman. On days when she did wrong, she was as meek as a slave-girl bought for a hundred pieces; whilst on days when she did not do wrong, she played my lady, passionate and tyrannical. The husband could not make her out. She worried him so much that he did not go to wait on the Buddha.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja65", "root_name": "Anabhiratij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "On Losing Interest ", "acronym": "Ja 65", "blurb": "\u201cLike highways.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about just such another lay-brother as the last. This man, when on enquiry he assured himself of his wife\u2019s misconduct, came to words with her, with the result that he was so upset that for seven or eight days he failed in his attendance. One day he came to the monastery, made his bow to the Blessed One and took his seat. Being asked why he had been absent for seven or eight days, he replied, \u201cSir, my wife has misconducted herself, and I have been so upset about her that I did not come.\u201d", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja66", "root_name": "Mudulakkha\u1e47aj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Queen Gentle-heart ", "acronym": "Ja 66", "blurb": "\u201cTill Gentle-heart was mine.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about concupiscence. Tradition says that a young gentleman of Savatthi, [30;3] on hearing the Truth preached by the Master, gave his heart to the Doctrine of the Three Gems. Renouncing the world for the Brother\u2019s life, he rose to walk in the Paths, to practise meditation, and never to slacken in his pondering over the theme he had chosen for thought. One day, whilst he was on his round for alms through Savatthi, he espied a woman in brave attire, and, for pleasure\u2019s sake, broke through the higher morality and gazed upon her! Passion was stirred within him, he became even as a fig-tree felled by the axe. From that day forth, under the sway of passion, the palate of his mind, as of his body, lost all its gust; like a brute beast, he took no joy in the Doctrine, and suffered his nails and hair to grow long and his robes to grow foul.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja67", "root_name": "Uccha\u1e45gaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Sons Fall in a Mother\u2019s Lap ", "acronym": "Ja 67", "blurb": "\u201cA son\u2019s an easy find.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a certain country-woman.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja68", "root_name": "S\u0101ketaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "At S\u0101keta ", "acronym": "Ja 68", "blurb": "\u201cThe man thy mind rests on.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master, while at Anjanavana, about a certain brahmin. Tradition says that when the Blessed One with his disciples was entering the city of Saketa, an old brahmin of that place, who was going out, met him in the gateway. Falling at the Buddha\u2019s feet, and clasping him by the ankles, the old man cried, \u201cSon, is it not the duty of children to cherish the old age of their parents? Why have you not let us see you all this long time? At last I have seen you; come, let your mother see you too.\u201d So saying, he took the Master with him to his house; and there the Master sat upon the seat prepared for him, with his disciples around him. Then came the brahmin\u2019s wife, and she too fell at the feet of the Blessed One, crying, \u201cMy son, where have you been all this time? Is it not the duty of children to comfort their parents in their old age?\u201d Hereon, she called to her sons and daughters that their brother was come, and made them salute the Buddha. And in their joy the aged pair shewed great hospitality to their guests. After his meal, the Master recited to the old people the Sutta concerning old-age; and, when he had ended, both husband and wife won fruition of the Second Path. Then rising up from his seat, the Master went back to Anjanavana.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja69", "root_name": "Visavantaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Poison Once Expelled ", "acronym": "Ja 69", "blurb": "\u201cMay shame.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about Sariputta, the Captain of the Faith. Tradition says that in the days when the Elder used to eat meal-cakes, folks came to the monastery with a quantity of such cakes for the Brotherhood. After the Brethren had all eaten their fill, much remained over; and the givers said, \u201cSirs, take some for those too who are away in the village.\u201d", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja70", "root_name": "Kudd\u0101laj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Spade Sage ", "acronym": "Ja 70", "blurb": "\u201cThe conquest.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about the Elder named Cittahattha-Sariputta. He is said to have been a youth of a good family in Savatthi; and one day, on his way home from ploughing, he turned in to the monastery. Here he received from the bowl of a certain Elder some dainty fare, rich and sweet, which made him think to himself,\u2014\u201cDay and night I am toiling away with my hands at divers tasks, yet never do I taste food so sweet. I must turn Brother myself!\u201d So he joined the Brotherhood, but after six weeks\u2019 zealous application to high thinking, fell under the dominion of Lusts and off he went. His belly again proving too much for him, back he came to join the Brotherhood once more, and studied the Abhidhamma. In this way, six times he left and came back again; but when for the seventh time he became a Brother, he mastered the whole seven books of the Abhidhamma, and by much chanting of the Doctrine of the Brothers won Discernment and attained to Arahatship. Now his friends among the Brethren scoffed at him, saying\u2014\u201cCan it be, sir, that Lusts have ceased to spring up within your heart?\u201d", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

translated_name: The Group of Linked Discourses Beginning With Causation
blurb: The “Book of Causation” is the second of the five books of the Linked Discourses. It is named after the first and longest saṁyutta, which deals with causation through the core Buddhist teaching of Dependent Origination. The remaining nine saṁyuttas deal with miscellaneous secondary themes, some organized by subject, others by person.
children: [{"uid": "sn12", "root_name": "Nid\u0101nasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on Causation ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on Causation\u201d is a major collection containing 93 discourses on the core Buddhist teaching of dependent origination. Dependent origination presents a series of conditional links laying bare how suffering originates and how it ends. As such, it is an extended treatment of the second and third noble truths. It integrates psychological and existential aspects of suffering, showing how when bound by attachment we make choices that bind us to transmigrating into future lives. One of the core purposes is to explain how rebirth takes place without having to invoke metaphysical concepts such as a \u201csoul\u201d. The collection begins by defining each of the terms in the standard 12-linked chain, definitions which are assumed to apply throughout. Remaining discourses iterate on this theme, introducing new perspectives and formulations. ", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 12", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 146}, {"uid": "sn13", "root_name": "Abhisamayasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on Comprehension ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on the Breakthrough\u201d contains 11 discourses on the value of realizing the Dhamma. Each discourse features a memorable simile illustrating the truly momentous implications of seeing the four noble truths.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 13", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 11}, {"uid": "sn14", "root_name": "Dh\u0101tusa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on the Elements ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on the Elements\u201d contains 39 discourses on various factors classified as \u201celements\u201d (dh\u0101tu). In Buddhism, the term \u201celement\u201d is applied to a range of phenomena, most commonly the main material properties of earth, water, fire and air. Here, however, these four elements play only a small role, and much of the text is devoted to analysis of the perceptual process, and to various character traits. The relation or dependence of elements on each other is a major theme, and this chapter can be seen as an appendix to the chapter on causality.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 14", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 39}, {"uid": "sn15", "root_name": "Anamataggasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on the Unknowable Beginning ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on the Unknowable Beginning\u201d contains 20 discourses that speak of how the ultimate origin of the process of transmigration (sa\u1e41s\u0101ra) is unknowable. This theme is a direct counter to the hubris of the creation myths found in most religions, which confidently recount events which are in fact permanently hidden from view. The Buddha emphasized that transmigration has been ongoing for a fathomless period of time, illustrating it with a series of powerful similes.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 15", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 21}, {"uid": "sn16", "root_name": "Kassapasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses with Kassapa ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses with Kassapa\u201d contains 13 discourses featuring one of the most famous of the Buddha\u2019s disciples, the monk Kassapa. Kassapa was an ascetic and diligent practitioner, whose sometimes critical voice was tempered by a love of nature and a tender concern for the lay community. These discourses show his magnificent spiritual attainments, and his overriding concern for the health and longevity of the Buddhist community.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 16", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 26}, {"uid": "sn17", "root_name": "L\u0101bhasakk\u0101rasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on Gains and Honor ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on Gains and Honor\u201d contains 43 discourses warning the mendicants of the terrible dangers inherent in material possessions and love of popularity and honors.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 17", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 31}, {"uid": "sn18", "root_name": "R\u0101hulasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses with R\u0101hula ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses with R\u0101hula\u201d contains 22 discourses with the Buddha interrogating his son R\u0101hula on fundamental doctrines such as the aggregates or sense fields.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 18", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 14}, {"uid": "sn19", "root_name": "Lakkha\u1e47asa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses with Lakkha\u1e47a ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses with Lakkha\u1e47a\u201d contains 21 discourses with the Buddha featuring the monk Lakkha\u1e47a (\u201cMark\u201d). Through his psychic powers he sees beings in various states of torment and distress, and describes them to the Buddha.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 19", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 21}, {"uid": "sn20", "root_name": "Opammasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses with Similes ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses with Similes\u201d contains 12 discourses with parables or similes illustrating diverse points of the teaching. This chapter highlights the Buddha\u2019s skill in choosing vivid and suitable similes for any occasion.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 20", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 13}, {"uid": "sn21", "root_name": "Bhikkhusa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses with Monks ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses with Monks\u201d contains 12 discourses featuring different monks. Unlike the chapter on nuns, this does not use a consistent template, but depicts a diverse range of scenarios. Each case shows a personal challenge or spiritual triumph, shedding a light on the life of the monks.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 21", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 24}]

blurb: The Buddha’s awakening has shown him a spiritual happiness that is better than any worldly happiness. This chapter focusses on the emotional dimension of enlightenment.

[{"uid": "sn12.41", "root_name": "Pa\u00f1caverabhayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.41", "blurb": "A noble disciple who is a layperson has eliminated the fear that comes from breaking precepts, possesses the four factors of stream-entry, and understands dependent origination.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.42", "root_name": "Dutiyapa\u00f1caverabhayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.42", "blurb": "A noble disciple who is a layperson has eliminated the fear that comes from breaking precepts, possesses the four factors of stream-entry, and understands dependent origination.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.43", "root_name": "Dukkhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.43", "blurb": "The origin and ending of suffering are explained in terms of sense experience giving rise to craving.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.44", "root_name": "Lokasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.44", "blurb": "The origin and ending of the world are explained in terms of sense experience giving rise to craving and suffering.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.45", "root_name": "\u00d1\u0101tikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.45", "blurb": "While on retreat, the Buddha exclaims how the origin and ending of the world are explained in terms of sense experience giving rise to craving and suffering. A mendicant overhears him, and the Buddha urges him to remember that teaching.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.46", "root_name": "A\u00f1\u00f1atarabr\u0101hma\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.46", "blurb": "A brahmin asks whether the person who acts is the same or different to the person who receives the result. blurb: The “Linked Discourses on the Unconditioned” contains 44 discourses on the theme of the unconditioned, i.e. nibbāna or “extinguishment”. They focus on the various practices that lead to the unconditioned. This chapter includes an extensive range of terms and idioms describing the final goal of Buddhist practice.

[{"uid": "an9.1", "root_name": "Sambodhisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 9.1", "blurb": "Beginning with good friendship, the Buddha teaches nine things that give rise to the qualities that lead to awakening.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an9.2", "root_name": "Nissayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 9.2", "blurb": "The things that a mendicant relies on as supports in spiritual practice.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an9.3", "root_name": "Meghiyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 9.3", "blurb": "Venerable Meghiya, while attending on the Buddha, wants to go off and meditate in a forest alone. The Buddha discourages him, but he goes anyway. When his meditation doesn\u2019t go well, he returns chastened to the Buddha, who teaches him about the benefits of good companions and other fundamentals of a balanced spiritual practice.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an9.4", "root_name": "Nandakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 9.4", "blurb": "Nandaka is teaching the monks when the Buddha arrives. Unbeknown to those inside, the Buddha waits until the talk was finished, then enters. Nandaka is embarrassed at keeping the Buddha waiting, but the Buddha praises him and offers a teaching on the four things a mendicant should complete. Nandaka then teaches five benefits of listening to Dhamma.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an9.5", "root_name": "Balasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 9.5", "blurb": "A noble disciple who develops four powers overcomes five fears.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an9.6", "root_name": "Sevan\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 9.6", "blurb": "Four kinds of person who one should or should not associate with. A similar distinction is made regarding robes, almsfood, lodgings, towns, and countries.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an9.7", "root_name": "Sutav\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 9.7", "blurb": "The wanderer Sutav\u0101 asks the Buddha about five things a perfected one cannot do; the Buddha expands it to nine.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an9.8", "root_name": "Sajjhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 9.8", "blurb": "The wanderer Sajjha asks the Buddha about five things a perfected one cannot do; the Buddha expands it to nine, which differ slightly from AN 9.7.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an9.9", "root_name": "Puggalasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 9.9", "blurb": "Nine kinds of persons: the eight noble persons and the ordinary person.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an9.10", "root_name": "\u0100huneyyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 9.10", "blurb": "Nine persons are worthy of gifts: the eight noble persons and a member of the spiritual family.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "an8.71", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamasaddh\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.71", "blurb": "Beginning with faith, a mendicant completes all good qualities that fulfill liberation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an8.72", "root_name": "Dutiyasaddh\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.72", "blurb": "Beginning with faith, a mendicant completes all good qualities that fulfill liberation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an8.73", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamamara\u1e47assatisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.73", "blurb": "Various mendicants practice mindfulness of death, but do so inadequately. The Buddha explains how to do so with proper urgency,", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an8.74", "root_name": "Dutiyamara\u1e47assatisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.74", "blurb": "A mendicant should reflect each night on the dangers that lie around them, and practice mindfulness of death with urgency to give up the unwholesome.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an8.75", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamasampad\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.75", "blurb": "Eight accomplishments, both worldly and spiritual.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an8.76", "root_name": "Dutiyasampad\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.76", "blurb": "Eight accomplishments, both worldly and spiritual, in detail.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an8.77", "root_name": "Icch\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.77", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta describes eight cases where a mendicant has a desire for material things. Sometimes they fall under the sway of that desire, but sometimes they rise above it.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an8.78", "root_name": "Ala\u1e41sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.78", "blurb": "Eight sets of qualities pertain to benefiting oneself and others, explained by S\u0101riputta.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an8.79", "root_name": "Parih\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.79", "blurb": "Eight conditions for the decline or success of a trainee mendicant.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an8.80", "root_name": "Kus\u012bt\u0101rambhavatthusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.80", "blurb": "Eight grounds for laziness, and the corresponding eight grounds for energy.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Stream-Entry” contains 74 discourses on the topic of stream-entry, or more precisely, two sets of four qualities, one of which distinguishes a person as a stream-enterer, and one which help lead to stream-entry. The primary qualities of the first set are faith and ethical conduct. For the second, it is hearing the teaching and practicing accordingly. Note that these sets do not exhaust the qualities of a stream-enterer, many others of which are described elsewhere, but serve to emphasis the crucial role especially of faith.

blurb: A partial translation of the Saṁyuktāgama (SA-2) was made between 385 and 431 by an anonymous translator. Known as the Shorter Saṁyuktāgama (Bieyi za ahan jing, 別譯雜阿含經), it may stem from the Mūlasarvāstivādin school. It consists of 364 sutras in 16 fascicles. Most of the texts have parallels in Chinese and/or Pali, primarily in the Sagāthāvagga of the Saṁyutta. In the Taishō edition of the Chinese canon, it is text number 100, located at T vol. 2, 374a.

blurb: The Upāyika, full name Abhidharmakośopāyikanāmaṭīkā, is a collection of quotes from the early suttas made by a monk called Śamathadeva, who probably lived in India sometime after the 5th century. It was translated into Tibetan by Jāyaśrī (ཞི་གནས་ལྷ།), probably around the 11th century. It gives the full sutta passages referred to by Vasubandhu in his Abhidharmakośa. The SuttaCentral text is from the Asian Classics Input Project, where it is listed as Tengyur 4091.04.

blurb: The version of the Middle Discourses found in the Chinese canon is known as the Madhyamāgama (Zhong ahan jing, 中阿含經), and is believed to stem from the Sarvāstivāda school. The original text is believed to have been in a form of Prākrit, probably Gandhārī, with some Sanskrit influence. It was translated in 60 fascicles by Gautama Saṅghadeva (瞿曇僧伽提婆) of the Eastern Jin Dynasty (東晋) at Dongting Monastery (東亭寺) in CE 397–398. It consists of 222 sutras, organized into five adhyāyas and eighteen vargas. The contents are similar to the Pali Majjhima Nikāya, though the collections are far from identical. In the Taishō edition of the Chinese canon, it is text number 26, located at T vol. 1, 421a.

blurb: The “Linked Discourses with Brahmins” contains 22 discourses featuring the Buddha interacting with various members of the brahmanical caste. The brahmins were the custodians of the brahmanical scriptures and traditions, and saw themselves as the spiritual elite of society. A central platform of the Buddha’s ethical teaching was that one’s worth is determined by one’s deeds, not by caste. This was a direct challenge to brahmanical authority, and a number of discourses have an understandably combative air to them. But the brahmins were a diverse community, and it’s just as common to find them relating to the Buddha with respect and gratitude.

translated_name: The Chapter on the Undeclared Points
children: [{"uid": "an7.54", "root_name": "Aby\u0101katasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.54", "blurb": "The Buddha explains why a noble disciple has no doubt when it comes to the unexplained points.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an7.55", "root_name": "Purisagatisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.55", "blurb": "Seven kinds of rebirth for non-returners, as well as extinguishment by not grasping.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.56", "root_name": "Tissabrahm\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.56", "blurb": "Two gods come to the Buddha on Vulture\u2019s Peak and declare that the nuns are liberated. Moggall\u0101na interrogates one of the deities on what he means, and the Buddha adds further explanation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.57", "root_name": "S\u012bhasen\u0101patisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.57", "blurb": "The Buddha explains the benefits of giving that are visible in the present life, and one that is only apparent in the next.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an7.58", "root_name": "Arakkheyyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.58", "blurb": "Four areas where the Realized One has nothing to hide, and three ways he is irreproachable.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.59", "root_name": "Kimilasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.59", "blurb": "Venerable Kimbila asks the Buddha the reasons for the long-lasting of Buddhism after the Buddha\u2019s demise.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an7.60", "root_name": "Sattadhammasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.60", "blurb": "Qualities required for arahantship.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.61", "root_name": "Pacal\u0101yam\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.61", "blurb": "Before his awakening, Moggall\u0101na is struggling with sleepiness in meditation. The Buddha visits him and gives seven ways to dispel drowsiness, and other important teachings.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an7.62", "root_name": "Mettasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.62", "blurb": "The incalculable benefits of merit that last for many aeons.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.63", "root_name": "Bhariy\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.63", "blurb": "An\u0101thapi\u1e47\u1e0dika\u2019s home was in an uproar due to the badly behaved Suj\u0101t\u0101, newly wedded to one of his sons. The Buddha speaks to her on the different kinds of wives.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.64", "root_name": "Kodhanasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.64", "blurb": "When someone is angry, they wish ill upon their enemy, and are disappointed if they do well. This sutta includes a powerful set of verses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses with Sāmaṇḍaka” contains 16 discourses recording the answers given by Sāriputta to the questions of a wanderer named Sāmaṇḍaka. The questions cover a wide range of themes, from the nature of extinguishment to the difficulty of practicing the Dhamma. This chapter is practically identical to the previous, differing only in the name of the wanderer, and the Pali editions abbreviate, instructing that it is to be expanded.

[{"uid": "an11.1", "root_name": "Kimatthiyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 11.1", "blurb": "Good conduct leads to non-regret, to joy, and so on all the way to liberation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an11.2", "root_name": "Cetan\u0101kara\u1e47\u012byasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 11.2", "blurb": "A virtuous person need not make a wish; it is natural for the path to flow on.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an11.3", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamaupanis\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 11.3", "blurb": "The Buddha teaches that ethical conduct is the vital cause of the good qualities that lead to awakening.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an11.4", "root_name": "Dutiyaupanis\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 11.4", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta teaches that ethical conduct is the vital cause of the good qualities that lead to awakening.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an11.5", "root_name": "Tatiyaupanis\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 11.5", "blurb": "\u0100nanda teaches that ethical conduct is the vital cause of the good qualities that lead to awakening.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an11.6", "root_name": "Byasanasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 11.6", "blurb": "When a mendicant abuses their fellow monastics, eleven disasters follow.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an11.7", "root_name": "Sa\u00f1\u00f1\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 11.7", "blurb": "\u0100nanda asks the Buddha about a deep state of meditation where all normal perception has ceased, but there is still perception. The Buddha affirms that such a state exists. \u0100nanda puts the same question to S\u0101riputta, and gets the same answer.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an11.8", "root_name": "Manasik\u0101rasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 11.8", "blurb": "\u0100nanda asks the Buddha about a deep state of meditation where all normal attention has ceased, but there is still attention. The Buddha affirms that such a state exists.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an11.9", "root_name": "Saddhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 11.9", "blurb": "The Buddha tells Venerable Sandha to meditate like a trained thoroughbred, not like a wild colt. Doing so, they may attain a deep state.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an11.10", "root_name": "Moraniv\u0101pasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 11.10", "blurb": "Possessing various sets of qualities, a mendicant is best among gods and men.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "sn46.31", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamakusalasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 46.31", "blurb": "Skillful qualities are rooted in diligence, which promotes the awakening factors.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn46.32", "root_name": "Dutiyakusalasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 46.32", "blurb": "Skillful qualities are rooted in proper attention, which promotes the awakening factors.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn46.33", "root_name": "Upakkilesasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 46.33", "blurb": "Hindrances sully the mind like impurities in gold.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn46.34", "root_name": "Anupakkilesasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 46.34", "blurb": "Awakening factors purify the mind and lead to liberation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn46.35", "root_name": "Yonisomanasik\u0101rasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 46.35", "blurb": "Improper attention promotes the hindrances; proper attention promotes the awakening factors.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn46.36", "root_name": "Buddhisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 46.36", "blurb": "The awakening factors lead to growth and non-decline.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn46.37", "root_name": "\u0100vara\u1e47an\u012bvara\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 46.37", "blurb": "Hindrances sully the mind, awakening factors purify it.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn46.38", "root_name": "An\u012bvara\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 46.38", "blurb": "Listening to the teaching, the hindrances are given up and the awakening factors developed.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn46.39", "root_name": "Rukkhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 46.39", "blurb": "As some large trees with small seeds will overgrow and ruin other trees, so the hindrances overgrow and ruin the mind.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn46.40", "root_name": "N\u012bvara\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 46.40", "blurb": "The hindrances cause blindness, the awakening factors cause vision.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

translated_name: Past Life Legends of the Senior Monks
blurb: The “Legends of the Senior Monks” contains 563 stories in verse telling the past life deeds of various senior monks. It is a much later counterpart to the Theragāthā, referring to many of the same monks. But whereas the Theragāthā verses relate the monks’ practice of meditation and mindfulness in this life, the Legends typically relate how they became awakened in this life by making an offering a Buddha in the distant past, and making a dedication to be reborn so as to become awakened in the future. The “Legends of the Senior Monks” has as companion the “Legends of the Senior Nuns”. Both these are late texts, and lack counterparts in the northern canons.

blurb: The main version of the Linked Discourses found in the Chinese canon is known as the Saṁyuktāgama (Za ahan jing, 雜阿含經), and is believed to stem from a branch of the Sarvāstivādin school. It was translated by Guṇabhadra (求那跋陀) and Baoyun (寶雲) in CE 435–436 at Waguan Monastery (瓦官寺,) Yangdu (楊都). Like the Pali Saṁyutta Nikāya, it contains over a thousand short suttas organized by topic. The texts, however, became disordered during the transmission in China, and an extraneous passage from a later life of Ashoka was mistakenly included. In the 20th century a series of scholars reconstructed the original sequence. The text as originally found is found in the Taishō edition of the Chinese canon as sutra number 99 at T vol. 2, 1a.

blurb: The Buddhavaṁsa is a late devotional text in verse detailing the lives of 24 past Buddhas and the prediction of the awakening of the historical Buddha Gotama. This is a late text, without direct counterparts in the northern collections. It is, however, part of an extensive pan-sectarian devotional literature composed in the second and first centuries BCE, presaging the birth of the Mahāyāna.

blurb: The “Linked” or “Connected” Discourses (Saṁyutta Nikāya, abbreviated SN) is a collection of over a thousand short discourses in the Pali canon. The word “linked” refers to the fact that the texts are collected and organized by topic. In most cases the organizing principle is a particular theme of Dhamma, for example, the five aggregates, dependent origination, the noble eightfold path, mindfulness meditation, or the four noble truths. This collection contains the most extensive range of texts on these core themes. In other cases chapters are organized according to the person or kind of person who speaks. This collection has a full parallel in the Saṁyuktāgama (SA) of the Sarvāstivāda school in Chinese translation. In addition, there are two partial collections in Chinese (SA-2 and SA-3) as well as a number of miscellaneous or fragmentary texts in Chinese, Sanskrit, and Tibetan. Much of the organizational structure of SN is shared with SA, suggesting that this structure preceded the split between these two collections.
children: [{"uid": "sn-sagathavaggasamyutta", "root_name": "Sag\u0101th\u0101vaggasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "The Group of Linked Discourses With Verses ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cBook With Verses\u201d is the first of the five books of the Linked Discourses. It is divided into eleven sa\u1e41yuttas or \u201csections\u201d, with a total of 271 suttas. Most of these are further subdivided into vaggas of ten suttas. The word vagga is thus used of both the major overarching \u201cbook\u201d and the subsidiary \u201cchapter\u201d. Each of the suttas in this collection contains verse with a prose narrative structure, although in many cases the prose has been omitted through abbreviation. Where most of the Sa\u1e41yutta is organized around subject matter, here the organizational principle is people. Each sa\u1e41yutta contains conversation involving the Buddha or his disciples with a different person or kind of person, such as gods, kings, nuns, or brahmins. A typical sutta has a bare narrative framework, where someone comes to the Buddha and utters a verse, and the Buddha replies with a better one. In some cases, notably the Sakkasa\u1e41yutta, the narrative element is developed into a lively exchange. Some of the texts in this collection are well known and widely quoted, such as the invitation of Brahm\u0101 or the nun Vajir\u0101\u2019s simile of the person as a chariot. Most of the suttas here have parallels in the Chinese Sa\u1e41yukt\u0101gama translations; the partial translations SA 2 and SA 3 include Sag\u0101th\u0101vagga material. In addition, many of the verses have parallels elsewhere throughout the Buddhist literature in all languages.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 1\u201311", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 413}, {"uid": "sn-nidanavaggasamyutta", "root_name": "Nid\u0101navaggasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "The Group of Linked Discourses Beginning With Causation ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cBook of Causation\u201d is the second of the five books of the Linked Discourses. It is named after the first and longest sa\u1e41yutta, which deals with causation through the core Buddhist teaching of Dependent Origination. The remaining nine sa\u1e41yuttas deal with miscellaneous secondary themes, some organized by subject, others by person.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 12\u201321", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 346}, {"uid": "sn-khandhavaggasamyutta", "root_name": "Khandhavaggasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "The Group of Linked Discourses Beginning With the Aggregates ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cBook of the Aggregates\u201d is the third of the five books of the Linked Discourses. It is named after the first and longest sa\u1e41yutta, which deals with the core Buddhist teaching of the five aggregates. Of the remaining twelve sa\u1e41yuttas, three also take up the theme of the aggregates, while the remainder deal with miscellaneous secondary themes, some organized by subject, others by person.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 22\u201334", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 440}, {"uid": "sn-salayatanavaggasamyutta", "root_name": "Sa\u1e37\u0101yatanavaggasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "The Group of Linked Discourses Beginning With the Six Sense Fields ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cBook of the Six Sense Fields\u201d is the fourth of the five books of the Linked Discourses. It is named after the first and longest sa\u1e41yutta, which deals with the core Buddhist teaching of the six sense fields. The second sa\u1e41yutta on Feelings also deals with a major doctrinal topic. The remaining eight sa\u1e41yuttas deal with miscellaneous secondary themes, some organized by subject, others by person.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 35\u201344", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 552}, {"uid": "sn-mahavaggasamyutta", "root_name": "Mah\u0101vaggasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "The Group of Linked Discourses on the Path ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cGreat Book\u201d is the last and largest of the five books of the Linked Discourses. It consists of twelve sa\u1e41yuttas, almost all of which deal with an aspect of Buddhist practice, or the path. The first of these, indeed, is the \u201cSection on the Path\u201d (Maggasa\u1e41yutta), and in the northern canons the book as a whole is referred to as the \u201cBook of the Path\u201d (Maggavagga). The first seven of the sa\u1e41yuttas treat the familiar set of seven groups of factors on Buddhist practice known to the later traditions as the bodhipakkhiy\u0101 dhamm\u0101, or \u201cqualities leading to awakening\u201d. This book is the primary source for these teachings. Subsequent sa\u1e41yuttas deal with the path from different perspectives, while the final two deal with stream-entry and the four noble truths respectively.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 45\u201356", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 910}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on the Aggregates” contains 159 discourses on the core doctrinal topic of the five aggregates. This term was introduced in the first sermon as the summary of the noble truth of suffering, and became a foundational teaching in all forms of Buddhism. The basic idea of an “aggregate” is a set or class of phenomena. The five are form (rūpa, i.e. “physical phenomena”, or sometimes simply “body”; note that in Buddhism, rūpa includes all things with material properties such as shape and color, including visions perceived only in the mind), feeling (vedanā, i.e. the pleasant, painful, or neutral tone of experience), perception (saññā, i.e. the recognition or interpretation of experience, not sense awareness), choices (saṅkhārā, i.e. intention, will, or volition; the choice to perform an act, especially one with an ethical dimension), and consciousness (viññāṇa, i.e. the subjective process of awareness itself). The “aggregates” are the various different phenomena so classified. Almost always, they are referred to as the “aggregates connected with grasping” (upādānakkhandha). The relation between “grasping” and “aggregate” encompasses a number of aspects. The aggregates are the subject of grasping, in that they are the things that are normally attached to and taken to be the permanent “self”. But they are not merely passive spectators: they are also the functional support of grasping, the things that make grasping work. As active participants in the process of grasping, they stimulate grasping to themselves (upādāniya). And finally, they are the product of grasping in the sense that attachments in past lives have given rise to the aggregates in this life (upādinna). One of the key functions of the aggregates is to categorize theories of the self. From the discourses, non-Buddhists seem to be familiar with this, yet we cannot identify the aggregates in any pre-Buddhist texts. Regardless of whether the set of categories was pre-Buddhist, the Buddha treated them in his own distinctive way, emphasizing that nothing in the aggregates was a permanent self or soul. In this collection we find a large number of striking and lively narratives, showing how the aggregates could be a solace at the time of death, a guide to the knotty theoretical debates on identity, or a framework for insight meditation. Many of the short abbreviated texts are built from the same templates employed in the “Linked Discourses on the Six Sense Fields”.

blurb: The Patna Dharmapada is based on a manuscript discovered in Tibet by Rāhula Saṅkṛtyāyana in 1934, written in proto-Bengali script, and dated around the twelfth century. It is in a distinct variety of Sanskritized Prākrit, and has been identified by Skilling and Mizuno as belonging to the Sāmmatīya school. The SuttaCentral text is based on the edition by Margaret Cone (1989), digitized by Ānandajoti.

He admits that he cannot read the minds of all the Buddhas, but he understands a principle of the Dhamma: all those who become awakened do so by giving up the five hindrances, practicing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, and developing the seven awakening factors.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.13", "root_name": "Cundasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.13", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta dies of illness, and the novice Cunda together with \u0100nanda take his bowl and robes and report the sad news to the Buddha. The Buddha dispels \u0100nanda\u2019s sadness by speaking of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.14", "root_name": "Ukkacelasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.14", "blurb": "After the passing of S\u0101riputta and Moggall\u0101na (whose actual death is unrecorded in the canon), the Buddha says the Sa\u1e45gha looks empty; yet he is not sad.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.15", "root_name": "B\u0101hiyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.15", "blurb": "When Venerable B\u0101hiya asks for a teaching to take on retreat, the Buddha teaches the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, well grounded on ethics.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.16", "root_name": "Uttiyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.16", "blurb": "When Venerable Uttiya asks for a teaching to take on retreat, the Buddha teaches the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, well grounded on ethics.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.17", "root_name": "Ariyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.17", "blurb": "The four kinds of mindfulness meditation lead to the end of suffering.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.18", "root_name": "Brahmasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.18", "blurb": "Just after the Buddha\u2019s awakening, Brahm\u0101 Sahampati supports the Buddha\u2019s reflection that the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the way to convergence.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.19", "root_name": "Sedakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.19", "blurb": "Two acrobats discuss whether one should support the other, or the other way around. The Buddha says they should support each other. In the same way we should practice the four kinds of mindfulness meditation both for one\u2019s own benefit and to protect others.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.20", "root_name": "Janapadakaly\u0101\u1e47\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.20", "blurb": "A parable that sets up an impossible challenge: to walk between a popular performer and the crowd jostling to see her, carrying a bowl of oil filled to the brim, while a man with a drawn sword waits to chop off your head if you spill a drop. That\u2019s mindfulness! ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Deities” contains 81 discourses, each one of which depicts the Buddha in conversation with a deity. Typically a deity approaches the Buddha in the monastery at Sāvatthī, illuminating the night with their glory. The deity addresses the Buddha with a question or verse, which may be a praise, a challenge, a riddle, or simply a reflection. The Buddha responds, usually elevating the discourse to a higher plane. As always in Buddhist texts, a deity is not worshiped, but is regarded as a temporary rebirth in a higher plane; the deities learn from the Buddha, not the other way around. In most cases, the narrative framework is slim, and after a while it is dropped entirely, retaining just the verses. There’s no particular theme to the discourses, which range from the simple to the profound.

translated_name: The Group of Linked Discourses on the Path
blurb: The “Great Book” is the last and largest of the five books of the Linked Discourses. It consists of twelve saṁyuttas, almost all of which deal with an aspect of Buddhist practice, or the path. The first of these, indeed, is the “Section on the Path” (Maggasaṁyutta), and in the northern canons the book as a whole is referred to as the “Book of the Path” (Maggavagga). The first seven of the saṁyuttas treat the familiar set of seven groups of factors on Buddhist practice known to the later traditions as the bodhipakkhiyā dhammā, or “qualities leading to awakening”. This book is the primary source for these teachings. Subsequent saṁyuttas deal with the path from different perspectives, while the final two deal with stream-entry and the four noble truths respectively.
children: [{"uid": "sn45", "root_name": "Maggasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on the Eightfold Path ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on the Path\u201d contains 180 discourses on the noble eightfold path, the \u201cmiddle way\u201d which is the first and most important of all the Buddha\u2019s teachings on the path of spiritual practice. It is mentioned in the first discourse as the fourth noble truth. It begins with \u201cright view\u201d which is initially an accurate conceptual understanding, based on hearing the teachings and reflecting on their meaning. The second factor is right intention, referring to the attitude or motivation that shapes practice. Next come three factors dealing with ethical conduct. And the final three factors directly deal with meditation. Once all these factors are mature, \u201cright immersion\u201d or the four absorptions (jh\u0101nas) enables the initial conceptual understanding to ascend to a higher level of insight and letting go. While this and subsequent chapters contains many substantive discourses on this theme, the large number of discourses is mainly attributable to the formulaic \u201crepetition series\u201d which append each chapter.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 45", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 218}, {"uid": "sn46", "root_name": "Bojjha\u1e45gasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on the Awakening Factors ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on the Awakening Factors\u201d contains 184 discourses on the seven awakening factors. These are qualities such as mindfulness and investigation which lead the meditator to awakening. The focus here is specifically on meditation, rather than the more holistic approach included in the previous chapter on the Path. Some distinctive features of this collection include the use recitation of the awakening factors in order to inspire those who are sick, and the frequent contrast between the seven awakening factors and the five hindrances.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 46", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 167}, {"uid": "sn47", "root_name": "Satipa\u1e6d\u1e6dh\u0101nasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on Mindfulness Meditation ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on Mindfulness Meditation\u201d contains 104 discourses on the four kinds of mindfulness meditation (satipa\u1e6d\u1e6dh\u0101na, otherwise known as the \u201cfoundations of mindfulness\u201d or \u201cestablishments of mindfulness\u201d). These are the body, feelings, mind, and principles. The last of these is translated in various ways, but a close reading of the texts in this chapter shows that it originally referred to the \u201cprinciples\u201d of causality underlying the process of meditation itself. These discourses on this fundamental topic are much less known than the longer \u201cDiscourse on Mindfulness Meditation\u201d found in versions in MN 10 and DN 22; however, they are historically earlier than that late compilation. Where MN 10 emphasizes insight meditation, in this collection we frequently find mindfulness closely connected to absorption, as it is the factor of the path that leads directly to \u201cright immersion\u201d. Insight is mentioned only rarely. The root meaning of the term mindfulness (sati) is \u201cmemory\u201d, and when used in meditation it refers to not \u201cforgetting\u201d one\u2019s meditation, but keeping focus on the breath or other theme of meditation. This collection presents a range of perspectives on mindfulness meditation; one of its most memorable features is a series of similes or parables illustrating the practice. The partner of mindfulness (sati) is \u201csituational awareness\u201d (sampaja\u00f1\u00f1a, sometimes rendered as \u201cclear comprehension\u201d), which refers to keeping a broad awareness and understanding especially in daily activities.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 47", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 110}, {"uid": "sn48", "root_name": "Indriyasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on the Faculties ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on the Faculties\u201d contains 178 discourses on various sets of \u201cfaculties\u201d (indriya). The \u201cfive faculties\u201d of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom are the most natural fit in this context. However the chapter also finds room for discourses on a wider range of 22 faculties, including the six sense faculties, five affective faculties (kinds of feeling), three faculties relating the process of enlightenment, and three concerning biology and gender. This flexible category thus serves as a link between the teachings on wisdom and those on the path.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 48", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 80}, {"uid": "sn49", "root_name": "Sammappadh\u0101nasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on the Right Efforts ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on the Right Efforts\u201d contains 54 discourses, which are, however, a mere instantiation of the standard repetition series as applied to the four right efforts. There are many discourses on right effort throughout the Pali nik\u0101yas, but for some reason the redactors did not collect them here.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 49", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "sn50", "root_name": "Balasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on the Five Powers ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on the Five Powers\u201d contains 108 discourses, which are, however, a mere instantiation of the standard repetition series as applied to the five powers. These powers are effectively identical with the five faculties, as stated at SN 48.43, being merely distinguished as a different teaching approach. There are several discourses on these qualities found mainly in the A\u1e45guttara Fives, but for some reason the redactors did not collect them here.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 50", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 10}, {"uid": "sn51", "root_name": "Iddhip\u0101dasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on the Bases of Psychic Power ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on the Bases of Psychic Power\u201d contains 86 discourses dealing with the qualities of enthusiasm or desire for practice, energy, higher consciousness, and inquiry, which are said to lead to the development of various psychic powers. The purpose of Buddhism, of course, is not to develop such powers. But they are a matter of constant interest and intrigue among spiritual practitioners\u2014not just in ancient India\u2014and it seems the Buddha formulated this approach to the path to inspire those interested in them. The emphasis is on the development of deep meditation immersion (sam\u0101dhi) through applying effort.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 51", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 37}, {"uid": "sn52", "root_name": "Anuruddhasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses with Anuruddha ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses with Anuruddha\u201d contains 24 discourses with Anuruddha, famous for his powers of clairvoyance, but here revealed as an exponent of mindfulness meditation. It is to mindfulness meditation that he attributes his spiritual attainments, whether psychic powers, absorptions, or awakening. This series of texts can be regarded as a supplement to SN 47.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 52", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 24}, {"uid": "sn53", "root_name": "Jh\u0101nasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on Absorption ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on Absorption\u201d contains 54 discourses on the topic of absorption meditation (jh\u0101na), which however merely apply the standard repetition series to the formula for the four absorptions.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 53", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "sn54", "root_name": "\u0100n\u0101p\u0101nasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on Breath Meditation ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on Breath Meditation\u201d contains 20 discourses on breath meditation (\u0101n\u0101p\u0101nassati), the most revered form of meditation from early Buddhism until the present day. It was practiced by the Buddha himself. The meditation is taught in a detailed series of sixteen steps. These are partially sequential, but also overlap in some cases. The development of these fulfills all four kinds of mindfulness meditation and the seven factors of awakening. Thus this one form of meditation can lead to awakening; which is not, however, to say that it is invariably the best approach. The Buddha taught many different meditations for a reason; each has its own qualities and benefits. Breath meditation is seen as a peaceful and pleasant meditation which helps still distracting thoughts. It is a simple practice broadly suitable for most meditators, but leading to profound depths.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 54", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 20}, {"uid": "sn55", "root_name": "Sot\u0101pattisa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on Stream-Entry ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on Stream-Entry\u201d contains 74 discourses on the topic of stream-entry, or more precisely, two sets of four qualities, one of which distinguishes a person as a stream-enterer, and one which help lead to stream-entry. The primary qualities of the first set are faith and ethical conduct. For the second, it is hearing the teaching and practicing accordingly. Note that these sets do not exhaust the qualities of a stream-enterer, many others of which are described elsewhere, but serve to emphasis the crucial role especially of faith.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 55", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 75}, {"uid": "sn56", "root_name": "Saccasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on the Truths ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on the Truths\u201d contains 131 discourses on the four noble truths: suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path. These formed the main subject of the Buddha\u2019s first discourse, which is included here as SN 56.11. The Buddha said that all of his teaching was comprised within the four noble truths. Indeed, the overall structure of the main doctrinal Sa\u1e41yuttas can be seen as an expanded example of this: The sections on the Aggregates and the Sense Fields deal with the first noble truth; Dependent Origination deals with the second and third; and the chapters on the Path deal with the final truth. This chapter thus provides an overall perspective on the other teachings, and the chapter occurs at the end just as the realization of the four noble truths emerges from the path.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 56", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 159}]

The Brethren had assembled in the Hall of Truth and were telling how Devadatta had gone to Gayasisa with five hundred followers, whom he was leading into error by declaring that the Truth was manifest in him \u201cand not in the ascetic Gotama\u201d; and how by his lies he was breaking up the Brotherhood; and how he kept two fast-days a week. And as they sate there talking of the wickedness of Devadatta, the Master entered and was told the subject of their conversation. \u201cBrethren,\u201d said he, \u201cDevadatta was as great a liar in past times as he is now.\u201d So saying, he told this story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja114", "root_name": "Mitacintij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Thoughtful ", "acronym": "Ja 114", "blurb": "\u201cThey twain in fisher\u2019s net.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about two aged Elders. But they kept putting off their departure day by day, till a month flew by. On this occasion the Master said, \u201cBrethren, this is not the first time Cinca has laid false accusations against me. She did the like in other times.\u201d So saying he told this story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: The Divyāvadāna or “Divine Tales” is a Sanskrit anthology of 38 tales, many originating in the Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya. Typically the stories illustrate how the consequences of actions in past lives affect the present, with a special emphasis on the merit of making offerings to the Buddha and his disciples. It includes the famous Aśokāvadāna, one of the primary sources for the life of King Ashoka. The text probably dates from around the third century CE, but includes a few parallels to early texts. Modern editions are based on a number of Nepalese manuscripts, mostly quite modern. It was first edited and published in the west by Cowell and Neil in 1884. The digital text on SuttaCentral is from GRETIL, based on the edition by Vaidya (1959), with input by Kensuke Okamoto.
