children: [{"uid": "mn81", "root_name": "Gha\u1e6dik\u0101rasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 81", "blurb": "The Buddha relates an unusual account of a past life in the time of the previous Buddha, Kassapa. At that time he was not interested in Dhamma, and had to be forced to go see the Buddha. This discourse is important in understanding the development of the Bodhisattva doctrine.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn82", "root_name": "Ra\u1e6d\u1e6dhap\u0101lasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 82", "blurb": "A wealthy young man, Ra\u1e6d\u1e6dhap\u0101la, has a strong aspiration to go forth, but has to prevail against the reluctance of his parents. Even after he became a monk, his parents tried to persuade him to disrobe. The discourse ends with a moving series of teachings on the fragility of the world.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn83", "root_name": "Maghadevasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 83", "blurb": "A rare extended mythic narrative, telling of an ancient kingly lineage and their eventual downfall.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn84", "root_name": "Madhurasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 84", "blurb": "In Madhur\u0101, towards the north-eastern limit of the Buddha\u2019s reach during his life, King Avantiputta asks Venerable Mah\u0101kacc\u0101na regarding the brahmanical claim to be the highest caste.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn85", "root_name": "Bodhir\u0101jakum\u0101rasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 85", "blurb": "Admitting that he used to believe that pleasure was to be gained through pain, the Buddha explains how his practice showed him the fallacy of that idea.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn86", "root_name": "A\u1e45gulim\u0101lasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 86", "blurb": "Ignoring warnings, the Buddha ventures into the domain of the notorious killer A\u1e45gulim\u0101la and succeeds in converting him to the path of non-violence. After becoming a monk A\u1e45gulim\u0101la still suffered for his past deeds, but only to a small extent. He uses his new commitment to non-violence to help a woman in labor.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn87", "root_name": "Piyaj\u0101tikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 87", "blurb": "A rare glimpse into the marital life of King Pasenadi, and how he is led to the Dhamma by his Queen, the incomparable Mallik\u0101. She confirms the Buddha\u2019s teaching that our loved ones bring us sorrow; but that\u2019s not something a husband, father, and king wants to hear.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn88", "root_name": "B\u0101hitikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 88", "blurb": "King Pasenadi takes a chance to visit Venerable \u0100nanda, where he asks about skillful and unskillful behavior, and what is praised by the Buddha. He offers \u0100nanda a valuable cloth in gratitude.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn89", "root_name": "Dhammacetiyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 89", "blurb": "King Pasenadi, near the end of his life, visits the Buddha, and shows moving devotion and love for his teacher.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn90", "root_name": "Ka\u1e47\u1e47akatthalasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 90", "blurb": "King Pasenadi questions the Buddha on miscellaneous matters: caste, omniscience, and the gods among them.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}]

[{"uid": "sn51.67-76", "root_name": "Esan\u0101vagga", "translated_name": "Searches ", "acronym": "SN 51.67\u201376", "blurb": null, "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "sn52.1", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamarahogatasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 52.1", "blurb": "While meditating alone, Anuruddha reflected that one who has neglected the four kinds of mindfulness meditation has neglected the path to the end of suffering. Moggall\u0101na reads his mind and visits to question him on this. Anuruddha speaks of developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation internally and externally, in terms of origin and cessation, and developing power over perceptions.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn52.2", "root_name": "Dutiyarahogatasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 52.2", "blurb": "While meditating alone, Anuruddha reflected that one who has neglected the four kinds of mindfulness meditation has neglected the path to the end of suffering. Moggall\u0101na reads his mind and visits to question him on this. Anuruddha speaks of developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation internally and externally.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn52.3", "root_name": "Sutanusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 52.3", "blurb": "When some mendicants ask Anuruddha how he attained such higher knowledge, he replies it is from developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn52.4", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamaka\u1e47\u1e0dak\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 52.4", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta and Moggall\u0101na ask Anuruddha what a trainee mendicant should practice. He replies that it is the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn52.5", "root_name": "Dutiyaka\u1e47\u1e0dak\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 52.5", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta and Moggall\u0101na ask Anuruddha what an adept mendicant should practice. He replies that it is the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn52.6", "root_name": "Tatiyaka\u1e47\u1e0dak\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 52.6", "blurb": "When S\u0101riputta ask Anuruddha how he attained such higher knowledge, he replies it is from developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn52.7", "root_name": "Ta\u1e47h\u0101kkhayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 52.7", "blurb": "The four kinds of mindfulness meditation lead to the ending of craving.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn52.8", "root_name": "Sala\u1e37\u0101g\u0101rasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 52.8", "blurb": "Even if kings beg them to disrobe, a mendicant who has developed the four kinds of mindfulness meditation is unmoved. Their mind flows to Nibb\u0101na like the Ganges to the sea.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn52.9", "root_name": "Ambap\u0101livanasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 52.9", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta asks why Anuruddha looks so peaceful, and he replies it is due to developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn52.10", "root_name": "B\u0101\u1e37hagil\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 52.10", "blurb": "Some mendicants ask Anuruddha how he remains equanimous even though ill. He replies that it is due to the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "ja-nilinikavagga", "root_name": "Ni\u1e37inik\u0101vagga", "translated_name": "Princess Ni\u1e37inik\u0101 ", "acronym": null, "blurb": null, "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "Ja 526\u2013528", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}]

[{"uid": "an9.32", "root_name": "Anupubbavih\u0101rasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 9.32", "blurb": "Nine progressive meditation states.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an9.33", "root_name": "Anupubbavih\u0101rasam\u0101pattisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 9.33", "blurb": "Nine progressive meditation states, explained in detail.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an9.34", "root_name": "Nibb\u0101nasukhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 9.34", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta declares that extinguishment is bliss, precisely because nothing is felt there. He explains this apparent paradox with reference to the nine progressive meditations.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an9.35", "root_name": "G\u0101v\u012bupam\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 9.35", "blurb": "Just as a foolish cow can get in trouble wandering the mountains, a foolish mendicant can get lost practicing absorption if they do it wrongly.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an9.36", "root_name": "Jh\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 9.36", "blurb": "The ending of defilements happens due to the practice of absorption meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an9.37", "root_name": "\u0100nandasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 9.37", "blurb": "\u0100nanda exclaims how amazing it is that the Buddha has found a way to freedom while still experiencing the world. Questioned by the monk Ud\u0101y\u012b, \u0100nanda recounts a discussion on advanced meditation with the nun Ja\u1e6dilag\u0101hiy\u0101.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an9.38", "root_name": "Lok\u0101yatikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 9.38", "blurb": "Two brahmin cosmologists ask the Buddha to decide between competing claims as to whether the cosmos is infinite. Rejecting metaphysical claims, the Buddha says that there is no end of the world that can be reached by traveling; but without reaching the end of the world you can\u2019t be free of suffering.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an9.39", "root_name": "Dev\u0101surasa\u1e45g\u0101masutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 9.39", "blurb": "In the wars between gods and demons, they find safety only in their own fortress. Similarly, a mendicant finds safety in absorption.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an9.40", "root_name": "N\u0101gasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 9.40", "blurb": "A bull elephant, annoyed by living in the herd, goes off by himself. Similarly, a mendicant feeling crowded in a monastery goes off by themselves and happily meditates in seclusion.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an9.41", "root_name": "Tapussasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 9.41", "blurb": "The householder Tapussa reflects that it is renunciation that distinguishes lay from monastic. The Buddha responds by giving a long account of his practice of absorption before awakening.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

[{"uid": "sn48.115-124", "root_name": "Oghavagga", "translated_name": "Floods ", "acronym": "SN 48.115\u2013124", "blurb": null, "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: The main version of the Numbered or Incremental Discourses found in the Chinese canon is known as the Ekottarikāgama (Zengyi ahan jing, 增一阿含經), and has been tentatively ascribed to the Mahāsaṅghika school. It was translated by Gautama Saṅghadeva (瞿曇僧伽提婆), who also translated the Madhyamāgama, in CE 397. Consisting of 51 fascicles, it is organized into 52 chapters, containing a total of 451 sutras. Like the Pali Aṅguttara, it is arranged by numbered sets from one to eleven. However, despite the structural similarity, the contents diverge widely from the Pali. It contains relatively fewer parallels than the other āgama collections. In the Taishō edition of the Chinese canon, it is text number 125, located at T vol. 2, 549a.

[{"uid": "sn3.11", "root_name": "Sattaja\u1e6dilasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 3.11", "blurb": "A diverse group of ascetics passes by, and Pasenadi asks the Buddha if any of them are perfected ones. The Buddha says it is not easy for one such as Pasenadi to judge the spiritual achievements of others. Pasenadi reveals that the men are, in fact, his spies.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn3.12", "root_name": "Pa\u00f1car\u0101jasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 3.12", "blurb": "Five kings including Pasenadi are enjoying themselves and wonder which of the senses affords the highest pleasure. They ask the Buddha, who replies that it is subjective, depending on a persons preferences. Inspired, the laymen Candana\u1e45galika offers a verse in praise of the Buddha.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn3.13", "root_name": "Do\u1e47ap\u0101kasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 3.13", "blurb": "In what is probably the world\u2019s first weight loss diet, when Pasenadi shows up overweight and out of breath, the Buddha advises him to cut down his eating. He gives a verse to one of the king\u2019s attendants, and asks him to recite it whenever the king is eating.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn3.14", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamasa\u1e45g\u0101masutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 3.14", "blurb": "Pasenadi loses a battle against his nephew King Aj\u0101tasattu of Magadha.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn3.15", "root_name": "Dutiyasa\u1e45g\u0101masutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 3.15", "blurb": "In a battle subsequent to SN 3.14, Pasenadi defeats Aj\u0101tasattu and takes him prisoner. Acting compassionately, he confiscates Aj\u0101tasattu\u2019s military assets but releases him alive.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn3.16", "root_name": "Mallik\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 3.16", "blurb": "Pasenadi is disappointed to hear that Queen Mallik\u0101 has given birth to a daughter. But the Buddha consoles him, saying a woman may turn out better than a man.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn3.17", "root_name": "Appam\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 3.17", "blurb": "Pasenadi asks the Buddha if there is one thing that secures benefit both in this life and the next.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn3.18", "root_name": "Kaly\u0101\u1e47amittasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 3.18", "blurb": "In answer to Pasenadi\u2019s praise of good friendship, the Buddha recounts an earlier conversation with A\u0304nanda on the topic. He then goes on to say that when one has good friends, it is important to develop diligence.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn3.19", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamaaputtakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 3.19", "blurb": "A wealthy man dies childless, having not enjoyed his riches. The Buddha says that wealth should be properly enjoyed and shared.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn3.20", "root_name": "Dutiyaaputtakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 3.20", "blurb": "A wealthy man dies childless, having not enjoyed his riches. The Buddha tells of how in the time of a solitary Buddha of the past named Tagarasikhi\u0304, a householder made an offering but later regretted it.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Mindfulness Meditation” contains 104 discourses on the four kinds of mindfulness meditation (satipaṭṭhāna, otherwise known as the “foundations of mindfulness” or “establishments of mindfulness”). These are the body, feelings, mind, and principles. The last of these is translated in various ways, but a close reading of the texts in this chapter shows that it originally referred to the “principles” of causality underlying the process of meditation itself. These discourses on this fundamental topic are much less known than the longer “Discourse on Mindfulness Meditation” found in versions in MN 10 and DN 22; however, they are historically earlier than that late compilation. Where MN 10 emphasizes insight meditation, in this collection we frequently find mindfulness closely connected to absorption, as it is the factor of the path that leads directly to “right immersion”. Insight is mentioned only rarely. The root meaning of the term mindfulness (sati) is “memory”, and when used in meditation it refers to not “forgetting” one’s meditation, but keeping focus on the breath or other theme of meditation. This collection presents a range of perspectives on mindfulness meditation; one of its most memorable features is a series of similes or parables illustrating the practice. The partner of mindfulness (sati) is “situational awareness” (sampajañña, sometimes rendered as “clear comprehension”), which refers to keeping a broad awareness and understanding especially in daily activities.

blurb: Collections of “linked” or “connected” discourses and other related texts.
children: [{"uid": "sn", "root_name": "Sa\u1e41yuttanik\u0101ya", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses Collection ", "acronym": "SN", "blurb": "The \u201cLinked\u201d or \u201cConnected\u201d Discourses (Sa\u1e41yutta Nik\u0101ya, abbreviated SN) is a collection of over a thousand short discourses in the Pali canon. The word \u201clinked\u201d refers to the fact that the texts are collected and organized by topic. In most cases the organizing principle is a particular theme of Dhamma, for example, the five aggregates, dependent origination, the noble eightfold path, mindfulness meditation, or the four noble truths. This collection contains the most extensive range of texts on these core themes. In other cases chapters are organized according to the person or kind of person who speaks. This collection has a full parallel in the Sa\u1e41yukt\u0101gama (SA) of the Sarv\u0101stiv\u0101da school in Chinese translation. In addition, there are two partial collections in Chinese (SA-2 and SA-3) as well as a number of miscellaneous or fragmentary texts in Chinese, Sanskrit, and Tibetan. Much of the organizational structure of SN is shared with SA, suggesting that this structure preceded the split between these two collections.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2661}, {"uid": "sa", "root_name": "Sa\u1e41yukt\u0101gama (1st)", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses Compilation (1st) ", "acronym": "SA", "blurb": "The main version of the Linked Discourses found in the Chinese canon is known as the Sa\u1e41yukt\u0101gama (Za ahan jing, \u96dc\u963f\u542b\u7d93), and is believed to stem from a branch of the Sarv\u0101stiv\u0101din school. It was translated by Gu\u1e47abhadra (\u6c42\u90a3\u8dcb\u9640) and Baoyun (\u5bf6\u96f2) in CE 435\u2013436 at Waguan Monastery (\u74e6\u5b98\u5bfa,) Yangdu (\u694a\u90fd). Like the Pali Sa\u1e41yutta Nik\u0101ya, it contains over a thousand short suttas organized by topic. The texts, however, became disordered during the transmission in China, and an extraneous passage from a later life of Ashoka was mistakenly included. In the 20th century a series of scholars reconstructed the original sequence. The text as originally found is found in the Taish\u014d edition of the Chinese canon as sutra number 99 at T vol. 2, 1a.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": "SA", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 367}, {"uid": "sa-2", "root_name": "Sa\u1e41yukt\u0101gama (2nd)", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses Compilation (2nd) ", "acronym": "SA 2", "blurb": "A partial translation of the Sa\u1e41yukt\u0101gama (SA-2) was made between 385 and 431 by an anonymous translator. Known as the Shorter Sa\u1e41yukt\u0101gama (Bieyi za ahan jing, \u5225\u8b6f\u96dc\u963f\u542b\u7d93), it may stem from the M\u016blasarv\u0101stiv\u0101din school. It consists of 364 sutras in 16 fascicles. Most of the texts have parallels in Chinese and/or Pali, primarily in the Sag\u0101th\u0101vagga of the Sa\u1e41yutta. In the Taish\u014d edition of the Chinese canon, it is text number 100, located at T vol. 2, 374a.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": "SA-2", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 62}, {"uid": "sa-3", "root_name": "Sa\u1e41yukt\u0101gama (3rd)", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses Compilation (3rd) ", "acronym": "SA 3", "blurb": "A second partial translation of the Sa\u1e41yukt\u0101gama (SA-3) (\u96dc\u963f\u542b\u7d93) was made approximately CE 222\u2013280 by an anonymous translator and consists of 27 sutras in one fascicle. In the Taish\u014d edition of the Chinese canon, it is text number 101, located at T vol. 2, 493a.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": "SA-3", "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}, {"uid": "sa-ot", "root_name": "Other Sa\u1e41yukta S\u016btras", "translated_name": "Other Linked Discourses ", "acronym": "Other SA", "blurb": "22 shorter discourses that in the Taish\u014d edition of the Chinese canon have been gathered in the second volume, at s\u016btra numbers 102\u2013124, following the three Sa\u1e41yukt\u0101gama collections. These are miscellaneous translations of various discourses from the Sa\u1e41yutta, made at various times by various translators.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": "SA ot", "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}]

[{"uid": "ja521", "root_name": "Tesaku\u1e47aj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Three Birds ", "acronym": "Ja 521", "blurb": "\u201c\u2019Tis this I ask\u201d\u2014This story the Master, while dwelling at Jetavana, told by way of admonition to the king of Kosala. Now this king came to hear the preaching of the law and the Master addressed him in the following terms: \u201cA king, Sire, ought to rule his kingdom righteously, for whenever kings are unrighteous, then also are his officers unrighteous.\u201d And admonishing him in the right way as related in the Catukkanipata (4th Book) he pointed out the suffering and the blessing involved in following or abstaining from evil courses, and expounded in detail the misery resulting from sensual pleasures, comparing them to dreams and the like, saying, \u201cIn the case of these men,", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja522", "root_name": "Sarabha\u1e45gaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Archer Sarabha\u1e45ga ", "acronym": "Ja 522", "blurb": "\u201cBeringed and gallantly\u201d\u2014This was a story the Master, while dwelling in the Bamboo Grove, told concerning the death of the Elder, the Great Moggallana. The Elder Sariputta, after gaining the consent of the Tathagata when he was living at Jetavana, went and died in the village of Nala, in the very room where he was born.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja523", "root_name": "Alambus\u0101j\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Nymph Alambus\u0101 ", "acronym": "Ja 523", "blurb": "\u201cThen mighty Indra\u201d\u2014This story the Master, while residing at Jetavana, told about the temptation of a Brother by the wife of his unregenerate days. The subject-matter of the tale is related in full in the Indriya Birth. Now the Master asked the Brother, \u201cIs it true, Brother, that you were rendered discontented?\u201d \u201cIt is true, Reverend Sir.\u201d \u201cBy whom?\u201d \u201cBy my wife of former days.\u201d \u201cBrother,\u201d he said, \u201cthis woman wrought mischief for you: it was owing to her that you fell away from mystic meditation, and lay for three years in a lost and distracted condition, and on the recovery of your senses you uttered a great lamentation,\u201d and so saying he told him a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja524", "root_name": "Sa\u1e45khap\u0101laj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Dragon of Lake Sa\u1e45khap\u0101la ", "acronym": "Ja 524", "blurb": "\u201cOf comely presence\u201d\u2014This was a story told by the Master, while dwelling at Jetavana, with regard to the duties of holy days. Now on this occasion the Master, expressing approval of certain lay folk who kept holy days, said: \u201cWise men of old, giving up the great glory of the Naga world, observed holy days,\u201d and at their request he related a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja525", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37asutasomaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Shorter Tale of Prince Moonface the Scholar ", "acronym": "Ja 525", "blurb": "\u201cGood friends\u201d\u2014This story the Master while residing at Jetavana told concerning the perfect exercise of self-abnegation. The introductory story corresponds with that of the Mahanaradakassapa Birth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: Named after the first discourses, which deal with emptiness, this chapter presents less analytical and more narrative texts.
children: [{"uid": "mn121", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37asu\u00f1\u00f1atasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 121", "blurb": "The Buddha describes his own practice of the meditation on emptiness.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "mn122", "root_name": "Mah\u0101su\u00f1\u00f1atasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 122", "blurb": "A group of mendicants have taken to socializing too much, so the Buddha teaches on the importance of seclusion in order to enter fully into emptiness.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "mn123", "root_name": "Acchariyaabbhutasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 123", "blurb": "Venerable \u0100nanda is invited by the Buddha to speak on the Buddha\u2019s amazing qualities, and proceeds to list a series of apparently miraculous events accompanying his birth. The Buddha caps it off by explaining what he thinks is really amazing about himself.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "mn124", "root_name": "B\u0101kulasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 124", "blurb": "Venerable Bakkula, regarded as the healthiest of the mendicants, explains to an old friend his strict and austere practice. The unusual form of this discourse suggests it was added to the canon some time after the Buddha\u2019s death.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "mn125", "root_name": "Dantabh\u016bmisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 125", "blurb": "A young monk is unable to persuade a prince of the blessings of peace of mind. The Buddha offers similes based on training an elephant that would have been successful, as this was a field the prince was familiar with.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "mn126", "root_name": "Bh\u016bmijasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 126", "blurb": "Success in the spiritual life does not depend on any vows you may or may not make, but on whether you practice well.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "mn127", "root_name": "Anuruddhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 127", "blurb": "A lay person becomes confused when encouraged to develop the \u201climitless\u201d and \u201cexpansive\u201d liberations, and asks Venerable Anuruddha to explain whether they are the same or different.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "mn128", "root_name": "Upakkilesasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 128", "blurb": "A second discourse set at the quarrel of Kosambi, this depicts the Buddha, having failed to achieve reconciliation between the disputing mendicants, leaving the monastery. He spends time in the wilderness before encountering an inspiring community of practicing monks. There he discusses in detail obstacles to meditation that he encountered before awakening.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "mn129", "root_name": "B\u0101lapa\u1e47\u1e0ditasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 129", "blurb": "A fool suffers both in this life and the next, while the astute benefits in both respects.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "mn130", "root_name": "Devad\u016btasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 130", "blurb": "Expanding on the previous, this discourse contains the most detailed descriptions of the horrors of hell.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "sn42.1", "root_name": "Ca\u1e47\u1e0dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 42.1", "blurb": "A headman known for his aggressive nature approaches the Buddha and asks how to give up irritability. The Buddha points out that such reactions are fueled by greed, hate, and delusion.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn42.2", "root_name": "T\u0101lapu\u1e6dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 42.2", "blurb": "Talapu\u1e6da the head of a troupe of performers asks the Buddha whether the belief that performers have a good rebirth is correct. The Buddha tries to dissuade him, but ultimately reveals that by inciting lust they head to a bad rebirth. Talapu\u1e6da is distressed and asks to ordain.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn42.3", "root_name": "Yodh\u0101j\u012bvasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 42.3", "blurb": "Yodha\u0304j\u0131\u0304va the professional warrior asks the Buddha whether the belief that warriors have a good rebirth is correct. The Buddha tries to dissuade him, but ultimately reveals that by following the way of violence they head to a bad rebirth. Yodha\u0304j\u0131\u0304va is distressed and takes refuge.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn42.4", "root_name": "Hatth\u0101rohasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 42.4", "blurb": "Hattha\u0304roha the elephant warrior asks the Buddha whether the belief that warriors have a good rebirth is correct. The Buddha tries to dissuade him, but ultimately reveals that by following the way of violence they head to a bad rebirth. Hattha\u0304roha is distressed and takes refuge.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn42.5", "root_name": "Ass\u0101rohasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 42.5", "blurb": "Assa\u0304roha the cavalry warrior asks the Buddha whether the belief that warriors have a good rebirth is correct. The Buddha tries to dissuade him, but ultimately reveals that by following the way of violence they head to a bad rebirth. Yodha\u0304j\u0131\u0304va is distressed and asks to ordain.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn42.6", "root_name": "Asibandhakaputtasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 42.6", "blurb": "The chief Asibandhakaputta asks whether the rituals advocated by the western brahmins can bring a person to heaven. The Buddha asserts that only good deeds can take you to a good rebirth, and rituals have no effect.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn42.7", "root_name": "Khett\u016bpamasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 42.7", "blurb": "The chief Asibandhakaputta asks the Buddha why, if he has equal compassion for all, he teaches some more than others. The Buddha answers with a simile of a field: a farmer knows to put most of their effort into the fertile land. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn42.8", "root_name": "Sa\u1e45khadhamasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 42.8", "blurb": "The Buddha asks the chief Asibandhakaputta, a Jain, how Mah\u0101v\u012bra the Jain leader teaches his followers. He replies that you go to a rebirth depending on what you usually do. But the Buddha points out that even a killer only spends a small amount of time actually killing. The Buddha\u2019s approach is to point out that deeds have results, and to encourage the abandoing of bad deeds and the adoption of good deeds.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn42.9", "root_name": "Kulasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 42.9", "blurb": "Mah\u0101v\u012bra asks Asibandhakaputta to refute the Buddha on behalf of the Jains. He suggests to try to trap the Buddha with a dilemma: he claims to have compassion for householders, yet visits them with a large Sa\u1e45gha in a time of scarcity. But the Buddha says no family has been harmed from this.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn42.10", "root_name": "Ma\u1e47ic\u016b\u1e37akasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 42.10", "blurb": "Several members of the king\u2019s retinue criticize the Buddhist mendicants for accepting offerings of money. Chief Ma\u1e47icu\u0304\u1e37aka is among them, and he visits the Buddha to find out the truth. The Buddha categorically denies the accusation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn42.11", "root_name": "Bhadrakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 42.11", "blurb": "The chief Bhadraka asks the Buddha about the origin and ending of suffering, and the Buddha points out that a loss among Bhadraka\u2019s own community would cause him suffering, due to his attachment.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn42.12", "root_name": "R\u0101siyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 42.12", "blurb": "The chief Ra\u0304siya asks whether the Buddha completely rejects all forms of asceticism. The Buddha denies that this is the case, and explains what he means by the middle way in a lengthy disquisition, covering useful and useless forms of asceticism.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn42.13", "root_name": "P\u0101\u1e6daliyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 42.13", "blurb": "The chief Pa\u0304\u1e6daliya asks whether the Buddha knows magic. He says he does\u2014but that does not make him a magician.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

translated_name: Linked Discourses on the Eightfold Path
blurb: The “Linked Discourses on the Path” contains 180 discourses on the noble eightfold path, the “middle way” which is the first and most important of all the Buddha’s teachings on the path of spiritual practice. It is mentioned in the first discourse as the fourth noble truth. It begins with “right view” which is initially an accurate conceptual understanding, based on hearing the teachings and reflecting on their meaning. The second factor is right intention, referring to the attitude or motivation that shapes practice. Next come three factors dealing with ethical conduct. And the final three factors directly deal with meditation. Once all these factors are mature, “right immersion” or the four absorptions (jhānas) enables the initial conceptual understanding to ascend to a higher level of insight and letting go. While this and subsequent chapters contains many substantive discourses on this theme, the large number of discourses is mainly attributable to the formulaic “repetition series” which append each chapter.

blurb: The “Numbered” or “Numerical” Discourses are usually known as Aṅguttara Nikāya in Pali, abbreviated AN. However, the Pali tradition also knows the form Ekottara (“one-up” or “incremental”), and this is the form usually found in the northern collections. These collections organize texts in numbered sets, from one to eleven. Compared to the other nikāyas, they are more oriented to the lay community. The Ekottarikāgama (EA) in Chinese is a highly unusual text, which features a range of variations within itself when it comes even to basic doctrines. It shares considerably less in common with the Pali Aṅguttara than the other collections do with their counterparts. In addition, there is a partial Ekottarikāgama in Chinese, as well as a variety of individual discourses and fragments in Chinese and Sanskrit.

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on the Elements” contains 39 discourses on various factors classified as “elements” (dhātu). In Buddhism, the term “element” is applied to a range of phenomena, most commonly the main material properties of earth, water, fire and air. Here, however, these four elements play only a small role, and much of the text is devoted to analysis of the perceptual process, and to various character traits. The relation or dependence of elements on each other is a major theme, and this chapter can be seen as an appendix to the chapter on causality.

blurb: Twelve longer poems that expand into sometimes legendary narrative. The first two discourses and the Nalaka Sutta offer early glimpses at crucial episodes in the Buddha’s life. While some of these poems are found elsewhere in the canon, the Dvayatānupassanā offers a unique perspective on dependent origination and other topics typically found in prose texts.

The sutta then gives a graphic description of the sufferings awaiting him there.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "snp3.11", "root_name": "N\u0101lakasutta", "translated_name": "The Sages Asita and N\u0101laka ", "acronym": "Snp 3.11", "blurb": "A sutta in two parts. blurb: A diverse chapter including biography, non-violence, not-self, and an influential teaching on the progress of meditation.
children: [{"uid": "mn21", "root_name": "Kakac\u016bpamasutta", "translated_name": "The Simile of the Saw ", "acronym": "MN 21", "blurb": "A discourse full of vibrant and memorable similes, on the importance of patience and love even when faced with abuse and criticism. The Buddha finishes with the simile of the saw, one of the most memorable similes found in the discourses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn22", "root_name": "Alagadd\u016bpamasutta", "translated_name": "The Simile of the Snake ", "acronym": "MN 22", "blurb": "One of the monks denies that prohibited conduct is really a problem. The monks and then the Buddha subject him to an impressive dressing down. The Buddha compares someone who understands only the letter of the teachings to someone who grabs a snake by the tail, and also invokes the famous simile of the raft.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "mn23", "root_name": "Vammikasutta", "translated_name": "The Ant-Hill ", "acronym": "MN 23", "blurb": "In a curious discourse laden with evocative imagery, a deity presents a riddle to a mendicant, who seeks an answer from the Buddha.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn24", "root_name": "Rathavin\u012btasutta", "translated_name": "Prepared Chariots ", "acronym": "MN 24", "blurb": "Venerable S\u0101riputta seeks a dialog with an esteemed monk, Venerable Pu\u1e47\u1e47a Mant\u0101niputta, and they discuss the stages of purification.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn25", "root_name": "Niv\u0101pasutta", "translated_name": "Fodder ", "acronym": "MN 25", "blurb": "The Buddha compares getting trapped by M\u0101ra with a deer getting caught in a snare, illustrating the ever more complex strategies employed by hunter and hunted.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn26", "root_name": "P\u0101sar\u0101sisutta", "translated_name": "The Noble Search ", "acronym": "MN 26", "blurb": "This is one of the most important biographical discourses, telling the Buddha\u2019s experiences from leaving home to realizing awakening. Throughout, he was driven by the imperative to fully escape from rebirth and suffering.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn27", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37ahatthipadopamasutta", "translated_name": "The Shorter Elephant\u2019s Footprint Simile ", "acronym": "MN 27", "blurb": "The Buddha cautions against swift conclusions about a teacher\u2019s spiritual accomplishments, comparing it to the care a tracker would use when tracking elephants. He presents the full training of a monastic.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn28", "root_name": "Mah\u0101hatthipadopamasutta", "translated_name": "The Longer Simile of the Elephant\u2019s Footprint ", "acronym": "MN 28", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta gives an elaborate demonstration of how, just as any footprint can fit inside an elephant\u2019s, all the Buddha\u2019s teaching can fit inside the four noble truths. This offers an overall template for organizing the Buddha\u2019s teachings.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "mn29", "root_name": "Mah\u0101s\u0101ropamasutta", "translated_name": "The Longer Simile of the Heartwood ", "acronym": "MN 29", "blurb": "Following the incident with Devadatta, the Buddha cautions the mendicants against becoming complacent with superficial benefits of spiritual life and points to liberation as the true heart of the teaching.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "mn30", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37as\u0101ropamasutta", "translated_name": "The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood ", "acronym": "MN 30", "blurb": "Similar to the previous. After the incident with Devadatta, the Buddha cautions the mendicants against becoming complacent and points to liberation as the true heart of the teaching.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}]

children: [{"uid": "sn24.19", "root_name": "V\u0101tasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 24.19", "blurb": "The Buddha mentions a strange view to the effect that all changing phenomena of the world are really still and motionless. Such a view arises from grasping to the five aggregates, which are suffering. But by seeing the aggregates as impermanent, such a view is given up.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn24.20-35", "root_name": "Eta\u1e41mam\u0101disutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 24.20\u201335", "blurb": "The various views arise from grasping to the five aggregates, which are suffering. But by seeing the aggregates as impermanent, these views are given up.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn24.36", "root_name": "Nevahotinanahotisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 24.36", "blurb": "The view that the Realized One neither exists nor does not exist after death arises from grasping to the five aggregates, which are suffering. [{"uid": "ja211", "root_name": "Somadattaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Farmer\u2019s Son Somadatta ", "acronym": "Ja 211", "blurb": "\u201cAll the year long never ceasing\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, about Elder Laludayi, or Udayi the Simpleton.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja212", "root_name": "Ucchi\u1e6d\u1e6dhabhattaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "A Meal of Leavings ", "acronym": "Ja 212", "blurb": "\u201cHot at top\u201d\u2014This is a story told by the Master while at Jetavana, about one who hankered after a lost wife. The Brother in question was asked by the Master if he really was lovesick. Yes, he said, so he was. \u201cFor whom?\u201d was the next question. \u201cFor my late wife.\u201d \u201cBrother,\u201d the Master said, \u201cthis same woman in former days was wicked, and made you eat the leavings of her paramour.\u201d Then he told this story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja213", "root_name": "Bharuj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "King Bharu ", "acronym": "Ja 213", "blurb": "\u201cThe king of Bharu\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while staying at Jetavana, about the king of Kosala.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja214", "root_name": "Pu\u1e47\u1e47anad\u012bj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Who Drinks When the River\u2019s Full ", "acronym": "Ja 214", "blurb": "\u201cThat which can drink\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while staying at Jetavana, about perfect wisdom.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja215", "root_name": "Kacchapaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Tortoise ", "acronym": "Ja 215", "blurb": "\u201cThe Tortoise needs must speak\u201d\u2014This is a story told by the Master while staying in Jetavana, about Kokalika. The circumstances which gave rise to it will be set forth under the Mahatakkari Birth. Here again the Master said: \u201cThis is not the only time, Brethren, that Kokalika has been ruined by talking; it was the same before.\u201d And then he told the story as follows.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja216", "root_name": "Macchaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Fish ", "acronym": "Ja 216", "blurb": "\u201c\u2019Tis not the fire\u201d\u2014This story the Master told during a stay in Jetavana, about one who hankered after a former wife. The Master asked this Brother, \u201cIs it true, Brother, what I hear, that you are lovesick?\u201d \u201cYes, Sir.\u201d \u201cFor whom?\u201d \u201cFor my late wife.\u201d Then the Master said to him: \u201cThis wife, Brother, has been the mischief to you. Long ago by her means you came near being spitted and roasted for food, but wise men saved your life.\u201d Then he told a tale of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja217", "root_name": "Segguj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Innocent Daughter Seggu ", "acronym": "Ja 217", "blurb": "\u201cAll the world\u2019s on pleasure bent\u201d\u2014This story the Master told, while dwelling at Jetavana, about a greengrocer who was a lay-brother.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja218", "root_name": "K\u016b\u1e6dav\u0101\u1e47ijaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Cheating Merchant ", "acronym": "Ja 218", "blurb": "\u201cWell planned indeed!\u201d\u2014 This story the Master told while staying in Jetavana, about a dishonest trader.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja219", "root_name": "Garahitaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Despised ", "acronym": "Ja 219", "blurb": "\u201cThe gold is mine\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Jetavana, about a brother who was downcast and discontent.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja220", "root_name": "Dhammadhajaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Chaplain Named Banner of the Teaching ", "acronym": "Ja 220", "blurb": "\u201cYou look as though\u201d\u2014This was told by the Master while staying at the Bamboo Grove, about attempts to murder him. On this occasion, as before, the Master said, \u201cThis is not the first time Devadatta has tried to murder me and has not even frightened me. He did the same before.\u201d And he told this story.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "sn35.134", "root_name": "Devadahasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.134", "blurb": "Not all mendicants have completed their work with regards to the six senses, but some of them have.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.135", "root_name": "Kha\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.135", "blurb": "The Buddha speaks of the hell named the \u201csix senses\u201d where all one experiences is sheer pain and unpleasantness.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.136", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamar\u016bp\u0101r\u0101masutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.136", "blurb": "Gods and humans take delight in the six sense, but the Realized One does not. This teaching is illustrated with a long series of verses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.137", "root_name": "Dutiyar\u016bp\u0101r\u0101masutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.137", "blurb": "Gods and humans take delight in the six sense, but the Realized One does not.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.138", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamanatumh\u0101kasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.138", "blurb": "Let go of what is not yours: the six interior sense fields. You wouldn\u2019t be upset if someone took the grass and sticks from the monastery grounds, so why worry over the senses?", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.139", "root_name": "Dutiyanatumh\u0101kasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.139", "blurb": "Let go of what is not yours: the six exterior sense fields. You wouldn\u2019t be upset if someone took the grass and sticks from the monastery grounds, so why worry over the senses?", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.140", "root_name": "Ajjhattaaniccahetusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.140", "blurb": "Since the causes of the six interior sense fields are impermanent, how can the senses be permanent?", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.141", "root_name": "Ajjhattadukkhahetusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.141", "blurb": "Since the causes of the six interior sense fields are suffering, how can the senses be free of suffering?", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.142", "root_name": "Ajjhatt\u0101nattahetusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.142", "blurb": "Since the causes of the six interior sense fields are not-self, how can the senses be self?", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.143", "root_name": "B\u0101hir\u0101niccahetusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.143", "blurb": "Since the causes of the six exterior sense fields are impermanent, how can the senses be permanent?", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.144", "root_name": "B\u0101hiradukkhahetusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.144", "blurb": "Since the causes of the six exterior sense "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn35.145", "root_name": "B\u0101hir\u0101nattahetusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.145", "blurb": "Since the causes of the six exterior sense translated_name: The Chapter on the Ceremony of Descent
children: [{"uid": "an10.113", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamaadhammasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.113", "blurb": "One should understand what is the teaching and what is contrary to the teaching, in brief.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an10.114", "root_name": "Dutiyaadhammasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.114", "blurb": "One should understand what is the teaching and what is contrary to the teaching, in detail.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an10.115", "root_name": "Tatiyaadhammasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.115", "blurb": "One should understand what is the teaching and what is contrary to the teaching. After hearing this in brief from the Buddha, the mendicants seek a detailed answer from \u0100nanda.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an10.116", "root_name": "Ajitasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.116", "blurb": "The wanderer Ajita informs the Buddha that a philosopher has proposed 500 cases for knowing that and argument has been won or lost. The Buddha asks the mendicants about these.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an10.117", "root_name": "Sa\u1e45g\u0101ravasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.117", "blurb": "The wrong path is the near shore where most people dwell; the right path is the far shore, where few have crossed over.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an10.118", "root_name": "Orimat\u012brasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.118", "blurb": "The wrong path is the near shore where most people dwell; the right path is the far shore, where few have crossed over.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an10.119", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamapaccoroha\u1e47\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.119", "blurb": "The Buddha sees J\u0101\u1e47usso\u1e47\u012b observing the brahmanical ceremony of \u201cdescent\u201d. The Buddha teaches his revised version.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an10.120", "root_name": "Dutiyapaccoroha\u1e47\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.120", "blurb": "The Buddha teaches his revised version of the brahmanical ceremony of \u201cdescent\u201d to the mendicants.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an10.121", "root_name": "Pubba\u1e45gamasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.121", "blurb": "As the dawn is the forerunner of the sunrise, right view is the forerunner of the path.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an10.122", "root_name": "\u0100savakkhayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.122", "blurb": "The ten path factors lead to the end of the defilements.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]
