The Buddha explains it as the cessation of the aggregates.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

translated_name: When Kaccāni Made a Death-Offering to Dhamma
children: [{"uid": "ja417", "root_name": "Kacc\u0101nij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "When Kacc\u0101ni Made a Death-Offering to Dhamma ", "acronym": "Ja 417", "blurb": "\u201cRobed in white\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale while dwelling at Jetavana, concerning a man who supported his mother.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja418", "root_name": "A\u1e6d\u1e6dhasaddaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Eight Sounds ", "acronym": "Ja 418", "blurb": "\u201cA pool so deep\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning an indistinguishable terrific sound heard at midnight by the king of Kosala. The occasion is like that already described in the Lohakumbhi Birth. At this time however, when the king said, \u201cLord, what does the hearing of these sounds import to me?\u201d the Master answered, \u201cGreat king, be not afraid: no danger shall befal you owing to these sounds: such terrible indistinguishable sounds have not been heard by you alone: kings of old also heard like sounds, and meant to follow the advice of brahmins to offer in sacrifice four animals of each species, but after hearing what wise men had to say, they set free the animals collected for sacrifice and caused proclamation by drum against all slaughter\u201d: and at the king\u2019s request, he told the old tale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja419", "root_name": "Sulas\u0101j\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Courtesan Sulas\u0101 ", "acronym": "Ja 419", "blurb": "\u201cHere is a golden necklace\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning a female servant of Anathapindika.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja420", "root_name": "Suma\u1e45galaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Park-Keeper Suma\u1e45gala ", "acronym": "Ja 420", "blurb": "\u201cConscious of an angry frown\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale while dwelling at Jetavana, concerning the admonition of a king. On this occasion the Master, at the king\u2019s request, told the tale of old.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja421", "root_name": "Ga\u1e45gam\u0101laj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Royal Barber Ga\u1e45gam\u0101la ", "acronym": "Ja 421", "blurb": "\u201cThe earth\u2019s like coals\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning the keeping of the weekly holy days. One day the Master was addressing the lay-brethren who were keeping the holy days and said, \u201cLay-brethren, your conduct is good; when men keep the holy days they should give alms, keep the moral precepts, never show anger, feel kindness and do the duties of the day: wise men of old gained great glory from even a partial keeping of the holy days: \u201c and at their request he told the tale of old.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja422", "root_name": "Cetiyaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "How the King of Ceti Told the First Lie ", "acronym": "Ja 422", "blurb": "\u201cInjured Right can injure sorely\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale while dwelling at Jetavana, concerning Devadatta\u2019s being swallowed up by the earth. On that day they were discussing in the Hall of Truth how Devadatta had spoken falsely, had sunk into the ground and become destined to the hell Avici. The Master came and, hearing the subject of their talk, said, \u201cThis is not the first time he sank into the earth,\u201d and so he told the tale of old.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja423", "root_name": "Indriyaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Senses ", "acronym": "Ja 423", "blurb": "\u201cWho through desire\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning temptation by the wife of one\u2019s former days.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja424", "root_name": "\u0100dittaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "When Your House is Burning Down ", "acronym": "Ja 424", "blurb": "\u201cWhate\u2019er a man can save\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning an incomparable gift. The incomparable gift must be described in full from the commentary on the Mahagovindasutta. On the day after that on which it had been given, they were talking of it in the Hall of Truth, \u201cSirs, the Kosala king after examination found the proper field of merit, and gave the great gift to the assembly with Buddha at its head.\u201d The Master came and was told what the subject of their talk was as they sat together: he said, \u201cBrethren, it is not strange that the king after examination has undertaken great gifts to the supreme field of merit: wise men of old also after examination gave such gifts,\u201d and so he told a tale of old.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja425", "root_name": "A\u1e6d\u1e6dh\u0101naj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Impossible ", "acronym": "Ja 425", "blurb": "\u201cMake Ganges calm\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning a backsliding Brother. The Master asked him, \u201cIs the story true, Brother, that you are backsliding?\u201d \u201cYes, lord.\u201d \u201cWhat is the cause?\u201d \u201cThe power of desire.\u201d \u201cBrother, womankind are ungrateful, treacherous, untrustworthy: of old wise men could not satisfy a woman, even by giving her a thousand pieces a day: and one day when she did not get the thousand pieces she had them taken by the neck and cast out: so ungrateful are womankind: do not fall into the power of desire for such a cause,\u201d and so he told an old tale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja426", "root_name": "D\u012bpij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Panther ", "acronym": "Ja 426", "blurb": "\u201cHow fares it with you\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning a certain she-goat.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "ja191", "root_name": "Ruhakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Priest Named Ruddy ", "acronym": "Ja 191", "blurb": "\u201cEven a broken bowstring\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling in Jetavana, about temptation arising from a former wife. The circumstances will be explained in the Eighth Book, in the Indriya J\u0101taka. Then the Master said to this brother, \u201cThat is a woman who does you harm. In former times, too, she put you to the blush before the king and his whole court, and gave you good reason to leave your home.\u201d And he told an old-world tale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja192", "root_name": "Sirik\u0101\u1e37aka\u1e47\u1e47ij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Lucky Unlucky ", "acronym": "Ja 192", "blurb": "\u201cEven though women may be fair\u201d\u2014This story will be given in the Maha-ummagga J\u0101taka", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja193", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37apadumaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Prince Lotus ", "acronym": "Ja 193", "blurb": "\u201c\u2019Tis I\u2014no other\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana about a backsliding brother. The circumstances will be explained in the Ummadanti Birth. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja194", "root_name": "Ma\u1e47icoraj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Jewel Thief ", "acronym": "Ja 194", "blurb": "\u201cYe gods are here\u201d\u2014This story the Master told during a stay in Veluvana, how Devadatta tried to kill hips. Hearing that Devadatta went about to kill him, he said, \u201cBrethren, this is not the only time that Devadatta has been trying to kill me; he tried to do so before, and failed.\u201d Then he told them this story.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja195", "root_name": "Pabbat\u016bpattharaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Sheltered by a Hill ", "acronym": "Ja 195", "blurb": "\u201cA happy lake\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, about the king of Kosala.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja196", "root_name": "Val\u0101hakassaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Flying Horse ", "acronym": "Ja 196", "blurb": "\u201cThey who will neglect\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while staying in Jetavana, about a Brother who had become a backslider.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja197", "root_name": "Mitt\u0101mittaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Friends and Enemies ", "acronym": "Ja 197", "blurb": "\u201cHe smiles not\u201d\u2014This story the Master told whilst dwelling at Savatthi, about a certain Brother.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja198", "root_name": "R\u0101dhaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "R\u0101dha the Parrot ", "acronym": "Ja 198", "blurb": "\u201cI come, my son\u201d\u2014This story the Master told whilst living at Jetavana, about a brother who was a backslider", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja199", "root_name": "Gahapatij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Householder ", "acronym": "Ja 199", "blurb": "\u201cI like not this\u201d\u2014This story the Master told, also about a backsliding Brother, during a sojourn in Jetavana, and in the course of his address he said, \u201cWomankind can never be kept right; somehow or other they will sin and trick their husbands.\u201d And then he told the following story.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja200", "root_name": "S\u0101dhus\u012blaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Good is Virtue ", "acronym": "Ja 200", "blurb": "\u201cOne is good\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, about a brahmin.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "ja51", "root_name": "Mah\u0101s\u012blavaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "King Great Morality ", "acronym": "Ja 51", "blurb": "\u201cToil on, my brother.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a Brother who had given up all earnest effort. Being asked by the Master whether the report was true that he was a backslider, the Brother said it was true. \u201cHow can you, Brother,\u201d said the Master, \u201cgrow cold in so saving a faith? Even when the wise and good of bygone days had lost their kingdom, yet so undaunted was their resolution that in the end they won back their sovereignty.\u201d And so saying, he told this story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja52", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37ajanakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Shorter Tale of King Janaka ", "acronym": "Ja 52", "blurb": "\u201cToil on, my brother.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about another backsliding Brother. All the incidents that are to be related here, will be given in the Maha-janaka J\u0101taka.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja53", "root_name": "Pu\u1e47\u1e47ap\u0101tij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Full Cup ", "acronym": "Ja 53", "blurb": "\u201cWhat? Leave untasted.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about some drugged liquor.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja54", "root_name": "Ki\u1e41phalaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Tree Named What-fruit ", "acronym": "Ja 54", "blurb": "\u201cWhen near a village.\u201d\u2014This was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a lay brother who was skilled in the knowledge of fruits. It appears that a certain squire of Savatthi had invited the Brotherhood with the Buddha at their head, and had seated them in his pleasaunce, where they were regaled with rice-gruel and cakes. Afterwards he bade his gardener go round with the Brethren and give mangoes and other kinds of fruits to their Reverences. In obedience to orders, the man walked about the grounds with the Brethren, and could tell by a single glance up at the tree what fruit was green, what nearly ripe, and what quite ripe, and so on. And what he said was always found true. So the Brethren came to the Buddha and mentioned how expert the gardener was, and how, whilst himself standing on the ground, he could accurately tell the condition of the hanging fruit. \u201cBrethren,\u201d said the Master, \u201cthis gardener is not the only one who has had knowledge of fruits. A like knowledge was shewn by the wise and good of former days also.\u201d And so saying, he told this story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja55", "root_name": "Pa\u00f1c\u0101vudhaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Five Weapons ", "acronym": "Ja 55", "blurb": "\u201cWhen no Attachment.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a Brother who had given up all earnest effort.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja56", "root_name": "Ka\u00f1canakkhandhaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "A Mass of Gold ", "acronym": "Ja 56", "blurb": "\u201cWhen gladness.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Savatthi, about a certain Brother. Tradition says that through hearing the Master preach a young gentleman of Savatthi gave his heart to the precious Faith and became a Brother. His teachers and masters proceeded to instruct him in the whole of the Ten Precepts of Morality, one after the other, expounded to him the Short, the Medium, and the Long Moralities, set forth the Morality which rests on self-restraint according to the Patimokkha, the Morality which rests on self-restraint as to the Senses, the Morality which rests on a blameless walk of life, the Morality which relates to the way a Brother may use the Requisites. Thought the young beginner, \u201cThere is a tremendous lot of this Morality; and I shall undoubtedly fail to fulfil all I have vowed. Yet what is the good of being a brother at all, if one cannot keep the rules of Morality? My best course is to go back to the world, take a wife and rear children, living a life of almsgiving and other good works.\u201d So he told his superiors what he thought, saying that he proposed to return to the lower state of a layman, and wished to hand back his bowl and robes. \u201cWell, if it be so with you,\u201d said they, \u201cat least take leave of the Buddha before you go;\u201d and they brought the young man before the Master in the Hall of Truth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja57", "root_name": "V\u0101narindaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Monkey King ", "acronym": "Ja 57", "blurb": "\u201cWhoso, O monkey-king.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master, while at the Bamboo-grove, about Devadatta\u2019s going about to kill him. Being informed of Devadatta\u2019s murderous intent, the Master said, \u201cThis is not the first time, Brethren, that Devadatta has gone about seeking to kill me; he did just the same in bygone days, but failed to work his wicked will.\u201d And so saying, he told this story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja58", "root_name": "Tayodhammaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Three Qualities ", "acronym": "Ja 58", "blurb": "\u201cWhoso, like you.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at the Bamboo-grove also upon the subject of going about to kill.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja59", "root_name": "Bheriv\u0101dakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Drummer ", "acronym": "Ja 59", "blurb": "\u201cGo not too far.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a certain self-willed Brother. Asked by the Master whether the report was true that he was self-willed, the Brother said it was true. \u201cThis is net the first time, Brother,\u201d said the Master, \u201cthat you have shewn yourself self-willed; you were just the same in bygone times as well.\u201d And so saying, he told this story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja60", "root_name": "Sa\u1e45khadhamaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Conch-blower ", "acronym": "Ja 60", "blurb": "\u201cGo not too far.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about another self-willed person.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "ja151", "root_name": "R\u0101jov\u0101daj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Kingly Advice ", "acronym": "Ja 151", "blurb": "\u201cRough to the rough\u201d\u2014This story the Master told whilst he was living in Jetavana, to explain how a king was taught a lesson.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja152", "root_name": "Si\u1e45g\u0101laj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Jackal ", "acronym": "Ja 152", "blurb": "\u201cWho rashly undertakes\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while staying in his gabled chamber, about a barber who lived at Vesali.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja153", "root_name": "S\u016bkaraj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Boar ", "acronym": "Ja 153", "blurb": "\u201cYou are a fourfoot\u201d\u2014This is a story told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a certain Elder well stricken in years.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja154", "root_name": "Uragaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Snake ", "acronym": "Ja 154", "blurb": "\u201cConcealed within a stone\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Jetavana, about a soldiers\u2019 quarrel.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja155", "root_name": "Bhaggaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Tale of Gagga ", "acronym": "Ja 155", "blurb": "\u201cGagga, live an hundred years\u201d\u2014This story the Master told when he was staying in the monastery made by King Pasenadi in front of Jetavana; it was about a sneeze which he gave.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja156", "root_name": "Al\u012bnacittaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Prince Braveheart ", "acronym": "Ja 156", "blurb": "\u201cPrince Winheart once upon a time\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Jetavana, about a fainthearted Brother. The circumstances will be set forth in the Samvara Birth in the eleventh Book. When the Master asked this Brother if he really were fainthearted, as was said, he replied, \u201cYes, Blessed One.\u201d To which the Master said, \u201cWhat, Brother! in former days did you not gain supremacy over the kingdom of Benares, twelve leagues either way, and give it to a baby boy, like a lump of flesh and nothing more, and all this just by perseverance! And now that you have embraced this great salvation, are you to lose heart and faint?\u201d And he told a story of olden days.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja157", "root_name": "Gu\u1e47aj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Favors ", "acronym": "Ja 157", "blurb": "\u201cThe strong will always have their way\u201d\u2014This was told by the Master whilst at Jetavana how Elder Amanda received a present of a thousand robes. The Elder had been preaching to the ladies of the king of Kosala\u2019s palace as described above in the Mahasara Birth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja158", "root_name": "Suhanuj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Tale of Strongjaw ", "acronym": "Ja 158", "blurb": "\u201cBirds of a feather\u201d\u2014This story the Master told whilst at Jetavana, about two hot-tempered Brothers.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja159", "root_name": "Moraj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Peacock ", "acronym": "Ja 159", "blurb": "\u201cThere he rises, king all-seeing,\u201d etc.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja160", "root_name": "Vin\u012blaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Goose Named Livid-blue ", "acronym": "Ja 160", "blurb": "\u201cAs yonder king goes galloping\u201d\u2014This story the Master told during a sojourn in Veluvana, how Devadatta imitated the Buddha.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

Meanwhile, the followers of Todeyya complain about the King.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an4.188", "root_name": "Upakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.188", "blurb": "If you criticize someone, you should have a good reason.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an4.189", "root_name": "Sacchikara\u1e47\u012byasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.189", "blurb": "Different things are realized in different ways.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an4.190", "root_name": "Uposathasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.190", "blurb": "On the Uposatha night, the Buddha praises monks of great spiritual attainments in the Sa\u1e45gha.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "sn14.30", "root_name": "Catudh\u0101tusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 14.30", "blurb": "The four material elements of earth, water, heat, and air. Note that \u201cair\u201d is close in meaning to \u201cwind\u201d.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn14.31", "root_name": "Pubbesambodhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 14.31", "blurb": "Before his awakening the Buddha saw the gratification, the drawback, and the escape in the four material elements.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn14.32", "root_name": "Acari\u1e41sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 14.32", "blurb": "The Buddha set out to discover the gratification, the drawback, and the escape in the four material elements, and found it.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn14.33", "root_name": "Noceda\u1e41sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 14.33", "blurb": "Each of the three aspects of the four material elements performs its own function. Gratification stimulates desire; drawbacks lead to disillusionment, while escape opens the possibility of freedom.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn14.34", "root_name": "Ekantadukkhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 14.34", "blurb": "If the material elements were solely painful, beings would not get attached. If they were solely pleasurable, it would be impossible to become detached. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn14.35", "root_name": "Abhinandasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 14.35", "blurb": "When you seek pleasure in the material elements, you seek pleasure in suffering.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn14.36", "root_name": "Upp\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 14.36", "blurb": "The arising of the material elements is the arising of suffering.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn14.37", "root_name": "Sama\u1e47abr\u0101hma\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 14.37", "blurb": "One who does not understand the four material elements is no true ascetic.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn14.38", "root_name": "Dutiyasama\u1e47abr\u0101hma\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 14.38", "blurb": "One who does not understand the four material elements is no true ascetic.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn14.39", "root_name": "Tatiyasama\u1e47abr\u0101hma\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 14.39", "blurb": "One who does not understand the four material elements is no true ascetic.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

translated_name: The Chapter on a Lay Follower
children: [{"uid": "sn7.11", "root_name": "Kasibh\u0101radv\u0101jasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 7.11", "blurb": "A brahmin farmer criticizes the Buddha for failing to produce food, merely living off the work of others. But the Buddha shows that his true work is spiritual.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn7.12", "root_name": "Udayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 7.12", "blurb": "A brahmin complains when the Buddha visits for alms again and again. The Buddha takes the chance to point out that all natural phenomena repeat in cycles, and only an awakened one escapes the cycle.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn7.13", "root_name": "Devahitasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 7.13", "blurb": "The Buddha is ill and sends his attendant monk Upav\u0101\u1e47a to fetch some hot water. A brahmin gives him not just water, but also molasses to ease his stomach. Later the brahmin visits the Buddha to discuss generosity.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn7.14", "root_name": "Mah\u0101s\u0101lasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 7.14", "blurb": "A brahmin in shabby clothes has been kicked out of his home by ungrateful sons. The Buddha gives him a verse to recite in the village council, comparing his faithless sons to his trusty wooden staff. Ashamed, the sons take back their father, bathe and dress him.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn7.15", "root_name": "M\u0101natthaddhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 7.15", "blurb": "A stuck-up brahmin listening to the Buddha teach is awestruck when the Buddha appears to read his mind. To the surprise of the crowd, he bows and kisses the Buddha\u2019s feet. The Buddha tells him to take his seat, and they exchange verses on the topic of conceit.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn7.16", "root_name": "Paccan\u012bkasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 7.16", "blurb": "A brahmin who loves to contradict everyone approaches the Buddha thinking to challenge him. But when he hears the Buddha speak, he cannot find anything to contradict.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn7.17", "root_name": "Navakammikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 7.17", "blurb": "A brahmin is enjoying his work in the woods. Seeing the Buddha in meditation, he wonders what sort of work the Buddha enjoys.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn7.18", "root_name": "Ka\u1e6d\u1e6dhah\u0101rasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 7.18", "blurb": "Some brahmin students are collecting firewood when they see the Buddha in meditation. They return and inform their teacher, who visits the Buddha to ask him how he is so peaceful in the wild forest.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn7.19", "root_name": "M\u0101tuposakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 7.19", "blurb": "A brahmin wonders whether the legitimate seeking of alms is a proper way to support his parents.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn7.20", "root_name": "Bhikkhakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 7.20", "blurb": "The Buddha explains that a true mendicant is one who has gone beyond evil.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn7.21", "root_name": "Sa\u1e45g\u0101ravasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 7.21", "blurb": "A brahmin believes that by bathing he can wash away his sins. But the Buddha speaks of the Dhamma as a lake for true purification.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn7.22", "root_name": "Khomadussasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 7.22", "blurb": "When the Buddha approaches a brahmin council in session, they complain that he is out of order.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

translated_name: The Chapter on the Boar’s Cave
children: [{"uid": "sn48.51", "root_name": "S\u0101lasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.51", "blurb": "Just as the lion is the king of beasts, wisdom is the chief of qualities that lead to awakening.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.52", "root_name": "Mallikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.52", "blurb": "Only when noble wisdom arises do the other four faculties become stable.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.53", "root_name": "Sekhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.53", "blurb": "How does someone recognize that they are a trainee? By understanding the four noble truths and the five faculties. But only a perfected one fully embodies these qualities.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.54", "root_name": "Padasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.54", "blurb": "Just as all footprints fit into that of an elephant, wisdom is the chief of qualities that lead to awakening.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.55", "root_name": "S\u0101rasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.55", "blurb": "Just as red sandalwood is the best of fragrances, wisdom is the chief of qualities that lead to awakening.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.56", "root_name": "Pati\u1e6d\u1e6dhitasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.56", "blurb": "When established in diligence, the five faculties come to be developed.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.57", "root_name": "Sahampatibrahmasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.57", "blurb": "Just after the Buddha\u2019s awakening, Brahm\u0101 Sahampati supports the Buddha\u2019s reflection that the five faculties lead to the deathless.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.58", "root_name": "S\u016bkarakhatasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.58", "blurb": "A mendicant honors the Realized One and his teaching for the sake of the supreme sanctuary.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.59", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamaupp\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.59", "blurb": "The five faculties only arise in the dispensation of a Realized One.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.60", "root_name": "Dutiyaupp\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.60", "blurb": "The five faculties only arise in the training of a Holy One.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: Texts and fragments in Sanskrit. Some of these are canonical texts, while others are later texts that quote from or include passages from the early discourses.
children: [{"uid": "sf", "root_name": "Sanskrit \u0100gama S\u016btras", "translated_name": "Sanskrit Canonical Discourses ", "acronym": "SF", "blurb": "This category is a miscellaneous groups of mostly Sarv\u0101stiv\u0101din Sanskrit texts that have been published at various times. Some of the text here are highly fragmentary, but some of them are fairly complete. The numbering system we use here is just an arbitrary list.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "san", "root_lang_name": "Sanskrit", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 7}, {"uid": "sht", "root_name": "SHT fragments", "translated_name": "Manuscript Fragments in SHT Project ", "acronym": "SHT", "blurb": "The Sanskrithandschriften aus den Turfanfunden is an ongoing series of publications devoted to identifying and cataloguing the manuscripts, often in highly fragmentary form, recovered from the Silk Road site at Turfan by German expeditions in the early twentieth century. These include many parallels to early sutras, which however are almost all just a few words or sentences. They may occasionally help to clarify a term or reading, but they mainly serve to illustrate the spread of these texts in the Central Asian region.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "san", "root_lang_name": "Sanskrit", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}, {"uid": "arv", "root_name": "Arthavini\u015bcaya", "translated_name": "Defining the Subject Matter ", "acronym": "Arv", "blurb": "The Arthavini\u015bcayas\u016btra is a Sanskrit text which consists almost entirely of quotations of early s\u016btra passages. The text has been edited and published in a series of editions by Alfonsa Ferrari (1944), P.L. Vaidya (1961), and N.H. Samtani based on several manuscripts discovered in Tibet and Nepal. The SuttaCentral text is based on the revision of Samtani by \u0100nandajoti. Ferrari and Vaidya classified this text under Mah\u0101y\u0101na, but Samtani and \u0100nandajoti point out that there are only a few mentions of Mah\u0101y\u0101na concepts, and these are likely to be later additions. The original text appears to be related to the Sarv\u0101stiv\u0101dins, possibly from the Sautr\u0101ntika school.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "san", "root_lang_name": "Sanskrit", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 27}, {"uid": "avs", "root_name": "Avad\u0101na\u015bataka", "translated_name": "A Hundred Legends of Past Lives ", "acronym": "Avs", "blurb": "The \u201cHundred Stories\u201d is a popular collection of legends, associated with the Sarv\u0101stiv\u0101dins, and dating to the first centuries CE. A number of manuscript sources for the text are found, but the oldest complete manuscript and the primary source for modern editions is a Nepalese manuscript dated 1645 and held at the Cambridge University Library. While the text is quite late, it contains a few parallels with early texts. The SuttaCentral text is from GRETIL, which was input by Klaus Wille based on the editions by Vaidya (1958) and Speyer (1906, 1909).", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "san", "root_lang_name": "Sanskrit", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}, {"uid": "divy", "root_name": "Divy\u0101vad\u0101na", "translated_name": "Divine Legend ", "acronym": "Divy", "blurb": "The Divy\u0101vad\u0101na or \u201cDivine Tales\u201d is a Sanskrit anthology of 38 tales, many originating in the M\u016blasarv\u0101stiv\u0101da Vinaya. Typically the stories illustrate how the consequences of actions in past lives affect the present, with a special emphasis on the merit of making offerings to the Buddha and his disciples. It includes the famous A\u015bok\u0101vad\u0101na, one of the primary sources for the life of King Ashoka. The text probably dates from around the third century CE, but includes a few parallels to early texts. Modern editions are based on a number of Nepalese manuscripts, mostly quite modern. It was first edited and published in the west by Cowell and Neil in 1884. The digital text on SuttaCentral is from GRETIL, based on the edition by Vaidya (1959), with input by Kensuke Okamoto.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "san", "root_lang_name": "Sanskrit", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}, {"uid": "lal", "root_name": "Lalitavistara", "translated_name": "The Play in Full ", "acronym": "Lal", "blurb": "The Lalitavistara or \u201cPlay in Extenso\u201d was one of the most popular of the ancient lives of the Buddha. Based on Sarv\u0101stiv\u0101din and Mah\u0101y\u0101na sources, numerous manuscripts from Nepal survive. The text is a compilation from multiple sources, dating around the fourth centry CE, but including a few parallels to early texts. The SuttaCentral text is from GRETIL, based on the edition by Vaidya (1958).", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "san", "root_lang_name": "Sanskrit", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "mkv", "root_name": "Mah\u0101karmavibha\u1e45ga", "translated_name": "Greater Analysis of Deeds ", "acronym": "Mkv", "blurb": "The Mah\u0101karmavibha\u1e45ga or \u201cGreat Analysis of Deeds\u201d is a Sanskrit Abhidharma text based on manuscripts from Nepal, which includes a number of quotations from early discourses, including the Dhammapada. The SuttaCentral text is from GRETIL, based on the edition by Sylvain L\u00e9vi (1932), and input by Klaus Wille.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "san", "root_lang_name": "Sanskrit", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}, {"uid": "ybs", "root_name": "Yog\u0101c\u0101rabh\u016bmi", "translated_name": "Stages of Meditation ", "acronym": " Ybs", "blurb": "Asa\u1e45ga\u2019s Yogac\u0101rabh\u016bmi\u015bastra, the \u201ctreatise on the stages of meditation practice\u201d is one of the largest and most influential compendiums in northern Buddhism. While the overall structure is Mahayanist, several chapters focus on the early teachings and quote extensively from the Suttas. Not only is Asa\u1e45ga\u2019s philosophical approach grounded in the teachnings of the Suttas, it is likely that this work, perhaps indirectly, inspired the creation of the Pali Visuddhimagga as a Theravadin equivalent.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "san", "root_lang_name": "Sanskrit", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}]

translated_name: The Chapter on Shaking the Stilt Longhouse
children: [{"uid": "sn51.11", "root_name": "Pubbasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.11", "blurb": "The Buddha recounts the process of inquiry that lead to him fully understanding the four bases of psychic power, as well as the powers that result from that.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn51.12", "root_name": "Mahapphalasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.12", "blurb": "The four bases of psychic power are very beneficial.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn51.13", "root_name": "Chandasam\u0101dhisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.13", "blurb": "An analysis of the four bases of psychic power showing how enthusiasm, energy, higher consciousness, and inquiry work in the context of advanced meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn51.14", "root_name": "Moggall\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.14", "blurb": "When lazy monks were wasting time, the Buddha asks Moggall\u0101na to stir them up. He shakes with his toe the large building in which they were staying, terrifying the monks. They sought refuge in the Buddha, and he taught them the four bases of psychic power.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn51.15", "root_name": "U\u1e47\u1e47\u0101bhabr\u0101hma\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.15", "blurb": "\u0100nanda explains to the brahmin U\u1e47\u1e47\u0101bha that the spiritual path is lived to give up desire through the the four bases of psychic power. But U\u1e47\u1e47\u0101bha says this is a contradiction, as desire is itself one of the four bases. \u0100nanda resolves the contradiction with the simile of a man walking to a park. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn51.16", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamasama\u1e47abr\u0101hma\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.16", "blurb": "Whatever ascetics are of great spiritual power have developed the four bases of psychic power.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn51.17", "root_name": "Dutiyasama\u1e47abr\u0101hma\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.17", "blurb": "Whatever ascetics are of great spiritual power have developed the four bases of psychic power.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn51.18", "root_name": "Bhikkhusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.18", "blurb": "It is because of developing the four bases of psychic power that a mendicant ends the defilements.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn51.19", "root_name": "Iddh\u0101didesan\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.19", "blurb": "The Buddha distinguishes between psychic powers, the basis for psychic power, and the development of the bases for psychic power.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn51.20", "root_name": "Vibha\u1e45gasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.20", "blurb": "The Buddha teaches the bases for psychic power and analyzes them in detail.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: This section includes texts recited as protection mantras, similar to the parittas of the Pali canon. Of the many texts classified in this way in the Chinese canon, two have been identified as parallel to the Pali Bhaddekaratta and Āṭānāṭiya suttas.
children: [{"uid": "t1245", "root_name": "\u6bd8\u6c99\u9580\u5929\u738b", "translated_name": "Great King Vai\u015brava\u1e47a ", "acronym": "T 1245", "blurb": null, "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}, {"uid": "t1362", "root_name": "\u5584\u591c", "translated_name": "One Fine Night", "acronym": "T 1362", "blurb": null, "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}]

[{"uid": "sn55.1", "root_name": "Cakkavattir\u0101jasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.1", "blurb": "Even a universal monarch may have a bad rebirth, but someone who has the four factors of stream-entry\u2014experiential faith in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Sa\u1e45gha, and ethical conduct\u2014is freed from such destinies.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn55.2", "root_name": "Brahmacariyogadhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.2", "blurb": "Someone who has the four factors of stream-entry\u2014experiential faith in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Sa\u1e45gha, and ethical conduct\u2014is a stream-enterer, destined for awakening.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn55.3", "root_name": "D\u012bgh\u0101vuup\u0101sakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.3", "blurb": "The lay follower D\u012bgh\u0101vu is ill and he asks for the Buddha to visit. D\u012bgh\u0101vu confirms that he possesses the four factors of stream-entry and in addition six contemplations leading to insight. Yet he is still worried that his father will miss him when he dies.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn55.4", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamas\u0101riputtasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.4", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta explains to \u0100nanda that someone who has the four factors of stream-entry\u2014experiential faith in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Sa\u1e45gha, and ethical conduct\u2014is a stream-enterer, destined for awakening.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn55.5", "root_name": "Dutiyas\u0101riputtasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.5", "blurb": "The Buddha asks S\u0101riputta about the four factors for stream-entry: association with good people, hearing the teaching, proper attention, and right practice. He also defines the \u201cstream\u201d and the \u201cstream-enterer\u201d.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn55.6", "root_name": "Thapatisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.6", "blurb": "After the rainy season, the chamberlains Isidatta and Pur\u0101\u1e47a hear that the Buddha is approaching and go to see him. They describe their joy at knowing when the Buddha is approaching, and speak of their special duties guarding the royal harem. The Buddha says they have four factors of stream-entry\u2014experiential faith in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Sa\u1e45gha; and here generosity rather than ethics as the final factor.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn55.7", "root_name": "Ve\u1e37udv\u0101reyyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.7", "blurb": "The brahmin householders of Bamboo Gate ask the Buddha how to live well in the home. The Buddha teaches them seven principles they can apply to themselves, which are practical applications of the Golden Rule. Someone with these seven principles and the four factors of stream-entry is a stream-enterer.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn55.8", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamagi\u00f1jak\u0101vasathasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.8", "blurb": "\u0100nanda asks the Buddha about the rebirths of several disciples. The Buddha confirms those details, and proposes a way for people to know for themselves by reflecting on the four factors of stream-entry.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn55.9", "root_name": "Dutiyagi\u00f1jak\u0101vasathasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.9", "blurb": "\u0100nanda asks the Buddha about the rebirths of several disciples. The Buddha confirms those details, and proposes a way for people to know for themselves by reflecting on the four factors of stream-entry.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn55.10", "root_name": "Tatiyagi\u00f1jak\u0101vasathasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.10", "blurb": "\u0100nanda asks the Buddha about the rebirths of several disciples. The Buddha confirms those details, and proposes a way for people to know for themselves by reflecting on the four factors of stream-entry.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: Miscellanous texts relating to the early scriptures. These are mostly Chinese translations of texts similar to those found in the Pali canon
children: [{"uid": "lzh-art", "root_name": "Arthavarg\u012bya", "translated_name": "Handbook of Meaning ", "acronym": "Art", "blurb": "The Yizu jing (Arthavarg\u012bya) in two fascicles at T 198 was translated into Chinese by Zhi Qian \u652f\u8b19 between the 2nd year of Huang Wu \u9ec3\u6b66 and 2nd year of Jianxing \u5efa\u8208, Wu dynasty \u5449 (223\u2013253 CE). This corresponds to the A\u1e6d\u1e6dhakavagga, the fourth of the five chapters of the Sutta Nip\u0101ta (Sn 766\u2013975) of the P\u0101li Tipitaka, though this Chinese version has additional passages. Since the P\u0101li version is cited by other P\u0101li and Sanskrit canonical texts, traditionally the A\u1e6d\u1e6dhaka vagga was taken to be an important encapsulation of key teachings, while scholars consider it one of the earliest compositions included in the Tipitaka. Its continuing influence amongst Buddhists is illustrated by the fact that noteworthy later citations of the text include Asa\u1e45ga in the Bodhisattvabh\u016bmi and Vasubandhu in the Abhidharmako\u015ba-bh\u0101\u1e63ya.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}, {"uid": "lzh-ja", "root_name": "J\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Past Life Stories of the Buddha ", "acronym": "Lzh Ja", "blurb": "Texts that have been classified as J\u0101takas (\u672c\u7de3\u90e8), or stories of the Buddha\u2019s past lives, similar to the J\u0101takas of the Pali Khuddhaka Nik\u0101ya. In the Taish\u014d edition of the Chinese canon they are found in volumes three and four.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}, {"uid": "lzh-nbs", "root_name": "N\u0101gasena Bhik\u1e63u S\u016btra", "translated_name": "Discourse with the Mendicant N\u0101gasena ", "acronym": "Nbs", "blurb": "The N\u0101gasena Bhik\u1e63u S\u016btra (\u90a3\u5148\u6bd4\u4e18\u7d93) is a Chinese version of the text found in Pali as the Milinda Pa\u00f1ha. The translator and date are unknown, but it is listed in the Tung Chin lu (\u6771\u6649\u9304) (CE 317\u2013420). In the Taish\u014d edition of the Chinese canon, it is text number 1670B, located at T vol. 32, 703c.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 78}, {"uid": "lzh-ssnp", "root_name": "S\u016btrasannip\u0101ta", "translated_name": "Anthology of Discourses ", "acronym": "SSnp", "blurb": "This portion of the Taish\u014d edition of the Chinese canon is simply called \u201cmiscellaneous collection\u201d ( \u7d93\u96c6\u90e8), and it includes s\u016btra texts that are not readily classifiable elsewhere. While the section is mostly for Mah\u0101y\u0101na s\u016btras, a number of parallels with early discourses have been identified. ", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}, {"uid": "lzh-dharani", "root_name": "Dh\u0101ra\u1e47\u012b", "translated_name": "Incantations ", "acronym": "Dhar", "blurb": "This section includes texts recited as protection mantras, similar to the parittas of the Pali canon. Of the many texts classified in this way in the Chinese canon, two have been identified as parallel to the Pali Bhaddekaratta and \u0100\u1e6d\u0101n\u0101\u1e6diya suttas.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}, {"uid": "lzh-svk", "root_name": "S\u016btravy\u0101kara\u1e47a", "translated_name": "Discussion of Discourses ", "acronym": "Svk", "blurb": "This section includes sutta parallels that have been identified within the portions of the Chinese canon containing treatises on Abhidharma and Mah\u0101y\u0101na philosophy. The identified parallels are quotations within commentarial texts.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}]

blurb: Discourses arranged as pairs of longer and shorter texts.
children: [{"uid": "mn31", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37agosi\u1e45gasutta", "translated_name": "The Shorter Discourse at Gosi\u1e45ga ", "acronym": "MN 31", "blurb": "The Buddha comes across three mendicants practicing diligently and harmoniously, and asks them how they do it. Reluctant to disclose their higher attainments, they explain how they deal with the practical affairs of living together. But when pressed by the Buddha, they reveal their meditation attainments.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn32", "root_name": "Mah\u0101gosi\u1e45gasutta", "translated_name": "The Longer Discourse at Gosi\u1e45ga ", "acronym": "MN 32", "blurb": "Several senior mendicants, reveling in the beauty of the night, discuss what kind of practitioner would adorn the park. They take their answers to the Buddha, who praises their answers, but gives his own twist.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn33", "root_name": "Mah\u0101gop\u0101lakasutta", "translated_name": "The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd ", "acronym": "MN 33", "blurb": "For eleven reasons a cowherd is not able to properly look after a herd. The Buddha compares this to the spiritual growth of a mendicant.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn34", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37agop\u0101lakasutta", "translated_name": "The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd ", "acronym": "MN 34", "blurb": "Drawing parallels with a cowherd guiding his herd across a dangerous river, the Buddha presents the various kinds of enlightened disciples who cross the stream of transmigration.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn35", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37asaccakasutta", "translated_name": "The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka ", "acronym": "MN 35", "blurb": "Saccaka was a debater, who challenged the Buddha to a contest. Despite his bragging, the Buddha is not at all perturbed at his attacks.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn36", "root_name": "Mah\u0101saccakasutta", "translated_name": "The Longer Discourse With Saccaka ", "acronym": "MN 36", "blurb": "In a less confrontational meeting, the Buddha and Saccaka discuss the difference between physical and mental development. The Buddha gives a long account of the various practices he did before awakening, detailing the astonishing lengths he took to mortify the body.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn37", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37ata\u1e47h\u0101sa\u1e45khayasutta", "translated_name": "The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving ", "acronym": "MN 37", "blurb": "Moggall\u0101na visits the heaven of Sakka, the lord of gods, to see whether he really understands what the Buddha is teaching.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn38", "root_name": "Mah\u0101ta\u1e47h\u0101sa\u1e45khayasutta", "translated_name": "The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving ", "acronym": "MN 38", "blurb": "To counter the wrong view that a self-identical consciousness transmigrates from one life to the next, the Buddha teaches dependent origination, showing that consciousness invariably arises dependent on conditions.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "mn39", "root_name": "Mah\u0101assapurasutta", "translated_name": "The Longer Discourse at Assapura ", "acronym": "MN 39", "blurb": "The Buddha encourages the mendicants to live up to their name, by actually practicing in a way that meets or exceeds the expectations people have for renunciants.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn40", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37aassapurasutta", "translated_name": "The Shorter Discourse at Assapura ", "acronym": "MN 40", "blurb": "The labels of being a "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an5.196", "root_name": "Mah\u0101supinasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 5.196", "blurb": "Before his awakening, the bodhisatta had five great dreams that foretold profound aspects of his awakening and dispensation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an5.197", "root_name": "Vassasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 5.197", "blurb": "Weather forecasters remain ignorant of these five obstacles to rain.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an5.198", "root_name": "V\u0101c\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 5.198", "blurb": "Five factors of good speech.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an5.199", "root_name": "Kulasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 5.199", "blurb": "When a renunciate visits a family, they make merit on five bases.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": escaped by different practices.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: The Buddha engages with the powerful caste of brahmins, contesting their claims to spiritual authority.
children: [{"uid": "mn91", "root_name": "Brahm\u0101yusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 91", "blurb": "The oldest and most respected brahmin of the age sends a student to examine the Buddha, and he spends several months following his every move before reporting back. Convinced that the Buddha fulfills an ancient prophecy of the Great Man, the brahmin becomes his disciple.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "mn92", "root_name": "Selasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 92", "blurb": "A brahmanical ascetic named Ke\u1e47iya invites the entire Sa\u1e45gha for a meal. When the brahmin Sela sees what is happening, he visits the Buddha and expresses his delight in a moving series of devotional verses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn93", "root_name": "Assal\u0101yanasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 93", "blurb": "A precocious brahmin student is encouraged against his wishes to challenge the Buddha on the question of caste. His reluctance turns out to be justified.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn94", "root_name": "Gho\u1e6damukhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 94", "blurb": "A brahmin denies that there is such a thing as a principled renunciate life, but Venerable Udena persuades him otherwise.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn95", "root_name": "Ca\u1e45k\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 95", "blurb": "The reputed brahmin Ca\u1e45k\u012b goes with a large group to visit the Buddha, despite the reservations of other brahmins. A precocious student challenges the Buddha, affirming the validity of the Vedic scriptures. The Buddha gives a detailed explanation of how true understanding gradually emerges through spiritual education.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn96", "root_name": "Esuk\u0101r\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 96", "blurb": "A brahmin claims that one deserves service and privilege depending on caste, but the Buddha counters that it is conduct, not caste, that show a person\u2019s worth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn97", "root_name": "Dhana\u00f1j\u0101nisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 97", "blurb": "A corrupt tax-collector is redeemed by his encounter with Venerable S\u0101riputta.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn98", "root_name": "V\u0101se\u1e6d\u1e6dhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 98", "blurb": "Two brahmin students ask the Buddha about what makes a brahmin: birth or deeds? the Buddha points out that, while the species of animals are determined by birth, for humans what matters is how you chose to live. This discourse anticipates the modern view that there are no such things as clearly defined racial differences among humans.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn99", "root_name": "Subhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 99", "blurb": "Working hard is not valuable in and of itself; what matters is the outcome. And just as in lay life, spiritual practice may or may not lead to fruitful results.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn100", "root_name": "Sa\u1e45g\u0101ravasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 100", "blurb": "Angered by the devotion of a brahmin lady, a brahmin visits the Buddha. He positions himself against traditionalists and rationalists, as someone whose teaching is based on direct experience.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}]

[{"uid": "sn37.25", "root_name": "Vis\u0101radasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 37.25", "blurb": "A woman with five powers lives confident at home.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn37.26", "root_name": "Pasayhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 37.26", "blurb": "A woman with five powers lives at home having won over her husband.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn37.27", "root_name": "Abhibhuyyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 37.27", "blurb": "A woman with five powers lives at home with her husband under her control.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn37.28", "root_name": "Ekasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 37.28", "blurb": "A man with one power has a woman under his control: authority.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn37.29", "root_name": "A\u1e45gasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 37.29", "blurb": "A woman may be complete with five powers.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn37.30", "root_name": "N\u0101sentisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 37.30", "blurb": "A woman lacking in any of the five powers may be expelled from a family.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn37.31", "root_name": "Hetusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 37.31", "blurb": "It is not because of beauty, wealth, relatives, or sons that a woman has a good rebirth, but because of ethical conduct.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn37.32", "root_name": "\u1e6ch\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 37.32", "blurb": "For a woman who has not made merit, five things are hard to come by.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn37.33", "root_name": "Pa\u00f1cas\u012blavis\u0101radasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 37.33", "blurb": "A woman with five qualities lives confidently at home.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn37.34", "root_name": "Va\u1e0d\u1e0dh\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 37.34", "blurb": "A woman who grows in faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom acquires the best.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

translated_name: The Chapter on the Six Senses
blurb: Most discourses in this chapter deal with the six sense fields.
children: [{"uid": "mn143", "root_name": "An\u0101thapi\u1e47\u1e0dikov\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 143", "blurb": "As the great lay disciple An\u0101thapi\u1e47\u1e0dika lies dying, Venerable S\u0101riputta visits him and gives a powerful teaching on non-attachment.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "mn144", "root_name": "Channov\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 144", "blurb": "The monk Channa is suffering a painful terminal illness and wishes to take his own life.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "mn145", "root_name": "Pu\u1e47\u1e47ov\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 145", "blurb": "On the eve of his departure to a distant country, full of wild and unpredictable people, Venerable Pu\u1e47\u1e47a is asked by the Buddha how he would respond if attacked there.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "mn146", "root_name": "Nandakov\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 146", "blurb": "When asked to teach the nuns, Venerable Nandaka proceeds by inviting them to engage with his discourse and ask if there is anything that needs further explanation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "mn147", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37ar\u0101hulov\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 147", "blurb": "The Buddha takes R\u0101hula with him to a secluded spot in order to lead him on to liberation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "mn148", "root_name": "Chachakkasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 148", "blurb": "The Buddha analyzes the six senses from six perspectives, and demonstrates the emptiness of all of them.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "mn149", "root_name": "Mah\u0101sa\u1e37\u0101yatanikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 149", "blurb": "Explains how insight into the six senses is integrated with the eightfold path and leads to liberation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn150", "root_name": "Nagaravindeyyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 150", "blurb": "In discussion with a group of householders, the Buddha helps them to distinguish those spiritual practitioners who are truly worthy of respect.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "mn151", "root_name": "Pi\u1e47\u1e0dap\u0101tap\u0101risuddhisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 151", "blurb": "The Buddha notices Venerable S\u0101riputta\u2019s glowing complexion, which is the result of his deep meditation. He then presents a series of reflections by which a mendicant can be sure that they are worthy of their alms-food.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "mn152", "root_name": "Indriyabh\u0101van\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 152", "blurb": "A brahmin teacher advocates that purification of the senses consists in simply avoiding seeing and hearing things. The Buddha explains that it is not about avoiding sense experience, but understanding it and learning to not be affected by sense experience.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "sn28.1", "root_name": "Vivekajasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 28.1", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta goes to Mirkwood for meditation, and afterwards \u0100nanda asks why his face is so radiant.
