[{"uid": "sn47.41", "root_name": "Amatasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.41", "blurb": "Develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, don\u2019t let the deathless be lost.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.42", "root_name": "Samudayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.42", "blurb": "The causes for the origination and cessation of the phenomena upon which the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are grounded.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.43", "root_name": "Maggasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.43", "blurb": "The Buddha tells the mendicants how, just after his awakening, Brahm\u0101 Sahampati supported the Buddha\u2019s reflection that the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the way to convergence", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.44", "root_name": "Satisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.44", "blurb": "Be mindful by developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.45", "root_name": "Kusalar\u0101sisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.45", "blurb": "The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are a heap of the skillful.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.46", "root_name": "P\u0101timokkhasa\u1e41varasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.46", "blurb": "When a mendicant asks for a teaching to take on retreat, the Buddha teaches the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, well grounded on restraint in the code of monastic rules.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.47", "root_name": "Duccaritasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.47", "blurb": "When a mendicant asks for a teaching to take on retreat, the Buddha teaches the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, well grounded on good bodily, verbal, and mental conduct.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.48", "root_name": "Mittasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.48", "blurb": "You should encourage your friends to practice the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.49", "root_name": "Vedan\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.49", "blurb": "The four kinds of mindfulness meditation help to understand the three feelings.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.50", "root_name": "\u0100savasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.50", "blurb": "The four kinds of mindfulness meditation help to give up the defilements.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: Asaṅga’s Yogacārabhūmiśastra, the “treatise on the stages of meditation practice” is one of the largest and most influential compendiums in northern Buddhism. While the overall structure is Mahayanist, several chapters focus on the early teachings and quote extensively from the Suttas. Not only is Asaṅga’s philosophical approach grounded in the teachnings of the Suttas, it is likely that this work, perhaps indirectly, inspired the creation of the Pali Visuddhimagga as a Theravadin equivalent.

[{"uid": "ja439", "root_name": "Catudv\u0101raj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Four Gates ", "acronym": "Ja 439", "blurb": "\u201cFour gates\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Jetavana, about a certain unruly person. The circumstances have been already set forth in the first Birth of the Ninth Book. Here again the Master asked this brother, \u201cIs it true, as they say, that you are disobedient?\u201d \u201cYes, Sir.\u201d \u201cLong ago,\u201d said he, \u201cwhen by disobedience you refused to do the bidding of wise men, a razor-wheel was given to you.\u201d And he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja440", "root_name": "Ka\u1e47haj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Black Sage ", "acronym": "Ja 440", "blurb": "\u201cBehold yon man\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Kapilavatthu, in the Banyan Park, about smiling.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja441", "root_name": "Catuposathiyaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Four Sabbaths ", "acronym": "Ja 441", "blurb": "This Birth will be described in the Punnaka Birth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja442", "root_name": "Sa\u1e45khaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Brahmin Sa\u1e45kha ", "acronym": "Ja 442", "blurb": "\u201cO learned brahmin\u201d\u2014This story the Master told in Jetavana, about the giving of all the requisites.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja443", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37abodhij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Shorter Tale of the Young Man Bodhi ", "acronym": "Ja 443", "blurb": "\u201cIf one seize\u201d\u2014This story the Master told in Jetavana, about a passionate man. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja444", "root_name": "Ka\u1e47had\u012bp\u0101yanaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Black D\u012bp\u0101yana ", "acronym": "Ja 444", "blurb": "\u201cSeven days\u201d\u2014This story the Master told in Jetavana, about a certain backsliding brother. The occasion will be explained under the Kusa Birth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja445", "root_name": "Nigrodhaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Banyan-Tree Boy ", "acronym": "Ja 445", "blurb": "\u201cWho is the man\u201d\u2014This story the Master told in the Bamboo Grove, about Devadatta. One day the Brethren said to him, \u201cFriend Devadatta, the Master is most helpful to you! From the Master you received your Orders, lesser and greater; you have learnt the Three Baskets, the voice of Buddha; you have caused the Ecstasy to arise within you; the glory and gain of the Dasabala belong to you.\u201d At this he held up a blade of grass, with the words, \u201cI can see no good that the ascetic Gotama has done me, not even this much!\u201d They talked it over in the Hall of Truth. When the Master came in, he asked what they talked of as they sat together. They told him. Said he, \u201cBrethren, this is not the first time, but long ago as now Devadatta was ungrateful and treacherous to friends.\u201d And he told them a tale of olden days. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja446", "root_name": "Takkalaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Bulbs ", "acronym": "Ja 446", "blurb": "\u201cNo bulbs are here\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Jetavana about a layman who supported his father.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja447", "root_name": "Mah\u0101dhammap\u0101laj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Dhammap\u0101la the Great ", "acronym": "Ja 447", "blurb": "\u201cWhat custom is it\u201d\u2014This story the Master told, after his first visit (as Buddha) to Kapilapura, while he lodged in his father\u2019s Banyan Grove, about the King his father\u2019s refusal to believe.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja448", "root_name": "Kukku\u1e6daj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Chicken ", "acronym": "Ja 448", "blurb": "\u201cTrust not in those\u201d\u2014This story the Master told in the Bamboo Grove, on the subject of going about to kill. In the Hall of Truth, the Brethren were discussing the evil nature of Devadatta. \u201cWhy, Sir, by suborning archers and others to the task, Devadatta is making an attempt to murder the Dasabala!\u201d The Master, entering, enquired, \u201cWhat is this, Brethren, that ye speak of as ye sit here together?\u201d They told him. Said he, \u201c\u2019Tis not now the first time that he has tried to murder me, but it was the same before\u201d; and he told them a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja449", "root_name": "Ma\u1e6d\u1e6dhaku\u1e47\u1e0dal\u012bj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Earrings ", "acronym": "Ja 449", "blurb": "\u201cWhy in the woodland\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while sojourning in Jetavana, about a landowner whose son had died. At Savatthi, we learn that death took a beloved son of a certain landowner who used to wait upon the Buddha. Afflicted with grief for his son, the man washed not and ate not, and neither went about his own business nor waited upon the Buddha, only cried, \u201cO my beloved son, thou hast left me, and gone before!\u201d", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja450", "root_name": "Bil\u0101rakosiyaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Rich Man Bil\u0101rakosiya ", "acronym": "Ja 450", "blurb": "\u201cWhen food is not\u201d\u2014This story the Master told, while dwelling at Jetavana, about a Brother who was devoted to giving.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja451", "root_name": "Cakkav\u0101kaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Red-Duck and the Crow ", "acronym": "Ja 451", "blurb": "\u201cFine-coloured art thou\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling in Jetavana, about a greedy Brother. This man, it is said, dissatisfied with his mendicant\u2019s garb and so forth, used to march about asking, \u201cWhere is there a meal for the Order? where is there an invitation?\u201d and when he heard mention of meat, he showed great delight. Then some well-meaning Brethren, from kindness towards him, told the Master about it. The Master summoning him, asked, \u201cIs it true, Brother, as I hear, that you are greedy?\u201d \u201cYes, my lord, it is true,\u201d said he. \u201cBrother,\u201d said the Master, \u201cwhy are you greedy, after embracing a faith like ours, that leads to salvation? The state of greed is sinful; long ago, by reason of greed, you were not satisfied with the dead bodies of elephants and other offal in Benares, and went away into the mighty forest.\u201d So saying, he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja452", "root_name": "Bh\u016bripa\u00f1\u00f1aj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Vast Wisdom ", "acronym": "Ja 452", "blurb": "\u201cIs\u2019t true, indeed\u201d\u2014This Bhuri-panha Birth will appear in the Ummagga Birth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja453", "root_name": "Mah\u0101ma\u1e45galaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Backstory for the Discourse on Blessings ", "acronym": "Ja 453", "blurb": "\u201cDeclare the truth\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling in Jetavana, about the Maha-mangala Scripture, or the Treatise on Omens.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja454", "root_name": "Gha\u1e6dapa\u1e47\u1e0ditaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Pot-Sage ", "acronym": "Ja 454", "blurb": "\u201cBlack Kanha, rise\u201d\u2014This story the Master told in Jetavana about a son\u2019s death. The circumstances are like those in the Mattha-Kundali Birth. Here again the Master asked the lay brother, \u201cAre you in grief, layman?\u201d He replied, \u201cYes, Sir.\u201d \u201cLayman,\u201d said the Master, \u201clong ago wise men listened to the bidding of the wise, and did not grieve for the death of a son.\u201d And at his request, he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

translated_name: The Iguana Who Befriended a Chameleon
children: [{"uid": "ja141", "root_name": "Godhaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Iguana Who Befriended a Chameleon ", "acronym": "Ja 141", "blurb": "\u201cBad company.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at the Bamboo-grove, about a traitorous Brother. The introductory incident is the same as that told in the Mahila-mukha jataka.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja142", "root_name": "Si\u1e45g\u0101laj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Jackal ", "acronym": "Ja 142", "blurb": "\u201cThy tightening grip.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at the Bamboo-grove, about Devadatta\u2019s going about to kill him. For, hearing the Brethren talking together as to this in the Hall of Truth, the Master said that, as Devadatta acted now, so he acted in times gone by, yet failed\u2014to his own grievous hurt\u2014of his wicked purpose. And so saying, he told this story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja143", "root_name": "Virocanaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Shining ", "acronym": "Ja 143", "blurb": "\u201cYour mangled corpse.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at the Bamboo-grove, about Devadatta\u2019s efforts to pose as a Buddha at Gayasisa.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja144", "root_name": "Na\u1e45gu\u1e6d\u1e6dhaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Tail ", "acronym": "Ja 144", "blurb": "\u201cVile Jataveda.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, touching the false austerity of the Ajivikas, or naked ascetics.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja145", "root_name": "R\u0101dhaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Tale of R\u0101dha ", "acronym": "Ja 145", "blurb": "\u201cHow many more?\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about hankering after the wife of one\u2019s mundane life. The incidents of the introductory story will be told in the Indriya-jataka.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja146", "root_name": "Samuddak\u0101kaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Crows Who Tried to Drink the Ocean ", "acronym": "Ja 146", "blurb": "\u201cOur throats are tired.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a number of aged Brethren. Whilst they were still of the world, they were rich and wealthy squires of Savatthi, all friends of one another; and tradition tells us that while they were engaged in good works they heard the Master preach. At once they cried, \u201cWe are old; what to us are house and home? Let us join the Brotherhood, and following the Buddha\u2019s lovely doctrine make an end of sorrow.\u201d", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja147", "root_name": "Puppharattaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "A Die of Flowers ", "acronym": "Ja 147", "blurb": "\u201cI count it not as pain.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a Brother who was passion-tost. Being questioned by the Master, he admitted his frailty, explaining that he longed for the wife of his mundane life, \u201cFor, oh sir!\u201d said he, \u201cshe is so sweet a woman that I cannot live without her.\u201d", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja148", "root_name": "Si\u1e45g\u0101laj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Jackal ", "acronym": "Ja 148", "blurb": "\u201cOnce bitten, twice shy.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master when at Jetavana, about subduing desires.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja149", "root_name": "Ekapa\u1e47\u1e47aj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "One Poison Leaf ", "acronym": "Ja 149", "blurb": "\u201cIf poison lurk.\u201d\u2014This story was told about the Licchavi Prince Wicked of Vesali by the Master when he was living in the gabled house in the great forest near Vesali.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja150", "root_name": "Sa\u00f1j\u012bvaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Life-bringer the Student ", "acronym": "Ja 150", "blurb": "\u201cBefriend a villain.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master when at the Bamboo-grove, about King Ajatasattu\u2019s adherence to false teachers. For he believed in that rancorous foe of the Buddhas, the base and wicked Devadatta, and in his infatuation, wishing to do honour to Devadatta, expended a vast sum in erecting a monastery at Gayasisa. And following Devadatta\u2019s wicked counsels, he slew the good and virtuous old King his father, who had entered on the Paths, thereby destroying his own chance of winning like goodness and virtue, and bringing great woe upon himself.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

translated_name: The Chapter on the Old and the New
children: [{"uid": "sn35.146", "root_name": "Kammanirodhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.146", "blurb": "The six interior sense fields are not yours, but are old kamma, generated by choices in past lives. This is explained in terms of the four noble truths.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.147", "root_name": "Aniccanibb\u0101nasapp\u0101yasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.147", "blurb": "The way suitable for realizing extinguishment is to contemplate the process of sense experience as impermanent.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.148", "root_name": "Dukkhanibb\u0101nasapp\u0101yasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.148", "blurb": "The way suitable for realizing extinguishment is to contemplate the process of sense experience as suffering.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.149", "root_name": "Anattanibb\u0101nasapp\u0101yasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.149", "blurb": "The way suitable for realizing extinguishment is to contemplate the process of sense experience as not-self.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn35.150", "root_name": "Nibb\u0101nasapp\u0101yapa\u1e6dipad\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.150", "blurb": "The way suitable for realizing extinguishment is to contemplate the process of sense experience as impermanent, suffering, and not-self.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.151", "root_name": "Antev\u0101sikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.151", "blurb": "One with no \u201cstudent\u201d and no \u201cteacher\u201d dwells in happiness. Here the Buddha plays with the Pali words such that \u201cstudent\u201d means \u201cone who dwells within\u201d and \u201cteacher\u201d means \u201cone who assails\u201d.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.152", "root_name": "Kimatthiyabrahmacariyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.152", "blurb": "If anyone asks why we live the holy life, it is for the ending of suffering.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.153", "root_name": "Atthinukhopariy\u0101yasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.153", "blurb": "How is it that a mendicant can declare their awakening? By understanding whether any desire arises from sense stimuli.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.154", "root_name": "Indriyasampannasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.154", "blurb": "One is accomplished in the sense faculties by being freed from attachment to them.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.155", "root_name": "Dhammakathikapucchasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.155", "blurb": "A speaker on the Dhamma is someone who teaches for letting go of the senses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

translated_name: The Chapter on the Way to the Beyond
blurb: This is perhaps the most sophisticated and moving poetic composition in early Buddhism. It begins with a brahmin, suffering an unwanted curse, who sends his students to seek the Buddha. At the end of a long journey they ask questions, the nature of which indicate their subtle philosophy and deep meditation. It concludes with an emotional declaration of faith and determination.

translated_name: The Chapter at the Village of Koṭi
children: [{"uid": "sn56.21", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamako\u1e6dig\u0101masutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.21", "blurb": "It is because of not understanding the four noble truths that both the Buddha and others have wandered for so long in transmigration. With verses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.22", "root_name": "Dutiyako\u1e6dig\u0101masutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.22", "blurb": "True ascetics understand the four noble truths. With verses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.23", "root_name": "Samm\u0101sambuddhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.23", "blurb": "The Realized One is called the Buddha because he understands the four noble truths.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.24", "root_name": "Arahantasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.24", "blurb": "All Buddhas become awakened through the four noble truths.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.25", "root_name": "\u0100savakkhayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.25", "blurb": "Only by knowing and seeing the four noble truths are the defilements ended.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.26", "root_name": "Mittasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.26", "blurb": "You should encourage your friends in the four noble truths.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.27", "root_name": "Tathasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.27", "blurb": "The four noble truths is real, not otherwise, that is why they are noble.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.28", "root_name": "Lokasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.28", "blurb": "In this world, the Realized One is the noble one, that is why the four truths are noble.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.29", "root_name": "Pari\u00f1\u00f1eyyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.29", "blurb": "The first truth is to be understood; the second is to be given up; the third is to be realized; and the fourth is to be developed.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.30", "root_name": "Gavampatisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.30", "blurb": "Some mendicants are discussing whether the four truths are necessarily seen together. Venerable Gavampati asserts that he has learned it from the Buddha that they are: if you see one, you see them all.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

[{"uid": "sn22.83", "root_name": "\u0100nandasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.83", "blurb": "\u0100nanda praises Venerable Pu\u1e47\u1e47a Mant\u0101niputta, and says that it was when hearing his teaching on the aggregates that he understood the Dhamma.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.84", "root_name": "Tissasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.84", "blurb": "Venerable Tissa, the Blessed One\u2019s paternal cousin, tells the monks that he is dissatisfied as a monk. When the Buddha hears of this, he calls Tissa to him, and questions him on the aggregates. As Tissa showed his understanding of each question, the Buddha praised him, lifting his spirits.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.85", "root_name": "Yamakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.85", "blurb": "Venerable Yamaka had the wrong view that one whose defilements have ended is annihilated at death. The monks ask S\u0101riputta to help, and he asks Yamaka whether the Realized One in this very life may be identified as one of the aggregates, or apart from them. Convinced, Yamaka lets go of his view and sees the Dhamma.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.86", "root_name": "Anur\u0101dhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.86", "blurb": "Venerable Anur\u0101dha is questioned by a number of ascetics, and ends up by saying that the Realized One is described in terms other than \u201cexisting after death\u201d and so on. The wanderers say he\u2019s a fool, so he checks with the Buddha, who says that a Realized One is not even apprehended in this life, so how can he be described after death?", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.87", "root_name": "Vakkalisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.87", "blurb": "Venerable Vakkali is ill, and asks the Buddha to visit him. The Buddha does so, but says there is no point in seeing his physical body, as one who sees the Dhamma sees him. Later, Vakkali is taken to the Black Rock on Isigili, where he declares that he has no attachment to the aggregates, and takes his own life. The Buddha says that he had attained final extinguishment.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.88", "root_name": "Assajisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.88", "blurb": "Venerable Assaji is ill, and asks the Buddha to visit him. The Buddha does so, and learns that Assaji has difficulty maintaining his meditation. The Buddha encourages him to contemplate the impermanence of the aggregates.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.89", "root_name": "Khemakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.89", "blurb": "Venerable Khemaka is ill, and some senior mendicants ask D\u0101saka to convey their concern to him. There follows a series of exchanges mediated by D\u0101saka until eventually Khemaka, despite his illness, goes to see the other mendicants himself. The seniors are asking to determine Khemaka\u2019s understanding of the Dhamma, and he says that although he has let go of the five lower fetters, he still has a residual attachment to the five aggregates.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.90", "root_name": "Channasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.90", "blurb": "Hearing that the Buddha, while on his deathbed, had announced a special punishment for him, Venerable Channa asks for teachings from the mendicants. Unsatisfied, he seeks out \u0100nanda, who teaches him the address to Kacc\u0101yana (SN 12.15).", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.91", "root_name": "R\u0101hulasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.91", "blurb": "R\u0101hula asks how to contemplate to let go of conceit. The Buddha urges him to see the aggregates as not-self.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.92", "root_name": "Dutiyar\u0101hulasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.92", "blurb": "R\u0101hula asks how to contemplate to let go of conceit and be free. The Buddha urges him to see the aggregates as not-self.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Phoenixes” is the second of four similar sections dealing with the modes in which various semi-celestial beings may be reborn. The current chapter is on the “phoenixes” or supaṇṇas, otherwise known as garuḍa, powerful bird-spirits that are the natural antagonists to the dragons in Indian mythology.

[{"uid": "an6.11", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamas\u0101ra\u1e47\u012byasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.11", "blurb": "Six warm-hearted qualities practiced among the mendicants.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.12", "root_name": "Dutiyas\u0101ra\u1e47\u012byasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.12", "blurb": "Six warm-hearted qualities practiced among the mendicants.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an6.13", "root_name": "Niss\u0101ra\u1e47\u012byasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.13", "blurb": "The Buddha\u2019s teachings are effective, so we can\u2019t claim to have practiced them fully if we\u2019re still afflicted by the various forms of suffering.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an6.14", "root_name": "Bhaddakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.14", "blurb": "A mendicant who lives well and doesn\u2019t waste time will have a good death.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.15", "root_name": "Anutappiyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.15", "blurb": "A mendicant who lives well and doesn\u2019t waste time dies without regret.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.16", "root_name": "Nakulapitusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.16", "blurb": "A sick householder is consoled by his wife, who says there is no need for him to be worried about dying, as she is well able to support the family and practice the Dhamma. He recovers, and visits the Buddha to sing the praises of his kind and wise wife.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an6.17", "root_name": "Soppasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.17", "blurb": "Neither a king nor a mendicant gets anything accomplished if they just sleep all the time.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.18", "root_name": "Macchabandhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.18", "blurb": "Those whose livelihood is the killing of animals do not prosper.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.19", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamamara\u1e47assatisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.19", "blurb": "Many of those who practice mindfulness of death don\u2019t do so urgently enough. Death might come to us at any moment.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an6.20", "root_name": "Dutiyamara\u1e47assatisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.20", "blurb": "A method for recollecting one\u2019s own death that leads to urgency, diligence, and joy.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: The Peṭakopadesa or “Illustration of the Baskets” is a systematic treatise intended to provide a guide for reading and interpreting the texts of the nikāyas. It is similar to the Netti, and the exact relationship between these two texts is not clear. The text provides an array of methods for reading texts, illustrating them with quotations, and taking the four noble truths as the overall framework. The Pali text of the Peṭakopadesa is quite corrupt, which is unusual in the Pali canon. A colophon in the text attributes it to the Buddha's disciple Kaccāna. It is, however, a late text, lacking counterparts in the northern collections. It is not universally accepted as canonical; SuttaCentral’s Pali texts, however, stem from the Mahāsaṅgīti edition, which as a Burmese text does include it.

translated_name: The Chapter on the Root of All Things
blurb: This chapter, though beginning with the abstruse Mūlapariyāya Sutta, mostly contains foundational teachings and can, as a whole, serve as an introduction to the discourses.
children: [{"uid": "mn1", "root_name": "M\u016blapariy\u0101yasutta", "translated_name": "The Root of All Things ", "acronym": "MN 1", "blurb": "The Buddha examines how the notion of a permanent self emerges from the process of perception. A wide range of phenomena are considered, embracing both naturalistic and cosmological dimensions. An unawakened person interprets experience in terms of a self, while those more advanced have the same experiences without attachment.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "mn2", "root_name": "Sabb\u0101savasutta", "translated_name": "All the Defilements ", "acronym": "MN 2", "blurb": "The diverse problems of the spiritual journey demand a diverse range of responses. Rather than applying the same solution to every problem, the Buddha outlines seven methods of dealing with defilements, each of which works in certain cases.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "mn3", "root_name": "Dhammad\u0101y\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": "Heirs in the Teaching ", "acronym": "MN 3", "blurb": "Some of the Buddha\u2019s students inherit from him only material profits and fame. But his true inheritance is the spiritual path, the way of contentment. Venerable S\u0101riputta explains how by following the Buddha\u2019s example we can experience the fruits of the path.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "mn4", "root_name": "Bhayabheravasutta", "translated_name": "Fear and Dread ", "acronym": "MN 4", "blurb": "The Buddha explains the difficulties of living in the wilderness, and how they are overcome by purity of conduct and meditation. He recounts some of the fears and obstacles he faced during his own practice.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "mn5", "root_name": "Ana\u1e45ga\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": "Unblemished ", "acronym": "MN 5", "blurb": "The Buddha\u2019s chief disciples, S\u0101riputta and Moggall\u0101na, use a simile of a tarnished bowl to illustrate the blemishes of the mind and conduct. They emphasize how the crucial thing is not so much whether there are blemishes, but whether we are aware of them.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn6", "root_name": "\u0100ka\u1e45kheyyasutta", "translated_name": "One Might Wish ", "acronym": "MN 6", "blurb": "According to the Buddha, careful observance of ethical precepts is the foundation of all higher achievements in the spiritual life.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "mn7", "root_name": "Vatthasutta", "translated_name": "The Simile of the Cloth ", "acronym": "MN 7", "blurb": "The many different kinds of impurities that defile the mind are compared to a dirty cloth. When the mind is clean we find joy, which leads to states of higher consciousness. Finally, the Buddha rejects the Brahmanical notion that purity comes from bathing in sacred rivers.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "mn8", "root_name": "Sallekhasutta", "translated_name": "Self-Effacement ", "acronym": "MN 8", "blurb": "The Buddha differentiates between peaceful meditation and spiritual practices that encompass the whole of life. He lists forty-four aspects, which he explains as \u201ceffacement\u201d, the wearing away of conceit.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "mn9", "root_name": "Samm\u0101di\u1e6d\u1e6dhisutta", "translated_name": "Right View ", "acronym": "MN 9", "blurb": "Venerable S\u0101riputta gives a detailed explanation of right view, the first factor of the noble eightfold path. At the prompting of the other mendicants, he approaches the topic from a wide range of perspectives.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "mn10", "root_name": "Mah\u0101satipa\u1e6d\u1e6dh\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": "The Discourse on Mindfulness Meditation ", "acronym": "MN 10", "blurb": "Here the Buddha details the seventh factor of the noble eightfold path, mindfulness meditation. This collects many of the meditation teachings found throughout the canon, especially the foundational practices focusing on the body, and is regarded as one of the most important meditation discourses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}]

blurb: The Gāndhārī Dharmapada (also known as the Khotan Dhammapada) is from a birch-bark manuscript in Kharoṣṭhī script discovered at Kohmāri Mazār near Khotan in Xinjiang in 1892. It dates to the early centuries CE, and is one of the oldest surviving Buddhist manuscripts. It was edited and published by Brough (1962), and was digitized by Gandhari.org.

blurb: While the Tibetan canon or Kangyur lacks the full Nikāyas/Āgamas found in Chinese and Pali, there is a large quantity of early material found as independent discourses or embedded within larger works.
children: [{"uid": "up", "root_name": "Up\u0101yik\u0101", "translated_name": "Key to the Abhidharmako\u015ba ", "acronym": "Up", "blurb": "The Up\u0101yika, full name Abhidharmako\u015bop\u0101yikan\u0101ma\u1e6d\u012bk\u0101, is a collection of quotes from the early suttas made by a monk called \u015aamathadeva, who probably lived in India sometime after the 5th century. It was translated into Tibetan by J\u0101ya\u015br\u012b (\u0f5e\u0f72\u0f0b\u0f42\u0f53\u0f66\u0f0b\u0f63\u0fb7\u0f0d), probably around the 11th century. It gives the full sutta passages referred to by Vasubandhu in his Abhidharmako\u015ba. The SuttaCentral text is from the Asian Classics Input Project, where it is listed as Tengyur 4091.04.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "xct", "root_lang_name": "Tibetan", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 7}, {"uid": "d", "root_name": "Other Tibetan Texts, Derg\u00e9 Canon", "translated_name": "Discourse Texts of the Derg\u00e9 Canon ", "acronym": "Other Tibetan", "blurb": "The Deg\u00e9 (or Derge) Kangyur is an edition of the Tibetan canon based on the traditional printing center at the town of Derge in Sichuan, China. The SuttaCentral text is from the digital edition of the Tibetan and Himalayan Library.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "xct", "root_lang_name": "Tibetan", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on the Undeclared” contains 44 discourses on the theme of the ten “undeclared” questions. These are a stock series of metaphysical hypotheses, which the Buddha dismissed as being based on the implicit assumption of a self, and hence as being counterproductive to liberation. The first discourse here features a conversation between King Pasenadi and the nun Khemā on this topic.

blurb: The Pali version of this famous text, consisting of 423 verses organized into memorable themes. It is the most widely read of the early texts, and has been translated many times into many languages. Versions of this text are found in Chinese, Tibetan, and several Indic languages, attesting to its timeless, universal appeal.

translated_name: The Chapter with Kaḷāra the Aristocrat
children: [{"uid": "sn12.31", "root_name": "Bh\u016btasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.31", "blurb": "The Buddha asks S\u0101riputta to explain a verse from \u201cThe Questions of Ajita\u201d in the Par\u0101yana (Snp 5.2). At first, S\u0101riputta hesitates, but proceeds when the Buddha indicates he is looking for an answer in terms of conditionality.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.32", "root_name": "Ka\u1e37\u0101rasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.32", "blurb": "A mendicant named Ka\u1e37a\u0304ra the Khattiya informs S\u0101riputta that the mendicant Mo\u1e37iyaphagguna had disrobed. Overinterpreting S\u0101riputta\u2019s reply, Ka\u1e37a\u0304ra reports to the Buddha that S\u0101riputta had claimed to have ended all defilements. The Buddha calls S\u0101riputta to clarify his statements, and S\u0101riputta explains in terms of dependent origination.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.33", "root_name": "\u00d1\u0101\u1e47avatthusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.33", "blurb": "An analysis of 44 contexts for developing insight with regard to dependent origination. This includes an important distinction between knowledge arising from direct vision of the present, and that derived from inference as to the past and future.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.34", "root_name": "Dutiya\u00f1\u0101\u1e47avatthusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.34", "blurb": "An analysis of 77 contexts for developing insight with regard to dependent origination.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.35", "root_name": "Avijj\u0101paccayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.35", "blurb": "A mendicant asks who possesses old age and death, and the other factors. The Buddha says the question is improper, as it assumes a self as agent. Rather, dependent origination is the teaching \u201cby the middle\u201d, explaining phenomena according to natural conditions.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.36", "root_name": "Dutiyaavijj\u0101paccayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.36", "blurb": "The content of this discourse is identical with SN 12.35, except presented as a general teaching by the Buddha, without an questioner.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.37", "root_name": "Natumhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.37", "blurb": "The body is not yours, but is old kamma, generated by choices in past lives.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.38", "root_name": "Cetan\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.38", "blurb": "Intentions or choices are the force that propels consciousness from one life to the next.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.39", "root_name": "Dutiyacetan\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.39", "blurb": "Intentions or choices are the force that propels consciousness from one life to the next.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.40", "root_name": "Tatiyacetan\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.40", "blurb": "Intentions or choices are the force that propels consciousness from one life to the next.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

translated_name: Linked Discourses on the Five Powers
blurb: The “Linked Discourses on the Five Powers” contains 108 discourses, which are, however, a mere instantiation of the standard repetition series as applied to the five powers. These powers are effectively identical with the five faculties, as stated at SN 48.43, being merely distinguished as a different teaching approach. There are several discourses on these qualities found mainly in the Aṅguttara Fives, but for some reason the redactors did not collect them here.

translated_name: The Group of Linked Discourses With Verses
blurb: The “Book With Verses” is the first of the five books of the Linked Discourses. It is divided into eleven saṁyuttas or “sections”, with a total of 271 suttas. Most of these are further subdivided into vaggas of ten suttas. The word vagga is thus used of both the major overarching “book” and the subsidiary “chapter”. Each of the suttas in this collection contains verse with a prose narrative structure, although in many cases the prose has been omitted through abbreviation. Where most of the Saṁyutta is organized around subject matter, here the organizational principle is people. Each saṁyutta contains conversation involving the Buddha or his disciples with a different person or kind of person, such as gods, kings, nuns, or brahmins. A typical sutta has a bare narrative framework, where someone comes to the Buddha and utters a verse, and the Buddha replies with a better one. In some cases, notably the Sakkasaṁyutta, the narrative element is developed into a lively exchange. Some of the texts in this collection are well known and widely quoted, such as the invitation of Brahmā or the nun Vajirā’s simile of the person as a chariot. Most of the suttas here have parallels in the Chinese Saṁyuktāgama translations; the partial translations SA 2 and SA 3 include Sagāthāvagga material. In addition, many of the verses have parallels elsewhere throughout the Buddhist literature in all languages.
children: [{"uid": "sn1", "root_name": "Devat\u0101sa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses With Deities ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on Deities\u201d contains 81 discourses, each one of which depicts the Buddha in conversation with a deity. Typically a deity approaches the Buddha in the monastery at S\u0101vatth\u012b, illuminating the night with their glory. The deity addresses the Buddha with a question or verse, which may be a praise, a challenge, a riddle, or simply a reflection. The Buddha responds, usually elevating the discourse to a higher plane. As always in Buddhist texts, a deity is not worshiped, but is regarded as a temporary rebirth in a higher plane; the deities learn from the Buddha, not the other way around. In most cases, the narrative framework is slim, and after a while it is dropped entirely, retaining just the verses. There\u2019s no particular theme to the discourses, which range from the simple to the profound.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 1", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 162}, {"uid": "sn2", "root_name": "Devaputtasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on Gods ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on Gods\u201d contains 30 discourses, each one of which depicts the Buddha in conversation with a god. Here the term devaputta is used, rather than devat\u0101 in the previous sa\u1e41yutta. The difference is purely nominal and there is no difference in the meaning. The style of discourses is similar to the \u201cLinked Discourses on Deities\u201d, although here there is a greater emphasis on the theme of renunciation. A number of these discourses are regularly recited in modern Therav\u0101da; the T\u0101yana verses on diligent striving at SN 2.8 are often recited by monastics, while the discourses on the sun and the moon (SN 2.9 and SN 2.10) are popular protection chants, which are also found in Tibetan.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 2", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 31}, {"uid": "sn3", "root_name": "Kosalasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses With King Pasenadi of Kosala ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses with the Kosalan\u201d contains 25 discourses featuring King Pasenadi of Kosala. Pasenadi shines through in the early texts as a complex human figure, one with foibles and foolishness, but with a great devotion and capacity to grow. He appears frequently elsewhere in the suttas; MN 87 tells the story of how Queen Mallik\u0101 led him to the Dhamma. Here Mallik\u0101 appears again, and in SN 3.8 she shows how she is not afraid to challenge her king. The suttas in this collection typically set the verses in substantive prose narratives, illustrating the struggles and problems that beset a king intent on Dhamma who must nonetheless rule in a world with spies, sacrifices, punishments, wars, and the many temptations of royal life.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 3", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 25}, {"uid": "sn4", "root_name": "M\u0101rasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses With M\u0101ra ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses with M\u0101ra\u201d contains 25 discourses featuring M\u0101ra, the god of temptation, deceit, and death. In these discourses, M\u0101ra typically appears in some terrifying or beguiling form, hoping to disturb the Buddha, or else he challenges the Buddha with a critical verse. Like the previous section, the narrative prose here is substantive. The Buddha recognizes him at once and exposes his deceit in a verse. M\u0101ra also appears throughout the next collection, where the nuns take him on. ", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 4", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 50}, {"uid": "sn5", "root_name": "Bhikkhun\u012bsa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses With Nuns ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses with Nuns\u201d contains 10 discourses describing occasions when various nuns retreat to a forest for meditation, only to be challenged by M\u0101ra. The verses here partly overlap with the Ther\u012bg\u0101th\u0101, though there are some that are unique to this context, and we also have a prose narrative to flesh out the context. M\u0101ra\u2019s challenges are various; sometimes he is sexist, alleging that women are weak in wisdom (SN 5.2). Several of these short texts are among the most frequently quoted of all the suttas.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 5", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 20}, {"uid": "sn6", "root_name": "Brahmasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses With Brahm\u0101 Gods ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses with Brahm\u0101s\u201d contains 15 discourses featuring high brahmanical deities. Most commonly we meet the \u201cGreat Brahm\u0101\u201d, regarded as the creator God, but he is merely one of a class of deities, and here we meet several others. Brahm\u0101 is depicted here and elsewhere in early Buddhist texts in a respectful way, regarded as a glorious deity reborn in his realm due to powerful good kamma. As here, he frequently acts as a champion for the Buddhist cause. However, like all the gods, he is still under the influence of delusion and has nor escaped rebirth.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 6", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 15}, {"uid": "sn7", "root_name": "Br\u0101hma\u1e47asa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses with Brahmins ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses with Brahmins\u201d contains 22 discourses featuring the Buddha interacting with various members of the brahmanical caste. The brahmins were the custodians of the brahmanical scriptures and traditions, and saw themselves as the spiritual elite of society. A central platform of the Buddha\u2019s ethical teaching was that one\u2019s worth is determined by one\u2019s deeds, not by caste. This was a direct challenge to brahmanical authority, and a number of discourses have an understandably combative air to them. But the brahmins were a diverse community, and it\u2019s just as common to find them relating to the Buddha with respect and gratitude.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 7", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 22}, {"uid": "sn8", "root_name": "Va\u1e45g\u012bsasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses With Va\u1e45g\u012bsa ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses with Va\u1e45g\u012bsa\u201d contains 12 discourses with verses spoken by Va\u1e45g\u012bsa, the most renowned poet of early Buddhism. His verses have a sophistication and personal vulnerability that stamp them as perhaps the most distinctive literary voice of the early texts. Several of these discourses speak of his insecurities and struggles, and how he was helped to overcome them. Others speak from his joyous devotion to the Buddha and the Sa\u1e45gha, and of his final triumph.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 8", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 12}, {"uid": "sn9", "root_name": "Vanasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses in the Woods ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses in the Woods\u201d contains 14 discourses with verses telling the experiences of certain monks living the woods. Typically the monk is slack or negligent in some way, and a deity appears to call them out and encourage them to greater diligence.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 9", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 14}, {"uid": "sn10", "root_name": "Yakkhasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses with Spirits ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses with Spirits\u201d contains 12 discourses with verses telling the encounters between the Buddha\u2014or in one case the monk Anuruddha\u2014and various spirits (yakkha). The spirits were local deities worshiped in ancient India, of a lower order than the gods and Brahm\u0101s. While in later forms of Buddhism, such spirits were typically depicted as malevolent or dangerous, in the early texts they are more ambivalent, and many of them are friendly, merely asking Dhamma questions, or extolling Dhamma virtues like mindfulness. That\u2019s not to say they couldn\u2019t be scary, and several discourses reveal a more ferocious aspect. Particularly interesting is the emphasis on the love that the female spirits feel for their children.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 10", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 12}, {"uid": "sn11", "root_name": "Sakkasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses with Sakka ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses with Sakka\u201d contains 25 discourses with verses telling stories involving Sakka, the Lord of the Thirty-Three gods. Many of these discourses are relatively lengthy, featuring substantive prose and extended dialogues in verse. Sakka is shown devoted to the Buddha, defending Buddhist virtues of kindness and forgiveness, even in the waging of war with the demons.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 11", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 50}]

blurb: Like the previous chapter, this contains a diverse range of discourses. It is named after the first discourse in the chapter. Among the discourses here are legendary accounts of the history and future of our world, which are extremely famous and influential in Buddhist circles.
children: [{"uid": "dn24", "root_name": "P\u0101thikasutta", "translated_name": "About P\u0101\u1e6dikaputta ", "acronym": "DN 24", "blurb": "When Sunakkhatta threatens to disrobe, the Buddha is unimpressed. Rejecting showy displays of asceticism or wondrous powers, he demonstrates his pre-eminence.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn25", "root_name": "Udumbarikasutta", "translated_name": "The Lion\u2019s Roar at Udumbarik\u0101\u2019s Monastery ", "acronym": "DN 25", "blurb": "This discourse gives a specially good example of dialog between religions. The Buddha insists that he is not interested to make anyone give up their teacher or practices, but only to help people let go of suffering.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn26", "root_name": "Cakkavattisutta", "translated_name": "The Wheel-Turning Monarch ", "acronym": "DN 26", "blurb": "In illustration of his dictum that one should rely on oneself, the Buddha gives a detailed account of the fall of a kingly lineage of the past, and the subsequent degeneration of society. This process, however, is not over, as the Buddha predicts that eventually society will fall into utter chaos. But far in the future, another Buddha, Metteyya, will arise in a time of peace and plenty.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn27", "root_name": "Agga\u00f1\u00f1asutta", "translated_name": "The Origin of the World ", "acronym": "DN 27", "blurb": "In contrast with the brahmin\u2019s self-serving mythologies of the past, the Buddha presents an account of evolution that shows how human choices are an integral part of the ecological balance, and how excessive greed destroys the order of nature.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn28", "root_name": "Sampas\u0101dan\u012byasutta", "translated_name": "Inspiring Confidence ", "acronym": "DN 28", "blurb": "Shortly before he passes away, Venerable S\u0101riputta visits the Buddha and utters a moving eulogy of his great teacher.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn29", "root_name": "P\u0101s\u0101dikasutta", "translated_name": "An Impressive Discourse ", "acronym": "DN 29", "blurb": "Following the death of Niga\u1e47\u1e6dha N\u0101taputta, the leader of the Jains, the Buddha emphasizes the stability and maturity of his own community. He encourages the community to come together after his death and recite the teachings in harmony.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn30", "root_name": "Lakkha\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": "The Marks of a Great Man ", "acronym": "DN 30", "blurb": "This presents the brahmanical prophecy of the Great Man, and explains the 32 marks in detail. This discourse contains some of the latest and most complex verse forms in the canon.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn31", "root_name": "Si\u1e45g\u0101lasutta", "translated_name": "Advice to Sig\u0101laka ", "acronym": "DN 31", "blurb": "The Buddha encounters a young man who honors his dead parents by performing rituals. The Buddha recasts the meaningless rites in terms of virtuous conduct. This is the most detailed discourse on ethics for lay people.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn32", "root_name": "\u0100\u1e6d\u0101n\u0101\u1e6diyasutta", "translated_name": "The \u0100\u1e6d\u0101n\u0101\u1e6diya Protection ", "acronym": "DN 32", "blurb": "Mighty spirits hold a congregation, and warn the Buddha that, since not all spirits are friendly, the mendicants should learn verses of protection.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn33", "root_name": "Sa\u1e45g\u012btisutta", "translated_name": "Reciting in Concert ", "acronym": "DN 33", "blurb": "The Buddha encourages Venerable S\u0101riputta to teach the mendicants, and he offers an extended listing of Buddhist doctrines arranged in numerical sequence.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn34", "root_name": "Dasuttarasutta", "translated_name": "Up to Ten ", "acronym": "DN 34", "blurb": "This is similar to the previous, but with a different manner of exposition. These two discourses anticipate some of the methods of the Abhidhamma.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}]

blurb: The Degé (or Derge) Kangyur is an edition of the Tibetan canon based on the traditional printing center at the town of Derge in Sichuan, China. The SuttaCentral text is from the digital edition of the Tibetan and Himalayan Library.
