translated_name: The Chapter on In the Woods
children: [{"uid": "sn9.1", "root_name": "Vivekasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 9.1", "blurb": "A monk in the forest lets his mind drift to thoughts of the lay life, but is warned by a local deity.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn9.2", "root_name": "Upa\u1e6d\u1e6dh\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 9.2", "blurb": "When a mendicant falls asleep in the middle of the day, a deity tries to rouse them up. But not all is at it seems.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn9.3", "root_name": "Kassapagottasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 9.3", "blurb": "A monk named Kassapagotta encounters a hunter in the forest and tries to dissuade him from his violent purpose. But a deity warns him not to waste his time.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn9.4", "root_name": "Sambahulasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 9.4", "blurb": "When a group of mendicants leave the forest in which they had been staying, the local deities lament their absence.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn9.5", "root_name": "\u0100nandasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 9.5", "blurb": "A deity warns \u0100nanda about getting too involved with teaching lay folk.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn9.6", "root_name": "Anuruddhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 9.6", "blurb": "A former partner of Venerable Anuruddha, now a deity named J\u0101lin\u012b, tries to tempt him with heavenly pleasures. But he has seen a higher happiness.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn9.7", "root_name": "N\u0101gadattasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 9.7", "blurb": "When Venerable N\u0101gadatta spends too much time in the village, a deity admonishes him.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn9.8", "root_name": "Kulaghara\u1e47\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 9.8", "blurb": "A deity becomes concerned of the gossip about a certain monk who had become close with a family in the village. Taking the form of one of the women of the family, she tries to warn him; but he says a true practitioner is not concerned with gossip.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn9.9", "root_name": "Vajjiputtasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 9.9", "blurb": "Hearing the sounds of a city festival, a mendicant feels lonely in the forest. A deity comes to give them solace and support.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn9.10", "root_name": "Sajjh\u0101yasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 9.10", "blurb": "When a mendicant gives up their habit of reciting the texts, a deity questions them. But it seems they have now found peace.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn9.11", "root_name": "Akusalavitakkasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 9.11", "blurb": "A mendicant plagued by bad thoughts is encouraged by a deity.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn9.12", "root_name": "Majjhanhikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 9.12", "blurb": "A deity speaks of the fearfulness of the murmuring forest. But to a mendicant it seems delightful.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn9.13", "root_name": "P\u0101katindriyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 9.13", "blurb": "A group of mendicants in the forest had fallen into bad ways, becoming conceited and confused. A deity came to admonish them, making clear that they were only speaking of the badly behaved, not all mendicants.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn9.14", "root_name": "Gandhatthenasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 9.14", "blurb": "A mendicant takes a bath in a pond and sniffs a lotus. A deity accuses him of being a \u201cthief of scent\u201d. For a person living a life of purity, even such a small matter is a cause for concern", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "an6.65", "root_name": "An\u0101g\u0101miphalasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.65", "blurb": "Six things lead to non-return.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.66", "root_name": "Arahattasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.66", "blurb": "Six things lead to perfection.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.67", "root_name": "Mittasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.67", "blurb": "With bad friends, a mendicant cannot fulfill six good qualities, but with good friends they can.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.68", "root_name": "Sa\u1e45ga\u1e47ik\u0101r\u0101masutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.68", "blurb": "A mendicant who loves to socialize can\u2019t find peace in meditation, but one who loves solitude can.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.69", "root_name": "Devat\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.69", "blurb": "A god speaks on the factors of non-decline. When the Buddha repeats what he says, S\u0101riputta gives an explaination.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.70", "root_name": "Sam\u0101dhisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.70", "blurb": "Without sam\u0101dhi or immersion it is impossible to realize the higher truths of the path.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.71", "root_name": "Sakkhibhabbasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.71", "blurb": "Six qualities that enable a mendicant to gain understanding.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.72", "root_name": "Balasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.72", "blurb": "Six qualities that enable a mendicant to gain strength in meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.73", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamatajjh\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.73", "blurb": "Six qualities that enable a mendicant to gain the first absorption.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.74", "root_name": "Dutiyatajjh\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.74", "blurb": "Six qualities that enable a mendicant to gain the first absorption.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

translated_name: The Spirit in the Clump of Grass
children: [{"uid": "ja121", "root_name": "Kusan\u0101\u1e37ij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Spirit in the Clump of Grass ", "acronym": "Ja 121", "blurb": "\u201cLet great and small.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about Anatha-pindika\u2019s true friend. For his acquaintances and friends and relations came to him and tried hard to stop his intimacy with a certain man, saying that neither in birth nor wealth was he Anatha-pindika\u2019s equal. But the great merchant replied that friendship should not depend on equality or inequality of externals. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja122", "root_name": "Dummedhaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Lacking Intelligence ", "acronym": "Ja 122", "blurb": "\u201cExalted station breeds a fool great woe.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at the Bamboo-grove, about Devadatta. For the Brethren had met together in the Hall of Truth, and were talking of how the sight of the Buddha\u2019s perfections and all the distinctive signs of Buddhahood maddened Devadatta; and how in his jealousy he could not bear to hear the praises of the Buddha\u2019s utter wisdom. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja123", "root_name": "Na\u1e45gal\u012bsaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Shaft of a Plough ", "acronym": "Ja 123", "blurb": "\u201cFor universal application.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about the Elder Laludayi who is said to have had a knack of always saying the wrong thing. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja124", "root_name": "Ambaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Mangoes ", "acronym": "Ja 124", "blurb": "\u201cToil on, my brother.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a good brahmin belonging to a noble Savatthi family who gave his heart to the Truth, and, joining the Brotherhood, became constant in all duties. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja125", "root_name": "Ka\u1e6d\u0101hakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Clever Young Man Ka\u1e6d\u0101haka ", "acronym": "Ja 125", "blurb": "\u201cIf he \u2018mid strangers.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a boastful Brother. The introductory story about him is like what has been already related.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja126", "root_name": "Asilakkha\u1e47aj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Lucky Swords ", "acronym": "Ja 126", "blurb": "\u201cOur diverse fates.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a brahmin retained by the King of Kosala because of his power of telling whether swords were lucky or not. We are told that when the king\u2019s smiths had forged a sword, this brahmin could by merely smelling it tell whether it was a lucky one or not. And he made it a rule only to commend the work of those smiths who gave him presents, while he rejected the work of those who did not bribe him.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja127", "root_name": "Kala\u1e47\u1e0dukaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Rascal Kala\u1e47\u1e0duka ", "acronym": "Ja 127", "blurb": "\u201cYou vaunt.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master once at Jetavana, about a boastful Brother. (The introductory story and the story of the past in this case are like those of Katahaka related above.)", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja128", "root_name": "Bi\u1e37\u0101ravataj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Hypocrite Like a Cat ", "acronym": "Ja 128", "blurb": "\u201cWhere saintliness.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a hypocrite. When the Brother\u2019s hypocrisy was reported to him, the Master said, \u201cThis is not the first time he has shewn himself a hypocrite; he was just the sane in times gone by.\u201d So saying he told this story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja129", "root_name": "Aggikabh\u0101radv\u0101jaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Bh\u0101radv\u0101ja, Servant of the Sacred Flame ", "acronym": "Ja 129", "blurb": "\u201c\u2019Twas greed.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about another hypocrite.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja130", "root_name": "Kosiyaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Woman Kosiya ", "acronym": "Ja 130", "blurb": "\u201cYou may ail or eat.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a woman of Savatthi. She is said to have been the wicked wife of a good and virtuous brahmin, who was a lay-brother. Her nights she spent in gadding about; whilst by day she did not a stroke of work, but made out to be ill and lay abed groaning.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "iti11", "root_name": "Mohapari\u00f1\u00f1\u0101sutta", "translated_name": "Complete Understanding of Delusion ", "acronym": "Iti 11", "blurb": "When the mind, cleansed of passion for delusion, abandons it, you are capable of putting an end to suffering.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "iti12", "root_name": "Kodhapari\u00f1\u00f1\u0101sutta", "translated_name": "Complete Understanding of Anger ", "acronym": "Iti 12", "blurb": "When the mind, cleansed of passion for anger, abandons it, you are capable of putting an end to suffering.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "iti13", "root_name": "Makkhapari\u00f1\u00f1\u0101sutta", "translated_name": "Complete Understanding of Disdain ", "acronym": "Iti 13", "blurb": "When the mind, cleansed of passion for contempt, abandons it, you are capable of putting an end to suffering.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "iti14", "root_name": "Avijj\u0101n\u012bvara\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": "The Hindrance of Ignorance ", "acronym": "Iti 14", "blurb": "Hindered by the hindrance of ignorance, people go wandering and transmigrating on for a long, long time.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "iti15", "root_name": "Ta\u1e47h\u0101sa\u1e41yojanasutta", "translated_name": "The Fetter of Craving ", "acronym": "Iti 15", "blurb": "Fettered with the fetter of craving, beings go wandering and transmigrating on for a long, long time.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "iti16", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamasekhasutta", "translated_name": "A Trainee (1st) ", "acronym": "Iti 16", "blurb": "Appropriate attention as the prime internal factor to help those in training.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "iti17", "root_name": "Dutiyasekhasutta", "translated_name": "A Trainee (2nd) ", "acronym": "Iti 17", "blurb": "Friendship with admirable people as the prime external factor to help those in training.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "iti18", "root_name": "Sa\u1e41ghabhedasutta", "translated_name": "Schism in the Sa\u1e45gha ", "acronym": "Iti 18", "blurb": "Schism in the Sangha leads to the detriment and unhappiness of many beings, both human and divine.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "iti19", "root_name": "Sa\u1e41ghas\u0101magg\u012bsutta", "translated_name": "Harmony in the Sa\u1e45gha ", "acronym": "Iti 19", "blurb": "Concord in the Sangha leads to the welfare and happiness of many beings, both human and divine.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "iti20", "root_name": "Padu\u1e6d\u1e6dhacittasutta", "translated_name": "A Corrupted Mind ", "acronym": "Iti 20", "blurb": "Corrupt-mindedness leads to rebirth in the planes of deprivation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: The “Stories of Celestial Mansions” contains eighty-five stories in verse that illustrate the heavenly rewards of virtuous deeds, especially making offerings to the Buddha or the Saṅgha. It is a counterpart to the Petavatthu. These are late devotional texts with no direct counterparts in other collections.

translated_name: The Chapter on Gods of the Clouds
children: [{"uid": "an4.101", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamaval\u0101hakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.101", "blurb": "Four people similar to clouds.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an4.102", "root_name": "Dutiyaval\u0101hakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.102", "blurb": "Four people similar to clouds.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an4.103", "root_name": "Kumbhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.103", "blurb": "Four people similar to pots.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an4.104", "root_name": "Udakarahadasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.104", "blurb": "Four people similar to ponds.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an4.105", "root_name": "Ambasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.105", "blurb": "Four people similar to mangoes.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an4.106", "root_name": "(Dutiyaambasutta)", "translated_name": "[Mangoes (2nd)] ", "acronym": "AN 4.106", "blurb": "This is a ghost sutta: there is no text for it in any available editions. However, the summary verse at the end of the chapter (AN 4.110) mentions \u201ctwo on mangoes\u201d. The commentary notes the existence of a discourse here, but merely says that its meaning is clear. A note in the VRI edition says that there is a reading that has obh\u0101sa where the previous sutta has va\u1e47\u1e47a.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an4.107", "root_name": "M\u016bsikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.107", "blurb": "Four people similar to mice.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an4.108", "root_name": "Bal\u012bbaddasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.108", "blurb": "Four people similar to oxen.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an4.109", "root_name": "Rukkhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.109", "blurb": "Four people similar to trees.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an4.110", "root_name": "\u0100s\u012bvisasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.110", "blurb": "Four people similar to vipers.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "ja41", "root_name": "Losakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "On the Mendicant Losaka ", "acronym": "Ja 41", "blurb": "\u201cThe headstrong man.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about the Elder Losaka Tissa.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja42", "root_name": "Kapotaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Pigeon ", "acronym": "Ja 42", "blurb": "\u201cThe headstrong man.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a certain greedy Brother. His greediness will be related in the Ninth Book in the Kaka J\u0101taka.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja43", "root_name": "Ve\u1e37ukaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Monk Who Kept a Viper in Bamboo as a Pet ", "acronym": "Ja 43", "blurb": "\u201cThe headstrong man.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a certain headstrong Brother. For the Blessed One asked him whether the report was true that he was headstrong, and the Brother admitted that it was. \u201cBrother,\u201d said the Master, \u201cthis is not the first time you have been headstrong: you were just as headstrong in former days. also, and, as the result of your headstrong refusal to follow the advice of the wise and good, you met your end by the bite of a snake.\u201d And so saying, he told this story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja44", "root_name": "Makasaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Mosquito ", "acronym": "Ja 44", "blurb": "\u201cSense-lacking friends.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master whilst on an alms-pilgrimage in Magadha, about some stupid villagers in a certain hamlet.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja45", "root_name": "Rohi\u1e47ij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Maid Rohin\u012b ", "acronym": "Ja 45", "blurb": "\u201cSense-lacking friends.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a maid servant of the Lord High Treasurer, Anatha-pindika. For he is said to have had a maid-servant named Rohini, whose aged mother came to where the girl was pounding rice, and lay down. The flies came round the old woman and stung her as with a needle, so she cried to her daughter, \u201cThe flies are stinging me, my dear; do drive them away.\u201d \u201cOh! I\u2019ll drive them away, mother,\u201d said the girl, lifting her pestle to the flies which had settled on her mother. Then, crying, \u201cI\u2019ll kill them!\u201d, she smote her mother such a blow as to kill the old woman outright. Seeing what she had done the girl began to weep and cry, \u201cOh! mother, mother!\u201d", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja46", "root_name": "\u0100r\u0101mad\u016bsakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The One Who Spoiled a Park ", "acronym": "Ja 46", "blurb": "\u201c\u2019Tis knowledge.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master in a certain hamlet of Kosala about one who spoiled a pleasaunce.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja47", "root_name": "V\u0101ru\u1e47id\u016bsakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The One Who Spoiled the Liquor ", "acronym": "Ja 47", "blurb": "\u201c\u2019Tis knowledge.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about one who spoiled spirits..", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja48", "root_name": "Vedabbaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Vedabba Spell ", "acronym": "Ja 48", "blurb": "\u201cMisguided effort.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a self-willed Brother. Said the Master to that Brother, \u201cThis is not the first time, Brother, that you have been self-willed; you were of just the same disposition in bygone times also ; and therefore it was that, as you would not follow the advice of the wise and good, you came to be cut in two by a sharp sword and were flung on the highway; and you were the sole cause why a thousand men met their end.\u201d And so saying, he told this story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja49", "root_name": "Nakkhattaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Lucky Stars ", "acronym": "Ja 49", "blurb": "\u201cThe fool may watch.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about a certain Naked-ascetic. Tradition says that a gentleman of the country near Savatthi asked in marriage for his son a young Savatthi lady of equal rank. Having fixed a day to come and fetch the bride, he subsequently consulted a Naked-ascetic who was intimate with his family, as to whether the stars were favourable for holding the festivities that day.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja50", "root_name": "Dummedhaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Sacrifice of a Thousand Reprobates ", "acronym": "Ja 50", "blurb": "\u201cA thousand evil-doers.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about actions done for the world\u2019s good, as will be explained in the Twelfth Book in the Maha-Kanha-jataka.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "sn36.1", "root_name": "Sam\u0101dhisutta", "translated_name": "Immersion ", "acronym": "SN 36.1", "blurb": "There are three feelings, and a meditator practicing immersion can understand them.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn36.2", "root_name": "Sukhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 36.2", "blurb": "There are three feelings, and all of them are suffering.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn36.3", "root_name": "Pah\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 36.3", "blurb": "One should give up desire for pleasant feeling, aversion for painful feeling, and ignorance regarding neutral feeling.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn36.4", "root_name": "P\u0101t\u0101lasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 36.4", "blurb": "Ordinary people think the ocean is a bottomless abyss; but really, it is the three feelings.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn36.5", "root_name": "Da\u1e6d\u1e6dhabbasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 36.5", "blurb": "See pleasant feeling as painful, painful feeling as a dart, and neutral feeling as impermanent.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn36.6", "root_name": "Sallasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 36.6", "blurb": "Both ordinary and awakened people experience the three feelings. The difference is that when an ordinary person is stricken with feeling, they react, creating more suffering, whereas an awakened person responds with equanimity.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "sn36.7", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamagela\u00f1\u00f1asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 36.7", "blurb": "A mendicant should await their death mindful and aware. They should bear the feelings of approaching death with wisdom and equanimity.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn36.8", "root_name": "Dutiyagela\u00f1\u00f1asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 36.8", "blurb": "A mendicant should await their death mindful and aware. They should bear the feelings of approaching death with wisdom and equanimity.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn36.9", "root_name": "Aniccasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 36.9", "blurb": "The three feelings are impermanent.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn36.10", "root_name": "Phassam\u016blakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 36.10", "blurb": "The three feelings are each produced by the appropriate contact.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

[{"uid": "ja261", "root_name": "Padumaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Lotus ", "acronym": "Ja 261", "blurb": "\u201cCut, and cut, and cut again\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Jetavana, about some Brethren who made offering of garlands under Ananda\u2019s tree. The circumstances will be given in the Kalinga-bodhi Birth. This was called Ananda\u2019s tree, because Ananda planted it. All India heard tell haw the Elder had planted this tree by the gate of Jetavana.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja262", "root_name": "Mudup\u0101\u1e47ij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "A Gentle Hand ", "acronym": "Ja 262", "blurb": "\u201cA soft hand\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Jetavana, about a back-sliding Brother. They brought him to the Hall of Truth, and the Master asked him if he were really a backslider? He replied, yes, he was. Then said the Master, \u201cO Brethren! It is impossible to keep women from going after their desires. In olden days, even wise men could not guard their own daughters; while they stood holding their fathers\u2019 hand, without their fathers\u2019 knowing, they went away wrong-doing with a paramour\u201d; and he told them an old-world tale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja263", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37apalobhanaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Shorter Tale of Allure ", "acronym": "Ja 263", "blurb": "\u201cNot through the sea\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Jetavana, also about a backsliding Brother. The Master had him brought into the Hall of Truth, and asked if it were true that he was a backslider. Yes, said he, it was. \u201cWomen,\u201d said the Master, \u201cin olden days made even believing souls to sin.\u201d Then he told a story.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja264", "root_name": "Mah\u0101pan\u0101daj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Palace of King Pan\u0101da ", "acronym": "Ja 264", "blurb": "\u201c\u2019Twas king Panada\u201d\u2014This story the Master told when he was settled on the bank of the Ganges, about the miraculous power of Elder Bhaddaji.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja265", "root_name": "Khurappaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Arrow ", "acronym": "Ja 265", "blurb": "\u201cWhen many a bow\u201d\u2014This story the Master told in Jetavana, about a Brother who had lost all energy. The Master asked, was it true that this Brother had lost his energy. Yes, he replied. \u201cWhy,\u201d asked he, \u201chave you slackened your energy, after embracing this doctrine of salvation? In days of yore, wise men were energetic even in matters which do not lead to salvation;\u201d and so saying he told an old-world tale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja266", "root_name": "V\u0101taggasindhavaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Steed Windswift ", "acronym": "Ja 266", "blurb": "\u201cHe for whose sake\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Jetavana, about a certain land-owner.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja267", "root_name": "Kakka\u1e6dakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Golden Crab ", "acronym": "Ja 267", "blurb": "\u201cGold-clawed creature\u201d\u2014 This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, about a certain woman.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja268", "root_name": "\u0100r\u0101mad\u016bsakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The One Who Spoiled a Park ", "acronym": "Ja 268", "blurb": "\u201cBest of all\u201d\u2014This story the Master told whilst dwelling in the country near Dakkhinagiri, about a gardener\u2019s son.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja269", "root_name": "Suj\u0101taj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Suj\u0101t\u0101 the Merchant\u2019s Daughter ", "acronym": "Ja 269", "blurb": "\u201cThose who are dowered\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while living in Jetavana about one Sujata, a daughter-in-law of Anatha-pindika, daughter of the great merchant Dhananjaya, and youngest sister of Visakha.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja270", "root_name": "Ul\u016bkaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Owl ", "acronym": "Ja 270", "blurb": "\u201cThe owl is King\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while living at Jetavana, about a quarrel between Crows and Owls.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

translated_name: Sayings of the Dharma With Stories (Chinese)
blurb: Four fascicles, compiled by Dharmatrāta and translated by Faju 法炬, and Fali 法立 during the years of Huidi 惠帝 (290–306 C.E.) in the Western Jin dynasty 西晉 at Luoyang. Also known by the titles of 法句本末經, 法句喩經, 法喩經, and 法句譬經. Written in thirty-nine chapters, it is, like the 法句經 (T 210), closely related to the Dhammapada of the Pāli Canon, and about two thirds of this text are the same as T 210. It is composed of explanatory text added to the verses of the Dharmapāda.

translated_name: The Chapter on Your Own Mind
children: [{"uid": "an10.51", "root_name": "Sacittasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.51", "blurb": "The Buddha teaches that, if you can\u2019t read anyone else\u2019s mind, read your own by regular self-reflection.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an10.52", "root_name": "S\u0101riputtasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.52", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta teaches that, if you can\u2019t read anyone else\u2019s mind, read your own by regular self-reflection.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an10.53", "root_name": "\u1e6chitisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.53", "blurb": "The Buddha doesn\u2019t praise stagnation in wholesome qualities, let alone decline.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an10.54", "root_name": "Samathasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.54", "blurb": "The Buddha teaches that, if you can\u2019t read anyone else\u2019s mind, read your own by regular self-reflection. translated_name: The Elephant Who Cared for His Mother
children: [{"uid": "ja455", "root_name": "M\u0101tuposakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Elephant Who Cared for His Mother ", "acronym": "Ja 455", "blurb": "\u201cThough far away\u201d\u2014This story the Master told, while dwelling in Jetavana, about an Elder who had his mother to support. The circumstances of the event are like those of the Sama Birth. On this occasion also the Master said, addressing the Brethren, \u201cBe not wroth, Brethren, with this man; wise men there have been of old, who even when born from the womb of animals, being parted asunder from their mothers, refused for seven days to take food, pining away; and even when they were offered food fit for a king, did but reply, Without my mother I will not eat; yet took food again when they saw the mother.\u201d So saying, he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja456", "root_name": "Ju\u1e47haj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Prince Moonlight ", "acronym": "Ja 456", "blurb": "\u201cO king of men\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana about the boons received by Elder Ananda.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja457", "root_name": "Dhammadevaputtaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Deity Named Dhamma ", "acronym": "Ja 457", "blurb": "\u201cI do the right\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling in Jetavana, how Devadatta was swallowed up in the earth. They gathered in the Hall of Truth to talk: \u201cFriend, Devadatta fell at enmity with the Tathagata, and was swallowed up in the earth.\u201d The Master entering asked what they were talking of as they sat there. They told him. He replied, \u201cNow, Brethren, he has been swallowed up in the earth because he dealt a blow at my victorious authority; but formerly he dealt a blow at the authority of right, and was swallowed up in the earth, and went on his way to nethermost hell.\u201d So saying, he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja458", "root_name": "Udayaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Prince Udayabhadda ", "acronym": "Ja 458", "blurb": "\u201cThee flawless\u201d\u2014This story the Master told, while dwelling in Jetavana, about a backsliding Brother. The occasion will be explained under the Kusa Birth. Again the Master asked the man, \u201cIs it true, Brother, that you have backslidden, as they say?\u201d And he replied, \u201cYes, Sir.\u201d Then he said, \u201cO Brother, why are you backsliding from a religion such as ours, that leads to salvation, and all for fleshly lusts? Wise men of old, who were kings in Surundha, a city prosperous and measuring twelve leagues either way, though for seven hundred years they abode in one chamber with a woman beauteous as the nymphs divine, yet did not yield to their senses, and never so much as looked at her with desire.\u201d So saying, he told a story of the past. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja459", "root_name": "P\u0101n\u012byaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Stolen Drink ", "acronym": "Ja 459", "blurb": "\u201cThe water-draught\u201d\u2014This story the Master told, whilst dwelling in Jetavana, about the subduing of evil passions.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja460", "root_name": "Yudha\u00f1cayaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Crown Prince Yudha\u00f1caya ", "acronym": "Ja 460", "blurb": "\u201cI greet the lord\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling in Jetavana, about the Great Renunciation. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja461", "root_name": "Dasarathaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "King Dasaratha ", "acronym": "Ja 461", "blurb": "\u201cLet Lakkhana\u201d\u2014This story the Master told in Jetavana about a landowner whose father was dead. This man on his father\u2019s death was overwhelmed with sorrow: leaving all his duties undone, he gave himself up to his sorrow wholly. The Master at dawn of day looking out upon mankind, perceived that he was ripe for attaining the fruit of the First Path. Next day, after going his rounds for alms in Savatthi, his meal done, he dismissed the Brethren, and taking with him a junior Brother, went to this man\u2019s house, and gave him greeting, and addressed him as he sat there in words of honey sweetness. \u201cYou are in sorrow, lay Brother?\u201d said he. \u201cYes, Sir, afflicted with sorrow for my father\u2019s sake.\u201d Said the Master, \u201cLay Brother, wise men of old who exactly knew the eight conditions of this world , felt at a father\u2019s death no grief, not even a little.\u201d Then at his request he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja462", "root_name": "Sa\u1e41varaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Prince Sa\u1e41vara ", "acronym": "Ja 462", "blurb": "\u201cYour nature, mighty monarch\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling in Jetavana, about a Brother who had ceased to strive.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja463", "root_name": "Supp\u0101rakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Sailor Supp\u0101raka ", "acronym": "Ja 463", "blurb": "\u201cMen with razor pointed\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, about the Perfection of Knowledge.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses with Monks” contains 12 discourses featuring different monks. Unlike the chapter on nuns, this does not use a consistent template, but depicts a diverse range of scenarios. Each case shows a personal challenge or spiritual triumph, shedding a light on the life of the monks.

[{"uid": "iti70", "root_name": "Micch\u0101di\u1e6d\u1e6dhikasutta", "translated_name": "Having Wrong View ", "acronym": "Iti 70", "blurb": "The Buddha reports having seen, for himself, beings reborn in planes of deprivation in line with their wrong views and evil actions.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "iti71", "root_name": "Samm\u0101di\u1e6d\u1e6dhikasutta", "translated_name": "Having Right View ", "acronym": "Iti 71", "blurb": "The Buddha reports having seen, for himself, beings reborn in good destinations in line with their right views and good actions.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "iti72", "root_name": "Nissara\u1e47iyasutta", "translated_name": "Elements of Escape ", "acronym": "Iti 72", "blurb": "Three properties for escape: from sensuality, from form, and from whatever is fabricated and dependently co-arisen.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "iti73", "root_name": "Santatarasutta", "translated_name": "More Peaceful ", "acronym": "Iti 73", "blurb": "Formless phenomena are more peaceful than forms; blurb: This chapter returns to the awakening of the Buddha, and employing water-based imagery, it reinforces the power of the Dhamma to carry us across the flood.
children: [{"uid": "ud7.1", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamalaku\u1e47\u1e0dakabhaddiyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "Ud 7.1", "blurb": "A dwarf becomes an arahant.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "ud7.2", "root_name": "Dutiyalaku\u1e47\u1e0dakabhaddiyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "Ud 7.2", "blurb": "Ven. S\u0101riputta doesn\u2019t realize that his listener has already become an arahant.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "ud7.3", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamasattasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "Ud 7.3", "blurb": "Attachment to sensual pleasures keeps you from crossing over the flood.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "ud7.4", "root_name": "Dutiyasattasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "Ud 7.4", "blurb": "Attachment to sensual pleasures keeps you trapped like a fish.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "ud7.5", "root_name": "Aparalaku\u1e47\u1e0dakabhaddiyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "Ud 7.5", "blurb": "Inner and outer beauty.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "ud7.6", "root_name": "Ta\u1e47h\u0101sa\u1e45khayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "Ud 7.6", "blurb": "Ven. blurb: The Mahāniddesa or “Great Exposition” is really one half of a book together with the Cūḷaniddesa, the “Shorter Exposition”. They offer commentaries on certain portions of the Sutta Nipāta, and lack counterparts in the northern canons. The Mahāniddesa comments on the sixteen poems of the fourth chapter, the “Chapter of the Eights” or Aṭṭhakavagga.

translated_name: The Chapter on the Simile of the Vipers
children: [{"uid": "sn35.238", "root_name": "\u0100s\u012bvisopamasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.238", "blurb": "The Buddha strings a series of powerful similes\u2014vipers, murderers, an empty village, and more\u2014into an extended parable of the dangers of existence and the way of escape.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.239", "root_name": "Rathopamasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.239", "blurb": "When a mendicant has three qualities they live happily: sense restraint, moderation in eating, and wakefulness.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.240", "root_name": "Kummopamasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.240", "blurb": "A parable of a jackal who fails to eat a tortoise who stays still, with limbs retracted, like a mendicant guarding the senses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn35.241", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamad\u0101rukkhandhopamasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.241", "blurb": "The Buddha gives a parable of a large log floating downstream, which, if it steers clear of the many obstacles, will eventually reach the ocean. A mendicant asks for an explanation, and the Buddha clarifies each item. A cowherd named Nanda was listening, and determined to go forth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.242", "root_name": "Dutiyad\u0101rukkhandhopamasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.242", "blurb": "The Buddha gives a parable of a large log floating downstream, which, if it steers clear of the many obstacles, will eventually reach the ocean. Venerable Kimbila asks for an explanation, and the Buddha clarifies each item.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.243", "root_name": "Avassutapariy\u0101yasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.243", "blurb": "The Buddha is invited to teach in a new hall in Kapilavatthu. Late at night, after teaching the Sakyans, the Buddha invites Moggall\u0101na to teach. He speaks on the mental corruption that flows from attachment to the senses. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.244", "root_name": "Dukkhadhammasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.244", "blurb": "The Buddha defines the things that entail suffering as the five aggregates, and urges mendicants to be free of desire for the six senses, giving a series of vivid similes. He then speaks of how even for a mendicant practicing restraint a lapse of mindfulness might occur from time to time.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.245", "root_name": "Ki\u1e41sukopamasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.245", "blurb": "A mendicant goes to a series of teachers and asks how vision is purified. Dissatisfied with all their answers, he complains to the Buddha, who illustrates his quandary with the famous simile of the Ki\u1e41suka tree. Just as the same Ki\u1e41suka tree might be described differently by people focusing on the leaves, or the fruit, or the bark, etc., so too the various teachers each speak of the aspect of Dhamma most meaningful to them. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.246", "root_name": "V\u012b\u1e47opamasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.246", "blurb": "One should restrain the senses like a farmer watching over a field. The Buddha gives the parable of a man bewitched when he first hears a lute. He takes apart the instrument in search of the sound, but is disillusioned when no sound is found.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.247", "root_name": "Chapp\u0101\u1e47akopamasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.247", "blurb": "The senses are like a snake, a crocodile, a bird, a dog, a jackal, and a monkey all tied up together, pulling this way and that. Mindfulness is like a post that keeps them grounded.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.248", "root_name": "Yavakal\u0101pisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.248", "blurb": "The six senses are like a sheaf of barley struck with six flails; and the desire for rebirth is a seventh flail. The Buddha goes on to speak of the cunning trap of the gods; but the trap of M\u0101ra, conceit, is even more subtle.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

translated_name: Linked Discourses on the Right Efforts
blurb: The “Linked Discourses on the Right Efforts” contains 54 discourses, which are, however, a mere instantiation of the standard repetition series as applied to the four right efforts. There are many discourses on right effort throughout the Pali nikāyas, but for some reason the redactors did not collect them here.

blurb: 24 long discourses that in the Taishō edition of the Chinese canon have been gathered in the first volume, at sūtra numbers 2–25, following the Dīrghāgama. These are miscellaneous translations of various discourses from the Dīgha, made at various times by various translators.

[{"uid": "an10.91", "root_name": "K\u0101mabhog\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.91", "blurb": "The Buddha teaches An\u0101thapi\u1e47\u1e0dika ten kinds of persons who enjoy sensual pleasures.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an10.92", "root_name": "Bhayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.92", "blurb": "A noble disciple has eliminated five perils, realized the four factors of stream-entry, and seen the noble process.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an10.93", "root_name": "Ki\u1e41di\u1e6d\u1e6dhikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.93", "blurb": "An\u0101thapi\u1e47\u1e0dika visits some wanderers, who ask him about the Buddha\u2019s views. An\u0101thapi\u1e47\u1e0dika asks them to explain their own view first. He then declares his own understanding of impermanence, leaving the wanderers speechless.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an10.94", "root_name": "Vajjiyam\u0101hitasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.94", "blurb": "The householder Vajjiyam\u0101hita visits some wanderers, who accuse the Buddha of condemning all asceticism. Vajjiyam\u0101hita counters this by saying the Buddha only criticizes what is worthy of criticism. The Buddha praises him, and explains in detail what this means.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an10.95", "root_name": "Uttiyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.95", "blurb": "The wanderer Uttiya asks the Buddha a series of ten metaphysical questions as to whether the cosmos is finite, etc. The Buddha responds by saying that he only teaches the end of suffering. Uttiya goes on to ask whether all beings will be liberated. The Buddha is silent, and \u0100nanda answers on his behalf.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an10.96", "root_name": "Kokanudasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.96", "blurb": "The wanderer Kokanada meets \u0100nanda at the baths and engages him on the topic of the ten metaphysical questions.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an10.97", "root_name": "\u0100huneyyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.97", "blurb": "With ten qualities, a mendicant is worthy.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an10.98", "root_name": "Therasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.98", "blurb": "With ten qualities, a senior mendicant is at ease wherever they live.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an10.99", "root_name": "Up\u0101lisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.99", "blurb": "When Up\u0101li asks to go into retreat, the Buddha warns him that secluded wilderness dwellings are hard to endure unless one is accomplished in meditation. He gives a long account of the training required before going into solitude, and ends by encouraging Up\u0101li to stay in the Sa\u1e45gha.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an10.100", "root_name": "Abhabbasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.100", "blurb": "Ten things must be given up before attaining perfection.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: This chapter is addressed to a diverse range of lay people.
children: [{"uid": "mn51", "root_name": "Kandarakasutta", "translated_name": "With Kandaraka ", "acronym": "MN 51", "blurb": "The Buddha discusses mindfulness meditation with lay practitioners. Contrasting the openness of animals with the duplicity of humans, he explains how to practice in a way that causes no harm to oneself or others.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn52", "root_name": "A\u1e6d\u1e6dhakan\u0101garasutta", "translated_name": "The Man From the City of A\u1e6d\u1e6dhaka ", "acronym": "MN 52", "blurb": "Asked by a householder to teach a path to freedom, Venerable \u0100nanda explains no less than eleven meditative states that may serve as doors to the deathless.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "mn53", "root_name": "Sekhasutta", "translated_name": "A Trainee ", "acronym": "MN 53", "blurb": "The Buddha is invited by his family, the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu, to inaugurate a new community hall. He invites Venerable \u0100nanda to explain in detail the stages of spiritual practice for a lay trainee.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn54", "root_name": "Potaliyasutta", "translated_name": "With Potaliya the Householder ", "acronym": "MN 54", "blurb": "When Potaliya got upset at being referred to as \u201chouseholder\u201d, the Buddha quizzed him as to the true nature of attachment and renunciation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn55", "root_name": "J\u012bvakasutta", "translated_name": "With J\u012bvaka ", "acronym": "MN 55", "blurb": "The Buddha\u2019s personal doctor, J\u012bvaka, hears criticisms of the Buddha\u2019s policy regarding eating meat, and asks him about it.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn56", "root_name": "Up\u0101lisutta", "translated_name": "With Up\u0101li ", "acronym": "MN 56", "blurb": "The Buddha disagrees with a Jain ascetic on the question of whether physical or mental deeds are more important. When he hears of this, the Jain disciple Up\u0101li decides to visit the Buddha and refute him, and proceeds despite all warnings.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn57", "root_name": "Kukkuravatikasutta", "translated_name": "The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog ", "acronym": "MN 57", "blurb": "Some ascetics in ancient India undertook extreme practices, such as a vow to behave like an ox or a dog. The Buddha meets two such individuals, and is reluctantly pressed to reveal the kammic outcomes of such practice.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn58", "root_name": "Abhayar\u0101jakum\u0101rasutta", "translated_name": "With Prince Abhaya ", "acronym": "MN 58", "blurb": "The leader of the Jains, Niga\u1e47\u1e6dha N\u0101taputta, gives his disciple Prince Abhaya a dilemma to pose to the Buddha, supposing that this will show his weakness. Things don\u2019t go quite as planned.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn59", "root_name": "Bahuvedan\u012byasutta", "translated_name": "The Many Kinds of Feeling ", "acronym": "MN 59", "blurb": "The Buddha resolves a disagreement on the number of kinds of feelings that he taught, pointing out that different ways of teaching are appropriate in different contexts, and should not be a cause of disputes. He goes on to show the importance of pleasure in developing higher meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn60", "root_name": "Apa\u1e47\u1e47akasutta", "translated_name": "Guaranteed ", "acronym": "MN 60", "blurb": "The Buddha teaches a group of uncommitted householders how to use a rational reflection to arrive at practices and principles that are guaranteed to have a good outcome, even if we don\u2019t know all the variables.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}]

[{"uid": "an6.55", "root_name": "So\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.55", "blurb": "When Venerable So\u1e47a thinks of disrobing, the Buddha comes and encourages him with the famous simile of the lute that is tuned neither too loose nor too tight.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an6.56", "root_name": "Phaggunasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.56", "blurb": "The Buddha consoles Venerable Phaggu\u1e47a on his deathbed, and he dies at peace. The Buddha then explains to \u0100nanda the benefits of hearing the Dhamma at the right time.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.57", "root_name": "Cha\u1e37abhij\u0101tisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.57", "blurb": "\u0100nanda asks the Buddha about the six classes of people described by the rival ascetic P\u016bra\u1e47a Kassapa. The Buddha rejects them, and proposes an alternate scheme, emphasizing the importance ones deeds in this life.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.58", "root_name": "\u0100savasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.58", "blurb": "The Buddha explains diverse methods for overcoming diverse kinds of defilements.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.59", "root_name": "D\u0101rukammikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.59", "blurb": "The householder D\u0101rukammika claims to give gifts to arahants. But the Buddha warns him that it\u2019s hard to know who is really an arahant, and encourage him instead to make offerings to the Sa\u1e45gha.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.60", "root_name": "Hatthis\u0101riputtasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.60", "blurb": "The junior monk Citta Hatthis\u0101riputta rudely interrupts his seniors, and is admonished by Mah\u0101ko\u1e6d\u1e6dhita. His friends speak in his defense, but Mah\u0101ko\u1e6d\u1e6dhita warns them with a long explanation of how hard it is to know another\u2019s mind. Ultimately, Citta disrobes.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.61", "root_name": "Majjhesutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.61", "blurb": "Several senior mendicants discuss the \u201cQuestions of Metteyya\u201d from the P\u0101r\u0101yana (Snp 5.3). Each propose an interpretation, and they then ask the Buddha. He praises each reading, but gives his own intended meaning.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.62", "root_name": "Purisindriya\u00f1\u0101\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.62", "blurb": "A monk asks whether, when the Buddha said that Devadatta was going to hell, he was speaking metaphorically. The Buddha castigates him, wondering how anyone could misunderstand such a straightforward statement, and explains how he reads the minds of others and understands where their deeds will lead them.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.63", "root_name": "Nibbedhikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.63", "blurb": "A detailed analysis of several central themes, including sense perception, feeling, defilements, kamma, etc.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an6.64", "root_name": "S\u012bhan\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.64", "blurb": "The Buddha possesses six spiritual powers that enable him to roar his lion\u2019s roar. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: The Stories of Hungry Ghosts” contains fifty-one stories in verse that illustrate rebirth as a hungry ghost as a result of bad deeds. It is a counterpart to the Vimānavatthu. These are late devotional and moralistic texts with no direct counterparts in other collections.

translated_name: Linked Discourses on the Six Sense Fields
blurb: The number of discourses in the “Linked Discourses on the Six Sense Fields” varies between editions, mainly due to the way repetitions are counted; SuttaCentral follows Bhikkhu Bodhi’s translation in counting 248 discourses. The six sense fields complement the five aggregates as the summary of the noble truth of suffering. Where the aggregates focus on the functional structure of experience as basis for views of self, the emphasis here is on how sense experience stimulates desire. Despite this difference in orientation, the two collections share much in common, and often the exact same template is applied in both cases. The six sense fields are the means through which the world is known, and so each of them has an “inner” and an “outer” aspect—the “eye” and “sights”, etc. Though common, it’s best to avoid thinking of the external sense field as the “object”, since in the suttas they are depicted in relation to the observing mind, and not as independently existing entities. This is straightforward until we come to the last sense, the “mind” and “thoughts” or “mental phenomena”. Just to clear up a possible confusion, this “sixth sense” is simply the mental faculty, and has nothing to do with psychic powers. The outer aspect is dhammā, a term so ambiguous its translation is always difficult. Here it refers to anything that may be known directly by the mind, distinct from the five senses. The most technically correct translation is probably “mental phenomena”, but “thought’ may be used as a more colloquial rendering, so long as it includes ideas, imagination, and so on, not just verbalized cognition.

blurb: Two fascicles compiled by Dharmatrāta 法救, T 210.4.559–574. It was brought by the Indian monk Vighna 維祇難 to Wuchang 武昌, China in 224 C.E., and translated by Zhu Jiangyan 竺將炎 and Zhi Qian 支謙. It is a collection of verses comprising the basic teachings of Buddhism which is similar to the Pali Dhammapada. The Chinese version contains 758 verses. There are four Chinese translations, dated CE 224, 290–306, 399, and 980–1001.
