translated_name: The Chapter on Mindfulness of the Body
children: [{"uid": "an1.575-615", "root_name": "K\u0101yagat\u0101sativagga", "translated_name": "Mindfulness of the Body ", "acronym": "AN 1.575\u2013615", "blurb": null, "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "sn2.11", "root_name": "Candimasasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.11", "blurb": "The deity Candimasa says that those who practice absorption will surely find escape. The Buddha adds that they must also be diligent and discard flaws.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.12", "root_name": "Ve\u1e47\u1e0dusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.12", "blurb": "The deity Ve\u1e47hu celebrates the joy of those who follow the Buddha\u2019s teaching. The Buddha affirms that such will escape death. Ve\u1e47hu is the Pali spelling of Sanskrit Vi\u1e63\u1e47u, and this marks a rare appearance of a god of this name in the early texts.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.13", "root_name": "D\u012bghala\u1e6d\u1e6dhisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.13", "blurb": "Di\u0304ghala\u1e6d\u1e6dhi the god comes to the Buddha at R\u0101jagaha and praises a mendicant who is a meditator.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.14", "root_name": "Nandanasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.14", "blurb": "The deity Nandana asks the Buddha who is virtuous, wise, beyond suffering, worshiped by the gods themselves. The Buddha replies that such a person is an arahant.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.15", "root_name": "Candanasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.15", "blurb": "Candana asks who crosses the flood. The Buddha replies that it is one who is virtuous , wise, peaceful, and beyond attachment to rebirth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.16", "root_name": "V\u0101sudattasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.16", "blurb": "The deity Vasudatta says that a mendicant should live like their hair is on fire so as to give up lust. The Buddha changes his verse to emphasize giving up attachment to self.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.17", "root_name": "Subrahmasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.17", "blurb": "Subrahma\u0304 the god asks for the escape from fear. The Buddha says there is no escape from fear without letting go of everything.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.18", "root_name": "Kakudhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.18", "blurb": "At Sa\u0304keta the god Kakudha asks the Buddha if he delights or sorrows. The Buddha replies that since he has no attachments he neither delights nor sorrows.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.19", "root_name": "Uttarasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.19", "blurb": "The god Uttara speaks of the transience of life, saying one should do good to be reborn in a happy future life. The Buddha replies that one should let go attachment.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.20", "root_name": "An\u0101thapi\u1e47\u1e0dikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.20", "blurb": "A deity who had been the Buddha\u2019s supporter Ana\u0304thapi\u1e47\u1e0dika in his former life comes to Buddha and speaks verses in celebration of the Jeta\u2019s Grove monastery\u2014which he had offered for the Buddha\u2019s use\u2014good deeds, the Dhamma, and Venerable S\u0101riputta.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "an10.21", "root_name": "S\u012bhan\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.21", "blurb": "Like a lion, a Realized One roars his preeminence based on ten powers.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an10.22", "root_name": "Adhivuttipadasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.22", "blurb": "The Buddha claims to be assured regarding the various different doctrinal hypotheses, based on the ten powers.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an10.23", "root_name": "K\u0101yasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.23", "blurb": "Some things are to be given by body, others by speech, and still others by wisdom.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an10.24", "root_name": "Mah\u0101cundasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.24", "blurb": "Venerable Mah\u0101cunda teaches that, though a mendicant might claim to be free of greed, hate, and delusion, this is not always the case.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an10.25", "root_name": "Kasi\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.25", "blurb": "Ten universal dimensions of meditation, or kasi\u1e47as.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an10.26", "root_name": "K\u0101\u1e37\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.26", "blurb": "The female lay follower K\u0101\u1e37\u012b of Kuraraghara in Avant\u012b asks Venerable Mah\u0101kacc\u0101na about a verse spoken by the Buddha in \u201cThe Maidens\u2019 Questions\u201d (SN 4.25). He replies in terms of the ten universal dimensions of meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an10.27", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamamah\u0101pa\u00f1h\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.27", "blurb": "Some wanderers claim to teach the direct knowledge of all things, just like the Buddha. However the Buddha disputes this by presenting ten \u201cGreat Questions\u201d that they cannot answer.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an10.28", "root_name": "Dutiyamah\u0101pa\u00f1h\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.28", "blurb": "Some lay people ask the nun from Kaja\u1e45gal\u0101 regarding the ten \u201cGreat Questions\u201d. Though she has not heard this teaching herself, she explains from her own understanding, and is praised by the Buddha.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an10.29", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamakosalasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.29", "blurb": "Starting with a comparison with the King of Kosala, the Buddha teaches a series of ten advanced teachings. He culminates by affirming that he teaches the full understanding of sensual pleasures, forms, and feelings.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an10.30", "root_name": "Dutiyakosalasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.30", "blurb": "King Pasenadi returns victorious from battle and immediately goes to see the Buddha, bowing reverentially to his feet, and declaring ten reasons for his love and devotion to the Buddha.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

[{"uid": "sn4.21", "root_name": "Sambahulasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 4.21", "blurb": "M\u0101ra approaches some young mendicants as an old brahmin, and tries to tempt them with talk of the pleasures of youth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn4.22", "root_name": "Samiddhisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 4.22", "blurb": "M\u0101ra repeatedly pesters the monk Samiddhi when he is on retreat. The Buddha encourages him, until eventually Samiddhi is able to recognize M\u0101ra for himself.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn4.23", "root_name": "Godhikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 4.23", "blurb": "Venerable Godhika finds himself repeatedly falling away from his meditation attainments due to severe illness. Eventually he considers suicide, and M\u0101ra tries to get the Buddha to deter him. But the Buddha says Godhika has already attained awakening and has died blamelessly.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn4.24", "root_name": "Sattavass\u0101nubandhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 4.24", "blurb": "M\u0101ra has tried to distract the Buddha for seven years without success. He laments his failure with the similes of a crab whose limbs are smashed by a group of children, and a crow who tried to eat a stone.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn4.25", "root_name": "M\u0101radh\u012btusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 4.25", "blurb": "Depressed, M\u0101ra laments to his three daughters of his failure to distract the Buddha. So they take on the task themselves, and assume a variety of sensuous forms to tempt him. But they fail too, and M\u0101ra castigates them for being so presumptuous", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: This portion of the Taishō edition of the Chinese canon is simply called “miscellaneous collection” ( 經集部), and it includes sūtra texts that are not readily classifiable elsewhere. While the section is mostly for Mahāyāna sūtras, a number of parallels with early discourses have been identified.

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Gods” contains 30 discourses, each one of which depicts the Buddha in conversation with a god. Here the term devaputta is used, rather than devatā in the previous saṁyutta. The difference is purely nominal and there is no difference in the meaning. The style of discourses is similar to the “Linked Discourses on Deities”, although here there is a greater emphasis on the theme of renunciation. A number of these discourses are regularly recited in modern Theravāda; the Tāyana verses on diligent striving at SN 2.8 are often recited by monastics, while the discourses on the sun and the moon (SN 2.9 and SN 2.10) are popular protection chants, which are also found in Tibetan.

translated_name: The Chapter on the Entire Spectrum of Ethics
blurb: The Chapter Containing the Section on Ethics (Sīlakkhandhavagga) is a chapter of 13 discourses. Each of these contains a long passage on the Gradual Training in ethics, meditation, and wisdom. The chapter is named after the first of these sections. The two other known versions of the Dīrghāgama (in Chinese and Sanskrit) also contain a similar chapter. Despite the monastic nature of the central teaching, most of these discourses are presented in dialog with lay people, with a strong emphasis on the relation between the Buddha’s teachings and other contemporary movements.
children: [{"uid": "dn1", "root_name": "Brahmaj\u0101lasutta", "translated_name": "The Prime Net ", "acronym": "DN 1", "blurb": "While others may praise or criticize the Buddha, they tend to focus on trivial details. The Buddha presents an analysis of 62 kinds of wrong view, seeing through which one becomes detached from meaningless speculations.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn2", "root_name": "S\u0101ma\u00f1\u00f1aphalasutta", "translated_name": "The Fruits of the Ascetic Life ", "acronym": "DN 2", "blurb": "The newly crowned King Aj\u0101tasattu is disturbed by the violent means by which he achieved the crown. He visits the Buddha to find peace of mind, and asks him about the benefits of spiritual practice. This is one of the greatest literary and spiritual texts of early Buddhism.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn3", "root_name": "Amba\u1e6d\u1e6dhasutta", "translated_name": "With Amba\u1e6d\u1e6dha ", "acronym": "DN 3", "blurb": "A young brahmin student attacks the Buddha\u2019s family, but is put in his place.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn4", "root_name": "So\u1e47ada\u1e47\u1e0dasutta", "translated_name": "With So\u1e47ada\u1e47\u1e0da ", "acronym": "DN 4", "blurb": "A reputed brahmin visits the Buddha, despite the reservations of other brahmins. They discuss the true meaning of a brahmin, and the Buddha skillfully draws him around to his own point of view.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn5", "root_name": "K\u016b\u1e6dadantasutta", "translated_name": "With K\u016b\u1e6dadanta ", "acronym": "DN 5", "blurb": "A brahmin wishes to undertake a great sacrifice, and asks for the Buddha\u2019s advice. The Buddha tells a legend of the past, in which a king is persuaded to give up violent sacrifice, and instead to devote his resources to supporting the needy citizens of his realm. However, even such a beneficial and non-violent sacrifice pales in comparison to the spiritual sacrifice of giving up attachments.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn6", "root_name": "Mah\u0101lisutta", "translated_name": "With Mah\u0101li ", "acronym": "DN 6", "blurb": "The Buddha explains to a diverse group of lay people how the results of meditation depend on the manner of development.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn7", "root_name": "J\u0101liyasutta", "translated_name": "With J\u0101liya ", "acronym": "DN 7", "blurb": "This discourse is mostly quoted by the Buddha in the previous.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn8", "root_name": "Mah\u0101s\u012bhan\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": "The Longer Discourse on the Lion\u2019s Roar ", "acronym": "DN 8", "blurb": "The Buddha is challenged by a naked ascetic on the topic of spiritual austerities. He points out that it is quite possible to perform all kinds of austere practices without having any inner purity of mind.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn9", "root_name": "Po\u1e6d\u1e6dhap\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": "With Po\u1e6d\u1e6dhap\u0101da ", "acronym": "DN 9", "blurb": "The Buddha discusses with a wanderer the nature of perception and how it evolves through deeper states of meditation. None of these, however, should be identified with a self or soul.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn10", "root_name": "Subhasutta", "translated_name": "With Subha ", "acronym": "DN 10", "blurb": "Shortly after the Buddha\u2019s death, Venerable \u0100nanda is invited to explain the core teachings.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn11", "root_name": "Keva\u1e6d\u1e6dasutta", "translated_name": "With Kevaddha ", "acronym": "DN 11", "blurb": "The Buddha refuses to perform miracles, explaining that this is not the right way to inspire faith. He goes on to tell the story of a monk whose misguided quest for answers led him as far as Brahm\u0101.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn12", "root_name": "Lohiccasutta", "translated_name": "With Lohicca ", "acronym": "DN 12", "blurb": "A brahmin has fallen into the idea that there is no point in trying to offer spiritual help to others. The Buddha goes to see him, and persuades him of the genuine benefits of spiritual teaching.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn13", "root_name": "Tevijjasutta", "translated_name": "The Three Knowledges ", "acronym": "DN 13", "blurb": "A number of brahmins are discussing the true path to Brahm\u0101. Contesting the claims to authority based on the Vedas, the Buddha insists that only personal experience can lead to the truth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}]

[{"uid": "ja371", "root_name": "D\u012bgh\u012btikosalaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "King D\u012bgh\u012bti of Kosala ", "acronym": "Ja 371", "blurb": "\u201cThou art within my power\u201d\u2014This story the Master, whilst dwelling at Jetavana, told concerning some quarrelsome folk from Kosambi.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja372", "root_name": "Migapotakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Fawn ", "acronym": "Ja 372", "blurb": "\u201cTo sorrow for the dead\u201d\u2014This story the Master, whilst dwelling at Jetavana, told about a certain elder. It is said that he admitted a youth to orders, and that this novice, after ministering to him zealously, by and bye fell sick and died. The old man overcome with grief at the youth\u2019s death went about loudly lamenting. The Brethren, failing to console him, raised a discussion in the Hall of Truth, saying, \u201cA certain old man on the death of his novice goes about lamenting. By dwelling on the thought of death, he will surely become a castaway.\u201d When the Master came, he inquired of the Brethren what was the subject they had met to discuss, and on hearing what it was he said, \u201cNot now only, but formerly also, the old man went about lamenting, when this youth died.\u201d And with this he related a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja373", "root_name": "M\u016bsikaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Tale of M\u016bsik\u0101 ", "acronym": "Ja 373", "blurb": "\u201cPeople cry \u201cWhere is she gone\u201d\u2014This story the Master, whilst residing in the Bamboo Grove, told about Ajatasattu. The incident that led to the story has been already fully told in the Thusa Birth. Here too the Master observed the king at the same moment playing with his boy and also listening to the Law. And knowing as he did that danger to the king will arise through his son, he said, \u201cSire, kings of old suspected what was open to suspicion, and kept their heirs in confinement, saying, \u201cLet them bear rule, after our bodies have been burned on the funeral pyre.\u201d And with this he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja374", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37adhanuggahaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Shorter Tale of Clever Little Archer ", "acronym": "Ja 374", "blurb": "\u201cSince thou hast gained\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master whilst living at Jetavana, about the temptation of a Brother by the wife of his unregenerate days. When the Brother confessed that it was owing to the wife that he had left, that he regretted having taken orders, the Master said, \u201cNot now only, Brother, did this woman do you a mischief. Formerly too it was owing to her that your head was cut off.\u201d And at the request of the Brethren he related a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja375", "root_name": "Kapotaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Pigeon ", "acronym": "Ja 375", "blurb": "\u201cI feel quite well\u201d\u2014This story the Master, whilst dwelling at Jetavana, told concerning a greedy Brother. This story of the greedy Brother has already been fully told in divers ways. In this case the Master asked him if he were greedy and on his confessing that it was so, said, \u201cNot now only, but formerly also, Brother, you were greedy, and through greed came by your death.\u201d And herewith he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "ja427", "root_name": "Gijjhaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Vulture ", "acronym": "Ja 427", "blurb": "\u201cFormed of rough logs;\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Jetavana concerning a, disobedient Brother.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja428", "root_name": "Kosambiyaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Incident at Kosambi ", "acronym": "Ja 428", "blurb": "\u201cWhene\u2019er the Brotherhood\u201d\u2014This story the Master, while dwelling in the Ghosita park near Kosambi, told concerning certain quarrelsome folk at Kosambi.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja429", "root_name": "Mah\u0101suvaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Longer Tale of King Parrot ", "acronym": "Ja 429", "blurb": "\u201cWherever fruitful trees\u201d\u2014This story the Master dwelling at Jetavana told concerning a certain Brother. The story goes that he lived in a forest near a border village in the Kosala country, and received instruction in forms of meditation from the Master. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja430", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37asuvaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Shorter Tale of King Parrot ", "acronym": "Ja 430", "blurb": "\u201cLo! countless trees\u201d\u2014This story the Master dwelling at Jetavana told concerning the Veranja section. When the Master after passing the rainy season at Veranja in due course arrived at Savatthi, the Brethren in the Hall of Truth raised a discussion saying, \u201cSirs, a Tathagata, a delicately nurtured kshatriya and Buddha, though possessed of supernatural powers, at the invitation of a brahmin of Veranja stayed three months with him, and when owing to the temptation of Mara he failed to receive an alms at the hands of the brahmin, even for a single day, he gave up all covetous ways, and keeping in the same place for three months lived on water and a modicum of the ground flour of roots. [4951 Oh the contented nature of Tathagatas!\u201d When the Master came and on inquiry learned the nature of their discussion he said, \u201cIt is no marvel, Brethren, that a Tathagata now has lost all covetousness, seeing that formerly when born in an animal form he forsook covetousness.\u201d And hereupon he told a story of the past. The whole story is now to be related in detail in exactly the same way as in the preceding tale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja431", "root_name": "Haritacaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Ascetic Goldskin ", "acronym": "Ja 431", "blurb": "\u201cFriend Harita\u201d\u2014This story the Master dwelling at Jetavana told concerning a discontented Brother. Now this Brother after seeing a smartly attired woman grew discontented and allowed his hair and nails to grow long, and wished to return to the world. And when he was brought against his will by his teachers and preceptors to the Master, and was asked by him, if it were true that he was a backslider, and if so why, he said, \u201cYes, your Reverence, it is owing to the power of sinful passion, after seeing a beautiful woman.\u201d The Master said, \u201cSin, Brother, is destructive of virtue, and insipid withal, and causes a man to be re-born in hell; and why should not this sin prove your destruction? For the hurricane that smites Mount Sineru is not ashamed to carry off a withered leaf. But owing to this sin men who walk according to knowledge and wisdom, and have acquired the five Faculties and the eight Attainments, though they were great and holy men, being unable to fix their thoughts, fell away from mystic meditation.\u201d And then he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja432", "root_name": "Padakusalam\u0101\u1e47avaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Student Who Could Trace Footsteps ", "acronym": "Ja 432", "blurb": "\u201cO Patala, by Ganges\u201d\u2014This story the Master dwelling at Jetavana told concerning a certain boy. He was, they say, the son of a householder at Savatthi, just seven years old, and skilled in recognizing footsteps. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja433", "root_name": "Lomasakassapaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Ascetic Hairy Kassapa ", "acronym": "Ja 433", "blurb": "\u201cA king like Indra\u201d\u2014This story the Master dwelling at Jetavana told concerning a worldly-minded Brother. The Master asked him if he were longing for the world, and when he admitted that it was so, the Master said, \u201cBrother, even men of the highest fame sometimes incur infamy. Sins like these defile even pure beings; much more one like you.\u201d And then he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja434", "root_name": "Cakkav\u0101kaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Red-Ducks ", "acronym": "Ja 434", "blurb": "\u201cTwin pair of birds\u201d\u2014This story the Master dwelling at Jetavana told concerning a greedy Brother. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja435", "root_name": "Haliddir\u0101gaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Unstable as Turmeric Dye ", "acronym": "Ja 435", "blurb": "\u201cIn lonesome forest\u201d\u2014This story the Master at Jetavana told about a youth who was tempted by a certain coarse maiden. The introductory story will be found in the Thirteenth Book in the Cullanarada Birth. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja436", "root_name": "Samuggaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Box ", "acronym": "Ja 436", "blurb": "\u201cWhence come ye, friends\u201d\u2014This story the Master, while dwelling at Jetavana, told of a worldly-minded Brother. The Master, they say, asked him if it were true that he was hankering after the world, and on his confessing that it was so, he said, \u201cWhy, Brother, do you desire a woman? Verily woman is wicked and ungrateful. Of old Asura demons swallowed women, and though they guarded them in their belly, they could not keep them faithful to one man. How then will you be able to do so?\u201d And hereupon he related an old-world tale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja437", "root_name": "P\u016btima\u1e41saj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Jackal P\u016btima\u1e41sa ", "acronym": "Ja 437", "blurb": "\u201cWhy thus does Putimansa\u201d\u2014This was a story told by the Master while at Jetavana concerning the subjugation of the senses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja438", "root_name": "Daddaraj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Partridge ", "acronym": "Ja 438", "blurb": "\u201cThy harmless offspring\u201d\u2014This story the Master, while dwelling at Vulture Peak, told concerning the going about of Devadatta to slay him.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: Diverse teachings.
children: [{"uid": "mn101", "root_name": "Devadahasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 101", "blurb": "The Buddha tackles a group of Jain ascetics, pressing them on their claim to be practicing to end all suffering by self-mortification. He points out a series of fallacies in their logic, and explains his own middle way.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn102", "root_name": "Pa\u00f1cattayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 102", "blurb": "A middle length version of the more famous Brahmajala Sutta (DN1), this surveys a range of speculative views and dismisses them all.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn103", "root_name": "Kintisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 103", "blurb": "The Buddha teaches the monks to not dispute about the fundamental teachings, but to always strive for harmony.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn104", "root_name": "S\u0101mag\u0101masutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 104", "blurb": "Hearing of the death of the Jain leader Niga\u1e47\u1e6dha N\u0101taputta, the Buddha encourages the Sa\u1e45gha to swiftly resolve any disputes. He lays down a series of seven methods for resolving disputes. These form the foundation for the monastic code.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn105", "root_name": "Sunakkhattasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 105", "blurb": "Not all of those who claim to be awakened are genuine. The Buddha teaches how true spiritual progress depends on an irreversible letting go of the forces that lead to suffering.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn106", "root_name": "\u0100ne\u00f1jasapp\u0101yasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 106", "blurb": "Beginning with profound meditation absorption, the Buddha goes on to deeper and deeper levels, showing how insight on this basis leads to the detaching of consciousness from any form of rebirth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn107", "root_name": "Ga\u1e47akamoggall\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 107", "blurb": "The Buddha compares the training of an accountant with the step by step spiritual path of his followers. But even with such a well explained path, the Buddha can only show the way, and it is up to us to walk it.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn108", "root_name": "Gopakamoggall\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 108", "blurb": "Amid rising military tensions after the Buddha\u2019s death, Venerable \u0100nanda is questioned about how the Sa\u1e45gha planned to continue in their teacher\u2019s absence. As the Buddha refused to appoint a successor, the teaching and practice that he laid down become the teacher, and the Sa\u1e45gha resolves issues by consensus.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn109", "root_name": "Mah\u0101pu\u1e47\u1e47amasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 109", "blurb": "On a lovely full moon night, one of the mendicants presents the Buddha with a series of questions that go to the heart of the teaching. But when he hears of the doctrine of not-self, another mendicant is unable to grasp the meaning.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn110", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37apu\u1e47\u1e47amasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 110", "blurb": "A good person is able to understand a bad person, but not vice versa.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

open his heart, or hurl him across the River Ganges\u201d if he doesn\u2019t solve the riddles to the yakkha\u2019s satisfaction.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "snp2.7", "root_name": "Br\u0101hma\u1e47adhammikasutta", "translated_name": "Brahmanical Traditions ", "acronym": "Snp 2.7", "blurb": "How brahmans, through greed, abandoned the good principles of their ancestors.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "snp2.8", "root_name": "Dhamma (n\u0101v\u0101) sutta", "translated_name": "The Boat ", "acronym": "Snp 2.8", "blurb": "A good teacher, like a good boatman, is one who knows firsthand how to cross to the further shore.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "snp2.9", "root_name": "Ki\u1e41s\u012blasutta", "translated_name": "What Morality? ", "acronym": "Snp 2.9", "blurb": "The attitudes and behavior that enable one best to learn and benefit from the Dhamma.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "snp2.10", "root_name": "U\u1e6d\u1e6dh\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": "Get up! Make an Effort! ", "acronym": "Snp 2.10", "blurb": "Get up! Don\u2019t let the opportunity for practice pass you by.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "snp2.11", "root_name": "R\u0101hulasutta", "translated_name": "With R\u0101hula ", "acronym": "Snp 2.11", "blurb": "R\u0101hula reflects on the teachings he received from his father, the Buddha.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "snp2.12", "root_name": "Nigrodhakappa (va\u1e45g\u012bsa) sutta", "translated_name": "Va\u1e45g\u012bsa and his Mentor Nigrodhakappa ", "acronym": "Snp 2.12", "blurb": "Va\u1e45g\u012bsa, the foremost poet among the Buddha\u2019s disciples, praises the Buddha in verse.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "snp2.13", "root_name": "Samm\u0101paribb\u0101jan\u012byasutta", "translated_name": "The Right Way to Wander ", "acronym": "Snp 2.13", "blurb": "The sort of person who, having gone forth, is fit to wander through the world.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "snp2.14", "root_name": "Dhammikasutta", "translated_name": "With Dhammika ", "acronym": "Snp 2.14", "blurb": "The proper code of conduct for lay followers of the Dhamma.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}]

blurb: Collections of “numbered” or “numerical” discourses and other related texts.
children: [{"uid": "an", "root_name": "A\u1e45guttaranik\u0101ya", "translated_name": "Numbered Discourses Collection ", "acronym": "AN", "blurb": "The \u201cNumbered\u201d or \u201cNumerical\u201d Discourses are usually known as A\u1e45guttara Nik\u0101ya in Pali, abbreviated AN. However, the Pali tradition also knows the form Ekottara (\u201cone-up\u201d or \u201cincremental\u201d), and this is the form usually found in the northern collections. These collections organize texts in numbered sets, from one to eleven. Compared to the other nik\u0101yas, they are more oriented to the lay community. The Ekottarik\u0101gama (EA) in Chinese is a highly unusual text, which features a range of variations within itself when it comes even to basic doctrines. It shares considerably less in common with the Pali A\u1e45guttara than the other collections do with their counterparts. In addition, there is a partial Ekottarik\u0101gama in Chinese, as well as a variety of individual discourses and fragments in Chinese and Sanskrit.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "AN", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1963}, {"uid": "ea", "root_name": "Ekottarik\u0101gama (1st)", "translated_name": "Numbered Discourses Compilation (1st) ", "acronym": "EA", "blurb": "The main version of the Numbered or Incremental Discourses found in the Chinese canon is known as the Ekottarik\u0101gama (Zengyi ahan jing, \u589e\u4e00\u963f\u542b\u7d93), and has been tentatively ascribed to the Mah\u0101sa\u1e45ghika school. It was translated by Gautama Sa\u1e45ghadeva (\u77bf\u66c7\u50e7\u4f3d\u63d0\u5a46), who also translated the Madhyam\u0101gama, in CE 397. Consisting of 51 fascicles, it is organized into 52 chapters, containing a total of 451 sutras. Like the Pali A\u1e45guttara, it is arranged by numbered sets from one to eleven. However, despite the structural similarity, the contents diverge widely from the Pali. It contains relatively fewer parallels than the other \u0101gama collections. In the Taish\u014d edition of the Chinese canon, it is text number 125, located at T vol. 2, 549a.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": "EA", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 150}, {"uid": "ea-2", "root_name": "Ekottarik\u0101gama (2nd)", "translated_name": "Numbered Discourses Compilation (2nd) ", "acronym": "EA 2 [T 150A]", "blurb": "A partial translation of the Ekottarik\u0101gama was made by An Shigao (\u5b89\u4e16\u9ad8 ) in CE 148\u2013170. Known as Qi Chu San Guan Jing (\u4e03\u8655\u4e09\u89c0\u7d93), it consists of one fascicle containing 47 shorter sutras. In the Taish\u014d edition of the Chinese canon, it is text number 150A, located at T vol. 2, 875b.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": "EA-2", "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}, {"uid": "ea-ot", "root_name": "Other Ekottarika S\u016btras", "translated_name": "Other Numbered Discourses ", "acronym": "Other EA", "blurb": "29 shorter discourses that in the Taish\u014d edition of the Chinese canon have been gathered in the second volume, at s\u016btra numbers 126\u2013151, following the complete Ekottarik\u0101gama collection. These are miscellaneous translations of various discourses from the Ekottara, made at various times by various translators.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": "EA ot", "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}]

[{"uid": "an7.32", "root_name": "Appam\u0101dag\u0101ravasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.32", "blurb": "A god speaks of the the seven principles of non-decline to the Buddha, who repeats it to the mendicants.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an7.33", "root_name": "Hirig\u0101ravasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.33", "blurb": "The Buddha tells of hearing the seven principles of non-decline from a god.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an7.34", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamasovacassat\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.34", "blurb": "The Buddha tells of hearing the seven principles of non-decline from a god.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an7.35", "root_name": "Dutiyasovacassat\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.35", "blurb": "The Buddha tells of hearing the seven principles of non-decline from a god. S\u0101riputta offers additional explanation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an7.36", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamamittasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.36", "blurb": "When a friend has seven factors, one should associate with them.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an7.37", "root_name": "Dutiyamittasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.37", "blurb": "When a mendicant has seven factors, one should stay close to them even if they send you away.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.38", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamapa\u1e6disambhid\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.38", "blurb": "With seven qualities, a mendicant will soon realize the four kinds of textual analysis.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.39", "root_name": "Dutiyapa\u1e6disambhid\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.39", "blurb": "With seven qualities, S\u0101riputta realized the four kinds of textual analysis.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.40", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamavasasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.40", "blurb": "Seven qualities leading to mastery of meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.41", "root_name": "Dutiyavasasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.41", "blurb": "With seven qualities, S\u0101riputta became a master of meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.42", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamaniddasasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.42", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta visits a sectarian hermitage and hears them saying that someone who lives the spiritual life for twelve years is fit to graduate. The Buddha rejects this, saying that a mendicant is qualified to graduate not merely by completing a certain number of years, but because of their spiritual qualities.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.43", "root_name": "Dutiyaniddasasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.43", "blurb": "\u0100nanda visits a sectarian hermitage and hears them saying that someone who lives the spiritual life for twelve years is fit to graduate. The Buddha rejects this, saying that a mendicant is qualified to graduate not merely by completing a certain number of years, but because of their spiritual qualities.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: This chapter contains a diverse range of discourses. Several focus on the events surrounding the Buddha’s death, while others range into fabulous scenarios set among the gods, and still others are grounded in detailed discussions of doctrine.
children: [{"uid": "dn14", "root_name": "Mah\u0101pad\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": "The Great Discourse on the Harvest of Deeds ", "acronym": "DN 14", "blurb": "The Buddha teaches about the six Buddhas of the past, and tells a lengthy account of one of those, Vipass\u012b.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn15", "root_name": "Mah\u0101nid\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": "The Great Discourse on Causation ", "acronym": "DN 15", "blurb": "Rejecting Venerable \u0100nanda\u2019s claim to easily understand dependent origination, the Buddha presents a complex and demanding analysis, revealing hidden nuances and implications of this central teaching.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn16", "root_name": "Mah\u0101parinibb\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": "The Great Discourse on the Buddha\u2019s Extinguishment ", "acronym": "DN 16", "blurb": "The longest of all discourses, this extended narrative tells of the events surrounding the Buddha\u2019s death. Full of vivid and moving details, it is an ideal entry point into knowing the Buddha as a person, and understanding how the Buddhist community coped with his passing.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn17", "root_name": "Mah\u0101sudassanasutta", "translated_name": "King Mah\u0101sudassana ", "acronym": "DN 17", "blurb": "An elaborate story of a past life of the Buddha as a legendary king who renounced all to practice meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn18", "root_name": "Janavasabhasutta", "translated_name": "With Janavasabha ", "acronym": "DN 18", "blurb": "Beginning with an account of the fates of disciples who had recently passed away, the scene shifts to a discussion of Dhamma held by the gods.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn19", "root_name": "Mah\u0101govindasutta", "translated_name": "The Great Steward ", "acronym": "DN 19", "blurb": "A minor deity informs the Buddha of the conversations and business of the gods.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn20", "root_name": "Mah\u0101samayasutta", "translated_name": "The Great Congregation ", "acronym": "DN 20", "blurb": "When deities from all realms gather in homage to the Buddha, he gives a series of verses describing them. These verses, which are commonly chanted in Theravadin countries, give one of the most detailed descriptions of the deities worshiped at the the time of the Buddha.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn21", "root_name": "Sakkapa\u00f1hasutta", "translated_name": "Sakka\u2019s Questions ", "acronym": "DN 21", "blurb": "After hearing a love song from a god of music, the Buddha engages in a deep discussion with Sakka on the conditioned origin of attachment and suffering.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn22", "root_name": "Mah\u0101satipa\u1e6d\u1e6dh\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": "The Longer Discourse on Mindfulness Meditation ", "acronym": "DN 22", "blurb": "The Buddha details the seventh factor of the noble eightfold path, mindfulness meditation. This discourse is essentially identical to MN 10, with the addition of an extended section on the four noble truths derived from MN 141.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "dn23", "root_name": "P\u0101y\u0101sisutta", "translated_name": "With P\u0101y\u0101si ", "acronym": "DN 23", "blurb": "This is a long and entertaining debate between a monk and a skeptic, who went to elaborate and bizarre lengths to prove that there is no such thing as an afterlife. The discourse contains a colorful series of parables and examples.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}]

blurb: 112 short discourses in mixed prose and verse, arranged in the Aṅguttara style of ascending numbered sets, from one to four. Alone among Buddhist texts, its survival is attributed not to the Saṅgha, but to a laywoman named Khujjuttarā. According to the Pali commentaries, she was a maid to the Queen of Kosambi, and memorized these teachings from the Buddha, earning her the title of the most learned of the laywomen disciples.

[{"uid": "sn6.1", "root_name": "Brahm\u0101y\u0101canasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 6.1", "blurb": "After his awakening, the Buddha hesitated to teach, thinking that the Dhamma is too subtle for people to understand. But the high divinity Brahm\u0101 Sahampati appears and encourages him to teach, pointing out that there are some with \u201clittle dust in their eyes\u201d who will understand.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn6.2", "root_name": "G\u0101ravasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 6.2", "blurb": "After his awakening, the Buddha reflects that one should live with reverence; but who is he to revere, since he is fully awakened? He realizes that he should live revering the Dhamma. Brahm\u0101 Sahampati appears and agrees with him, saying that this is how all Buddhas of past and future live too.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn6.3", "root_name": "Brahmadevasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 6.3", "blurb": "Brahm\u0101 Sahampati appears before a woman who is a devotee of his, and tells her to offer food instead to her son, a Buddhist monk, as Brahm\u0101s don\u2019t eat the food she offers.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn6.4", "root_name": "Bakabrahmasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 6.4", "blurb": "Baka the Brahm\u0101 conceives the wrong view that his status is permanent and imperishable. The Buddha goes to dissuade him, and they have an exchange in verse, with the Buddha telling Baka of his past lives. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn6.5", "root_name": "A\u00f1\u00f1atarabrahmasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 6.5", "blurb": "An unnamed brahm\u0101 god thinks to himself that he is so powerful no asectic can approach him. The Buddha goes straight to his realm and appears wrapped in flame above his head. Mah\u0101moggall\u0101na and several other disciples follow him. The brahm\u0101 and his retinue are sutiably impressed.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn6.6", "root_name": "Brahmalokasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 6.6", "blurb": "The brahm\u0101s Subrahm\u0101 and Suddh\u0101v\u0101sa note that a fellow-brahm\u0101 is living in negligence, overly impressed with his own glory, so they go to shake him from his complacence.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn6.7", "root_name": "Kok\u0101likasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 6.7", "blurb": "The brahm\u0101s Subrahm\u0101 and Suddh\u0101v\u0101sa come to the Buddha\u2019s hut and speak on the monk Kok\u0101lika, a follower of Devadatta.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn6.8", "root_name": "Katamodakatissasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 6.8", "blurb": "The brahm\u0101s Subrahm\u0101 and Suddh\u0101v\u0101sa come to the Buddha\u2019s hut and speak on the monk Katamorakatissaka, a follower of Devadatta.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn6.9", "root_name": "Tur\u016bbrahmasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 6.9", "blurb": "The brahm\u0101 Tudu tries to persuade Kok\u0101lika to have faith in S\u0101riputta and Moggall\u0101na, but Kok\u0101lika wants none of it.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn6.10", "root_name": "Kok\u0101likasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 6.10", "blurb": "Kok\u0101lika goes to the Buddha and criticizes S\u0101riputta and Moggall\u0101na. But having deliberately slandered such great monks, he dies and Brahm\u0101 Sahampati informs the Buddha he has been reborn in hell. The Buddha gives a memorable simile of the length of life in hell.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "sn45.31", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamapa\u1e6dipattisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 45.31", "blurb": "The wrong eightfold path is wrong practice; the right eightfold path is right practice.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn45.32", "root_name": "Dutiyapa\u1e6dipattisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 45.32", "blurb": "Practicing the wrong eightfold path is wrong; practicing the right awakening path is right.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn45.33", "root_name": "Viraddhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 45.33", "blurb": "Neglecting the eightfold path you neglect the path to the end of suffering.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn45.34", "root_name": "P\u0101ra\u1e45gamasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 45.34", "blurb": "The eightfold path leads from the near to the far shore. With a long set of verses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn45.35", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamas\u0101ma\u00f1\u00f1asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 45.35", "blurb": "The eightfold path is the ascetic life. Its fruits are stream-entry, once-return, non-return, and perfection.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn45.36", "root_name": "Dutiyas\u0101ma\u00f1\u00f1asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 45.36", "blurb": "The eightfold path is the ascetic life. Its fruits are the end of greed, hate, and delusion.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn45.37", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamabrahma\u00f1\u00f1asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 45.37", "blurb": "The eightfold path is brahminhood. Its fruits are stream-entry, once-return, non-return, and perfection.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn45.38", "root_name": "Dutiyabrahma\u00f1\u00f1asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 45.38", "blurb": "The eightfold path is brahminhood. blurb: The “Verses of the Senior Nuns” is a collection of about 524 verses attributed to 73 of the senior nuns alive in the Buddha’s time, or in a few cases, a little later. These verses celebrate the bliss of freedom and the life of meditation, full of proud and joyous proclamations of their spiritual attainments and their gratitude to other nuns as guides and teachers. The Therīgāthā is one of the oldest spiritual texts recording only women’s voices. It is a pair with the Theragāthā, the “Verses of the Senior Monks”. Together these collections constitute one of the oldest and largest collections of contemplative literature. Based on style and content, these collections belong to the early discourses. They are referred to on occasion in the northern canons, but no parallel collections have survived.

[{"uid": "ja81", "root_name": "Sur\u0101p\u0101naj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Drinking Liquor ", "acronym": "Ja 81", "blurb": "\u201cWe drank.\u201d\u2014This story was cold by the Master about the Elder Sagata, while he was dwelling in the Ghosita-park near Kosambi.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja82", "root_name": "Mittavindakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "On Mittavindaka ", "acronym": "Ja 82", "blurb": "\u201cNo more to dwell.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a self-willed Brother. The incidents of this Birth, which took place in the days of the Buddha Kassapa, will be related in the Tenth Book in the Maha-Mittavindaka Jataka.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja83", "root_name": "K\u0101\u1e37aka\u1e47\u1e47ij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Unlucky ", "acronym": "Ja 83", "blurb": "\u201cA friend is he.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a friend of Anatha-pindika\u2019s. Tradition says that the two had made mud-pies together, and had gone to the same school; but, as years went by, the friend, whose name was \u2018Curse,\u2019 sank into great distress and could not make a living anyhow. So he came to the rich man, who was kind to him, and paid him to look after all his property; and the poor friend was employed under Anatha-pindika and did all his business for him. After he had gone up to the rich man\u2019s It was a common thing to hear in the house\u2014\u201cStand up, Curse,\u201d or \u201cSit down, Curse,\u201d or \u201cHave your dinner, Curse.\u201d ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja84", "root_name": "Atthassadv\u0101raj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Gates of the Good ", "acronym": "Ja 84", "blurb": "\u201cSeek health.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a boy who was sage in matters relating to spiritual welfare. When he was only seven years old, the boy, who was the son of a very wealthy Treasurer, manifested great intelligence and anxiety for his spiritual welfare; and one day came to his father to ask what were the Paths leading to spiritual welfare. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja85", "root_name": "Ki\u1e41pakkaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Unknown Fruit ", "acronym": "Ja 85", "blurb": "\u201cAs they who ate.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a concupiscent Brother. Tradition says there was a scion of a good family who gave his heart to the Buddha\u2019s doctrine and joined the Brotherhood. But one day as he was going his round for alms in Savatthi, he was there stirred to concupiscence by the sight of a beautifully dressed woman. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja86", "root_name": "S\u012blav\u012bma\u1e41sakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "A Test of Virtue ", "acronym": "Ja 86", "blurb": "\u201cNaught can compare.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a brahmin who put to the test his reputation for goodness. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja87", "root_name": "Ma\u1e45galaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Omens ", "acronym": "Ja 87", "blurb": "\u201cWhoso renounces.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at the Bamboo-grove about a brahmin who was skilled in the prognostications which can be drawn from pieces of cloth. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja88", "root_name": "S\u0101rambhaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Ox S\u0101rambha ", "acronym": "Ja 88", "blurb": "\u201cSpeak kindly.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Savatthi, about the precept touching abusive language. The introductory story and the story of the past are the same as in the Nandivisala-jataka above.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja89", "root_name": "Kuhakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Cheat ", "acronym": "Ja 89", "blurb": "\u201cHow plausible.\u201d This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about a knave. The details of his knavery will be related in the Uddala-jataka.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja90", "root_name": "Akata\u00f1\u00f1uj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Ungrateful ", "acronym": "Ja 90", "blurb": "\u201cThe man ungrateful.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about Anatha-pindika.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: Ten discourses to monks, many of them focusing on matters of discipline.
children: [{"uid": "mn61", "root_name": "Ambala\u1e6d\u1e6dhikar\u0101hulov\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": "Advice to R\u0101hula at Ambala\u1e6d\u1e6dhika ", "acronym": "MN 61", "blurb": "Using the \u201cobject lesson\u201d of a cup of water, the Buddha explains to his son, R\u0101hula, the importance of telling the truth and reflecting on one\u2019s motives.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn62", "root_name": "Mah\u0101r\u0101hulov\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": "The Longer Advice to R\u0101hula ", "acronym": "MN 62", "blurb": "The Buddha tells R\u0101hula to meditate on not-self, which he immediately puts into practice. Seeing him, Venerable S\u0101riputta advises him to develop breath meditation, but the Buddha suggests a wide range of different practices first.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn63", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37am\u0101lukyasutta", "translated_name": "The Shorter Discourse With M\u0101lu\u1e45kya ", "acronym": "MN 63", "blurb": "A monk demands that the Buddha answer his metaphysical questions, or else he will disrobe. The Buddha compares him to a man struck by an arrow, who refuses treatment until he can have all his questions about the arrow and the archer answered.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn64", "root_name": "Mah\u0101m\u0101lukyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 64", "blurb": "A little baby has no wrong views or intentions, but the underlying tendency for these things is still there. Without practicing, they will inevitably recur.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn65", "root_name": "Bhadd\u0101lisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 65", "blurb": "A monk refuses to follow the rule forbidding eating after noon, but is filled with remorse and forgiven.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn66", "root_name": "La\u1e6dukikopamasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 66", "blurb": "Again raising the rule regarding eating, but this time as a reflection of gratitude for the Buddha in eliminating things that cause complexity and stress. The Buddha emphasizes how attachment even to little things can be dangerous.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn67", "root_name": "C\u0101tumasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 67", "blurb": "After dismissing some unruly monks, the Buddha is persuaded to relent, and teaches them four dangers for those gone forth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn68", "root_name": "Na\u1e37akap\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 68", "blurb": "Those who practice do so not because they are failures, but because they aspire to higher freedom. When he speaks of the attainments of disciples, the Buddha does so in order to inspire.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn69", "root_name": "Goliy\u0101nisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 69", "blurb": "A monk comes down to the community from the wilderness, but doesn\u2019t behave properly. Venerable S\u0101riputta explains how a mendicant should behave, whether in forest or town.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn70", "root_name": "K\u012b\u1e6d\u0101girisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 70", "blurb": "A third discourse that presents the health benefits of eating in one part of the day, and the reluctance of some mendicants to follow this.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}]

The Buddha told him to abandon desire for sense experience, which is not-self.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.79", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamaavijj\u0101pah\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.79", "blurb": "Through giving up ignorance, knowledge arises. To do this, contemplate the six senses as impermanent.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.80", "root_name": "Dutiyaavijj\u0101pah\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.80", "blurb": "Through giving up ignorance, knowledge arises. To do this, contemplate the six senses as impermanent. Then a mendicant truly understands, and sees everything differently.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.81", "root_name": "Sambahulabhikkhusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.81", "blurb": "Some mendicants check with the Buddha that it\u2019s correct to say that the spiritual life is lived to end suffering. The Buddha answers that it is, and explains what that suffering is: the process of sense experience.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.82", "root_name": "Lokapa\u00f1h\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.82", "blurb": "The \u201cworld\u201d consisting of six sense experience is said to be falling apart.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.83", "root_name": "Phaggunapa\u00f1h\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.83", "blurb": "The Buddhas of the past cannot be described in terms of the six senses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses with Vacchagotta” contains 55 discourses, each with a philosophical inquiry by the wanderer Vacchagotta. These do not exhaust his questions; he also appears in a number of other discourses, notably MN 71–73, where he resolves his doubts and becomes perfected. The current chapter shows him repeatedly raising the question of the ten speculative views, and why they appear. The discourses are entirely formulaic and appear to have been produced from a template. Unusually for a section of this length, it lacks vaggas.

257", "blurb": "\u201cIt is not a clever builder\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while sojourning at Jetavana, about the praise of wisdom. In the Hall of Truth sat the Brethren, praising the wisdom of the Buddha: \u201cThe Blessed One has wisdom great and wide, wisdom witty and quick, wisdom sharp and penetrating. He excels this world and the world of gods in wisdom.\u201d", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja258", "root_name": "Mandh\u0101tuj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "King Mandh\u0101t\u0101 ", "acronym": "Ja 258", "blurb": "\u201cWherever sun and moon\u201d\u2014This story the Master told during a stay at Jetavana, about a backsliding brother.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja259", "root_name": "Tir\u012b\u1e6davacchaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Ascetic Tir\u012b\u1e6davaccha ", "acronym": "Ja 259", "blurb": "\u201cWhen all alone\u201d\u2014This story the Master told whilst living at Jetavana, about the gift of a thousand garments, how the reverend Ananda received five hundred garments from the women of the household of the king of Kosala, and five hundred from the king himself. The circumstances have been described above, in the Sigala Birth, of the Second Book.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja260", "root_name": "D\u016btaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Messenger ", "acronym": "Ja 260", "blurb": "\u201cO king, the Belly\u2019s messenger\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while staying at Jetavana, about a Brother who was addicted to covetousness. The circumstances will be given at large under the Kaka Birth, in Book the Ninth. Here again the Master told the Brother, \u201cYou were greedy before, Brother, as you are now; and in olden days for your greed you had your head cleft with a sword.\u201d Then he told an old-world story.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: The “Verses of the Senior Monks” is a collection of about 1288 verses attributed to 264 of the senior monks alive in the Buddha’s time, or in a few cases, a little later. It is a pair with the Therīgāthā, the “Verses of the Senior Nuns”. These verses celebrate the joy of freedom and the life of meditation in the forest. Together these collections constitute one of the oldest and largest collections of contemplative literature, preserving the unique voices of hundreds of early practitioners. Based on style and content, these collections belong to the early discourses. They are referred to on occasion in the northern canons, but no parallel collections have survived.
