blurb: The “Group of Discourses” contains 74 mostly short texts in verse or mixed prose and verse, arranged in five chapters. This contains some of the most beloved texts in popular Buddhism, such as the Ratana, Maṅgala, and Mettā Suttas, which are known to all Theravada Buddhists and recited as uplifting and protective chants at auspicious ceremonies. The collection as a whole is somewhat late; it is not found in northern scriptures, and some portions, such as the opening verses of the Nālaka Sutta, belong to the latest strata of the early texts. Nevertheless, certain sections—the “Rhinoceros Horn”, the “Chapter of the Eights”, and the “Way to the Beyond”—appear to have existed before being gathered into the collection, and are regarded as early. While the collection as a whole has no counterpart elsewhere, several portions have parallels in Chinese or Sanskrit.
children: [{"uid": "snp-uragavagga", "root_name": "Uragavagga", "translated_name": "The Serpent Chapter ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "Twelve poems beginning with a set of similes comparing a liberated one with a serpent who sheds its skin. The poems are diverse in style and content, and appear to have been collected from different sources. This chapter includes many perennial favorites such as the Mett\u0101 Sutta on Love and the warnings of the Par\u0101bhava Sutta on downfalls.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "Snp 1", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 38}, {"uid": "snp-culavagga", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37avagga", "translated_name": "The Lesser Chapter ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "Thirteen diverse poems similar to the previous chapter.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "Snp 2", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 40}, {"uid": "snp-mahavagga", "root_name": "Mah\u0101vagga", "translated_name": "The Great Chapter ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "Twelve longer poems that expand into sometimes legendary narrative. The first two discourses and the Nalaka Sutta offer early glimpses at crucial episodes in the Buddha\u2019s life. While some of these poems are found elsewhere in the canon, the Dvayat\u0101nupassan\u0101 offers a unique perspective on dependent origination and other topics typically found in prose texts.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "Snp 3", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 34}, {"uid": "snp-atthakavagga", "root_name": "A\u1e6d\u1e6dhakavagga", "translated_name": "The Chapter of Eights ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "This chapter, which has parallels in Chinese, and received an early commentary in the Niddesa, is often regarded as one of the earliest texts in the canon. Shorn of literary embellishments, it is direct and  powerful. A distinctive aspect is the critique of meaningless debates and attachments to views. The Attada\u1e47\u1e0da Sutta gives an alternative account of the reasons for the Buddha\u2019s going forth.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "Snp 4", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 48}, {"uid": "snp-parayanavagga", "root_name": "P\u0101r\u0101yanavagga", "translated_name": "The Chapter on the Way to the Beyond ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "This is perhaps the most sophisticated and moving poetic composition in early Buddhism. It begins with a brahmin, suffering an unwanted curse, who sends his students to seek the Buddha. At the end of a long journey they ask questions, the nature of which indicate their subtle philosophy and deep meditation. It concludes with an emotional declaration of faith and determination.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "Snp 5", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 68}]

[{"uid": "ja161", "root_name": "Indasam\u0101nagottaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Unteachable Ascetic Indasam\u0101nagotta ", "acronym": "Ja 161", "blurb": "\u201cFriendship with evil\u201d\u2014This is a story told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a headstrong person; and the circumstances will be found in the Vulture Birth, of the Ninth Book. blurb: 22 shorter discourses that in the Taishō edition of the Chinese canon have been gathered in the second volume, at sūtra numbers 102–124, following the three Saṁyuktāgama collections. These are miscellaneous translations of various discourses from the Saṁyutta, made at various times by various translators.

blurb: The Milindapañha or “Questions of King Milinda” records a series of discussions on points of Dhamma between the monk Nāgasena and the Greek king known as in Pali as Milinda. He is usually identified with Menander I Soter, who ruled an Indo-Greek kingdom from his capital of Sagala around BCE 165–130. While the encounter between Greek and Indian culture is fascinating, the dialogs concern only interpretation of Buddhist ideas, with which the king was evidently very familiar, and does not mention Greek philosophy. The text is lively and dynamic, with the King constantly testing Nāgasena with abstruse questions, to which he responds with ingenious arguments and analogies. The text has a shorter Chinese counterpart in the Nāgasena Bhikṣu Sūtra. The text is not Theravādin in origin, but began among one of the schools in the north-west, perhaps the Sarvāstivādins. Most of the content, however, is not sectarian in nature. The Pali text has been extended over the years, and in addition, portions appear to be missing. It is not universally accepted as canonical; SuttaCentral’s Pali texts, however, stem from the Mahāsaṅgīti edition, which as a Burmese text does include it.

blurb: The Netti or “Guide” is a systematic treatise intended to provide a guide for reading and interpreting the texts of the nikāyas. It is similar to the Peṭakopadesa, and the exact relationship between these two texts is not clear. The text provides an array of methods for reading texts, illustrating them with quotations, and taking the four noble truths as the overall framework. A colophon in the text attributes it to the Buddha's disciple Kaccāna. It is, however, a late text, lacking counterparts in the northern collections. It is not universally accepted as canonical; SuttaCentral’s Pali texts, however, stem from the Mahāsaṅgīti edition, which as a Burmese text does include it.

[{"uid": "sn17.21", "root_name": "M\u0101tug\u0101masutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 17.21", "blurb": "Material possessions, honor, and praise can be even more tempting than a woman.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn17.22", "root_name": "Kaly\u0101\u1e47\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 17.22", "blurb": "Material possessions, honor, and praise can be even more tempting than the finest lady in the land.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn17.23", "root_name": "Ekaputtakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 17.23", "blurb": "A laywoman should wish that if her son remains in the household life, he should be like Citta and Hatthaka. But if he becomes a monk, may material possessions, honor, and praise not come to him!", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn17.24", "root_name": "Ekadh\u012btusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 17.24", "blurb": "A laywoman should wish that if her daughter remains in the household life, she should be like Khujjuttara\u0304 and Ve\u1e37uka\u1e47\u1e0dakiya\u0304. But if she becomes a nun, may material possessions, honor, and praise not come to her!", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn17.25", "root_name": "Sama\u1e47abr\u0101hma\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 17.25", "blurb": "Someone who "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn17.26", "root_name": "Dutiyasama\u1e47abr\u0101hma\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 17.26", "blurb": "Someone who doesn\u2019t fully understand material possessions, honor, and praise is no true ascetic.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn17.28", "root_name": "Chavisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 17.28", "blurb": "Material possessions, honor, and [{"uid": "an6.43", "root_name": "N\u0101gasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.43", "blurb": "When going for a bath, the Buddha encounters a giant royal elephant. But a spiritual giant is even more impressive.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.44", "root_name": "Migas\u0101l\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.44", "blurb": "In response to criticism, the Buddha explains that it is difficult to compare the spiritual development of different individuals, so we should not be judgmental.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.45", "root_name": "I\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.45", "blurb": "Poor people suffer when they get in debt. Spiritual practitioners who are devoid of good qualities suffer in a similar way.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an6.46", "root_name": "Mah\u0101cundasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.46", "blurb": "In a discourse evidently set some time after the Buddha\u2019s passing, Venerable Mah\u0101cunda urges different groups of meditators, whether they emphasize serenity or insight, to respect and support each other.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an6.47", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamasandi\u1e6d\u1e6dhikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.47", "blurb": "The Buddha explains to the wanderer Moliyas\u012bvaka how the teaching may be realized in the present life.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an6.48", "root_name": "Dutiyasandi\u1e6d\u1e6dhikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.48", "blurb": "The Buddha explains a brahmin how the teaching may be realized in the present life.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.49", "root_name": "Khemasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.49", "blurb": "Two monks separately come to the Buddha and speak of awakening in terms of letting go conceit. The Buddha affirms that they are, in fact, awakened, and that such indirect means are the proper way to make such declarations.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an6.50", "root_name": "Indriyasa\u1e41varasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.50", "blurb": "Just as a tree without leaves cannot grow, sense restraint is the foundation for spiritual growth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.51", "root_name": "\u0100nandasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.51", "blurb": "Venerables \u0100nanda and S\u0101riputta discuss how a mendicants gets to further their learning and understanding.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an6.52", "root_name": "Khattiyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.52", "blurb": "The Buddha explains to the brahmin J\u0101\u1e47usso\u1e47\u012b the ambition, quest, commitment, insistence, and ultimate goal of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, women, bandits, and ascetics.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.53", "root_name": "Appam\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.53", "blurb": "With a series of vivid similes, the Buddha shows how diligence leads to benefits in both this life and the next.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an6.54", "root_name": "Dhammikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 6.54", "blurb": "The monk Dhammika annoys both the monks and the layfolk so badly that they banish him. He comes to the Buddha, who consoles him and raises his spirits with a story, while at the same time showing him the error of his ways.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

go of desire for what is not-self, namely the five aggregates.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.69", "root_name": "Anattaniyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.69", "blurb": "One should let go of desire for what does not belong to self, namely the five aggregates.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.70", "root_name": "Rajan\u012byasa\u1e47\u1e6dhitasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.70", "blurb": "One should let go of desire for what appears tantalizing, namely the five aggregates.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.71", "root_name": "R\u0101dhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.71", "blurb": "Venerable R\u0101dha asks the Buddha how to see so as to let go of conceit. The Buddha tells him to contemplate the aggregates in terms of not-self.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.72", "root_name": "Sur\u0101dhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.72", "blurb": "Venerable Sur\u0101dha asks the Buddha how to see so as to let go of conceit and be freed. translated_name: The Chapter on Be Your Own Island
children: [{"uid": "sn22.43", "root_name": "Attad\u012bpasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.43", "blurb": "Dwell with yourself as an island and refuge, with the Dhamma as an island and refuge. How? By investigating how suffering arises from identification with the aggregates.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.44", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dipad\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.44", "blurb": "Contemplation of the five aggregates as not-self is the path to the end of identity.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.45", "root_name": "Aniccasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.45", "blurb": "Seeing the five aggregates as impermanent, etc., leads to freedom.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.46", "root_name": "Dutiyaaniccasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.46", "blurb": "Seeing the five aggregates as impermanent, etc., leads to letting go of views and ultimately to freedom.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.47", "root_name": "Samanupassan\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.47", "blurb": "When you identify anything as self, you always identify one or other of the five aggregates.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.48", "root_name": "Khandhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.48", "blurb": "The distinction between \u201cfive aggregates\u201d and \u201cfive grasping aggregates\u201d.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.49", "root_name": "So\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.49", "blurb": "The Buddha teaches a householder named So\u1e47a not to be conceited about the five aggregates.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.50", "root_name": "Dutiyaso\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.50", "blurb": "The Buddha teaches a householder named So\u1e47a that any true ascetic understands the five aggregates.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.51", "root_name": "Nandikkhayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.51", "blurb": "Right view is seeing the aggregates as they are, impermanent, and this leads to freedom.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.52", "root_name": "Dutiyanandikkhayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.52", "blurb": "Focusing properly on the five aggregates you see them as they are and become free.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Absorption” (Jhānasaṁyutta) is also known as the “Linked Discourses on Immersion” (Samādhisaṁyutta). It contains 55 discourses dealing with the meditative skills required to perfect absorption. Each discourse describes a meditator who is skilled in some aspects, but not in others, and holds the one skilled in all aspects to be the best.

[{"uid": "sn55.21", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamamah\u0101n\u0101masutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.21", "blurb": "Mah\u0101n\u0101ma the Sakyan expresses his fear that if he dies unmindful he may go to a bad rebirth. The Buddha tells him not to fear, as he will definitely go to a good place, since he has long practiced the Dhamma.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn55.22", "root_name": "Dutiyamah\u0101n\u0101masutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.22", "blurb": "Mah\u0101n\u0101ma the Sakyan expresses his fear that if he dies unmindful he may go to a bad rebirth. The Buddha tells him not to fear, as he will definitely go to a good place, since he has the four factors of stream-entry.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn55.23", "root_name": "Godhasakkasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.23", "blurb": "Mah\u0101n\u0101ma and Godh\u0101 the Sakyans discuss whether a stream-enterer has three or four factors. They go to the Buddha to settle it, and Mah\u0101n\u0101ma testifies to his faith.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn55.24", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamasara\u1e47\u0101nisakkasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.24", "blurb": "When Sarak\u0101ni the Sakyan died the Buddha declared him a stream-enterer. But others complained, since he was known as a drinker. However, the Buddha confirmed to Mah\u0101n\u0101ma that Sarak\u0101ni had undertaken the precepts on his deathbed.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn55.25", "root_name": "Dutiyasara\u1e47\u0101nisakkasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.25", "blurb": "When Sarak\u0101ni the Sakyan died the Buddha declared him a stream-enterer. But others complained, since he was known as a drinker. However, the Buddha confirmed to Mah\u0101n\u0101ma that Sarak\u0101ni had undertaken the precepts on his deathbed.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn55.26", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamaan\u0101thapi\u1e47\u1e0dikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.26", "blurb": "When the householder An\u0101thapi\u1e47\u1e0dika was sick, S\u0101riputta reminds him of his considerable accomplishments in the Dhamma, analyzing stream-entry in ten factors, at which An\u0101thapi\u1e47\u1e0dika recovers. Later he invited S\u0101riputta and \u0100nanda for a meal, and S\u0101riputta thanked him with verses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn55.27", "root_name": "Dutiyaan\u0101thapi\u1e47\u1e0dikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.27", "blurb": "When the householder An\u0101thapi\u1e47\u1e0dika was sick, \u0100nanda reminds him of the four factors of stream-entry, which An\u0101thapi\u1e47\u1e0dika claims to possess.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn55.28", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamabhayaver\u016bpasantasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.28", "blurb": "A noble disciple who is a layperson has eliminated the fear that comes from breaking precepts, possesses the four factors of stream-entry, and understands dependent origination.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn55.29", "root_name": "Dutiyabhayaver\u016bpasantasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.29", "blurb": "A noble disciple who is a layperson has eliminated the fear that comes from breaking precepts, possesses the four factors of stream-entry, and understands dependent origination.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn55.30", "root_name": "Nandakalicchavisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.30", "blurb": "The Buddha teaches the four factors of stream-entry to Nandaka, the minister of the Licchavis. When his servant tells him it is time for his ritual bath, he says that the inner bathing of the Dhamma is enough.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: The Mahākarmavibhaṅga or “Great Analysis of Deeds” is a Sanskrit Abhidharma text based on manuscripts from Nepal, which includes a number of quotations from early discourses, including the Dhammapada. The SuttaCentral text is from GRETIL, based on the edition by Sylvain Lévi (1932), and input by Klaus Wille.

translated_name: The Chapter on Overflowing Merit, With Verses
children: [{"uid": "sn55.41", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamaabhisandasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.41", "blurb": "The four factors of stream-entry\u2014with ethics as the fourth\u2014are streams of merit, and like the ocean cannot be counted. With verses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn55.42", "root_name": "Dutiyaabhisandasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.42", "blurb": "The four factors of stream-entry\u2014with generosity as the fourth\u2014are streams of merit, and like the ocean cannot be counted. With verses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn55.43", "root_name": "Tatiyaabhisandasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 55.43", "blurb": "The four factors of stream-entry\u2014with wisdom as the fourth\u2014are streams of merit, and like the ocean cannot be counted. [{"uid": "ja386", "root_name": "Kharaputtaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Foolish Donkey ", "acronym": "Ja 386", "blurb": "\u201cGoats are stupid\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale in Jetavana, concerning temptation of a Brother by his former wife. When the Brother confessed that he was longing for the world, the Master said, \u201cBrother, this woman does you harm: formerly also you came into the fire through her and were saved from death by sages,\u201d so he told an old tale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja387", "root_name": "S\u016bcij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Needles ", "acronym": "Ja 387", "blurb": "\u201cQuickly threaded\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning the perfection of wisdom. The occasion of the tale will be given in the Mahaummagga. The Master addressed the brethren, \u201cThis is not the first time the Tathagata is wise and skilled in devices,\u201d and so he told an old tale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja388", "root_name": "Tu\u1e47\u1e0dilaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Boar-Brothers Tu\u1e47\u1e0dila ", "acronym": "Ja 388", "blurb": "\u201cSomething strange to-day\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning a brother who feared death.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja389", "root_name": "Suva\u1e47\u1e47akakka\u1e6daj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Golden Crab ", "acronym": "Ja 389", "blurb": "\u201cGold-clawed creature\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale when dwelling in the Bamboo-grove, of Ananda\u2019s dying for his sake. The occasion is told in the Khandahala Birth about the hiring of bowmen, and in the Cullahamsa Birth about the roar of the elephant Dhanapala. Then they began a discussion in the Hall of Truth: \u201cSirs, has the Elder Ananda, Treasurer of the Law, who attained all the wisdom possible to one still under discipline, given up his life for the Perfect Buddha when Dhanapala came?\u201d The Master came and was told the subject of their discussion: he said, \u201cBrother, in former times also Ananda gave up his life for me:\u201d and so he told an old tale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja390", "root_name": "Mayhakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Bird Who Cried \u201cMine! Mine!\u201d ", "acronym": "Ja 390", "blurb": "\u201cDid we joy\u201d\u2014The Master told this while dwelling in Jetavana, of a stranger merchant who did not enjoy his wealth himself nor give it to others.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja391", "root_name": "Vijj\u0101dharaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Wizard ", "acronym": "Ja 391", "blurb": "\u201cNoble of face\u201d\u2014The Master told this while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning his going about for the whole world\u2019s good. The occasion will appear in the Mahakanha Birth. Then the Master said, \u201cBrethren, this is not the first time the Tathagata has gone about for the world\u2019s good,\u201d and so told an old tale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja392", "root_name": "Si\u1e45ghapupphaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Thief of Scent ", "acronym": "Ja 392", "blurb": "\u201cYou were never\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning a certain Brother. The story is that the Brother had left Jetavana and dwelt in the Kosala kingdom near a certain wood: one day he went down into a lotus-pool , and seeing a lotus in flower he stood to leeward and smelt it. Then the goddess who dwelt in that part of the forest frightened him saying, \u201cSir, you are a thief of odours, this is a kind of theft.\u201d He went back in a fright to Jetavana, and saluted the Master and sat down. \u201cWhere have you been staying, Brother?\u201d \u201cIn such and such a wood, and the goddess frightened me in such and such a way.\u201d The Master said, \u201cYou are not the first who have been frightened by a goddess when smelling a flower; sages of old have been frightened in like manner,\u201d and at the Brother\u2019s request he told an old tale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja393", "root_name": "Vigh\u0101s\u0101daj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Eaters of Leftovers ", "acronym": "Ja 393", "blurb": "\u201cHappy life is theirs\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale while dwelling in the East Garden, concerning some Brethren who were given to amusement. The great Moggallana had shaken their dwelling and alarmed them. The Brethren sat discussing their fault in the Hall of Truth. The Master being told this said to them, \u201cThey are not given to amusement for the first time,\u201d and so told an old tale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja394", "root_name": "Va\u1e6d\u1e6dakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Quail ", "acronym": "Ja 394", "blurb": "\u201cOil and butter\u201d\u2014The Master told this while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning a greedy Brother. Finding that he was greedy the Master said to him, \u201cThis is not the first time you are greedy: once before through greed in Benares you were not satisfied with carcases of elephants, oxen, horses and men; and in hopes of getting better food you went to the forest;\u201d and so he told an old tale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja395", "root_name": "P\u0101r\u0101vataj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Dove ", "acronym": "Ja 395", "blurb": "\u201cOur old friend\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning a greedy Brother. The occasion is as above.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: Returning to stories about the Buddha’s life, this chapter skips ahead to near the end. Meanwhile, it reminds us of those who have lost their way.

translated_name: The Chapter on the Iron Ball
children: [{"uid": "sn51.21", "root_name": "Maggasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.21", "blurb": "Before his awakening, the Buddha reflected on the path for developing the bases of psychic power.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn51.22", "root_name": "Ayogu\u1e37asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.22", "blurb": "\u0100nanda asks the Buddha whether he travels to the Brahm\u0101 realm in a mind-made body or in a physical body. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn51.23", "root_name": "Bhikkhusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.23", "blurb": "It is because of developing the four bases of psychic power that a mendicant ends the defilements.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn51.24", "root_name": "Suddhikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.24", "blurb": "The four bases for psychic power are desire, energy, higher mind, and inquiry.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn51.25", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamaphalasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.25", "blurb": "The four bases for psychic power lead to perfection or once-return.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn51.26", "root_name": "Dutiyaphalasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 51.26", "blurb": "The four bases for psychic power translated_name: Prince Arindama and His Friend Soṇaka
children: [{"uid": "ja529", "root_name": "So\u1e47akaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Prince Arindama and His Friend So\u1e47aka ", "acronym": "Ja 529", "blurb": "\u201cA thousand crowns\u201d\u2014This is a story told by the Master, while dwelling at Jetavana, concerning the Perfection of Renunciation. On this occasion the Bodhisatta sitting in the Hall of Truth in the midst of the Brethren, as they were singing the praises of the Perfection of Renunciation, said, \u201cBrethren, not now only, but of old also the Tathagata verily left the world and made the Great Renunciation,\u201d and so saying he related a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja530", "root_name": "Sa\u1e45kiccaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Prince Brahmadatta and His Friend Sa\u1e41kicca ", "acronym": "Ja 530", "blurb": "\u201cAt sight of Brahmadatta\u201d\u2014This story the Master, while dwelling in the mango grove of Jivaka, told concerning the murder of his own father by Ajatasattu. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: The Udānavarga or “Collection of Inspired Sayings” is a Sarvāstivādin Dhammapada-style text. At 1044 verses, it is over twice as long as the Pali Dhammapada, and the longest of all the Dhammapadas. The manuscript was among the Sanskrit texts discovered at Turfan. The SuttaCentral text is sourced from the Titus edition prepared by Gippert and Kupfer, and based on the edition by Bernhard (1965). There are Chinese and Tibetan translations of this text.

[{"uid": "an4.191", "root_name": "Sot\u0101nugatasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.191", "blurb": "The benefits in the next life of studying Dharma in this life.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an4.192", "root_name": "\u1e6ch\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.192", "blurb": "Ways of assessing a person\u2019s morality, integrity, resilience, and wisdom.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an4.193", "root_name": "Bhaddiyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.193", "blurb": "The Buddha is accused of using magic to convert followers.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an4.194", "root_name": "S\u0101mugiyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.194", "blurb": "Making an effort to be pure in morality, mind, view, and freedom.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an4.195", "root_name": "Vappasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.195", "blurb": "A discussion with a Jain on whether someone with purified understanding can experience the results of bad karma in the next life.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an4.196", "root_name": "S\u0101\u1e37hasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.196", "blurb": "The practice of self-torture doesn\u2019t purify you internally. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an4.197", "root_name": "Mallik\u0101dev\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.197", "blurb": "Queen Mallik\u0101 asks about the karmic causes of beauty, wealth, and power.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an4.198", "root_name": "Attantapasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.198", "blurb": "Those who torture themselves and others, and those who do not.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an4.199", "root_name": "Ta\u1e47h\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.199", "blurb": "The web of craving that wraps around the self.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an4.200", "root_name": "Pemasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.200", "blurb": "How love and hate give rise to love and hate; and how one doesn\u2019t fume, ignite, or burn up.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses in the Woods” contains 14 discourses with verses telling the experiences of certain monks living the woods. Typically the monk is slack or negligent in some way, and a deity appears to call them out and encourage them to greater diligence.

[{"uid": "thag15.1", "root_name": "A\u00f1\u00f1\u0101siko\u1e47\u1e0da\u00f1\u00f1attherag\u0101th\u0101", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "Thag 15.1", "blurb": null, "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "thag15.2", "root_name": "Ud\u0101yittherag\u0101th\u0101", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "Thag 15.2", "blurb": null, "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "sn46.1", "root_name": "Himavantasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 46.1", "blurb": "Dragons nurture their strength in the Himalayas, then enter the rivers and reach the ocean. So too, a mendicant nurtures ethics and then develops the seven awakening factors.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn46.2", "root_name": "K\u0101yasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 46.2", "blurb": "Just as the body depends on food, the awakening factors depend on nutriment. The Buddha gives specific conditions for each of the factors.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn46.3", "root_name": "S\u012blasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 46.3", "blurb": "Here the awakening factors are described in the context of hearing the teachings and reflecting on them. This leads to full enlightenment, or at least to some lesser attainment.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn46.4", "root_name": "Vatthasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 46.4", "blurb": "The various awakening factors can be donned at different times of the day, like a man who puts on bright colored clothes whenever he wants.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn46.5", "root_name": "Bhikkhusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 46.5", "blurb": "They\u2019re called awakening factors because they lead to awakening.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn46.6", "root_name": "Ku\u1e47\u1e0daliyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 46.6", "blurb": "The wanderer Ku\u1e47\u1e0daliya points out that some ascetics argue for the sake of winning debates. But the Buddha says his path is for the sake of liberation. Ku\u1e47\u1e0daliya asks what leads to liberation, and the Buddha traces a sequence of conditions back to sense restraint.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn46.7", "root_name": "K\u016b\u1e6d\u0101g\u0101rasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 46.7", "blurb": "The awakening factors lead to extinguishment, like rafters holding up the roof peak.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn46.8", "root_name": "Upav\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 46.8", "blurb": "Sa\u0304riputta asks Upava\u0304\u1e47a how one can reflect and see the awakening factors in oneself.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn46.9", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamauppannasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 46.9", "blurb": "The awakening factors do not arise apart from a Realized One.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn46.10", "root_name": "Dutiyauppannasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 46.10", "blurb": "The awakening factors do not arise apart from a Holy One\u2019s training.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

translated_name: The Chapter in a Rosewood Forest
children: [{"uid": "sn56.31", "root_name": "S\u012bsap\u0101vanasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.31", "blurb": "In a si\u1e41sap\u0101 grove, the Buddha holds up a handful of leaves, and compares it to all the leaves in the forest. So too, he has taught the four noble truths, which is only a fraction of what he knows.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.32", "root_name": "Khadirapattasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.32", "blurb": "Just as it\u2019s impossible to keep water in a basket of pine needles, it\u2019s impossible to end suffering without penetrating the four noble truths.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.33", "root_name": "Da\u1e47\u1e0dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.33", "blurb": "Beings who have not seen the four noble truths roam on from one birth to another, like a stick thrown end to end. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.34", "root_name": "Celasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.34", "blurb": "Even more than if your clothes are on fire, you should make an effort to understand the four noble truths.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.35", "root_name": "Sattisatasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.35", "blurb": "Even more than if you\u2019re being tortured with spikes, you should make an effort to understand the four noble truths.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.36", "root_name": "P\u0101\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.36", "blurb": "The small creatures in the ocean are greater in number than all the foliage in the jungles of India. Still, your rebirths are more than this.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.37", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamas\u016briyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.37", "blurb": "As the dawn precedes the sunrise, right view precedes the penetration of the four noble truths.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.38", "root_name": "Dutiyas\u016briyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.38", "blurb": "As long as there are no sun and moon, the world is in darkness. So too, as long as the Realized One has not arisen and declared the four noble truths, the world is in darkness.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.39", "root_name": "Indakh\u012blasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.39", "blurb": "One who has not seen the four noble truths is as feeble as a tuft of cotton wool, while one who has seen them is like a deep-rooted pillar.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.40", "root_name": "V\u0101datthikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.40", "blurb": "No-one can refute you if you are well grounded in the four noble truths.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

[{"uid": "ja-sankappavagga", "root_name": "Sa\u1e45kappavagga", "translated_name": "Thoughts of Lust ", "acronym": null, "blurb": null, "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "Ja 251\u2013260", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 10}, {"uid": "ja-padumavagga", "root_name": "Padumavagga", "translated_name": "The Lotus ", "acronym": null, "blurb": null, "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "Ja 261\u2013270", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 10}, {"uid": "ja-udapanavagga", "root_name": "Udap\u0101navagga", "translated_name": "The Fouled Well ", "acronym": null, "blurb": null, "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "Ja 271\u2013280", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 10}, {"uid": "ja-abbhantaravagga", "root_name": "Abbhantaravagga", "translated_name": "The Midmost Mango ", "acronym": null, "blurb": null, "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "Ja 281\u2013290", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 10}, {"uid": "ja-kumbhavagga", "root_name": "Kumbhavagga", "translated_name": "The Cup ", "acronym": null, "blurb": null, "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "Ja 291\u2013300", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 10}]

translated_name: The Chapter on the World and the Kinds of Sensual Stimulation
children: [{"uid": "sn35.114", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamam\u0101rap\u0101sasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.114", "blurb": "A mendicant who craves the senses is under the sway of M\u0101ra.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.115", "root_name": "Dutiyam\u0101rap\u0101sasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.115", "blurb": "A mendicant who craves the senses is under the sway of M\u0101ra.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.116", "root_name": "Lokantagamanasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.116", "blurb": "The Buddha states that the end of the world cannot be reached by traveling, yet it is impossible to end suffering without reaching the end of the world. The mendicants ask \u0100nanda to explain this enigmatic statement.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.117", "root_name": "K\u0101magu\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.117", "blurb": "While practicing for awakening, the Buddha reflected that he should be diligent when his mind strayed to sense pleasures of the past, future, or present. He urges the mendicants to realize that place where the senses completely cease, and they ask \u0100nanda to explain this to them.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.118", "root_name": "Sakkapa\u00f1hasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.118", "blurb": "Sakka asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.119", "root_name": "Pa\u00f1casikhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.119", "blurb": "The fairy Pa\u00f1casikha asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.120", "root_name": "S\u0101riputtasaddhivih\u0101rikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.120", "blurb": "A mendicant informs Sa\u0304riputta that one of his friends had disrobed. Sa\u0304riputta attributes this to lack of sense restraint, eating too much, and not being wakeful.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.121", "root_name": "R\u0101hulov\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.121", "blurb": "Realizing that his son Ra\u0304hula was ripe for awakening, the Buddha takes him for a personal teaching. He questions Ra\u0304hula on the impermanence of all the factors of sense experience, leading Ra\u0304hula to realize full freedom.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.122", "root_name": "Sa\u1e41yojaniyadhammasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.122", "blurb": "The exterior sense fields are the things that fetter, the craving is the fetter.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.123", "root_name": "Up\u0101d\u0101niyadhammasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.123", "blurb": "The exterior sense fields are the things that are graspable, the craving is the grasping.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

[{"uid": "ja171", "root_name": "Kaly\u0101\u1e47adhammaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "A Fine Reputation ", "acronym": "Ja 171", "blurb": "\u201cO king, when people hail us\u201d\u2014This story the Master told in Jetavana, about a deaf mother-in-law.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja172", "root_name": "Daddaraj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Who Sounds the Drum? ", "acronym": "Ja 172", "blurb": "\u201cWho is it with a mighty cry, etc.\u201d\u2014This is a story which the Master told at Jetavana about one Kokalika.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja173", "root_name": "Makka\u1e6daj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Monkey ", "acronym": "Ja 173", "blurb": "\u201cFather, see! a poor old fellow\u201d\u2014This story the Master told whilst staying in Jetavana, about a rogue. The circumstances will be explained in the Uddala Birth, Book xiv.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja174", "root_name": "Dubbhiyamakka\u1e6daj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Tricky Monkey ", "acronym": "Ja 174", "blurb": "\u201cPlenty of water\u201d\u2014This story the Master told in his sojourn at Veluvana, about Devadatta. One day it happened that the Brethren were talking in the Hall of Truth about Devadatta\u2019s ingratitude and treachery to his friends, when the Master broke in, \u201cNot this once only, Brethren, has Devadatta been ungrateful and treacherous to his own friends. He was just the same before.\u201d Then he told them an old story.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja175", "root_name": "\u0100diccupa\u1e6d\u1e6dh\u0101naj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Monkey Who Worshiped the Sun ", "acronym": "Ja 175", "blurb": "\u201cThere is no tribe\u201d\u2014This is a story told by the Master in Jetavana, about a rogue.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja176", "root_name": "Ka\u1e37\u0101yamu\u1e6d\u1e6dhij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Lost Pea ", "acronym": "Ja 176", "blurb": "\u201cA foolish monkey\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Jetavana, about a king of Kosala.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja177", "root_name": "Tindukaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Pale-moon Ebony Tree ", "acronym": "Ja 177", "blurb": "\u201cAll around us see them stand\u201d\u2014This is a story told by the Master whilst at Jetavana, about perfect knowledge. As in the Mahabodhi Birth, and the Ummagga Birth, on hearing his own knowledge praised, he remarked, \u201cNot this once only is the Buddha wise, but wise he was before and fertile in all resource;\u201d and told the following old story.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja178", "root_name": "Kacchapaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Tortoise ", "acronym": "Ja 178", "blurb": "\u201cHere was I born\u201d\u2014This story the Master told in Jetavana, how a man got rid of malaria.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja179", "root_name": "Satadhammaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Brahmin Satadhamma ", "acronym": "Ja 179", "blurb": "\u201cWhat a trifle\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while sojourning in Jetavana, about the twenty-one unlawful ways of earning a livelihood.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja180", "root_name": "Duddadaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Hard to Give ", "acronym": "Ja 180", "blurb": "\u201cTis hard to do as good men do\u201d\u2014This story the Master told whilst in Jetavana, about alms given in common.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: The Nāgasena Bhikṣu Sūtra (那先比丘經) is a Chinese version of the text found in Pali as the Milinda Pañha. The translator and date are unknown, but it is listed in the Tung Chin lu (東晉錄) (CE 317–420). In the Taishō edition of the Chinese canon, it is text number 1670B, located at T vol. 32, 703c.

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Cloud Gods” is the last of four similar sections dealing with the modes in which various semi-celestial beings may be reborn. The current chapter is on the “cloud gods” or valāhakas, who are deities of the weather controlling the clouds.

children: [{"uid": "sn56.11", "root_name": "Dhammacakkappavattanasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.11", "blurb": "The famous first discourse, taught at Varanasi to the group of five ascetics. It begins by rejecting the extremes of asceticism and indulgence and recommends the middle way of the eightfold path. Then it defines the four noble truths and analyzes them in twelve aspects. It ends with Venerable Konda\u00f1\u00f1a becoming the first person apart from the Buddha to realize the Dhamma.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", [{"uid": "sn25.1", "root_name": "Cakkhusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 25.1", "blurb": "One with faith in the teachings on the six interior sense fields is called a \u201cfollower by faith\u201d, while someone with conceptual understanding is called a \u201cfollower of the teachings\u201d. But someone who sees them directly is called a stream-enterer.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn25.2", "root_name": "R\u016bpasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 25.2", "blurb": "One with faith in the teachings on the six exterior sense fields is called a \u201cfollower by faith\u201d, while someone with conceptual understanding is called a \u201cfollower of the teachings\u201d. But someone who sees them directly is called a stream-enterer.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn25.3", "root_name": "Vi\u00f1\u00f1\u0101\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 25.3", "blurb": "One with faith in the teachings on the six kinds of consciousness is called a \u201cfollower by faith\u201d, while someone with conceptual understanding is called a \u201cfollower of the teachings\u201d. But someone who sees them directly is called a stream-enterer.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn25.4", "root_name": "Samphassasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 25.4", "blurb": "One with faith in the teachings on the six kinds of contact is called a \u201cfollower by faith\u201d, while someone with conceptual understanding is called a \u201cfollower of the teachings\u201d. But someone who sees them directly is called a stream-enterer.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn25.5", "root_name": "Samphassajasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 25.5", "blurb": "One with faith in the teachings on the six kinds of feeling is called a \u201cfollower by faith\u201d, while someone with conceptual understanding is called a \u201cfollower of the teachings\u201d. But someone who sees them directly is called a stream-enterer.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn25.6", "root_name": "R\u016bpasa\u00f1\u00f1\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 25.6", "blurb": "One with faith in the teachings on the six kinds of perception is called a \u201cfollower by faith\u201d, while someone with conceptual understanding is called a \u201cfollower of the teachings\u201d. But someone who sees them directly is called a stream-enterer.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn25.7", "root_name": "R\u016bpasa\u00f1cetan\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 25.7", "blurb": "One with faith in the teachings on the six kinds of intention is called a \u201cfollower by faith\u201d, while someone with conceptual understanding is called a \u201cfollower of the teachings\u201d. But someone who sees them directly is called a stream-enterer.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn25.8", "root_name": "R\u016bpata\u1e47h\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 25.8", "blurb": "One with faith in the teachings on the six kinds of craving is called a \u201cfollower by faith\u201d, while someone with conceptual understanding is called a \u201cfollower of the teachings\u201d. But someone who sees them directly is called a stream-enterer.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn25.9", "root_name": "Pathav\u012bdh\u0101tusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 25.9", "blurb": "One with faith in the teachings on the four physical elements is called a \u201cfollower by faith\u201d, while someone with conceptual understanding is called a \u201cfollower of the teachings\u201d. But someone who sees them directly is called a stream-enterer.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn25.10", "root_name": "Khandhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 25.10", "blurb": "One with faith in the teachings on the five aggregates is called a \u201cfollower by faith\u201d, while someone with conceptual understanding is called a \u201cfollower of the teachings\u201d. But someone who sees them directly is called a stream-enterer", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: The Arthaviniścayasūtra is a Sanskrit text which consists almost entirely of quotations of early sūtra passages. The text has been edited and published in a series of editions by Alfonsa Ferrari (1944), P.L. Vaidya (1961), and N.H. Samtani based on several manuscripts discovered in Tibet and Nepal. The SuttaCentral text is based on the revision of Samtani by Ānandajoti. Ferrari and Vaidya classified this text under Mahāyāna, but Samtani and Ānandajoti point out that there are only a few mentions of Mahāyāna concepts, and these are likely to be later additions. The original text appears to be related to the Sarvāstivādins, possibly from the Sautrāntika school.

Nevertheless, he persists, and the Buddha teaches him meditation in detail.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an8.64", "root_name": "Gay\u0101s\u012bsasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.64", "blurb": "At Gay\u0101, the Buddha describes his meditation before awakening. translated_name: Linked Discourses on Arrival at the Truth
blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Arrival” is the first of three similar sections, each of which takes a set of ten doctrinal items (shared also with SN 18 Rāhula) and presents it according to a set pattern. The current chapter focuses on the distinction between those who accept the teachings by either faith or intellectual understanding, and those who have realized them for themselves.

translated_name: The Chapter on the Undeclared Points
children: [{"uid": "sn44.1", "root_name": "Khem\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 44.1", "blurb": "While staying in Tora\u1e47avatthu, King Pasenadi wishes to visit a spiritual teacher, and the nun Khema\u0304 is highly recommended to him. He asks her about whether a realized One exists after death, and she says this is not answerable. Later he visits the Buddha, who replies in exactly the same way.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn44.2", "root_name": "Anur\u0101dhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 44.2", "blurb": "Venerable Anur\u0101dha is questioned by a number of ascetics, and ends up by saying that the Realized One is described in terms other than \u201cexisting after death\u201d and so on. The wanderers say he\u2019s a fool, so he checks with the Buddha, who says that a Realized One is not even apprehended in this life, so how can he be described after death?", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn44.3", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamas\u0101riputtako\u1e6d\u1e6dhikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 44.3", "blurb": "Maha\u0304ko\u1e6d\u1e6dhita asks S\u0101riputta whether a Realized One exists after death. S\u0101riputta says that to answer this would be to get involved in the five aggregates, something that a Realized One is free from.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn44.4", "root_name": "Dutiyas\u0101riputtako\u1e6d\u1e6dhikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 44.4", "blurb": "Maha\u0304ko\u1e6d\u1e6dhita asks S\u0101riputta whether a Realized One exists after death. S\u0101riputta says that one who understands the five aggregates would not think in such terms.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn44.5", "root_name": "Tatiyas\u0101riputtako\u1e6d\u1e6dhikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 44.5", "blurb": "Maha\u0304ko\u1e6d\u1e6dhita asks S\u0101riputta whether a Realized One exists after death. S\u0101riputta says that only someone who has desire for the five aggregates would think in such terms.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn44.6", "root_name": "Catutthas\u0101riputtako\u1e6d\u1e6dhikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 44.6", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta asks Maha\u0304ko\u1e6d\u1e6dhita whether a Realized One exists after death. Maha\u0304ko\u1e6d\u1e6dhita says that only someone who delights in the five aggregates would think in such terms, and offers a variety of further explanations of the same point.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn44.7", "root_name": "Moggall\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 44.7", "blurb": "The wanderer Vacchagotta asks Moggall\u0101na the ten metaphysical questions, starting with whether the cosmos is eternal. Moggall\u0101na says such questions would only be answered by someone who identifies with the six senses. Vacchagotta then asks the Buddha the same questions.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn44.8", "root_name": "Vacchagottasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 44.8", "blurb": "The wanderer Vacchagotta asks the Buddha the ten metaphysical questions, starting with whether the cosmos is eternal. He says such questions would only be answered by someone who identifies with the five aggregates.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn44.9", "root_name": "Kut\u016bhalas\u0101l\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 44.9", "blurb": "The wanderer Vacchagotta reports to the Buddha a conversation among ascetics on the views of the six heretical teachers as to where a perfected one is reborn. Unsure of what the Buddha\u2019s position was, he asks how it is to be understood. The Buddha says it is like a flame that burns dependent on fuel, and goes out when that fuel is extinguished.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn44.10", "root_name": "\u0100nandasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 44.10", "blurb": "Vacchagotta asks the Buddha whether a self exists, but the Buddha is silent. When \u0100nanda later asks him why he didn\u2019t answer, the Buddha replied that it was to avoid misunderstanding.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn44.11", "root_name": "Sabhiyakacc\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 44.11", "blurb": "The wanderer Vacchagotta asks Venerable Sabhiya Kacca\u0304na whether a Realized One exists after death. He answers that the basis for describing a Realized One no longer applies. Vacchagotta is impressed that such a junior monk understands this subtle matter.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

translated_name: A Hundred Legends of Past Lives
blurb: The “Hundred Stories” is a popular collection of legends, associated with the Sarvāstivādins, and dating to the first centuries CE. A number of manuscript sources for the text are found, but the oldest complete manuscript and the primary source for modern editions is a Nepalese manuscript dated 1645 and held at the Cambridge University Library. While the text is quite late, it contains a few parallels with early texts. The SuttaCentral text is from GRETIL, which was input by Klaus Wille based on the editions by Vaidya (1958) and Speyer (1906, 1909).

[{"uid": "sn35.63", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamamigaj\u0101lasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.63", "blurb": "Venerable Migaj\u0101la asks how one lives alone, and how with a partner. The Buddha says that so long as one is bound by desire to the senses, one lives with a partner. A mendicant free of such desire dwells alone, even if they live in close association with worldly people.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.64", "root_name": "Dutiyamigaj\u0101lasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.64", "blurb": "Venerable Migaj\u0101la asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha teaches him that the senses are delightful, but if you hold to them you will suffer. Meditating on this while on retreat, Migaj\u0101la became awakened.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.65", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamasamiddhim\u0101rapa\u00f1h\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.65", "blurb": "Venerable Samiddhi asks the Buddha what M\u0101ra is. The Buddha says that M\u0101ra is present so long as the senses exist.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.66", "root_name": "Samiddhisattapa\u00f1h\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.66", "blurb": "Venerable Samiddhi asks the Buddha what a \u201csentient being\u201d is. blurb: Twelve poems beginning with a set of similes comparing a liberated one with a serpent who sheds its skin. The poems are diverse in style and content, and appear to have been collected from different sources. This chapter includes many perennial favorites such as the Mettā Sutta on Love and the warnings of the Parābhava Sutta on downfalls.
