blurb: The word khuddaka means “lesser” or “minor”, and it seems that this category originally served to collect certain short collections, mostly verse, that were not conveniently assigned to one of the main nikāyas. Over time, however, the collection grew, so that the Khuddaka in the Pali canon today is the largest of the nikāyas. It includes some of the most popular texts in Theravāda Buddhism, such as the Dhammapada, the Sutta Nipāta, and the Jātakas. There is no closely parallel collection in the other canons, but many of the early texts have parallels in various places.
children: [{"uid": "kp", "root_name": "Khuddakap\u0101\u1e6dha", "translated_name": "Basic Passages ", "acronym": "Kp", "blurb": "Nine short texts, which appear to have been collected as a kind of basic study curriculum for novices. The collection itself was probably made in Sri Lanka, but most of the texts are found elsewhere in the nik\u0101yas.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 34}, {"uid": "dhp", "root_name": "Dhammapada", "translated_name": "Sayings of the Dhamma ", "acronym": "Dhp", "blurb": "The Pali version of this famous text, consisting of 423 verses organized into memorable themes. It is the most widely read of the early texts, and has been translated many times into many languages. Versions of this text are found in Chinese, Tibetan, and several Indic languages, attesting to its timeless, universal appeal.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 123}, {"uid": "ud", "root_name": "Ud\u0101na", "translated_name": "Heartfelt Sayings ", "acronym": "Ud", "blurb": "Eighty short discourses in mixed prose and verse. These take the form of a simple prose narrative, which serves to frame an inspired saying, usually in verse. The ud\u0101na and dhammapada literature appear to overlap, and can be considered as one genre. The Dhammapada verses also have associated narratives, but these are found in the commentary. There are some indications that some of the narratives in the Ud\u0101na may be a little later than most of the material in the four main nik\u0101yas.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 187}, {"uid": "iti", "root_name": "Itivuttaka", "translated_name": "So It Was Said ", "acronym": "Iti", "blurb": "112 short discourses in mixed prose and verse, arranged in the A\u1e45guttara style of ascending numbered sets, from one to four. Alone among Buddhist texts, its survival is attributed not to the Sa\u1e45gha, but to a laywoman named Khujjuttar\u0101. According to the Pali commentaries, she was a maid to the Queen of Kosambi, and memorized these teachings from the Buddha, earning her the title of the most learned of the laywomen disciples.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 235}, {"uid": "snp", "root_name": "Suttanip\u0101ta", "translated_name": "Anthology of Discourses ", "acronym": "Snp", "blurb": "The \u201cGroup of Discourses\u201d contains 74 mostly short texts in verse or mixed prose and verse, arranged in five chapters. This contains some of the most beloved texts in popular Buddhism, such as the Ratana, Ma\u1e45gala, and Mett\u0101 Suttas, which are known to all Theravada Buddhists and recited as uplifting and protective chants at auspicious ceremonies. The collection as a whole is somewhat late; it is not found in northern scriptures, and some portions, such as the opening verses of the N\u0101laka Sutta, belong to the latest strata of the early texts. Nevertheless, certain sections\u2014the \u201cRhinoceros Horn\u201d, the \u201cChapter of the Eights\u201d, and the \u201cWay to the Beyond\u201d\u2014appear to have existed before being gathered into the collection, and are regarded as early. While the collection as a whole has no counterpart elsewhere, several portions have parallels in Chinese or Sanskrit.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 228}, {"uid": "vv", "root_name": "Vim\u0101navatthu", "translated_name": "Stories of Heavenly Mansions ", "acronym": "Vv", "blurb": "The \u201cStories of Celestial Mansions\u201d contains eighty-five stories in verse that illustrate the heavenly rewards of virtuous deeds, especially making offerings to the Buddha or the Sa\u1e45gha. It is a counterpart to the Petavatthu. These verses celebrate the bliss of freedom and the life of meditation, full of proud and joyous proclamations of their spiritual attainments and their gratitude to other nuns as guides and teachers. The Ther\u012bg\u0101th\u0101 is one of the oldest spiritual texts recording only women\u2019s voices. It is a pair with the Therag\u0101th\u0101, the \u201cVerses of the Senior Monks\u201d. Together these collections constitute one of the oldest and largest collections of contemplative literature. Based on style and content, these collections belong to the early discourses. They are referred to on occasion in the northern canons, but no parallel collections have survived.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 188}, {"uid": "tha-ap", "root_name": "Ther\u0101pad\u0101na", "translated_name": "Past Life Legends of the Senior Monks ", "acronym": "Tha Ap", "blurb": "The \u201cLegends of the Senior Monks\u201d contains 563 stories in verse telling the past life deeds of various senior monks. It is a much later counterpart to the Therag\u0101th\u0101, referring to many of the same monks. But whereas the Therag\u0101th\u0101 verses relate the monks\u2019 practice of meditation and mindfulness in this life, the Legends typically relate how they became awakened in this life by making an offering a Buddha in the distant past, and making a dedication to be reborn so as to become awakened in the future. The \u201cLegends of the Senior Monks\u201d has as companion the \u201cLegends of the Senior Nuns\u201d. Both these are late texts, and lack counterparts in the northern canons.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 561}, {"uid": "thi-ap", "root_name": "Ther\u012bapad\u0101na", "translated_name": "Past Life Legends of the Senior Nuns ", "acronym": "Thi Ap", "blurb": "The \u201cLegends of the Senior Nuns\u201d contains 40 stories in verse telling the past life deeds of various senior nuns. It is a much later counterpart to the Ther\u012bg\u0101th\u0101, referring to many of the same nuns. But whereas the Ther\u012bg\u0101th\u0101 verses relate the nuns\u2019 practice of meditation and mindfulness in this life, the Legends typically relate how they became awakened in this life by making an offering a Buddha in the distant past, and making a dedication to be reborn so as to become awakened in the future. The \u201cLegends of the Senior Nuns\u201d has as companion the \u201cLegends of the Senior Monks\u201d. Both these are late texts, and lack counterparts in the northern canons.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 40}, {"uid": "bv", "root_name": "Buddhava\u1e41sa", "translated_name": "Chronicle of the Buddhas ", "acronym": "Bv", "blurb": "The Buddhava\u1e41sa is a late devotional text in verse detailing the lives of 24 past Buddhas and the prediction of the awakening of the historical Buddha Gotama. This is a late text, without direct counterparts in the northern collections. It is, however, part of an extensive pan-sectarian devotional literature composed in the second and first centuries BCE, presaging the birth of the Mah\u0101y\u0101na.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}, {"uid": "cp", "root_name": "Cariy\u0101pi\u1e6daka", "translated_name": "Canon of Conduct ", "acronym": "Cp", "blurb": "The \u201cBasket of Conduct\u201d represents an early systematization of the concept of the Bodhisattva and his path towards awakening. A selection of 34 past lives are told, each one illustrating a specific virtue developed by the Bodhisattva. It is a late text, without direct counterparts in the northern collections. Like the Buddhava\u1e41sa, it is part of an extensive pan-sectarian devotional literature composed in the second and first centuries BCE, presaging the birth of the Mah\u0101y\u0101na.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 55}, {"uid": "ja", "root_name": "J\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Past Life Stories of the Buddha ", "acronym": "Ja", "blurb": "A collection of 547 sets of verses telling stories of the Buddha\u2019s past lives. The canonical Pali collection consists of verses arranged in numbered sets in the A\u1e45guttara fashion. The shorter sets illustrate a high point of a story, while the longer sets tell a complete story. These verses would have been passed down from the beginning with prose narrative to flesh out the story, which in the Pali is now found in the commentary. It is in the commentary that we find the explicit connection between the stories of the past and the present day, identifying the hero of the tale with the bodhisattva and the major protagonists with the Buddha\u2019s contemporaries. This collection is the main source of J\u0101takas, but there are many similar stories found elsewhere in the Pali canon (a few in the four nik\u0101yas, others in the Cariyapi\u1e6daka) and throughout the Chinese, Tibetan, and Sanskrit texts. Most of the J\u0101takas began life as folk tales or myths, drops from the vast ocean of story in oral culture. Several J\u0101takas record versions of famous Hindu myths, while others share a common basis with European folk tales. The verse forms in the J\u0101takas are mostly of the earlier kinds, and the social and political reflect historical realities in the centuries before the Buddha, where, for example, Varanasi was an independent kingdom. The J\u0101takas are the oldest, largest, and best-preserved collection of ancient stories found anywhere in the world. One of the central themes is renunciation, with multiple stories depicting the hero going-forth from the home, each time from a different perspective. J\u0101takas generally illustrate moral messages, but since the hero is supposed to be imperfect, it is not unusual for him to be portrayed as making dubious choices, even breaking precepts. Taken as a whole, the J\u0101taka literature is a vast tapestry of story illustrating the twisting and uncertain path to Awakening. The J\u0101taka genre proved a popular and effective framework for incorporating popular tales into a Buddhist context. They feature prominently in Buddhist art both ancient and modern, and are a primary means of introducing Buddhism to children in modern Therav\u0101da.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 547}, {"uid": "mnd", "root_name": "Mah\u0101niddesa", "translated_name": "Longer Exposition ", "acronym": "Mnd", "blurb": "The Mah\u0101niddesa or \u201cGreat Exposition\u201d is really one half of a book together with the C\u016b\u1e37aniddesa, the \u201cShorter Exposition\u201d. They offer commentaries on certain portions of the Sutta Nip\u0101ta, and lack counterparts in the northern canons. The Mah\u0101niddesa comments on the sixteen poems of the fourth chapter, the \u201cChapter of the Eights\u201d or A\u1e6d\u1e6dhakavagga.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}, {"uid": "cnd", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37aniddesa", "translated_name": "Shorter Exposition ", "acronym": "Cnd", "blurb": "The C\u016b\u1e37aniddesa or \u201cShorter Exposition\u201d is really one half of a book together with the Mah\u0101niddesa or \u201cGreat Exposition\u201d. They offer commentaries on certain portions of the Sutta Nip\u0101ta, and lack counterparts in the northern canons. The C\u016b\u1e37aniddesa comments on the \u201cWay to the Beyond\u201d and the \u201cRhinoceros Horn Sutta\u201d.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}, {"uid": "ps", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6disambhid\u0101magga", "translated_name": "The Path of Discrimination ", "acronym": "Ps", "blurb": "The Pa\u1e6disambhid\u0101magga or \u201cPath of Analytical Discernment\u201d is an advanced critical treatise in thirty chapters on Buddhist practice, which the Pali commentaries attribute to the Buddha\u2019s disciple S\u0101riputta. Departing from the popular or folksy style of most Khuddaka texts, it is more reminiscent of the Abhidhamma, and indeed, while not included in the Abhidhammapi\u1e6daka, it deserves to be considered part of the Therav\u0101din Abhidhamma system. However, it does not make use of the main Abhidhamma m\u0101tik\u0101s. This text introduces a number of terms and ideas of great importance in later Buddhist philosophy. It does not have any counterparts in the northern canons, but articulates a dictinctly Therav\u0101din perspective on the path.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 31}, {"uid": "ne", "root_name": "Netti", "translated_name": "The Guidebook ", "acronym": "Ne", "blurb": "The Netti or \u201cGuide\u201d is a systematic treatise intended to provide a guide for reading and interpreting the texts of the nik\u0101yas. It is similar to the Pe\u1e6dakopadesa, and the exact relationship between these two texts is not clear. The text provides an array of methods for reading texts, illustrating them with quotations, and taking the four noble truths as the overall framework. A colophon in the text attributes it to the Buddha's disciple Kacc\u0101na. It is, however, a late text, lacking counterparts in the northern collections. It is not universally accepted as canonical; SuttaCentral\u2019s Pali texts, however, stem from the Mah\u0101sa\u1e45g\u012bti edition, which as a Burmese text does include it.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 37}, {"uid": "pe", "root_name": "Pe\u1e6dakopadesa", "translated_name": "Interpretation of the Canon ", "acronym": "Pe", "blurb": "The Pe\u1e6dakopadesa or \u201cIllustration of the Baskets\u201d is a systematic treatise intended to provide a guide for reading and interpreting the texts of the nik\u0101yas. It is similar to the Netti, and the exact relationship between these two texts is not clear. The text provides an array of methods for reading texts, illustrating them with quotations, and taking the four noble truths as the overall framework. The Pali text of the Pe\u1e6dakopadesa is quite corrupt, which is unusual in the Pali canon. A colophon in the text attributes it to the Buddha's disciple Kacc\u0101na. It is, however, a late text, lacking counterparts in the northern collections. It is not universally accepted as canonical; SuttaCentral\u2019s Pali texts, however, stem from the Mah\u0101sa\u1e45g\u012bti edition, which as a Burmese text does include it.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 9}, {"uid": "mil", "root_name": "Milindapa\u00f1ha", "translated_name": "Questions of King Milinda ", "acronym": "Mil", "blurb": "The Milindapa\u00f1ha or \u201cQuestions of King Milinda\u201d records a series of discussions on points of Dhamma between the monk N\u0101gasena and the Greek king known as in Pali as Milinda. He is usually identified with Menander I Soter, who ruled an Indo-Greek kingdom from his capital of Sagala around BCE 165\u2013130. While the encounter between Greek and Indian culture is fascinating, the dialogs concern only interpretation of Buddhist ideas, with which the king was evidently very familiar, and does not mention Greek philosophy. The text is lively and dynamic, with the King constantly testing N\u0101gasena with abstruse questions, to which he responds with ingenious arguments and analogies. The text has a shorter Chinese counterpart in the N\u0101gasena Bhik\u1e63u S\u016btra. The text is not Therav\u0101din in origin, but began among one of the schools in the north-west, perhaps the Sarv\u0101stiv\u0101dins. Most of the content, however, is not sectarian in nature. The Pali text has been extended over the years, and in addition, portions appear to be missing. It is not universally accepted as canonical; SuttaCentral\u2019s Pali texts, however, stem from the Mah\u0101sa\u1e45g\u012bti edition, which as a Burmese text does include it.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 320}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Causation” is a major collection containing 93 discourses on the core Buddhist teaching of dependent origination. Dependent origination presents a series of conditional links laying bare how suffering originates and how it ends. As such, it is an extended treatment of the second and third noble truths. It integrates psychological and existential aspects of suffering, showing how when bound by attachment we make choices that bind us to transmigrating into future lives. One of the core purposes is to explain how rebirth takes place without having to invoke metaphysical concepts such as a “soul”. The collection begins by defining each of the terms in the standard 12-linked chain, definitions which are assumed to apply throughout. Remaining discourses iterate on this theme, introducing new perspectives and formulations.

translated_name: The Chapter on Ethics and Duration
children: [{"uid": "sn47.21", "root_name": "S\u012blasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.21", "blurb": "Venerable Bhadda asks \u0100nanda about the ethical virtues encouraged by the Buddha\u2014what is their purpose? To develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.22", "root_name": "Cira\u1e6d\u1e6dhitisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.22", "blurb": "Venerable Bhadda asks \u0100nanda about the conditions under which the true teaching lasts long or does not last long after the Buddha\u2019s passing. \u0100nanda says it depends on whether the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are practiced.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.23", "root_name": "Parih\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.23", "blurb": "Venerable Bhadda asks \u0100nanda about the conditions under which the true teaching declines. \u0100nanda says it depends on whether the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are practiced.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.24", "root_name": "Suddhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.24", "blurb": "A simple teaching on the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.25", "root_name": "A\u00f1\u00f1atarabr\u0101hma\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.25", "blurb": "A brahmin asks the Buddha about the conditions under which the true teaching lasts long or does not last long after the Buddha\u2019s passing. The Buddha says it depends on whether the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are practiced.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.26", "root_name": "Padesasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.26", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta asks Anuruddha what makes someone a trainee. It is someone who has partly developed the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.27", "root_name": "Samattasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.27", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta asks Anuruddha what makes someone an adept. It is someone who has fully developed the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.28", "root_name": "Lokasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.28", "blurb": "Anuruddha claims to have developed the various direct knowledges by practicing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.29", "root_name": "Siriva\u1e0d\u1e0dhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.29", "blurb": "When the householder Siriva\u1e0d\u1e0dha is sick, \u0100nanda visits him and encourages him to practice mindfulness meditation. But he has already developed them, and abandoned the five lower fetters.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.30", "root_name": "M\u0101nadinnasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.30", "blurb": "When the householder M\u0101nadinna is sick, \u0100nanda visits him and encourages him to practice mindfulness meditation. But he has already developed them, and abandoned the five lower fetters.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses with Spirits” contains 12 discourses with verses telling the encounters between the Buddha—or in one case the monk Anuruddha—and various spirits (yakkha). The spirits were local deities worshiped in ancient India, of a lower order than the gods and Brahmās. While in later forms of Buddhism, such spirits were typically depicted as malevolent or dangerous, in the early texts they are more ambivalent, and many of them are friendly, merely asking Dhamma questions, or extolling Dhamma virtues like mindfulness. That’s not to say they couldn’t be scary, and several discourses reveal a more ferocious aspect. Particularly interesting is the emphasis on the love that the female spirits feel for their children.

blurb: Eighty short discourses in mixed prose and verse. These take the form of a simple prose narrative, which serves to frame an inspired saying, usually in verse. The udāna and dhammapada literature appear to overlap, and can be considered as one genre. The Dhammapada verses also have associated narratives, but these are found in the commentary. There are some indications that some of the narratives in the Udāna may be a little later than most of the material in the four main nikāyas.
children: [{"uid": "ud-bodhivagga", "root_name": "Bodhivagga", "translated_name": "The Chapter on Awakening ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "This chapter begins with a series of discourses set immediately after the Buddha\u2019s awakening, which are shared with the first chapter of the Khandhakas. It establishes the fundamental thesis of Buddhism: that awakening is possible through one\u2019s own efforts. Each discourse deals with the idea of the true \u201cbrahmin\u201d, defined not according to hereditary caste, but freedom from defilements.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "Ud 1", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 27}, {"uid": "ud-mucalindavagga", "root_name": "Mucalindavagga", "translated_name": "The Chapter with Mucalinda ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The Buddha\u2019s awakening has shown him a spiritual happiness that is better than any worldly happiness. This chapter focusses on the emotional dimension of enlightenment.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "Ud 2", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 24}, {"uid": "ud-nandavagga", "root_name": "Nandavagga", "translated_name": "The Chapter with Nanda ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The discourses in this chapter focus on equanimity in the face of pleasure and pain. There are several examples of monastic conduct of poise and balance.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "Ud 3", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 23}, {"uid": "ud-meghiyavagga", "root_name": "Meghiyavagga", "translated_name": "The Chapter with Meghiya ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "If a practitioner fails to achieve such balance, their undisciplined mind leads to harming themselves and others.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "Ud 4", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 25}, {"uid": "ud-sonavagga", "root_name": "So\u1e47avagga", "translated_name": "The Chapter with So\u1e47a ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "Broadening the focus from the individual practitioner, this chapter deals with the \u201call\u201d, and shows how the Dhamma is inclusive of all beings, from kings to little fish.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "Ud 5", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 23}, {"uid": "ud-jaccandhavagga", "root_name": "Jaccandhavagga", "translated_name": "The Chapter on Blind From Birth ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "Returning to stories about the Buddha\u2019s life, this chapter skips ahead to near the end. translated_name: Linked Discourses on the Bases of Psychic Power
blurb: The “Linked Discourses on the Bases of Psychic Power” contains 86 discourses dealing with the qualities of enthusiasm or desire for practice, energy, higher consciousness, and inquiry, which are said to lead to the development of various psychic powers. The purpose of Buddhism, of course, is not to develop such powers. But they are a matter of constant interest and intrigue among spiritual practitioners—not just in ancient India—and it seems the Buddha formulated this approach to the path to inspire those interested in them. The emphasis is on the development of deep meditation immersion (samādhi) through applying effort.

blurb: A number of Buddhist manuscripts in the Gāndhārī language, using the Kharoṣṭhī script and identified as Dharmaguptaka, have been discovered in eastern Afghanistan and western Pakistan. These include a range of texts, among which are substantial portions of early suttas. Digital work in this field is primarliy carried out by Gandhari.org.

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on the Faculties” contains 178 discourses on various sets of “faculties” (indriya). The “five faculties” of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom are the most natural fit in this context. However the chapter also finds room for discourses on a wider range of 22 faculties, including the six sense faculties, five affective faculties (kinds of feeling), three faculties relating the process of enlightenment, and three concerning biology and gender. This flexible category thus serves as a link between the teachings on wisdom and those on the path.

[{"uid": "ja511", "root_name": "Ki\u1e41chandaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "What Is Your Desire? ", "acronym": "Ja 511", "blurb": "\u201cWhy dost thou\u201d\u2014This story the Master told, while dwelling at Jetavana, about the observance of fast-days.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja512", "root_name": "Kumbhaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Sin Within the Cup ", "acronym": "Ja 512", "blurb": "\u201cWho art thou\u201d\u2014This story the Master, while dwelling at Jetavana, told concerning five hundred women, friends of Visakha, who were drinkers of strong drink.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja513", "root_name": "Jayaddisaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Prince Victor ", "acronym": "Ja 513", "blurb": "\u201cLo! after\u201d\u2014This story the Master told of a Brother who supported his mother. The introductory story is like that told in the Sama Birth. But on this occasion the Master said, \u201cSages of old gave up the white umbrella with its golden wreath to support their parents,\u201d and with these words he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja514", "root_name": "Chaddantaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Six-Tusked Elephant ", "acronym": "Ja 514", "blurb": "\u201cLarge-eyed and peerless one\u201d\u2014This was a story the Master, while sojourning at Jetavana, told of a female novice.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja515", "root_name": "Sambhavaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Wise Boy Sambhava ", "acronym": "Ja 515", "blurb": "\u201cThis rule\u201d\u2014This story the Master when residing at Jetavana told concerning the Perfection of Wisdom. The circumstances leading to the introductory story will be set forth in the Mahaummagga Birth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja516", "root_name": "Mah\u0101kapij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Monkey Betrayed ", "acronym": "Ja 516", "blurb": "\u201cA king of Kasi\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master, when dwelling in the Bamboo Grove, about Devadatta\u2019s hurling a stone at him. So when the Brethren blamed Devadatta for having suborned archers to shoot the Buddha and afterwards hurled a stone at him, the Master said, \u201cNot now only, but formerly also, Devadatta flung a stone at me,\u201d and so saying he related a story of the past. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja517", "root_name": "Dakarakkhasaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Daka the Ogre ", "acronym": "Ja 517", "blurb": "All of this will be set forth in the Mahaummagga Birth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja518", "root_name": "Pa\u1e47\u1e0daran\u0101gar\u0101jaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Dragon-King Pa\u1e47\u1e0dara ", "acronym": "Ja 518", "blurb": "\u201cNo man that lets\u201d\u2014This was a story told by the Master, whilst sojourning at Jetavana, as to how Devadatta told a lie, and how the earth opened and swallowed him up. At that time, when Devadatta was being blamed by the Brethren, the Master said, \u201cNot now only, Brethren, but of old too Devadatta told a lie and was swallowed up by the earth,\u201d and so saying he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja519", "root_name": "Sambul\u0101j\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Queen Sambul\u0101 ", "acronym": "Ja 519", "blurb": "\u201cTied to the spot\u201d\u2014This story the Master, while dwelling at Jetavana, told of queen Mallika. The introductory story is related at length in the Kummasapinda Birth. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja520", "root_name": "Gandhatindukaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Fragrant Pale-moon Ebony Tree ", "acronym": "Ja 520", "blurb": "\u201cZeal is the way\u201d\u2014This story the Master, dwelling at Jetavana, told concerning the admonition of a king. This admonition of a king has already been related in full.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "ja396", "root_name": "Kukkuj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Half a Yard ", "acronym": "Ja 396", "blurb": "\u201cThe peak\u2019s a cubit,\u201d etc\u2014The Master told this while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning the admonition of a king. The occasion will appear in the Tesakuna-Birth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja397", "root_name": "Manojaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Manoja the Lion Cub who Befriended a Jackal ", "acronym": "Ja 397", "blurb": "\u201cThe bow is bent\u201d\u2014The Master told this while dwelling in the Bamboo Grove, concerning a Brother who kept bad company. The occasion was given at length in the Mahilamukhata Birth. The Master said, \u201cBrethren, he is not keeping bad company for the first time,\u201d and told an old tale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja398", "root_name": "Sutanuj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Young Man Sutan\u016b ", "acronym": "Ja 398", "blurb": "\u201cThe King has sent\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning a Brother who supported his mother. The occasion will appear in the Sama Birth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja399", "root_name": "M\u0101tuposakagijjhaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Vulture Who Cared for His Parents ", "acronym": "Ja 399", "blurb": "\u201cHow will the old folks\u201d\u2014The Master told this when dwelling in Jetavana, concerning a Brother who supported his mother.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja400", "root_name": "Dabbhapupphaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Grey-Grass the Jackal ", "acronym": "Ja 400", "blurb": "\u201cFriend Anutiracari\u201d\u2014The Master told this while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning Upananda, of the Sakya tribe. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja401", "root_name": "Pa\u1e47\u1e47akaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Sword-Swallower ", "acronym": "Ja 401", "blurb": "\u201cDasanna\u2019s good sword\u201d\u2014The Master told this, when living in Jetavana, concerning the temptation of a Brother by his wife when a layman. The Brother confessed that he was backsliding for this reason. The Master said, \u201cThat woman does you harm: formerly too you were dying of mental sickness owing to her, and got life owing to wise men,\u201d and so he told a tale of old.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja402", "root_name": "Sattubhastaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Sack of Flour ", "acronym": "Ja 402", "blurb": "\u201cThou art confused\u201d\u2014The Master told this when staying in Jetavana, concerning the Perfection of Wisdom. The occasion of the story will appear in the Ummagga-Birth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja403", "root_name": "A\u1e6d\u1e6dhisenakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Ascetic Atthisena ", "acronym": "Ja 403", "blurb": "\u201cAtthisena, many beggars\u201d\u2014The Master told this when dwelling in the shrine called Aggalava near Alavi, concerning the regulations for the building of cells. The occasion was told in the Manikantha Birth above. The Master addressed the Brethren, saying, \u201cBrethren, formerly before Buddha was born in the world, priests of other religions, even though offered their choice by kings, never asked for alms, holding that begging from others was not agreeable or pleasant,\u201d and so he told the tale of old time.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja404", "root_name": "Kapij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Monkey ", "acronym": "Ja 404", "blurb": "\u201cLet not the wise man\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning Devadatta being swallowed up by the earth. Finding that the Brethren were talking about this in the Hall of Truth, he said, \u201cDevadatta has not been destroyed with his company now for the first time: he was destroyed before,\u201d and he told an old tale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja405", "root_name": "Bakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Crane ", "acronym": "Ja 405", "blurb": "\u201cSeventy and two\u201d\u2014The Master told this tale while dwelling in Jetavana, concerning the brahma Baka. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: 72 middle-length discourses that in the Taishō edition of the Chinese canon have been gathered in the first volume, at sūtra numbers 27–98, following the Madhyamāgama. These are miscellaneous translations of various discourses from the Majjhima, made at various times by various translators.

blurb: The Middle Discourses (Majjhima Nikāya, abbreviated MN) is a collection of 152 discourses in the Pali canon (Tipiṭaka) of the Theravada school of Buddhism. The word “middle” refers to the length of the individual discourses. This is perhaps the most popular collection of early discourses. It contains a wide variety of teachings, many of them presented as narratives between the Buddha and a diverse range of his contemporaries. The collection parallels the Madhyamāgama (MA) of the Sarvāstivāda school, which survives as a translation in the Chinese canon.

translated_name: The Chapter on the Garden of Delight
children: [{"uid": "sn1.11", "root_name": "Nandanasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 1.11", "blurb": "Even the divine Garden of Delight is impermanent.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn1.12", "root_name": "Nandatisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 1.12", "blurb": "We think our attachments bring us happiness, but they really bring sorrow.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn1.13", "root_name": "Natthiputtasamasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 1.13", "blurb": "Like many of these discourses, here the Buddha repeats a god\u2019s verses with a subtle twist towards the Dhamma.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn1.14", "root_name": "Khattiyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 1.14", "blurb": "A god\u2019s worldly values are improved by the Buddha\u2019s version.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn1.15", "root_name": "Sa\u1e47am\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 1.15", "blurb": "The quiet murmuring of the jungle can be scary\u2014but not to the Buddha.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn1.16", "root_name": "Nidd\u0101tand\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 1.16", "blurb": "Laziness is an obstruction to the path.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn1.17", "root_name": "Dukkarasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 1.17", "blurb": "Life is hard for an unrestrained ascetic; they should draw in their thoughts like a tortoise.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn1.18", "root_name": "Hir\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 1.18", "blurb": "Does anyone have a sense of conscience and shame?", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn1.19", "root_name": "Ku\u1e6dik\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 1.19", "blurb": "Do you have a little hut and a little nest\u2014or are you free?", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn1.20", "root_name": "Samiddhisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 1.20", "blurb": "A deity tries to tempt a monk to first enjoy sensual pleasures and then go forth. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

translated_name: The Chapter on the Six Faculties
children: [{"uid": "sn48.21", "root_name": "Punabbhavasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.21", "blurb": "The Buddha did not claim to be awakened until he realized the five faculties.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.22", "root_name": "J\u012bvitindriyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.22", "blurb": "Three faculties: femininity, masculinity, and vitality.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.23", "root_name": "A\u00f1\u00f1indriyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.23", "blurb": "Three faculties relating to stages in the realization of awakening.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.24", "root_name": "Ekab\u012bj\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.24", "blurb": "Depending on the strength of the five faculties, one is perfected, or reaches a lesser attainment.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.25", "root_name": "Suddhakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.25", "blurb": "Six faculties: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.26", "root_name": "Sot\u0101pannasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.26", "blurb": "Six faculties: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind. One who understand these is a stream-enterer.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.27", "root_name": "Arahantasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.27", "blurb": "Six faculties: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind. One who is freed by understanding these is perfected.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.28", "root_name": "Sambuddhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.28", "blurb": "The Buddha did not claim to be awakened until he realized the origin, the passing, the gratification, the drawback, and the escape regarding the six faculties.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.29", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamasama\u1e47abr\u0101hma\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.29", "blurb": "A true ascetic understands the six faculties in terms of gratification, drawback, and escape.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.30", "root_name": "Dutiyasama\u1e47abr\u0101hma\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.30", "blurb": "A true ascetic understands the six faculties in terms of the four noble truths.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

These include a range of texts, among which are substantial portions of early suttas. Digital work in this field is primarliy carried out by Gandhari.org.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pgd", "root_lang_name": "G\u0101ndh\u0101r\u012b", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}, {"uid": "kf", "root_name": "Khotanese fragments", "translated_name": "Manuscript Fragments in Khotanese ", "acronym": "KF", "blurb": "Fragments of a Khotanese Karmavibha\u1e45ga text published by Maggi (1995).", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "kho", "root_lang_name": "Khotanese", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}, {"uid": "pf", "root_name": "Pr\u0101krit fragments", "translated_name": "Manuscript Fragments in Pr\u0101krit ", "acronym": "PF", "blurb": "Fragments of a parallel to the P\u0101y\u0101si Sutta in Pr\u0101krit, as identified in Boll\u00e9e (2002).", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pra", "root_lang_name": "Pr\u0101krit", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}, {"uid": "tf", "root_name": "Tocharian fragments", "translated_name": "Manuscript Fragments in Tocharian ", "acronym": "TF", "blurb": "Fragments in Tocharian A. [{"uid": "ja131", "root_name": "Asampad\u0101naj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Refusing a Gift ", "acronym": "Ja 131", "blurb": "\u201cIf a friend.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at the Bamboo-grove, about Devadatta. For at that time the Brethren were discussing in the Hall of Truth the ingratitude of Devadatta and his inability to recognise the Master\u2019s goodness, when the Master himself entered and on enquiry was told the subject of their talk. \u201cBrethren,\u201d said he, \u201cthis is not the first time that Devadatta has been ungrateful; he was just as ungrateful in bygone days.\u201d So saying, he told this story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja132", "root_name": "Bh\u012brukaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Unshaken ", "acronym": "Ja 132", "blurb": "\u201cWise counsels heeding.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about the Sutta concerning the Temptation by the Daughters of Mara at the Goat-herds\u2019 Banyan-tree. The Master quoted the Sutta, beginning with its opening words\u2014", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja133", "root_name": "Ghat\u0101sanaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Like a Fire Consuming Ghee ", "acronym": "Ja 133", "blurb": "\u201cLo! in your stronghold.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a certain Brother who was given by the Master a subject for meditation, and, going to the borders, took up his abode in the forest near a hamlet.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja134", "root_name": "Jh\u0101nasodhanaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Purification of Absorption ", "acronym": "Ja 134", "blurb": "\u201cWith conscious.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about the interpretation by Sariputta, Captain of the Faith, at the gate of Samkassa town, of a problem tersely propounded by the Master. And the following was the story of the past he then told.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja135", "root_name": "Cand\u0101bhaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Moonshine ", "acronym": "Ja 135", "blurb": "\u201cWho sagely meditates.\u201d\u2014This story too was told by the Master while at Jetavana about the interpretation of a problem by the Elder Sariputta at the gate of Samkassa.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja136", "root_name": "Suva\u1e47\u1e47aha\u1e41saj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Golden Goose ", "acronym": "Ja 136", "blurb": "\u201cContented be.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master about a Sister named Fat Nanda.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja137", "root_name": "Babbuj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Hungry Cat ", "acronym": "Ja 137", "blurb": "\u201cGive food to one cat.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about the precept respecting Kana\u2019s mother.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja138", "root_name": "Godhaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Lizard ", "acronym": "Ja 138", "blurb": "\u201cWith matted hair.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the boaster while at Jetavana, about a hypocrite. The incidents were like those above related.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja139", "root_name": "Ubhatobha\u1e6d\u1e6dhaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "A Twofold Failure ", "acronym": "Ja 139", "blurb": "\u201cHis blinding and her beating.\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while at the Bamboo Grove, about Devadatta. We hear that the Brethren, meeting together in the Hall of Truth, spoke one with another, saying that even as a torch from a pyre, charred at both ends and bedunged in the middle, does not serve as wood either in forest-tree or village-hearth, so Devadatta by giving up the world to follow this saving faith had only achieved a twofold shortcoming and failure, seeing that he had missed the comforts of a-lay life yet had fallen short of his vocation as a Brother.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja140", "root_name": "K\u0101kaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Crow ", "acronym": "Ja 140", "blurb": "\u201cIn ceaseless dread.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a sagacious counsellor. The incidents will be related in the twelfth book in connection with the Bhaddasala-jataka.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

translated_name: Linked Discourses on the Awakening Factors
blurb: The “Linked Discourses on the Awakening Factors” contains 184 discourses on the seven awakening factors. These are qualities such as mindfulness and investigation which lead the meditator to awakening. The focus here is specifically on meditation, rather than the more holistic approach included in the previous chapter on the Path. Some distinctive features of this collection include the use recitation of the awakening factors in order to inspire those who are sick, and the frequent contrast between the seven awakening factors and the five hindrances.

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Breath Meditation” contains 20 discourses on breath meditation (ānāpānassati), the most revered form of meditation from early Buddhism until the present day. It was practiced by the Buddha himself. The meditation is taught in a detailed series of sixteen steps. These are partially sequential, but also overlap in some cases. The development of these fulfills all four kinds of mindfulness meditation and the seven factors of awakening. Thus this one form of meditation can lead to awakening; which is not, however, to say that it is invariably the best approach. The Buddha taught many different meditations for a reason; each has its own qualities and benefits. Breath meditation is seen as a peaceful and pleasant meditation which helps still distracting thoughts. It is a simple practice broadly suitable for most meditators, but leading to profound depths.

[{"uid": "sn48.41", "root_name": "Jar\u0101dhammasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.41", "blurb": "When \u0100nanda sees the Buddha\u2019s sense faculties fading, the Buddha speaks on the decrepitude of old age, including verses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.42", "root_name": "U\u1e47\u1e47\u0101bhabr\u0101hma\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.42", "blurb": "The brahmin U\u1e47\u1e47\u0101bha points out that the five physical sense faculties do not share a common domain, so where do they come together? In the mind. U\u1e47\u1e47\u0101bha pursues the teaching all the way to Nibb\u0101na.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.43", "root_name": "S\u0101ketasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.43", "blurb": "The Buddha discusses the five faculties and the five powers. They are like a river that flows around a central island. From one point of view they can be considered different, but from another they are just the same stream.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": blurb: The Lalitavistara or “Play in Extenso” was one of the most popular of the ancient lives of the Buddha. Based on Sarvāstivādin and Mahāyāna sources, numerous manuscripts from Nepal survive. The text is a compilation from multiple sources, dating around the fourth centry CE, but including a few parallels to early texts. The SuttaCentral text is from GRETIL, based on the edition by Vaidya (1958).

blurb: The “Linked Discourses with Vaṅgīsa” contains 12 discourses with verses spoken by Vaṅgīsa, the most renowned poet of early Buddhism. His verses have a sophistication and personal vulnerability that stamp them as perhaps the most distinctive literary voice of the early texts. Several of these discourses speak of his insecurities and struggles, and how he was helped to overcome them. Others speak from his joyous devotion to the Buddha and the Saṅgha, and of his final triumph.

[{"uid": "sn21.1", "root_name": "Kolitasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 21.1", "blurb": "Moggall\u0101na reflects that second absorption is the true noble silence, and the Buddha encourages him to develop it.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn21.2", "root_name": "Upatissasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 21.2", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta says that not even if the Buddha changed would it cause him sorrow.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn21.3", "root_name": "Gha\u1e6dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 21.3", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta and Moggall\u0101na come together for a discussion, which touches on the use of psychic powers and energy. The two great monks end up warmly praising each other.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn21.4", "root_name": "Navasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 21.4", "blurb": "When a certain monk neglects his duties in favor of solitude, other monks complain. The Buddha questions him, and finds that he is awakened.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn21.5", "root_name": "Suj\u0101tasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 21.5", "blurb": "The Buddha praises Venerable Suj\u0101ta as beautiful both inside and out.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn21.6", "root_name": "Laku\u1e47\u1e0dakabhaddiyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 21.6", "blurb": "Venerable Laku\u1e47\u1e6daka Bhaddiya is a dwarf, considered to be ugly and unsightly. The Buddha warns the monks not to despise him as he had realized full awakening.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn21.7", "root_name": "Vis\u0101khasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 21.7", "blurb": "The Buddha praises Venerable Vis\u0101kha Pa\u00f1c\u0101liputta for teaching the Dhamma.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn21.8", "root_name": "Nandasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 21.8", "blurb": "Venerable Nanda wore pretty robes, a fancy bowl, and makeup, so the Buddha encouraged him to embrace simplicity. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn21.9", "root_name": "Tissasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 21.9", "blurb": "Venerable Tissa admonished others but got upset when he was admonished. "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an4.29", "root_name": "Dhammapadasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.29", "blurb": "Contentment, good will, mindfulness and convergence are basic principles.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, [{"uid": "sn48.11", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dil\u0101bhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.11", "blurb": "The Buddha explains the five faculties in terms of how they are obtained.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.12", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamasa\u1e41khittasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.12", "blurb": "One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.13", "root_name": "Dutiyasa\u1e41khittasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.13", "blurb": "One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments. A difference in faculties leads to a difference in fruits.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.14", "root_name": "Tatiyasa\u1e41khittasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.14", "blurb": "One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments. The faculties are not barren.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.15", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamavitth\u0101rasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.15", "blurb": "One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.16", "root_name": "Dutiyavitth\u0101rasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.16", "blurb": "One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments. A difference in faculties leads to a difference in fruits.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.17", "root_name": "Tatiyavitth\u0101rasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.17", "blurb": "One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments. The faculties are not barren.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.18", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dipannasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.18", "blurb": "One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments. One who has none of them at all is an outsider.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.19", "root_name": "Sampannasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.19", "blurb": "Someone who develops the faculties is said to be equipped with faculties.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn48.20", "root_name": "\u0100savakkhayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 48.20", "blurb": "The five faculties lead to the ending of defilements in this very life.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "sn22.53", "root_name": "Upayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.53", "blurb": "Consciousness stands dependent on the other four aggregates, and this attachment is what fuels the cycle of rebirth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.54", "root_name": "B\u012bjasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.54", "blurb": "Consciousness is like a seed that is planted in the soil of the other four aggregates and watered with craving.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.55", "root_name": "Ud\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.55", "blurb": "The Buddha utters an enigmatic saying that non-identification leads to cutting off the fetters. A mendicant asks how to achieve this.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.56", "root_name": "Up\u0101d\u0101naparipavattasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.56", "blurb": "The Buddha did not claim to be awakened until he had fully understood each of the five aggregates in the light of each of the four noble truths. This discourse includes definitions of each of the aggregates.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.57", "root_name": "Satta\u1e6d\u1e6dh\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.57", "blurb": "To be fully accomplished, a mendicant should investigate the five aggregates in light of the four noble truths, as well as their gratification, drawback, and escape. In addition, they should investigate the elements, sense fields, and dependent origination.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.58", "root_name": "Samm\u0101sambuddhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.58", "blurb": "The Buddha declares that a mendicant is freed by wisdom by non-attachment to the aggregates, in just the same way as he himself. He then explains that the difference between himself and another awakened mendicant is simply that he was the first to discover the path and teach it to others.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.59", "root_name": "Anattalakkha\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.59", "blurb": "In the Deer Park at Varanasi the Buddha teaches the famous second discourse, on not-self with regard to the aggregates, to the group of five monks. At the conclusion, they become perfected ones.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.60", "root_name": "Mah\u0101lisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.60", "blurb": "Mah\u0101li the Licchavi reports to the Buddha that the rival teacher P\u016bra\u1e47a Kassapa asserts that there is no reason for beings to be either defiled or pure. The Buddha denies this, and goes on to explain how it happens.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.61", "root_name": "\u0100dittasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.61", "blurb": "The five aggregates are burning.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.62", "root_name": "Niruttipathasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.62", "blurb": "All philosophers must accept that the five aggregates are described in language that refers to either the past, future, or present.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]
