[{"uid": "ja71", "root_name": "Varu\u1e47aj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Temple Tree ", "acronym": "Ja 71", "blurb": "\u201cLearn thou from him.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about the Elder named Tissa the Squire\u2019s Son. Tradition says that one day thirty young gentlemen of Savatthi, who were all friends of one another, took perfumes and flowers and robes, and set out with a large retinue to Jetavana, in order to hear the Master preach. Arrived at Jetavana, they sat awhile in the several enclosures\u2014in the enclosure of the Iron-wood trees, in the enclosure of the Sal-trees, and so forth,\u2014till at evening the Master passed from his fragrant sweet-smelling perfumed chamber to the Hall of Truth and took his seat on the gorgeous Buddha-seat. Then, with their following, these young men went to the Hall of Truth, made an offering of perfumes and flowers, bowed down at his feet\u2014those blessed feet that were glorious as full-blown lotus-flowers, and bore imprinted on the sole the Wheel!\u2014and, taking their seats, listened to the Truth. Then the thought came into their minds, \u201cLet us take the vows, so far as we understand the Truth preached by the Master.\u201d Accordingly, when the Blessed One left the Hall, they approached him and with due obeisance asked to be admitted to the Brotherhood; and the Master admitted them to the Brotherhood. Winning the favour of their teachers and directors they received full Brotherhood, and after five years\u2019 residence with their teachers and directors, by which time they had got by heart the two Abstracts, had come to know what was proper and what was improper, had learnt the three modes of expressing thanks, and had stitched and dyed robes. At this stage, wishing to embrace the ascetic life, they obtained the consent of their teachers and directors, and approached the Master. Bowing before him they took their seats, saying, \u201cSir, we are troubled by the round of existence, dismayed by birth, decay, disease, and death; give us a theme, by thinking on which we may get free from the elements which occasion existence.\u201d The Master turned over in his mind the eight and thirty themes of thought, and therefrom selected a suitable one, which he expounded to them. And then, after getting their theme from the Master, they bowed and with a ceremonious farewell passed from his presence to their cells, and after gazing on their teachers and directors went forth with bowl and robe to embrace the ascetic life.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja72", "root_name": "S\u012blavahatthij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Virtuous Elephant King ", "acronym": "Ja 72", "blurb": "\u201cIngratitude lacks more.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at the Bamboo-grove about Devadatta. The Brethren sat in the Hall of Truth, saying, \u201cSirs, Devadatta is an ingrate and does not recognise the virtues of the Blessed One.\u201d Returning to the Hall, the Master asked what topic they were discussing, and was told. \u201cThis is not the first time, Brethren,\u201d said he, \u201cthat Devadatta has proved an ingrate; he was just the same in bygone days also, and he has never known my virtues.\u201d And so saying, at their request he told this story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja73", "root_name": "Sacca\u1e41kiraj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "It Seems They Knew the Truth ", "acronym": "Ja 73", "blurb": "\u201cThey knew the world.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at the Bamboo-grove, about going about to kill. For, seated in the Hall of Truth, the Brotherhood was talking of Devadatta\u2019s wickedness, saying, \u201cSirs, Devadatta has no knowledge of the Master\u2019s excellence; he actually goes about to kill him!\u201d Here the Master entered the Hall and asked what they were discussing. 323] Being told, he said, \u201cThis is not the first time, Brethren, that Devadatta has gone about to kill me; he did just the same in bygone days also.\u201d And so saying, he told this story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja74", "root_name": "Rukkhadhammaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Lesson of the Tree ", "acronym": "Ja 74", "blurb": "\u201cUnited, forest-like.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a quarrel concerning water which had brought woe upon his kinsfolk. Knowing of this, he passed through the air, sat cross-legged above the river Rohini, and emitted rays of darkness, startling his kinsfolk. Then descending from mid-air, he seated himself on the river-bank and told this story with reference to that quarrel. (Only a summary is given here; the full details will be related in the Kunala-jataka.) But on this occasion the Master addressed his kinsfolk, saying, \u201cIt is meet, sire, that kinsfolk should dwell together in concord and unity. For, when kinsfolk are at one, enemies find no opportunity. Not to speak of human beings, even sense-lacking trees ought to stand together. For in bygone days in the Himalayas a tempest struck a Sal-forest; yet, because the trees, shrubs, bushes, and creepers of that forest were interlaced one with another, the tempest could not overthrow even a single tree but passed harmlessly over their heads. But alone in a courtyard stood a mighty tree; and though it had many stems and branches, yet, because it was not united with other trees, the tempest uprooted it and laid it low. Wherefore, it is meet that you too should dwell together in concord and unity.\u201d And so saying, at their request he told this story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja75", "root_name": "Macchaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Fish ", "acronym": "Ja 75", "blurb": "\u201cPajjunna, thunder!\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while at Jetavana, about the rain he caused to fall. For in those days, so it is said, there fell no rain in Kosala; the crops withered; and everywhere the ponds, tanks, and lakes dried up. Even the pool of Jetavana by the embattled gateway of Jetavana gave out; and the fish and tortoises buried themselves in the mud. Then came the crows and hawks with their lance-like beaks, and busily picked them out writhing and wriggling, and devoured them.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja76", "root_name": "Asa\u1e41kiyaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Fearlessness ", "acronym": "Ja 76", "blurb": "\u201cThe village breeds no fear in me.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a lay-brother who lived at Savatthi. Tradition says that this man, who had entered the Paths and was an earnest believer, was once journeying along on some business or other in the company of a leader of a caravan; in the jungle the carts were unyoked and a laager was constructed; and the good man began to pace up and down at the foot of a certain tree hard by the leader.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja77", "root_name": "Mah\u0101supinaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Great Dreams ", "acronym": "Ja 77", "blurb": "\u201cBulls first, and trees.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about sixteen wonderful dreams. For in the last watch of one night (so tradition says) the King of Kosala, who had been asleep all the night, dreamed sixteen great dreams, and woke up in great fright and alarm as to what they might portend for him. So strong was the fear of death upon him that he could not stir, but lay there huddled up on his bed. Now, when the night grew light, his brahmins and chaplains came to him and with due obeisance asked whether his majesty had slept well.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja78", "root_name": "Illisaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Two Illisas ", "acronym": "Ja 78", "blurb": "\u201cBoth squint.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a miserly Lord High Treasurer. Hard by the city of Rajagaha, as we are told, was a town named Jagghery, and here dwelt a certain Lord High Treasurer, known as the Millionaire Miser, who was worth eighty crores! Not so much as the tiniest drop of oil that a blade of grass will take up, did he either give away or consume for his own enjoyment. So he made no use of all his wealth either for his family or for sages and brahmins: it remained unenjoyed,\u2014like a pool haunted by demons. Now, it fell out on a day that the Master arose at dawn moved with a great compassion, and as he reviewed those ripe for conversion throughout the universe, he became aware that this Treasurer with his wife some four hundred miles away were destined to tread the Paths of Salvation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja79", "root_name": "Kharassaraj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "A Harsh Drum ", "acronym": "Ja 79", "blurb": "\u201cHe gave the robbers time.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a certain Minister. He, \u2019Tis said, ingratiated himself with the king, and, after collecting the royal revenue in a border-village, privily arranged with a band of robbers that he would march the men off into the jungle, leaving the village for the rascals to plunder,\u2014on condition that they gave him half the booty. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja80", "root_name": "Bh\u012bmasenaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Weaver Bh\u012bmasena ", "acronym": "Ja 80", "blurb": "\u201cYou vaunted your prowess.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a certain braggart among the Brethren. Tradition says that he used to gather round him Brethren of all ages, and go about deluding everyone with lying boasts about his noble descent. \u201cAh, Brethren,\u201d he would say, \u201cthere\u2019s no family so noble as mine, no lineage so peerless. I am a scion of the highest of princely lines; no man is my equal in birth or ancestral estate; there is absolutely no end to the gold and silver and other treasures we possess. Our very slaves and menials are fed on rice and meat-stews, and are clad in the best Benares cloth, with the choicest Benares perfumes to perfume themselves withal; whilst I, because I have joined the Brotherhood, [3561 have to content myself with this vile fare and this vile garb.\u201d", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

translated_name: The Chapter of Abbreviated Texts on Followers of Other Paths
children: [{"uid": "sn45.41", "root_name": "R\u0101gavir\u0101gasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 45.41", "blurb": "If others ask why you follow the spiritual path, say it\u2019s for the fading away of lust.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn45.42-47", "root_name": "Sa\u1e41yojanappah\u0101n\u0101disuttachakka", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 45.42\u201347", "blurb": "If others ask why you follow the spiritual path, say it\u2019s for giving up fetters, etc.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn45.48", "root_name": "Anup\u0101d\u0101parinibb\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 45.48", "blurb": "If others ask why you follow the spiritual path, say it\u2019s for final extinguishment without anything left over.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

[{"uid": "an8.41", "root_name": "Sa\u1e41khitt\u016bposathasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.41", "blurb": "When the sabbath is observed by following the eight precepts, one lives for that day like the perfected ones. Such a sabbath is glorious.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an8.42", "root_name": "Vitthat\u016bposathasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.42", "blurb": "When the sabbath is observed by following the eight precepts, one lives for that day like the perfected ones. The benefits are explained at length.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an8.43", "root_name": "Vis\u0101kh\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.43", "blurb": "The Buddha teaches the wealthy laywoman Vis\u0101kh\u0101 that when the sabbath is observed by following the eight precepts, one lives for that day like the perfected ones.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an8.44", "root_name": "V\u0101se\u1e6d\u1e6dhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.44", "blurb": "The Buddha teaches the layman V\u0101se\u1e6d\u1e6dha that when the sabbath is observed by following the eight precepts, one lives for that day like the perfected ones. V\u0101se\u1e6d\u1e6dha exclaims that such a practice would be widely beneficial.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an8.45", "root_name": "Bojjhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.45", "blurb": "The Buddha teaches the laywoman Bojjh\u0101 that when the sabbath is observed by following the eight precepts, one lives for that day like the perfected ones. Bojjh\u0101 exclaims that such a practice would be widely beneficial.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an8.46", "root_name": "Anuruddhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.46", "blurb": "Some \u201cAgreeable\u201d gods put on a display of music and dance for Venerable Anuruddha, but he is not impressed. He then asks the Buddha how women are reborn in such a heaven.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an8.47", "root_name": "Dutiyavis\u0101kh\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.47", "blurb": "The Buddha teaches the laywoman Vis\u0101kh\u0101 eight qualities through which a woman may be reborn among the Agreeable gods.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an8.48", "root_name": "Nakulam\u0101t\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.48", "blurb": "The Buddha teaches the housewife Nakulam\u0101t\u0101 eight qualities through which a woman may be reborn among the Agreeable gods.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an8.49", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamaidhalokikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.49", "blurb": "The Buddha teaches the laywoman Vis\u0101kh\u0101 four qualities through which a woman succeeds in this life, and four through which she succeeds in the next.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an8.50", "root_name": "Dutiyaidhalokikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.50", "blurb": "The Buddha teaches the mendicants four qualities through which a woman succeeds in this life, and four through which she succeeds in the next.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

[{"uid": "sn35.228", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamasamuddasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.228", "blurb": "In the Buddha\u2019s teaching the \u201cocean\u201d is the sense organs, the current is the sense objects.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.229", "root_name": "Dutiyasamuddasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.229", "blurb": "In the Buddha\u2019s teaching the \u201cocean\u201d is the delights of sense stimuli.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.230", "root_name": "B\u0101\u1e37isikopamasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.230", "blurb": "Sense pleasures are like a baited hook.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.231", "root_name": "Kh\u012brarukkhopamasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.231", "blurb": "Like a tree that yields sap when cut, so long as desire is present it will be activated by the senses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.232", "root_name": "Ko\u1e6d\u1e6dhikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.232", "blurb": "Maha\u0304ko\u1e6d\u1e6dhita asks S\u0101riputta whether the interior and exterior sense fields are the fetters of each other. No; it is desire that is the fetter, like the yoke that binds two oxen. One with no desire still experiences the senses but without fetters.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.233", "root_name": "K\u0101mabh\u016bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.233", "blurb": "Ka\u0304mabhu\u0304 asks \u0100nanda whether the interior and exterior sense fields are the fetters of each other. No; it is desire that is the fetter. One with no desire still experiences the senses but without fetters.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.234", "root_name": "Ud\u0101y\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.234", "blurb": "Uda\u0304y\u0131\u0304 notes to \u0100nanda that the Buddha has taught the body as not-self; what then of consciousness? \u0100nanda then explains how consciousness arises dependent on conditions.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.235", "root_name": "\u0100dittapariy\u0101yasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.235", "blurb": "It would be better for the sense organs to be pierced with red-hot spikes than to get attached to a pleasant sense experience.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.236", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamahatthap\u0101dopamasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.236", "blurb": "So long as this body exists there is suffering due to the senses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.237", "root_name": "Dutiyahatthap\u0101dopamasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.237", "blurb": "So long as this body exists there is suffering due to the senses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: Collections of sutta texts outside the four main collections.
children: [{"uid": "kn", "root_name": "Khuddakanik\u0101ya", "translated_name": "Minor Collection ", "acronym": "KN", "blurb": "The word khuddaka means \u201clesser\u201d or \u201cminor\u201d, and it seems that this category originally served to collect certain short collections, mostly verse, that were not conveniently assigned to one of the main nik\u0101yas. Over time, however, the collection grew, so that the Khuddaka in the Pali canon today is the largest of the nik\u0101yas. It includes some of the most popular texts in Therav\u0101da Buddhism, such as the Dhammapada, the Sutta Nip\u0101ta, and the J\u0101takas. There is no closely parallel collection in the other canons, but many of the early texts have parallels in various places.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "KN", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2920}, {"uid": "dharmapadas", "root_name": "Dharmapadas", "translated_name": "Various Dharmapada Texts ", "acronym": "Dhp", "blurb": "Verse collections that are similar to the Dhammapada of the Pali Khuddhaka Nik\u0101ya.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": null, "root_lang_name": null, "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 243}, {"uid": "minor-lzh", "root_name": "Minor Chinese", "translated_name": "Minor Chinese Texts ", "acronym": "Minor Lzh", "blurb": "Miscellanous texts relating to the early scriptures. These are mostly Chinese translations of texts similar to those found in the Pali canon", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 78}]

[{"uid": "sn56.41", "root_name": "Lokacint\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.41", "blurb": "The Buddha tells the curious tale of a man who sat by a lotus pond to speculate about the world, and saw an army enter a lotus stalk. He thought he was going mad. The Buddha said that no, the army was real. Nevertheless, you should not speculate about such things, but should reflect on the four noble truths.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.42", "root_name": "Pap\u0101tasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.42", "blurb": "The Buddha takes the mendicants to a steep precipice, and points out that those who do not understand the four noble truths fall into a still deeper precipice.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.43", "root_name": "Mah\u0101pari\u1e37\u0101hasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.43", "blurb": "The Buddha speaks of a hell called the great inferno, and points out that those who do not understand the four noble truths fall into a still fiercer inferno.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.44", "root_name": "K\u016b\u1e6d\u0101g\u0101rasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.44", "blurb": "Just as it\u2019s impossible to climb the upper floor without building the lower floors first, it\u2019s impossible to end suffering without penetrating the four noble truths.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.45", "root_name": "V\u0101lasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.45", "blurb": "\u0100nanda sees Licchavi youths shoot arrows through keyholes. But seeing the four noble truths is even harder.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.46", "root_name": "Andhak\u0101rasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.46", "blurb": "Interstellar space is dark and empty; but not seeing the four noble truths is even worse.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.47", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamachigga\u1e37ayugasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.47", "blurb": "A blind turtle would put its head through a yoke with a hole in it floating in the ocean sooner than someone in the lower realms would be reborn as a human.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.48", "root_name": "Dutiyachigga\u1e37ayugasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.48", "blurb": "A blind turtle would put its head through a yoke with a hole in it floating in the ocean sooner than someone in the lower realms would be reborn as a human.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.49", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamasinerupabbatar\u0101jasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.49", "blurb": "As seven bits of gravel are smaller than Mount Sineru, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn56.50", "root_name": "Dutiyasinerupabbatar\u0101jasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 56.50", "blurb": "As seven bits of gravel are smaller than Mount Sineru, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: Collections of “long” discourses and other related texts.
children: [{"uid": "dn", "root_name": "D\u012bghanik\u0101ya", "translated_name": "Long Discourses Collection ", "acronym": "DN", "blurb": "A fabulous courtesan, a guilty king, a know-it-all teen, learned sages and earnest fools, a silent meditation in a thunderstorm. The Long Discourses reveal a Buddha in vital engagement with his times, an ideal of humanity in whom the extraordinary comes alive. These thirty-four discourses are set in an age of wonder, when prophecy was fulfilled and the deep truth of humanity was spoken, laid bare with sparkling clarity and relentless insight. In these tales set in the slow paths, chaotic cities, and deep forests of northern India, in the shadowy past or even among the gods themselves, we see the humble monk Gotama, wise and compassionate teacher of mindfulness and morality, begin his long and storied transformation into the Buddha of legend. ", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "DN", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 102}, {"uid": "da", "root_name": "D\u012brgh\u0101gama", "translated_name": "Long Discourses Compilation ", "acronym": "DA", "blurb": "The version of the Long Discourses found in the Chinese canon is known as the D\u012brgh\u0101gama (Chang ahan jing, \u9577\u963f\u542b\u7d93), and is believed to stem from the Dharmaguptaka school. It consists of 22 fascicles that were translated by Buddhaya\u015bas (\u4f5b\u9640\u8036\u820d) and Zhu Fonian (\u7afa\u4f5b\u5ff5) in CE 412\u201313. Its four chapters focus respectively on the life of the Buddha, teaching and practice, refutation of non-Buddhists, and cosmology. It contains 30 s\u016btras in contrast to the 34 suttas of the Therav\u0101din D\u012bgha Nik\u0101ya. In the Taish\u014d edition of the Chinese canon, it is the very first text, located at T vol. 1, 1a.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": "DA", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 31}, {"uid": "da-ot", "root_name": "Other D\u012brgha S\u016btras", "translated_name": "Other Long Discourses ", "acronym": "Other DA", "blurb": "24 long discourses that in the Taish\u014d edition of the Chinese canon have been gathered in the first volume, at s\u016btra numbers 2\u201325, following the D\u012brgh\u0101gama. These are miscellaneous translations of various discourses from the D\u012bgha, made at various times by various translators.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": "DA ot", "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}]

[{"uid": "an8.51", "root_name": "Gotam\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.51", "blurb": "Mah\u0101paj\u0101pat\u012b Gotam\u012b, the Buddha\u2019s foster mother, requests ordination from the Buddha. He declines, until urged to relent by \u0100nanda. He allows Mah\u0101paj\u0101pat\u012b to go forth on eight conditions.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an8.52", "root_name": "Ov\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.52", "blurb": "With eight qualities a monk may be appointed to teach the nuns.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an8.53", "root_name": "Sa\u1e41khittasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.53", "blurb": "Mah\u0101paj\u0101pat\u012b wishes to go on retreat, so the Buddha teaches her eight principles that summarize the Dhamma in brief.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an8.54", "root_name": "D\u012bghaj\u0101\u1e47usutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.54", "blurb": "D\u012bghaj\u0101\u1e47u of the Koliyans asks the Buddha to teach in a way suitable for lay people who enjoy life. The Buddha teaches four practical ways to ensure success in this life, and another four ways to ensure success in the next.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an8.55", "root_name": "Ujjayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.55", "blurb": "The brahmin Ujjaya is going abroad, and asks the Buddha to teach him. The Buddha teaches four practical ways to ensure success in this life, and another four ways to ensure success in the next.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an8.56", "root_name": "Bhayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.56", "blurb": "The Buddha explains how addiction to sensual pleasures is perilous.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an8.57", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhama\u0101huneyyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.57", "blurb": "With eight qualities, a mendicant is worthy.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an8.58", "root_name": "Dutiya\u0101huneyyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.58", "blurb": "With eight qualities, a mendicant is worthy.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an8.59", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamapuggalasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.59", "blurb": "Eight kinds of person are worthy.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an8.60", "root_name": "Dutiyapuggalasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.60", "blurb": "Eight kinds of person are worthy.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "ja271", "root_name": "Udap\u0101nad\u016bsakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Fouled Well ", "acronym": "Ja 271", "blurb": "\u201cThis well a forest-anchorite\u201d\u2014This story the Master told whilst dwelling at Isipatana, about a Jackal that fouled a well.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja272", "root_name": "Byagghaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Tiger ", "acronym": "Ja 272", "blurb": "\u201cWhat time the nearness\u201d\u2014 This story the Master told whilst living at Jetavana, about Kokalika. The circumstances of this story will be given in the Thirteenth Book, and the Takkariya-jataka. Here again Kokalika said, \u201cI will take Sariputta and Moggallana with me.\u201d So having left Kokalika\u2019s country, he travelled to Jetavana, greeted the Master, and went on to the Elders. He said, \u201cFriends, the citizens of Kokalika\u2019s country summon you. Let us go thither!!\u201d \u201cGo yourself, friend, we won\u2019t,\u201d was the answer. After this refusal he went away by himself.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja273", "root_name": "Kacchapaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Tortoise ", "acronym": "Ja 273", "blurb": "\u201cWho is the one who brings the food\u201d\u2014This story the Master told during a stay in Jetavana, how a quarrel was made up between two magnates of the king\u2019s court in Kosala. The circumstances have been told in the Second Book.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja274", "root_name": "Lolaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Greedy Monk ", "acronym": "Ja 274", "blurb": "\u201cWho is this tufted crane\u201d\u2014This story the Master told in Jetavana about a greedy Brother. He too was brought to the Audience Hall, when the Master said\u2014\u201cIt is not only now that he is greedy; greedy he was before, and his greed lost him his life; and by his means wise men of old were driven out of house and home.\u201d Then he told a story.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja275", "root_name": "Ruciraj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Splendid Crane ", "acronym": "Ja 275", "blurb": "\u201cWho is this pretty Crane\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Jetavana about some greedy Brother. The two stories are just the same as the last. And these are the verses\u2014", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja276", "root_name": "Garudhammaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Laws of Kuru ", "acronym": "Ja 276", "blurb": "\u201cKnowing thy faith\u201d\u2014This story the Master told whilst dwelling in Jetavana, about a Brother that killed a wild goose.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja277", "root_name": "Romakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Pigeon ", "acronym": "Ja 277", "blurb": "\u201cHere in the hills\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master when at the Bamboo-grove, about attempted murder. The circumstances explain themselves.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja278", "root_name": "Mahi\u1e41sar\u0101jaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Buffalo King ", "acronym": "Ja 278", "blurb": "\u201cWhy do yore patiently\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Jetavana, about a certain impertinent monkey. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja279", "root_name": "Satapattaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Woodpecker ", "acronym": "Ja 279", "blurb": "\u201cAs the youth upon his way\u201d\u2014This story the Master told in Jetavana, about Panduka and Lohita.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja280", "root_name": "Pu\u1e6dad\u016bsakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Destroyer of Leaf-Baskets ", "acronym": "Ja 280", "blurb": "\u201cNo doubt the king\u201d\u2014This story the Master told in Jetavana, about one who destroyed pottles.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: The Buddha in dialog with ascetics and wanderers.
children: [{"uid": "mn71", "root_name": "Tevijjavacchasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 71", "blurb": "The Buddha denies being omniscient, and sets forth the three higher knowledges that form the core of his awakened insight.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn72", "root_name": "Aggivacchasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 72", "blurb": "Refusing to take a stance regarding useless metaphysical speculations, the Buddha illustrates the spiritual goal with the simile of a flame going out.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn73", "root_name": "Mah\u0101vacchasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 73", "blurb": "In the final installment of the \u201cVacchagotta trilogy\u201d, Vacchagotta lets go his obsession with meaningless speculation, and asks about practice.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn74", "root_name": "D\u012bghanakhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 74", "blurb": "Deftly outmaneuvering an extreme skeptic, the Buddha discusses the outcomes of belief and disbelief. Rather than getting stuck in abstractions, he encourages staying close to the feelings one experiences.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn75", "root_name": "M\u0101ga\u1e47\u1e0diyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 75", "blurb": "Accused by a hedonist of being too negative, the Buddha recounts the luxury of his upbringing, and his realization of how little value there was in such things. Through renunciation he found a far greater pleasure.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn76", "root_name": "Sandakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 76", "blurb": "Venerable \u0100nanda teaches a group of wanderers how there are many different approaches to the spiritual life, many of which lead nowhere.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn77", "root_name": "Mah\u0101sakulud\u0101yisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 77", "blurb": "Unlike many teachers, the Buddha\u2019s followers treat him with genuine love and respect, since they see the sincerity of his teaching and practice.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn78", "root_name": "Sama\u1e47amu\u1e47\u1e0dikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 78", "blurb": "A wanderer teaches that a person has reached the highest attainment when they keep four basic ethical precepts. The Buddha\u2019s standards are considerably higher.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn79", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37asakulud\u0101yisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 79", "blurb": "A wanderer teaches his doctrine of the \u201chighest splendor\u201d but is unable to give a satisfactory account of what that means. The Buddha memorably compares him to someone who is in love with an idealized women who he has never met.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn80", "root_name": "Vekhanasasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 80", "blurb": "Starting off similar to the previous, the Buddha goes on to explain that one is not converted to his teaching just because of clever arguments, but because you see in yourself the results of the practice.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}]

[{"uid": "iti21", "root_name": "Pasannacittasutta", "translated_name": "A Pure Mind ", "acronym": "Iti 21", "blurb": "Clear-mindedness leads to rebirth in a heavenly world.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "iti22", "root_name": "Mettasutta", "translated_name": "The Benefits of Love ", "acronym": "Iti 22", "blurb": "\u201cActs of merit\u201d is a synonym for what is blissful, desirable, pleasing, endearing, charming. The Buddha recalls the results he himself has experienced from doing meritorious deeds.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "iti23", "root_name": "Ubhayatthasutta", "translated_name": "Both Kinds of Benefit ", "acronym": "Iti 23", "blurb": "Heedfulness with regard to skillful qualities keeps both kinds of benefit secure: benefit in this live and benefit in lives to come.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "iti24", "root_name": "A\u1e6d\u1e6dhipu\u00f1jasutta", "translated_name": "A Heap of Bones ", "acronym": "Iti 24", "blurb": "In this course of transmigrating, one person would leave behind a heap of bones as large as a mountain\u2014if there were someone to collect the bones and the collection were not destroyed.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "iti25", "root_name": "Mus\u0101v\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": "Lying ", "acronym": "Iti 25", "blurb": "A person who tells a deliberate lie is capable of any evil deed.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "iti26", "root_name": "D\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": "Giving ", "acronym": "Iti 26", "blurb": "If you knew, as the Buddha did, the results of giving and sharing, you wouldn\u2019t eat without having shared.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "iti27", "root_name": "Mett\u0101bh\u0101van\u0101sutta", "translated_name": "The Meditation on Love ", "acronym": "Iti 27", "blurb": "Goodwill far outshines all other ways of making merit.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

[{"uid": "ja526", "root_name": "Ni\u1e37inik\u0101j\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Princess Ni\u1e37inik\u0101 ", "acronym": "Ja 526", "blurb": "\u201cLo! the land\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while residing at Jetavana concerning the temptation of a Brother by the wife of his unregenerate days. And in telling the story he asked the Brother by whom he had been led astray. \u201cBy a former wife,\u201d said he. \u201cVerily, Brother,\u201d the Master said, \u201cshe worketh mischief for you. Of old it was owing to her that you fell away from mystic meditation and were mightily destroyed.\u201d And so saying he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja527", "root_name": "Umm\u0101dant\u012bj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Merchant\u2019s Daughter Ummadant\u012b ", "acronym": "Ja 527", "blurb": "\u201cWhose house is this\u201d\u2014This story the Master, while residing at Jetavana, told about a back-sliding Brother.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja528", "root_name": "Mah\u0101bodhij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Longer Tale of the Young Man Bodhi ", "acronym": "Ja 528", "blurb": "\u201cWhat mean, these things\u201d\u2014This story the Master, while residing at Jetavana, told concerning the Perfection of Wisdom. The incident will be found related in the Mahaummagga. Now on this occasion the Master said, \u201cNot now only, but formerly also, the Tathagata was wise and crushed all disputants,\u201d and with these words he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "sn35.104", "root_name": "Yogakkhemisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.104", "blurb": "Someone who has given up attraction to the senses has arrived at the sanctuary.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.105", "root_name": "Up\u0101d\u0101yasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.105", "blurb": "Pleasure and pain arise inside oneself due to grasping the senses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.106", "root_name": "Dukkhasamudayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.106", "blurb": "The origin and ending of suffering are explained in terms of sense experience giving rise to craving.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.107", "root_name": "Lokasamudayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.107", "blurb": "The origin and ending of the world are explained in terms of sense experience giving rise to craving and suffering.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.108", "root_name": "Seyyohamasmisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.108", "blurb": "Conceit stems from clinging to the senses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.109", "root_name": "Sa\u1e41yojaniyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 35.109", "blurb": "The interior sense fields are the things that fetter, the craving is the fetter.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": grasping.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn35.111", "root_name": [{"uid": "sn22.1", "root_name": "Nakulapitusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.1", "blurb": "The householder Nakulapit\u0101 asks the Buddha for help in coping with old age. The Buddha says to reflect: \u201cEven though I am afflicted in body, my mind will be unafflicted.\u201d Later S\u0101riputta explains this in terms of the five aggregates.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.2", "root_name": "Devadahasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.2", "blurb": "A number of mendicants are heading for lands west, but the Buddha advises them to speak with S\u0101riputta before they go. S\u0101riputta reminds them that in foreign lands they will be scrutinized for their understanding, so they need to be able to answer questions on the teaching. He goes on to explain that the Dhamma is for the removal of desire for the five aggregates.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.3", "root_name": "H\u0101liddik\u0101nisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.3", "blurb": "The householder H\u0101liddak\u0101ni approaches the Venerable Mah\u0101kacc\u0101na in the Avanti country and asks how to understand a verse from \u201cThe Questions of M\u0101gandiya\u201d of the A\u1e6d\u1e6dhakavagga (Snp 4.9). Though the verse appears to be pitched at an ethical level, describing a sage intimate with none in the village, Mah\u0101kacc\u0101na explains it in philosophical terms as non-attachment to the aggregates.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.4", "root_name": "Dutiyah\u0101liddik\u0101nisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.4", "blurb": "The householder H\u0101liddak\u0101ni approaches the Venerable Mah\u0101kacc\u0101na in the Avanti country and asks how to understand a passage on liberation from \u201cThe Questions of Sakka\u201d (see MN 37 and DN 21). Mah\u0101kacc\u0101na explains it in terms of freedom from attachment to the aggregates.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.5", "root_name": "Sam\u0101dhisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.5", "blurb": "A mendicant should develop immersion (sam\u0101dhi) in order to truly understand the origin and ending of the five aggregates.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.6", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6disall\u0101\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.6", "blurb": "A mendicant should make an effort in seclusion in order to truly understand the origin and ending of the five aggregates.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.7", "root_name": "Up\u0101d\u0101paritassan\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.7", "blurb": "An ordinary person identifies their self with the five aggregates and suffers anxiety when the aggregates change. But a noble disciple, free of such identification, does not suffer.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.8", "root_name": "Dutiyaup\u0101d\u0101paritassan\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.8", "blurb": "An ordinary person identifies their self with the five aggregates and suffers anxiety when the aggregates change. But a noble disciple, free of such identification, does not suffer.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.9", "root_name": "K\u0101lattayaaniccasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.9", "blurb": "The aggregates are impermanent in the past and future as in the present.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.10", "root_name": "K\u0101lattayadukkhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.10", "blurb": "The aggregates are suffering in the past and future as in the present.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.11", "root_name": "K\u0101lattayaanattasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.11", "blurb": "The aggregates are not-self in the past and future as in the present.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: The Sanskrithandschriften aus den Turfanfunden is an ongoing series of publications devoted to identifying and cataloguing the manuscripts, often in highly fragmentary form, recovered from the Silk Road site at Turfan by German expeditions in the early twentieth century. These include many parallels to early sutras, which however are almost all just a few words or sentences. They may occasionally help to clarify a term or reading, but they mainly serve to illustrate the spread of these texts in the Central Asian region.

blurb: The “Linked Discourses with Jambukhādaka” contains 16 discourses recording the answers given by Sāriputta to the questions of a wanderer named Jambukhādaka. The questions cover a wide range of themes, from the nature of extinguishment to the difficulty of practicing the Dhamma. This chapter is practically identical to the next, differing only in the name of the wanderer.

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Females” contains 34 discourses regarding various qualities of women. Note that the Pali texts use two distinct terms for women, itthī and mātugāma, the latter of which can be translated as “females”. These texts deal with such themes as the kinds of suffering unique to women, why women are reborn in various states, or the qualities that lead to a woman taking charge in her marriage.

[{"uid": "ja221", "root_name": "K\u0101s\u0101vaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Ocher Robe ", "acronym": "Ja 221", "blurb": "\u201cIf any man\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while staying at Jetavana, about Devadatta.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja222", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37anandiyaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Monkey Nandiya ", "acronym": "Ja 222", "blurb": "\u201cI call to mind\u201d\u2014This story the Master told whilst dwelling in the Bamboo Grove, about Devadatta.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja223", "root_name": "Pu\u1e6dabhattaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Meal-Packet ", "acronym": "Ja 223", "blurb": "\u201cHonour for honour\u201d\u2014This story the Master told in Jetavana, about a landed proprietor.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja224", "root_name": "Kumbhilaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Crocodile ", "acronym": "Ja 224", "blurb": "\u201cO Ape\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at the Bamboo Grove, about Devadatta.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja225", "root_name": "Khantiva\u1e47\u1e47aj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "In Praise of Patience ", "acronym": "Ja 225", "blurb": "\u201cThere is a man\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Jetavana, about the king of Kosala. A very useful subordinate intrigued in the harem. Even though he knew the culprit, the king pocketed the affront, because the fellow was useful, and told the Master of it. The Master said, \u201cOther kings in days long gone by have done the same;\u201d and at his request, told the following story.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja226", "root_name": "Kosiyaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Owl ", "acronym": "Ja 226", "blurb": "\u201cThere is a time\u201d\u2014A story told by the Master at Jetavana, about the king of Kosala. This king started to quell a border rising at a bad season of the year. The circumstances have been described already. The Master as before told the king a story.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja227", "root_name": "G\u016bthap\u0101\u1e47aj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Dung-Beetle ", "acronym": "Ja 227", "blurb": "\u201cWell matched\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, about one of the Brethren.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja228", "root_name": "K\u0101man\u012btaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Brahmin Named Desire-Led ", "acronym": "Ja 228", "blurb": "\u201cThree forts\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Jetavana about a brahmin named Kamanita. The circumstances will be explained in the Twelfth Book, and the Kama J\u0101taka.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja229", "root_name": "Pal\u0101yitaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Fleer (1st) ", "acronym": "Ja 229", "blurb": "\u201cLo, my elephants\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Jetavana, about a mendicant, with vagrant tastes.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja230", "root_name": "Dutiyapal\u0101yitaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Fleer (2nd) ", "acronym": "Ja 230", "blurb": "\u201cCountless are my banners\u201d\u2014 This story the Master told whilst living at Jetavana, about this same gadabout mendicant.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: A fabulous courtesan, a guilty king, a know-it-all teen, learned sages and earnest fools, a silent meditation in a thunderstorm. The Long Discourses reveal a Buddha in vital engagement with his times, an ideal of humanity in whom the extraordinary comes alive. These thirty-four discourses are set in an age of wonder, when prophecy was fulfilled and the deep truth of humanity was spoken, laid bare with sparkling clarity and relentless insight. In these tales set in the slow paths, chaotic cities, and deep forests of northern India, in the shadowy past or even among the gods themselves, we see the humble monk Gotama, wise and compassionate teacher of mindfulness and morality, begin his long and storied transformation into the Buddha of legend.
children: [{"uid": "dn-silakkhandhavagga", "root_name": "S\u012blakkhandhavagga", "translated_name": "The Chapter on the Entire Spectrum of Ethics ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The Chapter Containing the Section on Ethics (S\u012blakkhandhavagga) is a chapter of 13 discourses. Each of these contains a long passage on the Gradual Training in ethics, meditation, and wisdom. The chapter is named after the first of these sections. The two other known versions of the D\u012brgh\u0101gama (in Chinese and Sanskrit) also contain a similar chapter. Despite the monastic nature of the central teaching, most of these discourses are presented in dialog with lay people, with a strong emphasis on the relation between the Buddha\u2019s teachings and other contemporary movements.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "DN 1\u201313", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 39}, {"uid": "dn-mahavagga", "root_name": "Mah\u0101vagga", "translated_name": "The Great Chapter ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "This chapter contains a diverse range of discourses. Several focus on the events surrounding the Buddha\u2019s death, while others range into fabulous scenarios set among the gods, and still others are grounded in detailed discussions of doctrine.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "DN 14\u201323", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 30}, {"uid": "dn-pathikavagga", "root_name": "P\u0101thikavagga", "translated_name": "The Chapter with P\u0101\u1e6dikaputta ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "Like the previous chapter, this contains a diverse range of discourses. It is named after the first discourse in the chapter. Among the discourses here are legendary accounts of the history and future of our world, which are extremely famous and influential in Buddhist circles.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "DN 24\u201334", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 33}]

Then step by step he proceeded to Savatthi, and outside Jetavana, the earth yawned, and he went down into the hell Avici.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja475", "root_name": "Phandanaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Lion and the Boxwood Tree ", "acronym": "Ja 475", "blurb": "\u201cO man, who stand\u201d\u2014This story the Master told on the bank of the river Rohini, about a family quarrel. story the Master told while dwelling in Jetavana, about Kokalika.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja482", "root_name": "Rurumigar\u0101jaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Golden Deer ", "acronym": "Ja 482", "blurb": "\u201cI bring you tidings\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling in the Bamboo-grove, about Devadatta. One might say to him, \u201cThe Master is most useful to you, friend Devadatta. You received holy orders from the Tathagata, from him you learnt the Three Baskets, you obtained gifts and honour.\u201d When such things were said, it is credibly reported he would reply, \u201cNo, friend; the Master has done me no good, not so much as a blade of grass is worth. Of myself I received holy orders, myself I learned the Three Baskets, by myself I gained gifts and honour.\u201d In the Hall of Truth the Brethren talked of all this: \u201cUngrateful is Devadatta, my friend, and forgets a kindness done.\u201d The Master came in, and would know what they talked of sitting there. They told him. Said he, \u201cIt is not now the first time, Brethren, that Devadatta is ungrateful, but ungrateful he was before; and in days long gone by his life was saved by me, yet he knew not the greatness of my merit.\u201d So saying, he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja483", "root_name": "Sarabhamigaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Stag ", "acronym": "Ja 483", "blurb": "\u201cToil on, O man\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling in Jetavana, to explain fully a question concisely put by himself to the Commander of the Faith.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: The Paṭisambhidāmagga or “Path of Analytical Discernment” is an advanced critical treatise in thirty chapters on Buddhist practice, which the Pali commentaries attribute to the Buddha’s disciple Sāriputta. Departing from the popular or folksy style of most Khuddaka texts, it is more reminiscent of the Abhidhamma, and indeed, while not included in the Abhidhammapiṭaka, it deserves to be considered part of the Theravādin Abhidhamma system. However, it does not make use of the main Abhidhamma mātikās. This text introduces a number of terms and ideas of great importance in later Buddhist philosophy. It does not have any counterparts in the northern canons, but articulates a dictinctly Theravādin perspective on the path.

blurb: Verse collections that are similar to the Dhammapada of the Pali Khuddhaka Nikāya.
children: [{"uid": "dhp", "root_name": "Dhammapada", "translated_name": "Sayings of the Dhamma ", "acronym": "Dhp", "blurb": "The Pali version of this famous text, consisting of 423 verses organized into memorable themes. It is the most widely read of the early texts, and has been translated many times into many languages. Versions of this text are found in Chinese, Tibetan, and several Indic languages, attesting to its timeless, universal appeal.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 123}, {"uid": "uv", "root_name": "Ud\u0101navarga", "translated_name": "Handbook of Heartfelt Sayings ", "acronym": "Uv", "blurb": "The Ud\u0101navarga or \u201cCollection of Inspired Sayings\u201d is a Sarv\u0101stiv\u0101din Dhammapada-style text. At 1044 verses, it is over twice as long as the Pali Dhammapada, and the longest of all the Dhammapadas. The manuscript was among the Sanskrit texts discovered at Turfan. The SuttaCentral text is sourced from the Titus edition prepared by Gippert and Kupfer, and based on the edition by Bernhard (1965). There are Chinese and Tibetan translations of this text.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "san", "root_lang_name": "Sanskrit", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}, {"uid": "uvs", "root_name": "Ud\u0101navarga de Suba\u0161i", "translated_name": "Handbook of Heartfelt Sayings (Suba\u0161i edition) ", "acronym": "UvS", "blurb": "A critical edition by H. Nakatani of the Sanskrit manuscript on wood from Suba\u0161i, Biblioth\u00e8que nationale de Paris, Pelliot Collection, 1987\u20131988.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "san", "root_lang_name": "Sanskrit", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}, {"uid": "pdhp", "root_name": "Patna Dharmapada", "translated_name": "Handbook of Heartfelt Sayings (Patna) ", "acronym": "P-Dhp", "blurb": "The Patna Dharmapada is based on a manuscript discovered in Tibet by R\u0101hula Sa\u1e45k\u1e5bty\u0101yana in 1934, written in proto-Bengali script, and dated around the twelfth century. It is in a distinct variety of Sanskritized Pr\u0101krit, and has been identified by Skilling and Mizuno as belonging to the S\u0101mmat\u012bya school. The SuttaCentral text is based on the edition by Margaret Cone (1989), digitized by \u0100nandajoti.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pra", "root_lang_name": "Pr\u0101krit", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 22}, {"uid": "gdhp", "root_name": "G\u0101ndh\u0101r\u012b Dharmapada", "translated_name": "Handbook of Heartfelt Sayings (G\u0101ndh\u0101r\u012b, 1st) ", "acronym": "G 3 Dhp", "blurb": "The G\u0101ndh\u0101r\u012b Dharmapada (also known as the Khotan Dhammapada) is from a birch-bark manuscript in Kharo\u1e63\u1e6dh\u012b script discovered at Kohm\u0101ri Maz\u0101r near Khotan in Xinjiang in 1892. It dates to the early centuries CE, and is one of the oldest surviving Buddhist manuscripts. It was edited and published by Brough (1962), and was digitized by Gandhari.org.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pgd", "root_lang_name": "G\u0101ndh\u0101r\u012b", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}, {"uid": "g2dhp", "root_name": "G\u0101ndh\u0101r\u012b 2nd Dharmapada", "translated_name": "Handbook of Heartfelt Sayings (G\u0101ndh\u0101r\u012b, 2nd) ", "acronym": "G Dhp", "blurb": "Fragments of a Dhammapada in G\u0101ndh\u0101r\u012b", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pgd", "root_lang_name": "G\u0101ndh\u0101r\u012b", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}, {"uid": "g3dhp", "root_name": "G\u0101ndh\u0101r\u012b 3rd Dharmapada", "translated_name": "Handbook of Heartfelt Sayings (G\u0101ndh\u0101r\u012b, 3rd) ", "acronym": "G 2 Dhp", "blurb": "Fragments of another Dhammapada in G\u0101ndh\u0101r\u012b", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pgd", "root_lang_name": "G\u0101ndh\u0101r\u012b", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}, {"uid": "t210", "root_name": "\u6cd5\u53e5\u7d93 (T 210)", "translated_name": "Sayings of the Dharma (Chinese) ", "acronym": "Lzh Dhp 1", "blurb": "Two fascicles compiled by Dharmatr\u0101ta \u6cd5\u6551, T 210.4.559\u2013574. It was brought by the Indian monk Vighna \u7dad\u7947\u96e3 to Wuchang \u6b66\u660c, China in 224 C.E., and translated by Zhu Jiangyan \u7afa\u5c07\u708e and Zhi Qian \u652f\u8b19. It is a collection of verses comprising the basic teachings of Buddhism which is similar to the Pali Dhammapada. The Chinese version contains 758 verses. There are four Chinese translations, dated CE 224, 290\u2013306, 399, and 980\u20131001.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 26}, {"uid": "t211", "root_name": "\u6cd5\u53e5\u8b6c\u55bb\u7d93 (T 211)", "translated_name": "Sayings of the Dharma With Stories (Chinese) ", "acronym": "Lzh Dhp 2", "blurb": "Four fascicles, compiled by Dharmatr\u0101ta and translated by Faju \u6cd5\u70ac, and Fali \u6cd5\u7acb during the years of Huidi \u60e0\u5e1d (290\u2013306 C.E.) in the Western Jin dynasty \u897f\u6649 at Luoyang. Also known by the titles of \u6cd5\u53e5\u672c\u672b\u7d93, \u6cd5\u53e5\u55a9\u7d93, \u6cd5\u55a9\u7d93, and \u6cd5\u53e5\u8b6c\u7d93. Written in thirty-nine chapters, it is, like the \u6cd5\u53e5\u7d93 (T 210), closely related to the Dhammapada of the P\u0101li Canon, and about two thirds of this text are the same as T 210. It is composed of explanatory text added to the verses of the Dharmap\u0101da.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 39}, {"uid": "t212", "root_name": "\u51fa\u66dc\u7d93 (T 212)", "translated_name": "The Appearance of Light ", "acronym": "Lzh Dhp 3", "blurb": "The Indian original text compiled by Dharmatr\u0101ta \u6cd5\u6551 consisted of 33 chapters and about 1000 verses, and it was translated by Sa\u1e43ghabhadra \u50e7\u4f3d\u8dcb\u6f84 and Zhu Fonian \u7afa\u4f5b\u5ff5 during 398\u2013399. The present T 212 has 34 chapters, and its chapters correspond to the present Ud\u0101navarga, which has 33 chapters and 1050 verses, except that it has two separated chapters, i.e. the chapter of non-carelessness \u7121\u653e\u9038\u54c1 and the chapter of carelessness \u653e\u9038\u54c1, for the chapter 'Apram\u0101davarga' of the Ud\u0101navarga. Like T 211, this text also provides the verses along with the background stories in prose. When the verses are same with those of T 210, the translators of T 211 followed the translation of T 210 rather than did a new translation.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}, {"uid": "t213", "root_name": "\u6cd5\u96c6\u8981\u980c\u7d93 (T 213)", "translated_name": "Handbook of Heartfelt Sayings (Chinese) ", "acronym": "Lzh Dhp 4", "blurb": "Also attributed to Dharmatr\u0101ta\u2019s compilation, this was translated by Tianxizai \u5929\u606f\u707d (?\u20131000), who arrived at the capital of Song dynasty in 980. It has 33 chapters corresponding to the chapters of the Ud\u0101navarga, but, unlike T 212, this text has only verses without commentaries. The translator of T 213 followed the translation of T 212, and he also followed the translation of T 210 when those verses are not in T 212 but same with T 210.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}, {"uid": "uv-kg", "root_name": "\u0f46\u0f7a\u0f51\u0f0b\u0f51\u0f74\u0f0b\u0f56\u0f62\u0f97\u0f7c\u0f51\u0f0b\u0f54\u0f60\u0f72\u0f0b\u0f5a\u0f7c\u0f58\u0f66\u0f0b", "translated_name": "Handbook of Heartfelt Sayings (Tibetan) ", "acronym": "Uv Kg", "blurb": "A Tibetan translation of the Ud\u0101navarga, attributed to Dharmatr\u0101ta. There is a commentary on this text by Praj\u00f1\u0101varman.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 33}]

[{"uid": "ja533", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37aha\u1e41saj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Shorter Tale of the Golden Goose ", "acronym": "Ja 533", "blurb": "\u201cAll other birds, etc.\u201d This was a story told by the Master, while dwelling in the Bamboo Grove, as to how the venerable Ananda renounced his life.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja534", "root_name": "Mah\u0101ha\u1e41saj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Longer Tale of the Golden Goose ", "acronym": "Ja 534", "blurb": "\u201cThere go the birds\u201d\u2014This story the Master, while residing in the Bamboo Grove, told concerning the elder Ananda\u2019s renunciation of life. The introductory story is exactly like one already given, but on this occasion the Master in telling a story of the past related the following tale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja535", "root_name": "Sudh\u0101bhojanaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "An Offering of Ambrosia ", "acronym": "Ja 535", "blurb": "\u201cNo huckster I\u201d\u2014This was a story told by the Master, while dwelling at Jetavana, concerning a liberally minded Brother.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja536", "root_name": "Ku\u1e47\u0101laj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Cuckoo ", "acronym": "Ja 536", "blurb": "\u201cThis is the report and the fame thereof\u201d This was a story told by the Master, while dwelling beside lake Kunala, concerning five hundred Brethren who were overwhelmed with discontent.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja537", "root_name": "Mah\u0101sutasomaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Longer Tale of Prince Moonface the Scholar ", "acronym": "Ja 537", "blurb": "\u201cMaster of dainty flavours\u201d\u2014This story the Master while dwelling at Jetavana told concerning the Elder, Angulimala.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

"Dutiyaaggasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.75", "blurb": "The best form, feeling, perception, and state of existence.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an4.77", "root_name": "Acinteyyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.77", "blurb": "If you try to think about these things you will go mad or get frustrated.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an4.78",
