[{"uid": "sn2.21", "root_name": "Sivasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.21", "blurb": "The deity Siva says one should associate only with the good, and this will lead to happiness. The Buddha adds that associating with the good leads to the end of suffering. Siva is the Pali spelling of Sanskrit \u015aiva, and this marks a rare appearance of a god of this name in the early texts.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.22", "root_name": "Khemasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.22", "blurb": "The deity Khema utters a series of verses in praise of good deeds. The Buddha responds with a simile for someone who departs the path of the good.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.23", "root_name": "Ser\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.23", "blurb": "The deity Seri\u0304 speaks of how everyone loves food., to which the Buddha responds with verses in praise of giving. Seri\u0304 speaks of his own generosity in a past life.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.24", "root_name": "Gha\u1e6d\u012bk\u0101rasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.24", "blurb": "The deity Gha\u1e6di\u0304ka\u0304ra speaks of the seven mendicants reborn in the Aviha realm. The sutta is similar to SN 1.50.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.25", "root_name": "Jantusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.25", "blurb": "Some monks in Kosala fell into negligence, and were admonished by the deity Jantu.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.26", "root_name": "Rohitassasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.26", "blurb": "Rohitassa asks the Buddha if it is possible to reach the end of the world by traveling. The Buddha says no; and Rohitassa tells of how in a past life as a seer he had tried to accomplish this very feat and failed. The Buddha says the end of the world is found in this body.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.27", "root_name": "Nandasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.27", "blurb": "Nanda speaks of the transience of life, saying one should do good to be reborn in a happy future life. The Buddha replies that one should let go attachment.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.28", "root_name": "Nandivis\u0101lasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.28", "blurb": "The god Nandivisa\u0304la gives an elaborate metaphor for the body, and asks how to escape from it. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.29", "root_name": "Susimasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.29", "blurb": "The Buddha asks A\u0304nanda if he likes Sa\u0304riputta, and when he replies that he does, the god Susi\u0304ma and his assembly appear, rejoicing in Sa\u0304riputta\u2019s praises, and radiating in lustrous colors.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn2.30", "root_name": "N\u0101n\u0101titthiyas\u0101vakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 2.30", "blurb": "A series of deities who had formerly been ascetics in the non-Buddhist sects came to the Buddha, speaking verses in praise\u2014or occasional criticism\u2014of their former teachers", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

translated_name: The Chapter of Abbreviated Texts Beginning With Anger
children: [{"uid": "an2.180-229", "root_name": "Kodhapeyy\u0101lavagga", "translated_name": "Abbreviated Texts Beginning With Anger", "acronym": "AN 2.180\u2013229", "blurb": null, "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "ja361", "root_name": "Va\u1e47\u1e47\u0101rohaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "In Beauty and Stature ", "acronym": "Ja 361", "blurb": "\u201cIs it thus, Sudatha\u201d\u2014This story the Master, while dwelling at Jetavana, told concerning the two chief disciples.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja362", "root_name": "S\u012blav\u012bma\u1e41saj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "A Test of Virtue ", "acronym": "Ja 362", "blurb": "\u201cVirtue and learning\u201d\u2014This story the Master, while residing at Jetavana, told concerning a brahmin who would test the power of virtue. The king, they say, owing to his reputation for virtue, regarded him with special honour, beyond what was paid to other brahmins. He thought, \u201cCan it be that the king regards me with special honour, because I am endowed with virtue, or as one devoted to the acquisition of learning? I will just test the comparative importance of virtue and learning.\u201d", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja363", "root_name": "Hirij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Conscience ", "acronym": "Ja 363", "blurb": "\u201cWho spite of honour\u201d\u2014This story the Master, when dwelling at Jetavana, told concerning a rich merchant, a friend of Anathapindika, who lived in a border province. Both the introductory story and the story of the past are related in full in the concluding Birth of the ninth division of the first book, but in this version when the merchant of Benares was told that the followers of the foreign merchant were mulcted of all their property and, after losing everything they possessed, had to take to flight, he said, \u201cBecause they failed to do what they ought for the strangers who came to them, they find no one ready to do them a good turn.\u201d And so saying he repeated these verses:", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja364", "root_name": "Khajjopanakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Firefly ", "acronym": "Ja 364", "blurb": "This Question about a fire-fly will be set forth in full in the Mahaummagga.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja365", "root_name": "Ahitu\u1e47\u1e0dikaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Snake-Charmer ", "acronym": "Ja 365", "blurb": "\u201cLo! here we lie\u201d\u2014This story the Master, whilst living at Jetavana, told concerning an aged priest. The story has been already related in full in the Salaka Birth. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja366", "root_name": "Gumbiyaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Gumbiya the Ogre ", "acronym": "Ja 366", "blurb": "\u201cPoison like honey\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while dwelling at Jetavana, about a Brother who regretted taking orders. The Master asked him if it were true that he regretted it. \u201cIt is true, Holy Sir,\u201d he said. \u201cWhat have you seen to cause this feeling?\u201d asked the Master. When the Brother replied, \u201cIt was owing to the charms of a woman,\u201d the Master said, \u201cThese five qualities of desire are like the honey sprinkled over with deadly poison, and left in the road by one Gumbika.\u201d And hereupon at the request of the Brother he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja367", "root_name": "S\u0101\u1e37iyaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Hedgehog ", "acronym": "Ja 367", "blurb": "\u201cWho got his friend\u201d\u2014This was a story told by the Master, whilst living in the Bamboo Grove, in reference to a saying that Devadatta could not even inspire alarm.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja368", "root_name": "Tacas\u0101raj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Bamboo Fetters ", "acronym": "Ja 368", "blurb": "204] \u201cFallen into hand of foes\u201d\u2014This story the Master, whilst dwelling at Jetavana, told concerning the Perfection of Wisdom. It was then the Master said, \u201cNot now only, Brethren, but formerly also the Tathagata proved himself wise and full of resources.\u201d And herewith he related an old legend of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja369", "root_name": "Mittavindakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "On Mittavindaka ", "acronym": "Ja 369", "blurb": "\u201cWhat was the evil\u201d\u2014This story the Master whilst living at Jetavana told concerning an unruly Brother. The incident that led to the story will be found in the Mahamittavinda Birth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja370", "root_name": "Pal\u0101saj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Parrot Tree ", "acronym": "Ja 370", "blurb": "\u201cThe goose said to the Judas tree\u201d\u2014This was a story told by the Master, whilst residing at Jetavana, concerning the rebuke of sin. The incident that led to the story will be set forth in the Panna Birth. But on this occasion the Master addressing the Brethren said, \u201cBrothers, sin ought to be regarded with suspicion. Though it be as small as a banyan shoot, it may prove fatal. Sages of old too suspected whatever was open to suspicion.\u201d And with this he related a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: Collections of “middle-length” discourses and other related texts.
children: [{"uid": "mn", "root_name": "Majjhimanik\u0101ya", "translated_name": "Middle Discourses Collection ", "acronym": "MN", "blurb": "The Middle Discourses (Majjhima Nik\u0101ya, abbreviated MN) is a collection of 152 discourses in the Pali canon (Tipi\u1e6daka) of the Theravada school of Buddhism. The word \u201cmiddle\u201d refers to the length of the individual discourses. This is perhaps the most popular collection of early discourses. It contains a wide variety of teachings, many of them presented as narratives between the Buddha and a diverse range of his contemporaries. The collection parallels the Madhyam\u0101gama (MA) of the Sarv\u0101stiv\u0101da school, which survives as a translation in the Chinese canon.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "MN", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 503}, {"uid": "ma", "root_name": "Madhyam\u0101gama", "translated_name": "Middle Discourses Compilation ", "acronym": "MA", "blurb": "The version of the Middle Discourses found in the Chinese canon is known as the Madhyam\u0101gama (Zhong ahan jing, \u4e2d\u963f\u542b\u7d93), and is believed to stem from the Sarv\u0101stiv\u0101da school. The original text is believed to have been in a form of Pr\u0101krit, probably Gandh\u0101r\u012b, with some Sanskrit influence. It was translated in 60 fascicles by Gautama Sa\u1e45ghadeva (\u77bf\u66c7\u50e7\u4f3d\u63d0\u5a46) of the Eastern Jin Dynasty (\u6771\u664b) at Dongting Monastery (\u6771\u4ead\u5bfa) in CE 397\u2013398. It consists of 222 sutras, organized into five adhy\u0101yas and eighteen vargas. The contents are similar to the Pali Majjhima Nik\u0101ya, though the collections are far from identical. In the Taish\u014d edition of the Chinese canon, it is text number 26, located at T vol. 1, 421a.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": "MA", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 53}, {"uid": "ma-ot", "root_name": "Other Madhyama S\u016btras", "translated_name": "Other Middle Discourses ", "acronym": "Other MA", "blurb": "72 middle-length discourses that in the Taish\u014d edition of the Chinese canon have been gathered in the first volume, at s\u016btra numbers 27\u201398, following the Madhyam\u0101gama. These are miscellaneous translations of various discourses from the Majjhima, made at various times by various translators.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "lzh", "root_lang_name": "Chinese", "child_range": "MA ot", "yellow_brick_road": false, "yellow_brick_road_count": 0}]

translated_name: The Chapter on a Lay Follower
children: [{"uid": "an5.171", "root_name": "S\u0101rajjasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 5.171", "blurb": "Confidence or lack thereof in layfolk is due to their precepts.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an5.172", "root_name": "Vis\u0101radasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 5.172", "blurb": "Confidence or lack thereof in layfolk is due to their precepts.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an5.173", "root_name": "Nirayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 5.173", "blurb": "Reasons one is cast down to hell or raised to heaven.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an5.174", "root_name": "Verasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 5.174", "blurb": "Breaking of precepts is a threat and a danger.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an5.175", "root_name": "Ca\u1e47\u1e0d\u0101lasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 5.175", "blurb": "An outcaste is not born, but they make themselves an outcaste by their behavior. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an5.176", "root_name": "P\u012btisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 5.176", "blurb": "The Buddha encourages An\u0101thapi\u1e47\u1e0dika to not rest short with generosity, but to practice meditation too.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an5.177", "root_name": "Va\u1e47ijj\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 5.177", "blurb": "Five kinds of trade that are wrong livelihood.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an5.178", "root_name": "R\u0101j\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 5.178", "blurb": "Kings do not punish people for keeping precepts.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an5.179", "root_name": "Gihisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 5.179", "blurb": "Qualities possessing which a lay person may claim to be a stream-enterer.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an5.180", "root_name": "Gaves\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 5.180", "blurb": "The Buddha tells of the layman Gaves\u012b in the time of Buddha Kassapa, and how he went forth with all his followers.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses with Anuruddha” contains 24 discourses with Anuruddha, famous for his powers of clairvoyance, but here revealed as an exponent of mindfulness meditation. It is to mindfulness meditation that he attributes his spiritual attainments, whether psychic powers, absorptions, or awakening. This series of texts can be regarded as a supplement to SN 47.

The Buddha affirms that his claim to superiority is because he was the first to achieve awakening.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an8.12", "root_name": "S\u012bhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 8.12", "blurb": "General S\u012bha, a prominent disciple of the Jains, visits the Buddha against the wishes of Mah\u0101v\u012bra, the Jain leader. blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Dragons” is the first of four similar sections dealing with the modes in which various semi-celestial beings may be reborn. The current chapter is on the “dragons” or nāgas, a powerful but morally ambiguous serpentine creature of the waterways.

the relation to emotional and cognitive processes.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "mn138", "root_name": "Uddesavibha\u1e45gasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 138", "blurb": "The Buddha gives a brief and enigmatic statement on the ways consciousness may become attached. Venerable Mah\u0101kacc\u0101na is invited by the mendicants to draw out the implications.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "mn139", "root_name": "Ara\u1e47avibha\u1e45gasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 139", "blurb": "Achieving peace is no simple matter. The Buddha explains how to avoid conflict through contentment, right speech, understanding pleasure, and not insisting on local conventions.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn140", "root_name": "Dh\u0101tuvibha\u1e45gasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 140", "blurb": "While staying overnight in a potter\u2019s workshop, the Buddha has a chance encounter with a monk who does not recognize him. They have a long and profound discussion based on the four elements. This is one of the most insightful and moving discourses in the canon.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "mn141", "root_name": "Saccavibha\u1e45gasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 141", "blurb": "Expanding on the Buddha\u2019s first sermon, Venerable S\u0101riputta gives a detailed explanation of the four noble truths.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "mn142", "root_name": "Dakkhi\u1e47\u0101vibha\u1e45gasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "MN 142", "blurb": "When his step-mother Mah\u0101paj\u0101pat\u012b wishes to offer him a robe for his personal use, the Buddha encourages her to offer it to the entire Sa\u1e45gha instead. He goes on to explain that the best kind of offering to the Sa\u1e45gha is one given to the dual community of monks and nuns, headed by the Buddha.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "ja231", "root_name": "Up\u0101hanaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "A Pair of Sandals ", "acronym": "Ja 231", "blurb": "\u201cAs when a pair of shoes\u201d\u2014This story the Master told in the Bamboo Grove, about Devadatta. The Brethren gathered together in the Hall of Truth, and began to discuss the matter. \u201cFriend, Devadatta having repudiated his teacher, and become the foe and adversary of the Tathagata, has come to utter destruction.\u201d The Master came in, and asked what they were talking about as they sat there. They told him. The Master said, \u201cBrethren, this is not the first time that Devadatta has repudiated his teacher, and become my enemy, and come to utter destruction. The same thing happened before.\u201d Then he told them an old-world tale.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, idea\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while staying at Jetavana, about a young lady.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, [{"uid": "ja331", "root_name": "Kokilaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Cuckoo ", "acronym": "Ja 331", "blurb": "\u201cThey that with speech inopportune\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master at Jetavana about Kokalika. The introductory story is told in full in the Takkarika Birth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja332", "root_name": "Rathala\u1e6d\u1e6dhij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Chariot-Whip ", "acronym": "Ja 332", "blurb": "\u201cWounding another\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master when he was at Jetavana, about the family priest of the king of Kosala, who, it is said, as he was driving in his chariot to a village on his estate came upon a caravan in a narrow road, and crying out once and again, \u201cOut of the way with you,\u201d was so enraged at a cart not clearing out of his way that he threw his goad-stick at the driver of the first cart.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja333", "root_name": "Pakkagodhaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Cooked Lizard ", "acronym": "Ja 333", "blurb": "\u201cThen wert thou\u201d\u2014This is a story told by the Master while at Jetavana, of a certain landowner.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja334", "root_name": "R\u0101jov\u0101daj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Kingly Advice ", "acronym": "Ja 334", "blurb": "\u201cThe bull through floods\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master when at Jetavana concerning the admonition of a king. The introductory story will be found in full in the Tesakuna Birth. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja335", "root_name": "Jambukaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Jackal ", "acronym": "Ja 335", "blurb": "\u201cJackal beware\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while dwelling in the Bamboo Grove, about the attempt of Devadatta to imitate the Buddha. The incident that gave rise to the story has been told in full before. Here is a short summary of it. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja336", "root_name": "Brah\u0101chattaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Chatta the Tall ", "acronym": "Ja 336", "blurb": "\u201cGrass is still\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, of a certain rogue. The incident that suggested the story has been already related.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja337", "root_name": "P\u012b\u1e6dhaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Seat ", "acronym": "Ja 337", "blurb": "\u201cAlas! we offered thee\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while living at Jetavana, about a certain Brother.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja338", "root_name": "Thusaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Grain by Grain ", "acronym": "Ja 338", "blurb": "\u201cWith sense so nice\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while living in the Bamboo Grove, of prince Ajatasattu. At the time of his conception there arose in his mother, the daughter of the king of Kosala, a chronic longing to drink blood from the right knee of king Bimbisara (her husband).", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja339", "root_name": "B\u0101veruj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Selling Crows to Babylon ", "acronym": "Ja 339", "blurb": "\u201cBefore the crested peacock\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master when at Jetavana, of certain heretics who lost their former gains and glory.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja340", "root_name": "Visayhaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Merchant Visayha ", "acronym": "Ja 340", "blurb": "\u201cOf old, Visayha\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana of Anathapindika. The incident that gave rise to the story has been already told in full in the Khadirangara Birth. On this occasion the Master addressing Anathapindika said, \u201cWise men of old, my lay brother, gave alms, rejecting the counsel of Sakka, king of heaven, when he stood in mid-air and tried to prevent them, saying, \u201cGive not alms.\u201d And at his request the Master told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

translated_name: Linked Discourses With King Pasenadi of Kosala
blurb: The “Linked Discourses with the Kosalan” contains 25 discourses featuring King Pasenadi of Kosala. Pasenadi shines through in the early texts as a complex human figure, one with foibles and foolishness, but with a great devotion and capacity to grow. He appears frequently elsewhere in the suttas; MN 87 tells the story of how Queen Mallikā led him to the Dhamma. Here Mallikā appears again, and in SN 3.8 she shows how she is not afraid to challenge her king. The suttas in this collection typically set the verses in substantive prose narratives, illustrating the struggles and problems that beset a king intent on Dhamma who must nonetheless rule in a world with spies, sacrifices, punishments, wars, and the many temptations of royal life.

[{"uid": "sn14.11", "root_name": "Sattadh\u0101tusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 14.11", "blurb": "A rare group of seven elements: light, beauty, the four formless states, and the attainment of cessation. Each of these is known due to the negation of something: light vs. darkness, beauty vs. ugliness, and so on. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn14.12", "root_name": "Sanid\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 14.12", "blurb": "Thoughts of sensuality, ill-will, and cruelty arise due to a series of causes.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn14.13", "root_name": "Gi\u00f1jak\u0101vasathasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 14.13", "blurb": "When unenlightened people have the view that certain people are Buddhas, this is due to ignorance.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn14.14", "root_name": "H\u012bn\u0101dhimuttikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 14.14", "blurb": "People of poor character associate together, while people of good character associate together.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn14.15", "root_name": "Ca\u1e45kamasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 14.15", "blurb": "The Buddha points out that each of the great disciples has a retinue of students of a similar character. And the monks in Devadattas\u2019s retinue all have evil wishes.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn14.16", "root_name": "Sag\u0101th\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 14.16", "blurb": "People of poor character associate together, while people of good character associate together. [{"uid": "an7.615", "root_name": "", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.615", "blurb": "Develop insight into greed through the awakening factors.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.616", "root_name": "", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.616", "blurb": "Develop insight into greed through seven perceptions starting with impermanence.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.617", "root_name": "", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.617", "blurb": "Develop insight into greed through seven perceptions starting with ugliness.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.618-644", "root_name": "", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.618\u2013644", "blurb": "Develop complete understanding, etc., of greed.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an7.645-1124", "root_name": "", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 7.645\u20131124", "blurb": "Develop complete understanding, etc., of hate, etc.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "sn11.1", "root_name": "Suv\u012brasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.1", "blurb": "When Sakka, the Lord of Gods, tries to organize a counterattack against the demons, he is frustrated by his lazy general Suv\u012bra. Sakka asks Suv\u012bra how one might get what one wants without effort; but Suv\u012bra apparently believes Sakka can grant any wish he wants. The Buddha emphasizes that if effort is valuable among the gods, how much more so for mendicants.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn11.2", "root_name": "Sus\u012bmasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.2", "blurb": "When Sakka, the Lord of Gods, tries to organize a conterattack against the demons, he is frustrated by his lazy general Sus\u012bma. Sakka asks Sus\u012bma how one might get what one wants without effort; but Sus\u012bma apparently believes Sakka can grant any wish he wants. The Buddha emphasizes that if effort is valuable among the gods, how much more so for mendicants.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn11.3", "root_name": "Dhajaggasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.3", "blurb": "Sakka rallies his troops with the sight of his banner. But the Buddha points out that the deities, powerful as they are, are not free of fear, but he is. He encourages the mendicants to recollect the Triple Gem to abandon fear.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn11.4", "root_name": "Vepacittisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.4", "blurb": "In a battle between the gods and the demons, and the demon lord Vepacitti is captured and brought in chains to Sakka\u2019s hall. Vepacitti abuses Sakka, who endures his harsh words in patience. The charioteer Ma\u0304tali asks whether he is silent out of weakness or fear, but Sakka says there is no point is wasting words arguing with a fool.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn11.5", "root_name": "Subh\u0101sitajayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.5", "blurb": "The demon lord Vepacitti proposes to Sakka that they engage in a battle of wits in debate rather than war. Vepacitti speaks in praise of forceful punishment, while Sakka stands up for patience and forgiveness.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn11.6", "root_name": "Kul\u0101vakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.6", "blurb": "Fleeing the demon host, Sakka\u2019s chariot risks endangering the nests of little birds in the forest. Rather than render the birds homeless, Sakka instructs his charioteer to turn back, even at the cost of his life.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn11.7", "root_name": "Nadubbhiyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.7", "blurb": "Sakka reflects that one should not harm even one\u2019s enemy. Knowing this, Vepacitti immediately takes advantage of it.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn11.8", "root_name": "Verocanaasurindasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.8", "blurb": "Sakka, lord of gods, and Verocana, lord of demons, approach the Buddha\u2019s hut and speak in praise of effort.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn11.9", "root_name": "Ara\u00f1\u00f1\u0101yatanaisisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.9", "blurb": "In days gone by, Sakka, lord of gods, and Vepacitti, lord of demons, visited a hermitage of seers. But Vepacitti behaves rudely, while Sakka honors them. However, the seers beg Sakka to leave, on account of the stink of their unwashed bodies. But he says he loves their smell.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn11.10", "root_name": "Samuddakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 11.10", "blurb": "In the past, when battle between the gods and demons loomed, some seers sought out the demon lord Sambara to beg for protection. But due to their devotion to Sakka, he rejected them, so they cursed him.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

[{"uid": "an4.1", "root_name": "Anubuddhasutta", "translated_name": "Understood ", "acronym": "AN 4.1", "blurb": "Both the Buddha and his disciples have been reborn for a long time due to ignorance.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "an4.2", "root_name": "Papatitasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.2", "blurb": "Without morality, convergence, wisdom, and freedom, one has fallen from the teaching.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an4.3", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamakhatasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.3", "blurb": "After reflection, you should criticize those worthy or criticism, and praise those worthy of praise.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an4.4", "root_name": "Dutiyakhatasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.4", "blurb": "You harm yourself by acting badly towards parents, the Buddha, and spiritual practitioners.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an4.5", "root_name": "Anusotasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.5", "blurb": "A person who goes with the stream; a person who goes against the stream; a stable person; and one who has crossed over.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an4.6", "root_name": "Appassutasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.6", "blurb": "Learning the texts and getting the point of learning.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an4.7", "root_name": "Sobhanasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.7", "blurb": "A monk, nun, laywoman, and layman who light up the Sa\u1e45gha.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an4.8", "root_name": "Ves\u0101rajjasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.8", "blurb": "Because of his spiritual attainments and practice, a Buddha is supremely self-confident.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an4.9", "root_name": "Ta\u1e47hupp\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.9", "blurb": "Sources of craving for mendicants.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an4.10", "root_name": "Yogasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 4.10", "blurb": "The yokes of sensual pleasures, future lives, views, and ignorance.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

translated_name: The Chapter on Ambapālī the Courtesan
children: [{"uid": "sn47.1", "root_name": "Ambap\u0101lisutta", "translated_name": "", "acronym": "SN 47.1", "blurb": "At Ambap\u0101l\u012b\u2019s mango grove, the Buddha teaches the mendicants about the \u201cway to convergence\u201d, the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.2", "root_name": "Satisutta", "translated_name": "", "acronym": "SN 47.2", "blurb": "At Ambap\u0101l\u012b\u2019s mango grove, the Buddha teaches the mendicants about the four kinds of mindfulness meditation and the practice of situational awareness. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.3", "root_name": "Bhikkhusutta", "translated_name": "", "acronym": "SN 47.3", "blurb": "When a mendicant asks for a teaching to take on retreat, the Buddha issues an unexpected rebuke. Evidently the mendicant had been badly behaved; but now, he insists, he is sincere. The Buddha relents, and teaches the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, well grounded on ethics.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.4", "root_name": "S\u0101lasutta", "translated_name": "", "acronym": "SN 47.4", "blurb": "Newly ordained mendicants should practice the four kinds of mindfulness meditation; trainees are practicing them, and perfected ones have perfected the practice.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.5", "root_name": "Akusalar\u0101sisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.5", "blurb": "The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are a complete heap of what is skillful.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.6", "root_name": "Saku\u1e47agghisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.6", "blurb": "The parable of the quail and the hawk. When the quail ventured outside her ancestral territory, she became vulnerable. And what is a mendicant\u2019s ancestral territory? The four kinds of mindfulness meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.7", "root_name": "Makka\u1e6dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.7", "blurb": "The parable of the foolish monkey who gets trapped in tar when it ventures outside its ancestral territory. And what is a mendicant\u2019s ancestral territory? The four kinds of mindfulness meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.8", "root_name": "S\u016bdasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.8", "blurb": "The parable of the cook. They present different kinds of dishes to the king, and observe which the king likes. In the same way, a mendicant observes why their meditation succeeds or fails. When the four kinds of mindfulness meditation succeeds it leads to giving up hindrances and entering immersion.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.9", "root_name": "Gil\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.9", "blurb": "The Buddha decides to spend his final rains retreat at Ves\u0101l\u012b in Beluvag\u0101maka. During the retreat he becomes very ill, but later recovers. \u0100nanda wonders who will guide the Sa\u1e45gha when the Buddha dies, but the Buddha says they should be their own refuge, grounded on the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.10", "root_name": "Bhikkhunupassayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.10", "blurb": "When \u0100nanda visits the nuns\u2019s quarters they tell him that their meditation is prospering to higher and higher levels. \u0100nanda reporrts the good news to the Buddha, who speaks of two ways of developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation: directed and undirected.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

translated_name: The Chapter on Not Learned From Anyone Else
children: [{"uid": "sn47.31", "root_name": "Ananussutasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.31", "blurb": "The full knowledge of mindfulness meditation was not learned before the Buddha.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.32", "root_name": "Vir\u0101gasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.32", "blurb": "The four kinds of mindfulness meditation lead to peace.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.33", "root_name": "Viraddhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.33", "blurb": "Someone who has neglected the four kinds of mindfulness meditation has neglected the noble path.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.34", "root_name": "Bh\u0101vitasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.34", "blurb": "The four kinds of mindfulness meditation lead from the near to the far shore.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.35", "root_name": "Satisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.35", "blurb": "Mindfulness is the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. Situational awareness is watching the arising and passing of feelings, thoughts, and perceptions.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.36", "root_name": "A\u00f1\u00f1\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.36", "blurb": "When the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are developed, perfection or non-return may be expected.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.37", "root_name": "Chandasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.37", "blurb": "Developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, desire is abandoned.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.38", "root_name": "Pari\u00f1\u00f1\u0101tasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.38", "blurb": "The four kinds of mindfulness meditation lead to realizing the deathless.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.39", "root_name": "Bh\u0101van\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.39", "blurb": "The development of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn47.40", "root_name": "Vibha\u1e45gasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 47.40", "blurb": "The Buddha teaches the simple passage on the four kinds of mindfulness meditation and an advanced analysis, which involves contemplating them as impermanent.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: The version of the Long Discourses found in the Chinese canon is known as the Dīrghāgama (Chang ahan jing, 長阿含經), and is believed to stem from the Dharmaguptaka school. It consists of 22 fascicles that were translated by Buddhayaśas (佛陀耶舍) and Zhu Fonian (竺佛念) in CE 412–13. Its four chapters focus respectively on the life of the Buddha, teaching and practice, refutation of non-Buddhists, and cosmology. It contains 30 sūtras in contrast to the 34 suttas of the Theravādin Dīgha Nikāya. In the Taishō edition of the Chinese canon, it is the very first text, located at T vol. 1, 1a.

translated_name: Past Life Legends of the Senior Nuns
blurb: The “Legends of the Senior Nuns” contains 40 stories in verse telling the past life deeds of various senior nuns. It is a much later counterpart to the Therīgāthā, referring to many of the same nuns. But whereas the Therīgāthā verses relate the nuns’ practice of meditation and mindfulness in this life, the Legends typically relate how they became awakened in this life by making an offering a Buddha in the distant past, and making a dedication to be reborn so as to become awakened in the future. The “Legends of the Senior Nuns” has as companion the “Legends of the Senior Monks”. Both these are late texts, and lack counterparts in the northern canons.

translated_name: Linked Discourses with Citta the Householder
blurb: The “Linked Discourses with Citta” contains 10 discourses featuring the householder Citta, who was praised by the Buddha as the foremost lay disciple in speaking on the Dhamma. Here he engages in a series of insightful and sharp-witted dialogues with various monks. Citta emerges as a distinctive personality, knowledgeable and witty, curious and incisive, with no lack of humor. But he is more than just a clever speaker, for he also lays claim to exalted meditation and spiritual attainments.

Practicing in line with these eight thoughts of a great man, Venerable Anuruddha achieves perfection.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

"yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an3.96", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhama\u0101j\u0101n\u012byasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 3.96", "blurb": "A mendicant is beautiful, strong, and perfection.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an3.99", "root_name": purifying gold. A meditator should progressively eliminate more refined corruptions.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an3.102", "root_name": "Nimittasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 3.102", "blurb": "Meditation is like purifying gold. A meditator should focus on different aspects at different times in order to proceed smoothly.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on the Breakthrough” contains 11 discourses on the value of realizing the Dhamma. Each discourse features a memorable simile illustrating the truly momentous implications of seeing the four noble truths.

[{"uid": "sn12.61", "root_name": "Assutav\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.61", "blurb": "An ignorant person might become free of attachment to their body, but not their mind. Still, it would be better to attach to the body, as it is less changeable than the mind, which jumps about like a monkey.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.62", "root_name": "Dutiyaassutav\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.62", "blurb": "An ignorant person might become free of attachment to their body, but not their mind. Still, it would be better to attach to the body, as it is less changeable than the mind. But a noble disciple reflects on dependent origination.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.63", "root_name": "Puttama\u1e41sasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.63", "blurb": "The Buddha defines the four kinds of \u201cfood\u201d or \u201cnutriment\u201d, which include edible food, contact, intention, and consciousness. He illustrates them with a series of powerful and horrifying similes.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.64", "root_name": "Atthir\u0101gasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.64", "blurb": "The Buddha defines the four kinds of \u201cfood\u201d or \u201cnutriment\u201d, which include edible food, contact, intention, and consciousness, showing how they lead to suffering according to dependent origination. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.65", "root_name": "Nagarasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.65", "blurb": "The Buddha tells the story of how his awakening came about through investigation into dependent origination. He compares it to a man discovering and ancient city, lost and overgrown with weeds.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.66", "root_name": "Sammasasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.66", "blurb": "The right way to investigate inside oneself is to see how suffering is created by craving and attachment, stimulated by pleasant experiences.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.67", "root_name": "Na\u1e37akal\u0101p\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.67", "blurb": "Venerables Maha\u0304ko\u1e6d\u1e6dhita and S\u0101riputta discuss whether the factors of dependent origination are created by oneself, another, both, or by chance.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.68", "root_name": "Kosambisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.68", "blurb": "Venerable Savi\u1e6d\u1e6dha questions Venerable Mus\u012bla about his attainments, and concludes he is an arahant. But Venerable Na\u0304rada offers an explanation showing that it is possible to see the Dhamma without having fully realized arahantship.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.69", "root_name": "Upayantisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.69", "blurb": "Like rivers flowing to the ocean, the factors of dependent origination lead to suffering.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.70", "root_name": "Susimaparibb\u0101jakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.70", "blurb": "The wanderer Sus\u0131\u0304ma fraudulently enters the Sangha so that the wanderers can learn the secret to the Buddha\u2019s fame and success. Hearing that some mendicants claimed to be perfected, Sus\u012bma approaches and asks them if they have developed psychic powers or the formless states, to which they say no. Perplexed, he asks the Buddha, who explains that awakening follows insight into the principles of impermanence and causality. Eventually Sus\u0131\u0304ma confesses his misdeed.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

translated_name: The Chapter on the Wrong Way
children: [{"uid": "sn45.21", "root_name": "Micchattasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 45.21", "blurb": "The wrong eightfold path is a wrong state; the right eightfold path is a right state.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn45.22", "root_name": "Akusaladhammasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 45.22", "blurb": "The factors of the wrong eightfold path are unskillful qualities; those of the right eightfold path are skillful qualities.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn45.23", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamapa\u1e6dipad\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 45.23", "blurb": "The wrong eightfold path is the wrong way; the right eightfold path is the right way.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn45.24", "root_name": "Dutiyapa\u1e6dipad\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 45.24", "blurb": "Regardless of whether one is a lay person or a renunciate, the Buddha praises the right way, not the wrong way. The wrong eightfold path is the wrong way; the right eightfold path is the right way.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn45.25", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamaasappurisasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 45.25", "blurb": "A bad person practices wrong eightfold path; a good person practices the right eightfold path.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn45.26", "root_name": "Dutiyaasappurisasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 45.26", "blurb": "A bad person practices wrong eightfold path, and a worse person has wrong knowledge and wrong liberation, too; a good person is the opposite.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn45.27", "root_name": "Kumbhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 45.27", "blurb": "Someone without the eightfold path is easily knocked over, like a pot without a stand.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn45.28", "root_name": "Sam\u0101dhisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 45.28", "blurb": "The eightfold path is the necessary prerequisite for right immersion (sam\u0101dhi).", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn45.29", "root_name": "Vedan\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 45.29", "blurb": "The eightfold path is developed to understand the three feelings.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn45.30", "root_name": "Uttiyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 45.30", "blurb": "The Buddha taught the eightfold path in order to give up the five kinds of sensual stimulation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

translated_name: The Chapter on the Ten Powers
children: [{"uid": "sn12.21", "root_name": "Dasabalasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.21", "blurb": "The Buddha\u2019s teaching rests on his possession of ten powers and four grounds for self-confidence.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.22", "root_name": "Dutiyadasabalasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.22", "blurb": "The Buddha\u2019s teaching rests on his possession of ten powers and four grounds for self-confidence. When hearing such an open teaching, a mendicant puts forth great effort, considering the good for both themselves and for others.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.23", "root_name": "Upanisasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.23", "blurb": "The ending of defilements comes only when the truth is seen. But seeing the truth comes about due to a vital condition. In this way, twelve factors leading to freedom are united with the twelve factors leading to suffering.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.24", "root_name": "A\u00f1\u00f1atitthiyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.24", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta is asked by various ascetics as to the origin of suffering. He replies that the Buddha teaches that suffering originates by conditions. Moreover, all those who offer opinions as to the source of suffering are themselves part of the web of conditions, as they cannot state their views without contact. A\u0304nanda reports the exchange to the Buddha, who praises S\u0101riputta\u2019s answer.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.25", "root_name": "Bh\u016bmijasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.25", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta is asked by Venerable Bh\u016bmija as to the origin of pleasure and pain. He replies that the Buddha teaches that pleasure and pain originate by conditions. Moreover, all those who offer opinions on this question are themselves part of the web of conditions, as they cannot state their views without contact. A\u0304nanda reports the exchange to the Buddha, who praises S\u0101riputta\u2019s answer.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.26", "root_name": "Upav\u0101\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.26", "blurb": "The Buddha is asked by Venerable Upava\u0304\u1e47a as to the origin of suffering. He replies that suffering originates by conditions. Moreover, all those who offer opinions as to the source of suffering are themselves part of the web of conditions, as they cannot state their views without contact.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.27", "root_name": "Paccayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.27", "blurb": "Dependent origination is framed within the four noble truths.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.28", "root_name": "Bhikkhusutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.28", "blurb": "A mendicant who understands dependent origination is a trainee who is accomplished in view.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.29", "root_name": "Sama\u1e47abr\u0101hma\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.29", "blurb": "An ascetic who understands dependent origination will realize the goal of the ascetic life.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.30", "root_name": "Dutiyasama\u1e47abr\u0101hma\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.30", "blurb": "An ascetic who understands dependent origination may well escape those conditions.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: The Yizu jing (Arthavargīya) in two fascicles at T 198 was translated into Chinese by Zhi Qian 支謙 between the 2nd year of Huang Wu 黃武 and 2nd year of Jianxing 建興, Wu dynasty 呉 (223–253 CE). This corresponds to the Aṭṭhakavagga, the fourth of the five chapters of the Sutta Nipāta (Sn 766–975) of the Pāli Tipitaka, though this Chinese version has additional passages. Since the Pāli version is cited by other Pāli and Sanskrit canonical texts, traditionally the Aṭṭhaka vagga was taken to be an important encapsulation of key teachings, while scholars consider it one of the earliest compositions included in the Tipitaka. Its continuing influence amongst Buddhists is illustrated by the fact that noteworthy later citations of the text include Asaṅga in the Bodhisattvabhūmi and Vasubandhu in the Abhidharmakośa-bhāṣya.

translated_name: Linked Discourses on Gains and Honor
blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Gains and Honor” contains 43 discourses warning the mendicants of the terrible dangers inherent in material possessions and love of popularity and honors.

[{"uid": "sn22.73", "root_name": "Ass\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.73", "blurb": "Only a noble disciple truly understand the five aggregates\u2019 gratification, drawback, and escape.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.74", "root_name": "Samudayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.74", "blurb": "Only a noble disciple truly understand the five aggregates\u2019 origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.75", "root_name": "Dutiyasamudayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.75", "blurb": "Only a noble disciple truly understand the five aggregates\u2019 origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.76", "root_name": "Arahantasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.76", "blurb": "One who is freed after truly understanding the aggregates is a perfected one. They are the best of beings, even up to the pinnacle of existence. A set of verses extols the perfected ones.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.77", "root_name": "Dutiyaarahantasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.77", "blurb": "One who is freed after truly understanding the aggregates is a perfected one. They are the best of beings, even up to the pinnacle of existence. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.78", "root_name": "S\u012bhasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.78", "blurb": "When a lion emerges from its lair and roars, animals are terrified. Similarly, when the Buddha teaches of the impermanence of the aggregates, even the gods are filled with fear. This is illustrated with a set of verses.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.79", "root_name": "Khajjan\u012byasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.79", "blurb": "One of the most extensive discourses in this collection begins with the Buddha saying that when anyone recollects a past life, all they are recollecting is the five aggregates. He then gives a distinctive set of definitions of the aggregates in terms of their functions, and discusses them from various aspects.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.80", "root_name": "Pi\u1e47\u1e0dolyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.80", "blurb": "While staying at Kapilavatthu the Buddha dismissed the the Sangha for misbehaving. Later he decided to support them for the sake of the young mendicants. He reminds them that their livelihood is considered a lowly one, and that one should let go of bad thoughts and wrong views, and see the aggregates as impermanent. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.81", "root_name": "P\u0101lileyyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.81", "blurb": "Leaving behind the quarreling monks at Kosambi, the Buddha went to stay in the empty forest at P\u0101rileyyaka. \u0100nanda brings some mendicants to receive a teaching, and one of them wonders how to see so as to end defilements in this very life. The Buddha teaches the 37 practices that lead to awakening, and then goes on to show that various ways of regarding the aggregates are conditioned phenomena.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn22.82", "root_name": "Pu\u1e47\u1e47amasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 22.82", "blurb": "On a sabbath day with the Sangha at S\u0101vatthi, the Buddha answers a series of ten questions on the aggregates.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses with Brahmās” contains 15 discourses featuring high brahmanical deities. Most commonly we meet the “Great Brahmā”, regarded as the creator God, but he is merely one of a class of deities, and here we meet several others. Brahmā is depicted here and elsewhere in early Buddhist texts in a respectful way, regarded as a glorious deity reborn in his realm due to powerful good kamma. As here, he frequently acts as a champion for the Buddhist cause. However, like all the gods, he is still under the influence of delusion and has nor escaped rebirth.

[{"uid": "sn41.1", "root_name": "Sa\u1e41yojanasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 41.1", "blurb": "Citta the householder hears of a conversation among the monks regarding the distinction between the fetters and the things that are fettered. He goes to ask them on this topic, but they are unable to give a satisfactory answer, so he explained it to them. It is desire that is the fetter, like the yoke that binds two oxen. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn41.2", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamaisidattasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 41.2", "blurb": "Citta the householder invites some mendicants to his home for a meal. He asks them about the diversity of the elements, but only the junior monk, Isidatta, is able to answer.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn41.3", "root_name": "Dutiyaisidattasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 41.3", "blurb": "Citta the householder invites some mendicants to his home for a meal. He asks them what is the cause of the ten metaphysical questions and the 62 views of the Brahmajala Sutta, but only the junior monk, Isidatta, is able to answer. Citta realizes that Isidatta is in fact an unseen friend of his from Avant\u012b. He offers to support him with requisites, but Isidatta left, never to return.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn41.4", "root_name": "Mahakap\u0101\u1e6dih\u0101riyasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 41.4", "blurb": "Citta the householder invites some mendicants to his home for a meal. When they left he followed them, and witnessed the junior monk Venerable Mahaka performing a psychic feat. Citta approached Mahaka in his hut and asked him to demonstrate his skills, and Mahaka obliged. Citta offers to support him with requisites, but Mahaka left, never to return.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn41.5", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamak\u0101mabh\u016bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 41.5", "blurb": "Venerable Ka\u0304mabhu\u0304 asks Citta to explain an enigmatic verse on a \u201cone-spoked chariot\u201d. After a brief consideration, Citta is able to explain it in detail.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn41.6", "root_name": "Dutiyak\u0101mabh\u016bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 41.6", "blurb": "Citta asks Ka\u0304mabhu\u0304 about the different kinds of processes (sa\u1e45kh\u0101ra) in a series of questions that lead to the most profound of meditation experiences. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn41.7", "root_name": "Godattasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 41.7", "blurb": "Venerable Godatta asks Citta whether the liberations of measurelessness, nothingness, emptiness, and signlessness are different states, or just different words for the same thing. Citta explains that they are both: they are terms for different meditation experiences, but may also be used of perfection or arahantship.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn41.8", "root_name": "Niga\u1e47\u1e6dhan\u0101\u1e6daputtasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 41.8", "blurb": "The Jain leader Mah\u0101v\u012bra, known as Niga\u1e47\u1e6dha Na\u0304taputa in the Buddhist tradition, is visited by Citta. Mah\u0101v\u012bra asks him whether he believes in a certain state of immersion. When Citta replies that he doesn\u2019t go by faith in the Buddha on this point, Mah\u0101v\u012bra is delighted. But it turns out Citta doesn\u2019t need faith, as he experiences such a state for himself.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn41.9", "root_name": "Acelakassapasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 41.9", "blurb": "Citta meets with the naked ascetic Kassapa, an old friend of his, and asks what gains he has realized from the spiritual life. Kassapa admits he has realized no higher attainments, whereupon Citta reveals he has realized many such attainments. Kassapa decides to ordain as a Buddhist mendicant.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn41.10", "root_name": "Gil\u0101nadassanasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 41.10", "blurb": "When Citta was on his deathbed, rather than receiving comfort, he gave comfort and teaching to those present.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Views” contains 96 discourses on views, methodically analyzed through the lens of the aggregates. A wide variety of views is assessed, most of which are familiar from elsewhere in the canon, although the first one is unique.

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Fairies” is the third of four similar sections dealing with the modes in which various semi-celestial beings may be reborn. The current chapter is on the “fairies” or gandhabbas, who take on a number of benign aspects as minor deities associated with music, childbirth, and as here, plants.
