translated_name: The Group of Linked Discourses Beginning With the Six Sense Fields
blurb: The “Book of the Six Sense Fields” is the fourth of the five books of the Linked Discourses. It is named after the first and longest saṁyutta, which deals with the core Buddhist teaching of the six sense fields. The second saṁyutta on Feelings also deals with a major doctrinal topic. The remaining eight saṁyuttas deal with miscellaneous secondary themes, some organized by subject, others by person.
children: [{"uid": "sn35", "root_name": "Sa\u1e37\u0101yatanasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on the Six Sense Fields ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The number of discourses in the \u201cLinked Discourses on the Six Sense Fields\u201d varies between editions, mainly due to the way repetitions are counted; SuttaCentral follows Bhikkhu Bodhi\u2019s translation in counting 248 discourses. The six sense fields complement the five aggregates as the summary of the noble truth of suffering. Where the aggregates focus on the functional structure of experience as basis for views of self, the emphasis here is on how sense experience stimulates desire. Despite this difference in orientation, the two collections share much in common, and often the exact same template is applied in both cases. The six sense fields are the means through which the world is known, and so each of them has an \u201cinner\u201d and an \u201couter\u201d aspect\u2014the \u201ceye\u201d and \u201csights\u201d, etc. Though common, it\u2019s best to avoid thinking of the external sense field as the \u201cobject\u201d, since in the suttas they are depicted in relation to the observing mind, and not as independently existing entities. This is straightforward until we come to the last sense, the \u201cmind\u201d and \u201cthoughts\u201d or \u201cmental phenomena\u201d. Just to clear up a possible confusion, this \u201csixth sense\u201d is simply the mental faculty, and has nothing to do with psychic powers. The outer aspect is dhamm\u0101, a term so ambiguous its translation is always difficult. Here it refers to anything that may be known directly by the mind, distinct from the five senses. The most technically correct translation is probably \u201cmental phenomena\u201d, but \u201cthought\u2019 may be used as a more colloquial rendering, so long as it includes ideas, imagination, and so on, not just verbalized cognition.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 35", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 351}, {"uid": "sn36", "root_name": "Vedan\u0101sa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on Feelings ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on Feelings\u201d contains 31 discourses on the three kinds of feeling. In Sinhalese-script manuscripts, this is reckoned as the last portion of the section on six sense fields. The term \u201cfeelings\u201d renders vedan\u0101, which is the simple affective or hedonic tone of experience as pleasant, painful, and neutral, rather than the complex states we call \u201cemotions\u201d. In the process of experience, feeling emerges from sense contact, and stimulates craving. One of the aims of mental development is to first loosen, then eliminate that second link, so that one still has feelings, but does not experience craving for them. The current collection includes a number of rich and significant discourses on this theme.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 36", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 62}, {"uid": "sn37", "root_name": "M\u0101tug\u0101masa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on Females ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on Females\u201d contains 34 discourses regarding various qualities of women. Note that the Pali texts use two distinct terms for women, itth\u012b and m\u0101tug\u0101ma, the latter of which can be translated as \u201cfemales\u201d. These texts deal with such themes as the kinds of suffering unique to women, why women are reborn in various states, or the qualities that lead to a woman taking charge in her marriage.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 37", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 34}, {"uid": "sn38", "root_name": "Jambukh\u0101dakasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses with Jambukh\u0101daka ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses with Jambukh\u0101daka\u201d contains 16 discourses recording the answers given by S\u0101riputta to the questions of a wanderer named Jambukh\u0101daka. The questions cover a wide range of themes, from the nature of extinguishment to the difficulty of practicing the Dhamma. This chapter is practically identical to the next, differing only in the name of the wanderer.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 38", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 16}, {"uid": "sn39", "root_name": "S\u0101ma\u1e47\u1e0dakasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses with S\u0101ma\u1e47\u1e0daka ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses with S\u0101ma\u1e47\u1e0daka\u201d contains 16 discourses recording the answers given by S\u0101riputta to the questions of a wanderer named S\u0101ma\u1e47\u1e0daka. The questions cover a wide range of themes, from the nature of extinguishment to the difficulty of practicing the Dhamma. This chapter is practically identical to the previous, differing only in the name of the wanderer, and the Pali editions abbreviate, instructing that it is to be expanded.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 39", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn40", "root_name": "Moggall\u0101nasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses with Moggall\u0101na ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses with Moggall\u0101na\u201d contains 11 discourses featuring Moggall\u0101na, one of the chief disciples. He tells the monks of his struggles in meditation, and how he was encouraged by the Buddha. In the last two discourses, he visit the heavens and teaches the gods.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 40", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 11}, {"uid": "sn41", "root_name": "Cittasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses with Citta the Householder ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses with Citta\u201d contains 10 discourses featuring the householder Citta, who was praised by the Buddha as the foremost lay disciple in speaking on the Dhamma. Here he engages in a series of insightful and sharp-witted dialogues with various monks. Citta emerges as a distinctive personality, knowledgeable and witty, curious and incisive, with no lack of humor. But he is more than just a clever speaker, for he also lays claim to exalted meditation and spiritual attainments.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 41", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 10}, {"uid": "sn42", "root_name": "G\u0101ma\u1e47isa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses with Chiefs ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses with Chiefs\u201d contains 13 discourses featuring various headmen or chiefs. They sometimes ask questions relating to their professions, from entertainers to warriors, while several discourses touch on familiar Dhamma themes, such as overcoming anger, the validity of brahmanical rites, or whether monastics should use money. Some of the chiefs are quite adversarial, aiming to trip up the Buddha in debate, or accusing him of being a magician. In the end, though, the Buddha\u2019s compassionate and measured responses win them over.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 42", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 14}, {"uid": "sn43", "root_name": "Asa\u1e45khatasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on the Unconditioned ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on the Unconditioned\u201d contains 44 discourses on the theme of the unconditioned, i.e. nibb\u0101na or \u201cextinguishment\u201d. They focus on the various practices that lead to the unconditioned. This chapter includes an extensive range of terms and idioms describing the final goal of Buddhist practice.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 43", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 30}, {"uid": "sn44", "root_name": "Aby\u0101katasa\u1e41yutta", "translated_name": "Linked Discourses on the Undeclared ", "acronym": null, "blurb": "The \u201cLinked Discourses on the Undeclared\u201d contains 44 discourses on the theme of the ten \u201cundeclared\u201d questions. These are a stock series of metaphysical hypotheses, which the Buddha dismissed as being based on the implicit assumption of a self, and hence as being counterproductive to liberation. The first discourse here features a conversation between King Pasenadi and the nun Khem\u0101 on this topic.", "node_type": "branch", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": "SN 44", "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 22}]

[{"uid": "ja181", "root_name": "Asadisaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Prince Peerless ", "acronym": "Ja 181", "blurb": "\u201cPrince Peerless, skilled in archers\u2019 craft\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Jetavana, about the Great Renunciation. The Master said, \u201cNot now alone, Brethren, has the Tathagata made the Great Renunciation: in other days he also renounced the white parasol of royalty, and did the same.\u201d And he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja182", "root_name": "Sa\u1e45g\u0101m\u0101vacaraj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "At Home in Battle ", "acronym": "Ja 182", "blurb": "\u201cO Elephant, a hero thou\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while staying at Jetavana, about Elder Nanda.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja183", "root_name": "V\u0101lodakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "A Nasty Drink ", "acronym": "Ja 183", "blurb": "\u201cThis sorry draught\u201d\u2014This story the Master told whilst at Jetavana, about five hundred persons who ate broken meat.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja184", "root_name": "Giridattaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Groom Giridatta ", "acronym": "Ja 184", "blurb": "\u201cThanks to the groom\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while staying in Veluvana Park, about keeping bad company. The circumstances have been already recounted under the Mahilamukha Jataka. Again, as before, the Master said: \u201cIn former days this Brother kept bad company just as he does now.\u201d Then he told an old story.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja185", "root_name": "Anabhiratij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Dissatsfaction ", "acronym": "Ja 185", "blurb": "\u201cThick, muddy water\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while staying in Jetavana, and it was about a young brahmin.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja186", "root_name": "Dadhiv\u0101hanaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The King Carried on Curds ", "acronym": "Ja 186", "blurb": "\u201cSweet was once the mango\u2019s savour\u201d\u2014This story the Master told whilst dwelling in Jetavana, on the subject of keeping bad company. The circumstances were the same as above. Again the Master said: \u201cBrethren, bad company is evil and injurious; why should one talk of the evil effects of had company on human beings? In days long gone by, even a vegetable, a mango tree, whose sweet fruit was a dish fit for the gods, turned sour and bitter through the influence of a noisome and bitter nimb tree.\u201d Then he told a story.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja187", "root_name": "Catuma\u1e6d\u1e6dhaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Polished in Four Ways ", "acronym": "Ja 187", "blurb": "\u201cSit and sing\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while staying at Jetavana, about an old Brother.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja188", "root_name": "S\u012bhakotthuj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Lion-Jackal ", "acronym": "Ja 188", "blurb": "\u201cLion\u2019s claws and lion\u2019s paws\u201d\u2014This is a story told by the Master whilst at Jetavana, about Kokalika.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja189", "root_name": "S\u012bhacammaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Jackal Wearing Lionskin ", "acronym": "Ja 189", "blurb": "\u201cNor lion, nor tiger I see\u201d\u2014This story, like the last, was about Kokalika, told by the Master in Jetavana. This time he wanted to intone. The Master. on hearing of it told the following story.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja190", "root_name": "S\u012bl\u0101nisa\u1e41saj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Benefits of Morality ", "acronym": "Ja 190", "blurb": "\u201cBehold the fruit of sacrifice\u201d\u2014This story the Master told whilst staying in Jetavana, about a believing layman.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

staying in Jetavana, about the prison-house.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja202", "root_name": "Ke\u1e37is\u012blaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The King Who Pranked the Elderly ", "acronym": "Ja 202", "blurb": "\u201cGeese, herons, elephants\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, about Lakuntaka the venerable and good.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja203", "root_name": "Kha\u1e47\u1e0daj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Love For the Families of Snakes ", "acronym": "Ja 203", "blurb": "\u201cVirupakkha snakes I love\u201d\u2014This story the Master told whilst living at Jetavana, about a certain brother.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja204", "root_name": "V\u012brakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Crow Named Heroic ", "acronym": "Ja 204", "blurb": "\u201cO have you seen\u201d\u2014This story the Master told, while dwelling at Jetavana, about imitating the Buddha.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja205", "root_name": "Ga\u1e45geyyaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Fish of the Ganges ", "acronym": "Ja 205", "blurb": "\u201cFine are the fish\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, about two young Brethren.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja206", "root_name": "Kuru\u1e45gamigaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Antelope ", "acronym": "Ja 206", "blurb": "\u201cCome, Tortoise\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Veluvana, about Devadatta. News came to the Master that Devadatta was plotting his death. \u201cAh, Brethren,\u201d said he, \u201cit was just the same long ago; Devadatta tried then to kill me, as he is trying now.\u201d And he told them this story.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja207", "root_name": "Assakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "How the Queen Loved a Worm More Than King Assaka ", "acronym": "Ja 207", "blurb": "\u201cOnce with the great king Assaka\u201d\u2014This story the Master told whilst staying in Jetavana, about some one who was distracted by the recollection of a former wife. He asked the Brother whether he were really lovesick. The man said, Yes. \u201cWhom are you in love with?\u201d the Master continued. \u201cMy late wife,\u201d was the reply. Then the Master said, \u201cNot this once only, Brother, have you been full of desire for this woman; in olden days her love brought you to great misery.\u201d And he told a story.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja208", "root_name": "Susum\u0101raj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Crocodile ", "acronym": "Ja 208", "blurb": "\u201cRose-apple, jack fruit\u201d\u2014This story the Master told at Jetavana, about Devadatta\u2019s attempts to murder him. When he heard of these attempts, the Master said, This is not the first time that Devadatta has tried to murder me; he did the same before, and yet could not so much as make me afraid.\u201d Then he told this story.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja209", "root_name": "Kukku\u1e6daj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Old Chook ", "acronym": "Ja 209", "blurb": "\u201cTrees a many have I seen\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, about a Brother who was one of the fellow-students of Elder Sariputta, Captain of the Faith.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja210", "root_name": "Kandagalakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Woodpecker Named Eatbulb ", "acronym": "Ja 210", "blurb": "\u201cO friend\u201d\u2014This was told by the Master, during a stay in Veluvana, about Devadatta\u2019s attempts to imitate him. When he heard of these attempts to imitate him, the Master said, \u201cThis is not the first time Devadatta has destroyed himself by imitating me; the same thing happened before.\u201d Then he told this story.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

[{"uid": "ja497", "root_name": "M\u0101ta\u1e45gaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "M\u0101ta\u1e45ga the Wise ", "acronym": "Ja 497", "blurb": "\u201cWhence comest thou\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling in Jetavana, about the hereditary king Udena. At that time, the reverend Pindola-bharadvaja passing from Jetavana through the air, used generally to pass the heat of the day in king Udena\u2019s park at Kosambi. The Elder, we are told, had in a former existence been king, and for a long time had enjoyed glory in that very park with his retinue. By virtue of the good then by him performed, he used to sit there in the heat of the day, enjoying the bliss of Attainment which was its fruit.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja498", "root_name": "Cittasambh\u016btaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Tale of Citta and Sambh\u016bta ", "acronym": "Ja 498", "blurb": "\u201cEvery good deed\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling in Jetavana, about two fellow-priests of the reverend Maha-kassapa, who lived happily together. This pair, we are told, were most friendly, and had share for share in all things with the utmost fairness: even when they walked for alms, together they went out and together came in, nor could they endure to be apart. In the Hall of Truth sat the Brethren, praising their friendship, when the Master came in, and asked what they talked of as they sat there. They told him; and he replied, \u201cTheir friendship in one existence, Brethren, is nothing to wonder at; for wise men of old kept friendliness unbroken throughout three or four different existences.\u201d So saying, he told them a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja499", "root_name": "Sivij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Prince Sivi ", "acronym": "Ja 499", "blurb": "\u201cIf there be any human\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, about the gift incomparable. The circumstances have been fully told in Book Viii. under the Sovira Birth. But here the king, on the seventh day, gave all the requisites and asked for thanks; but the Master went away without thanking him. After breakfast the king went to the monastery, and said, \u201cWhy did you return no thanks, Sir?\u201d The Master said, \u201cThe people were unpurified, your majesty.\u201d He went on to declare the Law, reciting the stanza that begins \u201cTo heaven the avaricious shall not go.\u201d The king, pleased at heart, did reverence to the Tathagata by presenting an outer robe of the Sivi country, worth a thousand pieces of money; then he returned to the city.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja500", "root_name": "Sir\u012bmantaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Question of Sirimanta ", "acronym": "Ja 500", "blurb": "\u201cOf wisdom full\u201d\u2014This Problem of Sirimanda will be given at large in the Maha-ummagga.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja501", "root_name": "Roha\u1e47amigaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Golden Deer ", "acronym": "Ja 501", "blurb": "\u201cIn fear of death\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling in the Bamboo Grove, about the reverend Ananda, who made renunciation of his life. This renunciation will be described in Book Xxi., under the Culla-hamsa Birth, the Subduing of Dhanapala. When this reverend man had renounced his life for the Master\u2019s sake, they gossiped about it in the Hall of Truth: \u201cSirs, the reverend Ananda, having attained to the detailed knowledge of the course of religious training, renounced his life for the Dasabala.\u201d The Master came in, asking what they spoke of as they sat there. They told him. Said he, \u201cBrothers, this is not the first time he has laid down his life for my sake; he has done it before.\u201d Then he told them a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja502", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37aha\u1e41saj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Shorter Tale of the Golden Goose ", "acronym": "Ja 502", "blurb": "\u201cThere go the birds\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling in the Bamboo Grove, about Elder Ananda\u2019s renunciation of life. Then also the Brethren were talking in the Hall of Truth about the Elder\u2019s good qualities, when the Master came in and asked them what they sat talking of there. He said, \u201cThis is not the first time, Brethren, that Ananda has renounced his life for my sake, but he did the same before.\u201d And then he told them a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja503", "root_name": "Sattigumbaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Parrot Named Bristling Spears ", "acronym": "Ja 503", "blurb": "\u201cWith, a great host\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while sojourning in the deer-park Maddakucchi, about Devadatta. When Devadatta threw the stone, and a fragment pierced the Blessed One\u2019s foot, there was great pain in it. Numbers of the Brethren gathered to see the Tathagata. Now when the Blessed One saw the people gathered together, he said to them, \u201cBrethren, this place is crowded: there will be a great gathering. Come now, carry me in a litter to Maddakucchi.\u201d So then the Brethren did. Jivaka made the Tathagata\u2019s foot well. The Brethren sitting before the Master talked of it: \u201cSirs, a sinner is Devadatta and sinners are all his people; the sinner keeps company with the sinful.\u201d The Master asked, \u201cWhat do ye talk of, Brethren?\u201d They told him. Said he, \u201cIt has been so before, and this is not the first time Devadatta the sinner has kept sinful company.\u201d Then he told them a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja504", "root_name": "Bhall\u0101tiyaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "King Bhall\u0101tiya and the Pixies ", "acronym": "Ja 504", "blurb": "\u201cWas a king Bhallatiya\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana about Mallika, the Jessamine Bride. One day we are told there was a quarrel between her and the king about conjugal rights. The king was angry and would not look at her. \u201cI suppose,\u201d she thought, \u201cthe Tathagata does not know that the king is wroth with me.\u201d When the Master learnt of it, next day, he sought alms in Benares, accompanied by the Brethren, and then repaired to the gate of the king\u2019s palace. The king came to meet him, and relieved him of his bowl, took him up on the terrace, set the Brethren down in due order, gave them the water of welcome, offered them excellent food; after the meal he sat down on one side. \u201cWhy,\u201d asked the Master, \u201cwhy does not Mallika appear?\u201d He said, \u201c\u2019Tis her own foolish pride in her prosperity.\u201d The Master said, \u201cO great king! long, long ago when you were a fairy, you kept apart for one night from your mate, and then went mourning for seven hundred years.\u201d Then at his request, he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja505", "root_name": "Somanassaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Prince Happiness ", "acronym": "Ja 505", "blurb": "\u201cWho does thee harm, etc.\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling at Jetavana, how Devadatta went about to slay him. Then the Master said, \u201cThis is not the first time, Brethren, that Devadatta has sought to slay me, but he did the same thing before.\u201d Then he told them a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja506", "root_name": "Campeyyaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Dragon of Campeyya ", "acronym": "Ja 506", "blurb": "\u201cWho is it like\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling in Jetavana, about the fast-day vows. The Master said, \u201cIt is well done, lay Brethren, that ye have taken upon you the fast-day vows. Wise men of old likewise even renounced the glory of being a Serpent King, and lived under these vows.\u201d Then at their request he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja507", "root_name": "Mah\u0101palobhanaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Longer Tale of Allure ", "acronym": "Ja 507", "blurb": "\u201cFrom Brahma\u2019s heaven\u201d\u2014This story the Master told while dwelling in Jetavana, about the defilement of the sanctified. The circumstances have already been given. Here again said the Master, \u201cWomen cause defilement even in sanctified souls,\u201d and then told this story of the past. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja508", "root_name": "Pa\u00f1capa\u1e47\u1e0ditaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Five Wise Men ", "acronym": "Ja 508", "blurb": "The Birth of the Five Wise Men will be given in the Maha-ummagga.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja509", "root_name": "Hatthip\u0101laj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Elephant Driver ", "acronym": "Ja 509", "blurb": "\u201cAt last we see\u201d\u2014This story the Master told, while dwelling at Jetavana, about the Renunciation. Then with these words,\u2014\u201cIt is not the first time, Brethren, that the Tathagata made the Renunciation, but it was so before\u201d\u2014the Master told them a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja510", "root_name": "Ayogharaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Prince of the Iron House ", "acronym": "Ja 510", "blurb": "\u201cLife once conceived, etc.\u201d This story the Master told about the Great Renunciation. Here again he said, \u201cThis is not the first time, Brethren, that the Tathagata has made the Great Renunciation, for he did the same before.\u201d And he told them a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

Said the Master on this occasion, \u201cIs it true, as I hear, Brother, that you are passion-tost?\u201d", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja35", "root_name": "Va\u1e6d\u1e6dakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Quail ", "acronym": "Ja 35", "blurb": "\u201cWith, wings that fly not.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master, whilst on an alms-pilgrimage through Magadha, about the going-out of a jungle fire.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", blurb: The “Linked Discourses with Rāhula” contains 22 discourses with the Buddha interrogating his son Rāhula on fundamental doctrines such as the aggregates or sense fields.

blurb: The “Linked Discourses on Feelings” contains 31 discourses on the three kinds of feeling. In Sinhalese-script manuscripts, this is reckoned as the last portion of the section on six sense fields. The term “feelings” renders vedanā, which is the simple affective or hedonic tone of experience as pleasant, painful, and neutral, rather than the complex states we call “emotions”. In the process of experience, feeling emerges from sense contact, and stimulates craving. One of the aims of mental development is to first loosen, then eliminate that second link, so that one still has feelings, but does not experience craving for them. The current collection includes a number of rich and significant discourses on this theme.

[{"uid": "ja531", "root_name": "Kusaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "King Grass ", "acronym": "Ja 531", "blurb": "\u201cThis realm\u201d\u2014This was a tale the Master, while dwelling at Jetavana, told about a backsliding Brother. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja532", "root_name": "So\u1e47anandaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Brothers So\u1e47a and Nanda ", "acronym": "Ja 532", "blurb": "\u201cAngel or minstrel-god\u201d\u2014This was a story told by the Master, while living at Jetavana, about a Brother who supported his mother. The circumstance which led up to it was the same as that related in the Sama Birth. But on this occasion the Master said, \u201cBrethren, do not take offence at this Brother. Sages of old, though they were offered rule over all India, refused to accept it and supported their parents\u201d: and so saying he told a story of the past.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: This chapter, which has parallels in Chinese, and received an early commentary in the Niddesa, is often regarded as one of the earliest texts in the canon. Shorn of literary embellishments, it is direct and  powerful. A distinctive aspect is the critique of meaningless debates and attachments to views. The Attadaṇḍa Sutta gives an alternative account of the reasons for the Buddha’s going forth.
children: [{"uid": "snp4.1", "root_name": "K\u0101masutta", "translated_name": "Sensual Pleasures ", "acronym": "Snp 4.1", "blurb": "The drawbacks of sensual desires.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "snp4.2", "root_name": "Guha\u1e6d\u1e6dhakasutta", "translated_name": "Eight on the Cave ", "acronym": "Snp 4.2", "blurb": "Those who remain attached to the body, to sensuality, and to their sense of \u201cmine\u201d will have a hard time freeing themselves from fear of death and from further becoming.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "snp4.3", "root_name": "Du\u1e6d\u1e6dha\u1e6d\u1e6dhakasutta", "translated_name": "Eight on Malice ", "acronym": "Snp 4.3", "blurb": "Freedom isn\u2019t to be found by boasting of your precepts and practices or by debating your views.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "snp4.4", "root_name": "Suddha\u1e6d\u1e6dhakasutta", "translated_name": "Eight on the Pure ", "acronym": "Snp 4.4", "blurb": "How to avoid the trap of letting go of one thing only to cling to something more subtle.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "snp4.5", "root_name": "Parama\u1e6d\u1e6dhakasutta", "translated_name": "Eight on the Ultimate ", "acronym": "Snp 4.5", "blurb": "The conceit that comes from clinging to practices or views\u2014even if they\u2019re supreme\u2014is a fetter preventing full freedom.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "snp4.6", "root_name": "Jar\u0101sutta", "translated_name": "Old Age ", "acronym": "Snp 4.6", "blurb": "Life is short. Possessiveness brings grief. Freedom comes from abandoning any sense of \u201cmine.\u201d", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "snp4.7", "root_name": "Tissametteyyasutta", "translated_name": "To Tissametteyya on the Dangers of Sex ", "acronym": "Snp 4.7", "blurb": "The drawbacks of falling away from the celibate life.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "snp4.8", "root_name": "Pas\u016brasutta", "translated_name": "To Pas\u016bra on Debate ", "acronym": "Snp 4.8", "blurb": "The drawbacks of engaging in debates, for winners and losers alike.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "snp4.9", "root_name": "M\u0101ga\u1e47\u1e0diyasutta", "translated_name": "With M\u0101ga\u1e47\u1e0diya ", "acronym": "Snp 4.9", "blurb": "M\u0101gandiya offers the Buddha his daughter in marriage. The Buddha refuses and further subdues M\u0101gandiya\u2019s pride by describing a state of peace that M\u0101gandiya doesn\u2019t understand.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "snp4.10", "root_name": "Pur\u0101bhedasutta", "translated_name": "Before the Breakup ", "acronym": "Snp 4.10", "blurb": "How to live at peace.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "snp4.11", "root_name": "Kalahaviv\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": "Quarrels and Disputes ", "acronym": "Snp 4.11", "blurb": "The Buddha is questioned on the source of quarrels and disputes, and on the highest level of spiritual attainment.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "snp4.12", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37aby\u016bhasutta", "translated_name": "The Shorter Discourse on Arrayed For Battle ", "acronym": "Snp 4.12", "blurb": "If the truth is one, how should a person behave in a world where many different truths are taught?", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "snp4.13", "root_name": "Mah\u0101by\u016bhasutta", "translated_name": "The Longer Discourse on Arrayed For Battle ", "acronym": "Snp 4.13", "blurb": "How to maintain freedom in a world full of disputes.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "snp4.14", "root_name": "Tuva\u1e6dakasutta", "translated_name": "Speedy ", "acronym": "Snp 4.14", "blurb": "The attitudes and behavior of a monk training for the sake of total release.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "snp4.15", "root_name": "Attada\u1e47\u1e0dasutta", "translated_name": "Taking Up Arms ", "acronym": "Snp 4.15", "blurb": "The Buddha speaks in poignant terms of the sa\u1e41vega that led him to leave the household life. He concludes with recommendations for practice and a description of the person who has attained the goal of true peace and security.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "snp4.16", "root_name": "S\u0101riputtasutta", "translated_name": "The Questions of S\u0101riputta ", "acronym": "Snp 4.16", "blurb": "When a monk, disaffected with the world, takes up the life of seclusion, what fears should he overcome? What dangers should he beware of? How should he train to blow away the impurities in his heart?", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}]

[{"uid": "ja11", "root_name": "Lakkha\u1e47amigaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Lucky Deer ", "acronym": "Ja 11", "blurb": "\u201cThe upright man.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master in the Bamboo-grove near Rajagaha about Devadatta. The story of Devadatta will be related, up to the date of the Abhimara-employment, in the Khandahala-jataka; up to the date of his dismissal from the office of Treasurer, in the Cullahamsa-jataka; and, up to the date of his being swallowed up by the earth, in the Sixteenth Book in the Samudda-vanija-jataka.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja12", "root_name": "Nigrodhamigaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Banyan Deer ", "acronym": "Ja 12", "blurb": "\u201cKeep only with the Banyan Deer.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about the mother of the Elder named Prince Kassapa. The daughter, we learn, of a wealthy merchant of Rajagaha was deeply rooted in goodness and scorned all temporal things; she had reached her final existence, and within her breast, like a lamp in a pitcher, glowed her sure hope of winning Arahatship. As soon as she reached knowledge of herself, she took no joy in a worldly life but yearned to renounce the world. With this aim, she said to her mother and father, \u201cMy dear parents, my heart takes no joy in a worldly life; fain would I embrace the saving doctrine of the Buddha. Suffer me to take the vows.\u201d", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja13", "root_name": "Ka\u1e47\u1e0dij\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Dart ", "acronym": "Ja 13", "blurb": "\u201cCursed be the dart of love.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about the temptation caused to Brethren by the wives of their mundane life. This will be related in the Indriya-jataka in the Eighth Book. Said the Blessed One to the Brother, \u201cBrother, it was because of this very woman that in bygone days you met your death and were roasted over glowing embers.\u201d The Brethren asked the Blessed One to explain this. The Blessed One made clear what had been concealed from them by re-birth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja14", "root_name": "V\u0101tamigaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Wind-antelope ", "acronym": "Ja 14", "blurb": "\u201cThere\u2019s nothing worse.\u201d This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about the Elder Tissa, called Direct-alms the Less. Tradition says that, while the Master was dwelling at the Bamboo-grove near Rajagaha, the scion of a wealthy house, Prince Tissa by name, coming one day to the Bamboo-grove and there hearing a discourse from the Master, wished to join the Brotherhood, but, being refused because his parents would not give their consent, obtained their consent by following Rattha-pala\u2019s example and refusing food for seven days, and finally took the vows with the Master.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja15", "root_name": "Khar\u0101diyaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "With Khar\u0101diya ", "acronym": "Ja 15", "blurb": "\u201cFor when a deer.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about an unruly Brother. Tradition says that this Brother was unruly and would not heed admonition. Accordingly, the Master asked him, saying, \u201cIs it true, as they say, that you are unruly and will not heed admonition?\u201d", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja16", "root_name": "Tipallatthamigaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Deer With Three Ruses ", "acronym": "Ja 16", "blurb": "\u201cIn all three postures.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while dwelling do the Badarika Monastery in Kosambi, about the Elder Rahula whose heart was set on observing the rules of the Brotherhood.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja17", "root_name": "M\u0101lutaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Breeze ", "acronym": "Ja 17", "blurb": "\u201cIn light or dark.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about two Brethren who had joined the Brotherhood in their old age. Tradition says that they were living in a forest-dwelling in the Kosala country, and that one was named the Elder Dark and the other the Elder Light. Now one day Light said to Dark, \u201cSir, at what time does what is called cold appear?\u201d \u201cIt appears in the dark half of the month.\u201d And one day Dark said to Light, \u201cSir, at what time does what is called cold appear?\u201d \u201cIt appears in the light half of the month.\u201d", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja18", "root_name": "Matakabhattaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Feasts for the Dead ", "acronym": "Ja 18", "blurb": "\u201cIf folk but knew.\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about Feasts for the Dead. For at this time the folk were putting to death goats, sheep, and other animals, and offering them up as what is called a Feast for the Dead, for the sake of their departed kinsmen. Finding them thus engaged, the Brethren asked the Master, saying, \u201cJust now, sir, the folk are taking the lives of many living creatures and offering them up as what is called a Feast for the Dead. Can it be, sir, that there is any good in this?\u201d", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja19", "root_name": "\u0100y\u0101citabhattaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Sacrifice to Fulfill a Wish ", "acronym": "Ja 19", "blurb": "\u201cTake thought of life hereafter.\u201d This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about the offering of a sacrifice under vow to gods. Tradition says that in those days folk when going a journey on business, used to slay living creatures and offer them as a sacrifice to gods, and set out on their way, after making this vow,\u2014\u201cIf we come safely back with a profit, we will give you another sacrifice.\u201d And when they did come safely back with a profit, the Idea that this was all due to gods made them slay a number of living creatures and offer them up as a sacrifice to obtain a release from their vow.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja20", "root_name": "Na\u1e37ap\u0101naj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Drinking With Straws ", "acronym": "Ja 20", "blurb": "\u201cI found the footprints.\u201d This story was told by the Master whilst journeying on an alms-pilgrimage through Kosala, when he had come to the village of Nalaka-pana (Cane-drink) and was dwelling at Ketaka-vana near the Pool of Nalaka-pana, about cane-sticks. In those days the Brethren, after bathing in the Pool of Nalaka-pana, made the novices get them cane-sticks for needle-cases, but, finding them hollow throughout, went to the Master and said, \u201cSir, we had cane-sticks got in order to provide needle-cases; and from top to bottom they are quite hollow. Now how can that be?\u201d", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

blurb: The “Linked Discourses with Kassapa” contains 13 discourses featuring one of the most famous of the Buddha’s disciples, the monk Kassapa. Kassapa was an ascetic and diligent practitioner, whose sometimes critical voice was tempered by a love of nature and a tender concern for the lay community. These discourses show his magnificent spiritual attainments, and his overriding concern for the health and longevity of the Buddhist community.

[{"uid": "sn12.11", "root_name": "\u0100h\u0101rasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.11", "blurb": "The Buddha defines the four kinds of \u201cfood\u201d or \u201cnutriment\u201d, which include edible food, contact, intention, and consciousness. These are all produced by craving, and hence connect with dependent origination.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.12", "root_name": "Mo\u1e37iyaphaggunasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.12", "blurb": "Venerable Mo\u1e37iyaphagguna asks who eats the consciousness food. The Buddha says the question is improper, as it assumes a self as agent. Rather, all the factors of dependent origination are simply natural conditions and have nothing to do with a \u201cself\u201d.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "sn12.13", "root_name": "Sama\u1e47abr\u0101hma\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.13", "blurb": "One who does not understand dependent origination is no true ascetic.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.14", "root_name": "Dutiyasama\u1e47abr\u0101hma\u1e47asutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.14", "blurb": "One who does not understand dependent origination is no true ascetic.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.15", "root_name": "Kacc\u0101nagottasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.15", "blurb": "Venerable Kacca\u0304nagotta asks the Buddha about right view, and the Buddha answers that right view arises when one sees the origin and cessation of the world and is free of attachments. This sutta, brief but profound and difficult, became renowned as the only canonical reference named in N\u0101g\u0101rjuna\u2019s M\u016blamadhyamakak\u0101rik\u0101, perhaps the most famous philosophical treatise in all Buddhism.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "sn12.16", "root_name": "Dhammakathikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.16", "blurb": "One is qualified to be called a \u201cDhamma speaker\u201d if one teaches for the ending of suffering.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.17", "root_name": "Acelakassapasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.17", "blurb": "A naked ascetic named Kassapa approaches the Buddha while he is on alms round and asks whether suffering is created by oneself, by another, by both, or by chance. Explaining why he rejects all these options, the Buddha asserts that suffering arises due to conditions.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.18", "root_name": "Timbarukasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.18", "blurb": "A wanderer named Timbaruka asks the Buddha whether pleasure and pain are created by oneself, by another, by both, or by chance. Explaining why he rejects all these options, the Buddha asserts that pleasure and pain arise due to conditions.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.19", "root_name": "B\u0101lapa\u1e47\u1e0ditasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.19", "blurb": "Both the wise and the foolish have been reborn in this life due to their deeds conditioned by ignorance in past lives. But a fool continues to make the same mistakes and is reborn yet again, whereas a wise person does not.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "sn12.20", "root_name": "Paccayasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 12.20", "blurb": "The Buddha distinguishes between \u201cdependently originated phenomena\u201d\u2014the twelve factors\u2014and \u201cdependent origination\u201d\u2014the principle of conditionality. Someone who understands these things no longer worries about the past or future.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}]

blurb: The discourses in this chapter focus on equanimity in the face of pleasure and pain. There are several examples of monastic conduct of poise and balance.
children: [{"uid": "ud3.1", "root_name": "Kammavip\u0101kajasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "Ud 3.1", "blurb": "A monk meditates in pain engendered by past kamma but without being struck down by it.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "ud3.2", "root_name": "Nandasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "Ud 3.2", "blurb": "The Buddha makes a deal with his step-brother: Stay a monk, and you\u2019ll be rewarded with nymphs in the next life.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "ud3.3", "root_name": "Yasojasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "Ud 3.3", "blurb": "A group of monks, rebuked by the Buddha, take it as an encouragement to reach awakening.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "ud3.4", "root_name": "S\u0101riputtasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "Ud 3.4", "blurb": "Ven. S\u0101riputta meditates, his mind as solid as rock.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "ud3.5", "root_name": "Mah\u0101moggall\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "Ud 3.5", "blurb": "Ven. Mah\u0101 Moggall\u0101na meditates.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "ud3.6", "root_name": "Pilindavacchasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "Ud 3.6", "blurb": "Some old habits die hard.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "ud3.7", "root_name": "Sakkud\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "Ud 3.7", "blurb": "A deva-king disguises himself to give alms to Ven. Mah\u0101 Kassapa.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}, {"uid": "ud3.8", "root_name": "Pi\u1e47\u1e0dap\u0101tikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "Ud 3.8", "blurb": "The Buddha rebukes monks who are chatting about the agreeable things that one can encounter on almsround.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "ud3.9", "root_name": "Sippasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "Ud 3.9", "blurb": "More lessons in what monks should and shouldn\u2019t talk about.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "ud3.10", "root_name": "Lokasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "Ud 3.10", "blurb": "Shortly after awakening, the Buddha contemplates future rebirth.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 3}]

blurb: This chapter begins with a series of discourses set immediately after the Buddha’s awakening, which are shared with the first chapter of the Khandhakas. It establishes the fundamental thesis of Buddhism: that awakening is possible through one’s own efforts. Each discourse deals with the idea of the true “brahmin”, defined not according to hereditary caste, but freedom from defilements.

The Buddha praises them, saying that noise is a thorn to absorption.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an10.73", "root_name": "I\u1e6d\u1e6dhadhammasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.73", "blurb": "Ten desirable things that are hard to get.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an10.74", "root_name": "Va\u1e0d\u1e0dhisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.74", "blurb": "Ten aspects of prosperity.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an10.75", "root_name": "Migas\u0101l\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.75", "blurb": "The female lay disciple Migas\u0101l\u0101 questions \u0100nanda how the Buddha could have declared her father and her uncle had the same level of spiritual attainment, when one was much more strict than the other. \u0100nanda conveys this to the Buddha, who responds that only such as he can pass judgment, since the spiritual faculties of individuals are complex and hard to understand.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an10.76", "root_name": "Tayodhammasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 10.76", "blurb": "Without rebirth, old age, and death, there would be no teaching of Dhamma. blurb: The “Linked Discourses with Sakka” contains 25 discourses with verses telling stories involving Sakka, the Lord of the Thirty-Three gods. Many of these discourses are relatively lengthy, featuring substantive prose and extended dialogues in verse. Sakka is shown devoted to the Buddha, defending Buddhist virtues of kindness and forgiveness, even in the waging of war with the demons.

blurb: The “Basket of Conduct” represents an early systematization of the concept of the Bodhisattva and his path towards awakening. A selection of 34 past lives are told, each one illustrating a specific virtue developed by the Bodhisattva. It is a late text, without direct counterparts in the northern collections. Like the Buddhavaṁsa, it is part of an extensive pan-sectarian devotional literature composed in the second and first centuries BCE, presaging the birth of the Mahāyāna.

translated_name: The Chapter on the Perfected Ones
children: [{"uid": "sn7.1", "root_name": "Dhana\u00f1j\u0101n\u012bsutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 7.1", "blurb": "When a brahmin lady expresses her confidence in the Triple Gem, her husband is annoyed. She encourages him to visit the Buddha, who soothes his anger.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn7.2", "root_name": "Akkosasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 7.2", "blurb": "A brahmin visits the Buddha and unleashes a tirade of abuse, but the Buddha refuses to accept it, showing that he remains free of anger.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn7.3", "root_name": "Asurindakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 7.3", "blurb": "A brahmin visits the Buddha and abuses him, but the Buddha responds only with patience.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn7.4", "root_name": "Bila\u1e45gikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 7.4", "blurb": "Hearing that a brahmin had gone forth under the Buddha, another brahmin was upset. But once again the Buddha calms him down, pointing out that anger only harms oneself.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn7.5", "root_name": "Ahi\u1e41sakasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 7.5", "blurb": "A brahmin called \u201cHarmless\u201d visits the Buddha, who teaches him the true meaning of harmlessness.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn7.6", "root_name": "Ja\u1e6d\u0101sutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 7.6", "blurb": "A brahmin with matted hair asks the Buddha how we can become disentangled. This short set of verses became one of the most important in all of Therav\u0101da Buddhism when it was used as the cornerstone of the commentarial treatise Visuddhimagga (Path of Purification).", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn7.7", "root_name": "Suddhikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 7.7", "blurb": "The brahmin Suddhika makes the strikingly Buddhist assertion that mere austerities don\u2019t lead to purity; only knowledge and conduct do. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn7.8", "root_name": "Aggikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 7.8", "blurb": "A brahmin conducting a fire sacrifice invites the Buddha to accept the blessed milk-rice, claiming that the Buddha is a true brahmin.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn7.9", "root_name": "Sundarikasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 7.9", "blurb": "A brahmin conducting a fire sacrifice wishes to offer the sacrificial cake. He sees the Buddha meditating and wants to give it to him, but hesitates when he realizes he is a shaven-headed ascetic. He asks the Buddha\u2019s caste, but the Buddha argues that conduct is the important thing, not caste. The Buddha gives a metaphorical reinterpretation of the elements of brahmanical ritual.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "sn7.10", "root_name": "Bahudh\u012btarasutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "SN 7.10", "blurb": "A brahmin is searching for his lost oxen when he sees the Buddha meditating peacefully in the forest. Likelwise, a mendicant with eleven qualities can grow in the Dhamma.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 2}, {"uid": "an11.18", "root_name": "Pa\u1e6dhamasam\u0101dhisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 11.18", "blurb": "The Buddha is asked by the mendicants about a deep state of meditation where all normal perception has ceased, but there is still perception.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an11.19", "root_name": "Dutiyasam\u0101dhisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 11.19", "blurb": "The Buddha teaches the mendicants about a deep state of meditation where all normal perception has ceased, but there is still perception.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an11.20", "root_name": "Tatiyasam\u0101dhisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 11.20", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta is asked by the mendicants about a deep state of meditation where all normal perception has ceased, but there is still perception.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "an11.21", "root_name": "Catutthasam\u0101dhisutta", "translated_name": null, "acronym": "AN 11.21", "blurb": "S\u0101riputta teaches the mendicants about a deep state of meditation where all normal perception has ceased, but there is still perception.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

"Ja 323", "blurb": "\u201cSuch is the quality\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master, while dwelling in the Aggalava shrine near Alavi, concerning the regulations to be observed in the building of cells.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja324", "root_name": "Cammas\u0101\u1e6dakaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Wanderer Who Wore a Leather Jacket ", "acronym": "Ja 324", "blurb": "\u201cThe kindly beast\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while living at Jetavana, about a mendicant priest who wore a leather jerkin.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja325", "root_name": "Godhar\u0101jaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Lizard King ", "acronym": "Ja 325", "blurb": "\u201cOne that plays\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master, while living at Jetavana, with regard to a certain cheating rogue. The introductory story has been already given in full. But oh this occasion they brought the Brother to the Master and exposed him, saying, \u201cHoly Sir, this Brother is a cheat.\u201d The Master said, \u201cNot now only, but formerly also he was a rogue.\u201d And then he told an old-world story.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja326", "root_name": "Kakk\u0101ruj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Heavenly Pumpkin Flowers ", "acronym": "Ja 326", "blurb": "\u201cHe that from thievish act\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while he was at Jetavana, about Devadatta, how that after causing a schism in the Order, as he was going away with his chief disciples, when the assembly broke up, a hot stream of blood gushed from his mouth. Then the Brethren discussed the matter in the Hall of Truth, and said that Devadatta by speaking falsely had created a schism, and afterwards fell sick and suffered great rain. The Master came and inquired what subject the Brethren were discussing as they sat in conclave, and on hearing what it was he said, \u201cNot now only, Brethren, but of old too this fellow was a liar, and not now only, but of old also he suffered pain as the penalty of lying.\u201d And so saying he repeated this old-world legend.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja327", "root_name": "K\u0101kavat\u012bj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Queen K\u0101kavat\u012b ", "acronym": "Ja 327", "blurb": "\u201cFragrant odours\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while residing at Jetavana, of a certain Brother who regretted having taken orders. On this occasion the Master asked the Brother if it were true that he was discontented, and on his answering, \u201cYes, Holy Sir,\u201d he asked him the reason. The Brother replied, \u201cBy reason of sinful passion.\u201d The Master said, \u201cWoman cannot be guarded. There is no keeping her safe. Sages of old placed a woman in mid ocean in a palace by the Simbali lake, but failed to preserve her honour.\u201d Then he told a story of the olden time. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja328", "root_name": "Ananusociyaj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "Grieve Not ", "acronym": "Ja 328", "blurb": "\u201cWhy should I shed tears\u201d\u2014This story was told by the Master while living at Jetavana, of a certain landowner who had lost his wife.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja329", "root_name": "K\u0101\u1e37ab\u0101huj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "The Monkey Black-Arm ", "acronym": "Ja 329", "blurb": "\u201cOnce we enjoyed\u201d\u2014This was a story told by the Master while dwelling in the Bamboo Grove, with regard to Devadatta\u2019s loss of gains and honour. For when Devadatta had unreasonably conceived a grudge against the Buddha and suborned a band of archers to slay him, his offence became known by the letting loose of the elephant Nalagiri. Then men took away his office and the rations provided for him, and the king ceased to regard him. And having lost his source of gains and honour, he went about living on what he begged in noble families. The Brethren started a discussion in the Hall of Truth, how that Devadatta thought to get gain and honour, but when he had got it he could not keep it. The Master came and inquired what was the subject the Brethren sat in conclave to discuss, and on being told what it was he said, \u201cNot only now, Brethren, but formerly too, Devadatta was deprived of gains and honour.\u201d And he then told them an old-world legend.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}, {"uid": "ja330", "root_name": "S\u012blav\u012bma\u1e41saj\u0101taka", "translated_name": "A Test of Virtue ", "acronym": "Ja 330", "blurb": "\u201cPower on earth\u201d\u2014This was a story told by the Master when at Jetavana, about a brahmin who was ever proving his virtue. Two similar stories have been told before. In this case the Bodhisatta was the family priest of the king of Benares. ", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 1}]

translated_name: The Chapter on the Lion’s Roar
blurb: Beginning with two discourses containing a “lion’s roar”, this chapter deals with suffering, community life, and practical meditation advice.
children: [{"uid": "mn11", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37as\u012bhan\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": "The Shorter Discourse on the Lion\u2019s Roar ", "acronym": "MN 11", "blurb": "The Buddha declares that only those following his path can genuinely experience the four stages of awakening. This is because, while much is shared with other systems, none of them go so far as to fully reject all attachment to the idea of a self.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "mn12", "root_name": "Mah\u0101s\u012bhan\u0101dasutta", "translated_name": "The Longer Discourse on the Lion\u2019s Roar ", "acronym": "MN 12", "blurb": "A disrobed monk, Sunakkhatta, attacks the Buddha\u2019s teaching because it merely leads to the end of suffering. The Buddha counters that this is, in fact, praise, and goes on to enumerate his many profound and powerful achievements.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "mn13", "root_name": "Mah\u0101dukkhakkhandhasutta", "translated_name": "The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering ", "acronym": "MN 13", "blurb": "Challenged to show the difference between his teaching and that of other ascetics, the Buddha points out that they speak of letting go, but do not really understand why. He then explains in great detail the suffering that arises from attachment to sensual stimulation.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "mn14", "root_name": "C\u016b\u1e37adukkhakkhandhasutta", "translated_name": "The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering ", "acronym": "MN 14", "blurb": "A lay person is puzzled at how, despite their long practice, they still have greedy or hateful thoughts. The Buddha explains the importance of absorption meditation for letting go such attachments. But he also criticizes self-mortification, and recounts a previous dialog with Jain ascetics.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "mn15", "root_name": "Anum\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": "Measuring Up ", "acronym": "MN 15", "blurb": "Venerable Moggall\u0101na raises the topic of admonishment, without which healthy community is not possible. He lists a number of qualities that will encourage others to think it worthwhile to admonish you in a constructive way.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn16", "root_name": "Cetokhilasutta", "translated_name": "Emotional Barrenness ", "acronym": "MN 16", "blurb": "The Buddha explains various ways one can become emotionally cut off from one\u2019s spiritual community.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn17", "root_name": "Vanapatthasutta", "translated_name": "Jungle Thickets ", "acronym": "MN 17", "blurb": "While living in the wilderness is great, not everyone is ready for it. The Buddha encourages meditators to reflect on whether one\u2019s environment is genuinely supporting their meditation practice, and if not, to leave.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 4}, {"uid": "mn18", "root_name": "Madhupi\u1e47\u1e0dikasutta", "translated_name": "The Honey-Cake ", "acronym": "MN 18", "blurb": "Challenged by a brahmin, the Buddha gives an enigmatic response on how conflict arises due to proliferation based on perceptions. Venerable Kacc\u0101na draws out the detailed implications of this in one of the most insightful passages in the entire canon.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "mn19", "root_name": "Dvedh\u0101vitakkasutta", "translated_name": "Two Kinds of Thought ", "acronym": "MN 19", "blurb": "Recounting his own experiences in developing meditation, the Buddha explains how to understand harmful and harmless thoughts, and how to go beyond thought altogether.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}, {"uid": "mn20", "root_name": "Vitakkasa\u1e47\u1e6dh\u0101nasutta", "translated_name": "How to Stop Thinking ", "acronym": "MN 20", "blurb": "In a practical meditation teaching, the Buddha describes five different approaches to stopping thoughts.", "node_type": "leaf", "root_lang_iso": "pli", "root_lang_name": "P\u0101li", "child_range": null, "yellow_brick_road": true, "yellow_brick_road_count": 5}]
